description:
To me, what differentiates a restaurant that gets four stars vs one that gets five stars is the ability to serve me something that truly impresses me. Locanda did that today with the grilled whole fish (trout) as well as their chocolate budino dessert.  The rest of the dining experience, from the starter to the pasta to the beverages and the service, was on point as well. 

(1).  The meal started with marinated anchovies and these were really great. The super fresh anchovies are lightly cured and doused in olive oil.  If you are a fan of anchovies, this dish is for you. 

(2).  When dining at an Italian establishment, you have to order a pasta dish and the server recommended the Fettucine with soft shell crab as the best pasta to go with the fish. She was right - the pasta was perfectly cooked and complemented the rest of the meal. I also got the pro-tip to pour the olive oil from the anchovies to this pasta and this really took the pasta to a new level. 

(3).  The grilled fish was trout - it came with simple sauces and was just spectacular. 

(4).  The chocolate budino dessert was perfect to me - it had savory/sweet/bitter flavors with contrasting textures and temperatures. This is the kind of dessert that really stands out for me. It's Michelin star quality. 

In the beverage department, the house made ginger beer was great and I always like peppermint tea with chocolate at the end of the meal.  Service was attentive and the ambiance is indicative of the gentrification of Valencia street.  With tax and tip, this was about $110, a bargain in terms of fine dining these days. Highly recommended and I'll be coming back.
author: Andrew S.

description:
Came here after a movie at the nearby Roxy theater. It was busy even on a weeknight, but my group of 5 was able to be seated within 10 minutes. Our waiter was nice, but he made me slightly uncomfortable with his comments..

I tried:
- bucatini (red sauce with bacon)
- rigatoni carbonara (creamy sauce w/ bacon)
- cacio e pepe (pasta w/ pepper sauce, too peppery in my opinion)
- mashed potatoes (so yummy!)

The pasta was cooked well and the flavors were pretty good, but I wasn't blown away. Overall, it was a pretty expensive meal and I didn't feel like I got my money's worth with the quality of service/food. The portions were pretty small, so I don't think the price was justified. 

All in all, it was a good experience, but I don't know if I would come back here, when there are so many other less expensive options for good italian food in SF.
author: Sara S.

description:
Over priced for the bad quality of food. I would expect  courtesy of waiting for you to finish your appetiser before asking for the mains from the wait staff- but she kept hounding us! Come on people - better service for the price one had to pay. 
We expect had to send back the pasta as it was undercooked, but it didn't come out too great the second time either. There were 4 small pieces of meat in the pasta - not acceptable. 

Very disappointing
author: Abhishek S.

description:
Excellent late night dinner - started with a Negroni cocktail and a lovely glass of wine (thanks to our waitress for a the great recommendation).

Started with a soft shell crab with puslane and spicy aioli, very good start. Then we had pasta with Morels, fava beans and fresh ricotta, which was way more decadent than it sounds. Lamb chops marinated in olive oil and rosemary were drop dead delicious. The lamb was perfectly charred and had plenty of nice fatty bits to chew on, the scent of rosemary was in every single juice bite. I'm just about to start drooling just thinking about it, haha. Charred little gems were excellent and a huge portion for side dish, probably better for 4 than for 2. We regrettably did not have room for dessert after this feast. Next time though, the dessert selection seemed promising.

Italian food is generally not top of the list for me, but I'd come back anytime for the wonderful food.
author: Vanessa K.

description: I love the interior design of the place. Dim light, cozy leather sofa. The food was very delicate, too, but it is a bit expensive given the limited amount. There are a lot of options for drinks, so I would definitely recommend this place to people who come here mostly for drinking.
author: Yifan L.

description: Ordered to-go and for the pasta with short ribs. Two stars because the flavors were great but my portion was TINY! Crazy that you'd charge $23 bucks for this! I don't know if this was because it was a to-go order or towards the end of the night but truly disappointed and still hungry!
author: Gabby R.

description:
I've only been here once and it was a decent experience. We ordered the fried olives, a pasta dish and the whole fish family-style, and for dessert we shared the budino. The olives and fish were excellent but the pasta dish was underwhelming ... I'm not a pasta fan so perhaps my opinion is skewed. The dessert was really tasty :) 

There's a nice selection of cocktails and service is good. The dress code isn't as fancy as the prices would lead you to believe; there were people in jeans and more casual evening attire. I was overdressed in a black dress and heels.
author: Sarah L.

description:
Went there on Good Friday and had a drink called Church! Lol. Seriously, this was one of the best cocktails I've ever had. Somewhat of an adult orange soda, in a good way! I also loved the old fashioned flights!

Whole grilled fish "Aqua pazza" is the way to go, so delicious, perfectly seasoned and cooked. I wasn't a huge fan of the artichoke, but got some cool photos of them. Pizza Bianca is worth the hype. Pastas are so delicious, definitely recommend the crab pasta! 

Lemon dessert was very yummy and light! Big enough to share!
author: Kimia M.

description:
I was recommended to this place by my salesperson at Kermit Lynch. She said it was one of her favorite Italian restaurants in SF. Consistently excellent. I was visiting with my son who's a chef and had just returned from a month in Italy so the bar was set high.
We started with the fried olives which were fantastic. A couple of classic Negronis; perfect.
I had the Amatriciana which was better than any I had in Rome. My son had two pasta dishes, both outstanding. Our sever was Michelin star level.
She suggested an excellent Sicilian red.
A perfect meal. Wish I lived in the neighborhood!
author: Sergio L.

description:
I admit - Locanda and I got off to a rocky start. The first time I made a reservation here we had to wait 40 minutes to be seated. A restaurant can do a lot to make this a better experience - like drinks or apps, but instead we had to wait outside because the space was too full. At the end of the meal, the manager came by and mentioned she'd like to make it up to us at a next visit. 

So return we did - and this time we were treated to free bread, prosciutto and a round of prosecco. Not a bad way to improve my sentiments!

Locanda's handmade pasta is very tasty but where I was truly impressed during our third visit was the fresh fish dish. It was served in it's own broth along with a hearty and delicious assortment of fresh vegetables: reminded me of a lovely dinner I had once on a farm, but right in the middle of the Mission!

Also not to be missed is the salted focaccia (made in-house). A restaurant has to do bread pretty darn well to charge for it and while it pains me a bit to pay for it, this dish is well worth it. 

Brunch is decidedly overpriced for what it is. Unless you're really in a hurry to eat (generally no wait) and need something upscale I'd recommend taking that business almost anywhere else in the neighborhood.
author: Stephanie T.

description:
Solid spot for both brunch and dinner in the Mission that seemingly always has availability for last minute reservations. 

Flavors feel a little pared down on some dishes (something about Locanda feels a tad too New American), but dishes are overall reliable. One standout for me is the lemon ricotta "corzetti" pancake dish available at brunch--the flavor and texture on these mini pancakes is just right, and they remind me of a more elegant version of the Dutch poffertjes I fell in love with in Amsterdam.

Good for groups!
author: Kelly R.

description: Love the place. Amazing food & cocktails. Get the grilled whole fish or spare ribs.  Locanda mule is amazing as well
author: Frank S.

description:
BESTEST!!!!! 
 
The food tasted as good as it looked. We had the baked eggs, French toast and side of hasbrowns for brunch on a Sunday at 11:30 ish. We loved everything!!!  We were running half an hour late, we called and moved our reservation without any fuss. We are coming here again and soon! Loved it!!
author: Sharanya A.

description:
Tried the Cacio e Pepe and I had the fusilli with mushrooms. Both were heavenly. The cacio e Pepe was cooked perfectly al dente and flavored so lightly. The fusilli was on the opposite end of the spectrum, with a heavier flavor profile yet the mushrooms weren't overpowering. Need this meal again. 

Tried the pizza Bianca app which was tasty, but the pasta is what you need to come here for - do It sooner than later. 

Pros:
Pasta
Service
Ambiance 
Cocktails - I had the whiskey hot toddy which was hella soothing on my sore throat 

Cons: 
None from this trip at all
author: Vyshak C.

description: This is a pretty good place to come for dinner and drinks - come a bit early as it does get busy after 7 on the weekends. The drinks are solid - definitely recommend on getting "Church." Appetizers are okay - the one not to get is the jerky as it's really dry and stringy (unless that's your thing). The pastas, however, are great!
author: Gary Y.

description:
4 star service 
3 star food. Pasta did not taste fresh made and lack flavor, creativity and overall umami. We ordered some large fish that tasted good but nothing to compel me to come back to.
author: cristina s.

description:
Wonderful food, exquisite front house staff. BUT BEWARE OF "Rovie" the waiter who exhibits an experienced and service-oriented posture. First she directs you to the most expensive bottles: you ask: " is your minimum bottle $70", "Yes" she replies, but Locanda offers many lovely bottles for under $50. But wait, she orders a bottle that is not what you requested: you ask for the specific Piemonte at $44 and at the check its a different bottle for $70, not the bottle you requested. Rovie is experienced and expert in the bait and switch.
Unfortunately you don't realize it until you receive the check and the bottle you are charged is thirty dollars more than the one you requested. And of course she gets very huffy...so you don't pursue it.
Unfortunately she's ruined the experience of the exquisite food and service of the front house staff, as well soiling the stellar local reputation of the Delfina brand.
author: Peppermint P.

description:
I recently enjoyed a great meal at Locanda, much to no one's surprise based on how well-regarded the restaurant is. We (group of 6) showed up a bit early for our reservation and had to stand around right until the reservation time, so do keep that in mind if you're going to show up early--this place is popular!

Once seated, we were quickly noticed by our server who explained some of the menu options to us, and also informed us of the specials. We got a round of drinks going almost at once--I highly recommend the Prince if you enjoy Boulevardiers--and the appetizers began arriving shortly afterward. Midway through our appetizers, we ordered our entrees as well as another round of drinks. At the end of all that food, we were too stuffed for dessert, as enticing as some of those options looked.

Some highlights of the meal:
- Jewish-style Artichoke: a must-have! This is a traditional Roman preparation, and it's hard to find in this part of the world. Fried yet chewy, and delicious.
- Fried olives: boy were these good. Light, crispy, and juicy to a fault.
- House-cured anchovies: I usually don't like anchovies, but even I caved in and enjoyed a piece of these. The hint of spice accompanying them was perfect.
- Pizza Bianca: who knew you could make such wonders with perfect bread, olive oil, and salt? We pigged out on our first really hard, and ordered a second immediately after.
- Rigatoni alla Carbonara: al dente pasta, lusciously creamy sauce, and perfectly smoked meat? I was all in from the first bite.

Overall, this was a thoroughly enjoyable meal. The restaurant takes reservations for slightly larger groups like ours, which made it perfect for the occasion. I can see why this spot is so popular!
author: Leela S.

description:
Consistently good even the second time around. Really like their French toast and Benedict.  Found a caramel coffee that I loooooove 

Bloody Mary was pretty delicious
author: Vasini G.

description:
Brunch review.

Toasted pizza bianca (Peach jam) - 3/5
French toast (Strawberries, pistachio butter) - 3/5
House made bacon - 4/5
Carbonara benedict - 4/5

Overall, "I'm a fan."
author: Mark O.

description:
Happy to have finally tried Locanda.

Didn't think too much of the snacks/appetizers, but the orecchiette with sausage/broccoli rabe and squid ink tonnarelli were very tasty. 

Ended the meal with the apple cake and ginger gelato - yum!
author: Christine A.

description:
Locanda has risen to be one of our favorite neighborhood spots. It's upscale casual and not fussy but always delicious. There are some dishes that are better than others to be fair -- I recommend sticking to the pastas. Especially the specials. We've always been thrilled with their pasta specials -- even better than some of their classics like the cacio e pepe or the rigatoni carbonara. Also even olive haters will find themselves snacking on the tasty fried olives appetizer. And cocktails are always delicious. 

The service is always friendly and attentive and the restaurant is always the right level of crowded. Reservations are recommended by you can sometimes luck out with a seat at the bar.
author: Vic C.

description:
Visited here with a friend who was in town. At least they take reservations for larger parties (6+), but probably won't be coming back given the other Italian food options in the city.  The orichette pasta was so salty that I couldn't taste the other flavors going on (my friends who got the same thing agreed).

What also confused me was that the pastas were "designed" to be 4-5 bites less than an entree.  Why would you do that on purpose? :( 

Pasta and drink came out to about $45 (including tax and tip), probably about 25% more than the threshold that I would have convinced me to give it a second shot.
author: Alison L.

description:
Delicious, delicious, delicious! Locanda is the place to dine for its creative takes on Italian food--I came for brunch on a Sunday with a reservation, and we were seated in the airy, bright dining room. 

The brunch menu is so creative--we started with the eggs in purgatory, which came with two baked eggs in a spicy tomato sauce, shaved pecorino cheese, and grilled pizza bianca (airy, chewy pizza dough-like bread) on the side. Oh my goodness.. the pizza bianca was the perfect vehicle for dipping into the spicy, flavorful, decadent sauce, and every bite was bursting with flavor! The only problem was that there wasn't enough pizza bianca in an order, so we got two more side orders to finish the dish up! 

We also had the eggs benedict carbonara--a really creative take on the classic brunch dish. Instead of an English muffin, the entire dish was built on more pizza bianca, and instead of ham, there was thinly-sliced, relatively lean prosciutto on top. The eggs were poached beautifully and topped with a "cacio e pepe" (cheese and pepper) hollandaise sauce. Whoever thought this dish up was a genius! Finally, we had the savory porridge, a simple yet tasty concoction of oats, maitake mushrooms, ricotta, and greens. Nothing crazy here (after all, it's just oatmeal), but a great way to round out the meal.

Locanda is definitely a place I'd recommend for brunch, and I'm already hoping to come back for their dinner service. Everything is just delicious, the service is quick, and the atmosphere trendy and comfortable. The prices are also fair, and the pizza bianca "toast" (accompanied by some tomato sauce or orange marmalade) lives up to all the hype!
author: David K.

description:
Locanda is an Italian upscale restaurant in Upper Mission that offers a selection of pastas, meats, antipasti dishes, and small plates. They also provide a decent variety of wines, cocktails and champagnes that were very enticing while looking through their menu. The food and service were great, but definitely on the pricier side, so save this place for a special occasion and make reservations if you plan to come here because it can get booked rather quickly.

We ordered the pizza bianca, which I thought would be an actual pizza, but actually turned out to be buttery thin bread. Not to say that was bad, but it wasn't what you would expect. The grilled leg of lamb looked amazing because one of the members of our party decided to go with that option. I opted for the Cacio e Pepe because I just go nuts for pasta prepared in cheese wedges. If you're looking for a simple option that won't fill you up too much for dessert, then I would go with this. Speaking of dessert, the one you absolutely must try is the Mocha Semifreddo. Even in pictures it looks rich and mouthwatering! It is a chocolate ganache pastry with crunchies and cherries embedded within it. If that's not great, then what is?

Looking forward to coming back and trying out other dishes!
author: Steve N.

description: I love traditional Italian food with a modern twist to it. The food was all very delicious and tasty and not overly complex. Our waiter was very attentive despite me seeing him "taste" wine all night as he was pouring it and all the staff very welcoming and friendly. We sat next to the entrance but I wish we could have sat in the back since it looked cozier. We ordered 3 snacks and 2 entrees and all were delicious. My favorite was the fish of the day (rainbow trout) served with a tomato wine sauce and artichokes, onions and olives. The rigatoni al carbonara was also flavorful with the pork and pecorino cheese. Definitely must try the Jerusalem style artichoke and the fried soft shell crab. We didn't feel like drinking and opted for the basil lime cooler and it was refreshing. If you don't have a carb phobia the pizza Bianca is simple but delicious. I need to come back!
author: Christine H.

description:
I come here all the time for the bar, and occasionally for nice meals. The brunch is delicious and a sane wait time, and reservable.

The restaurant week menu is a bit weak though.
author: Victoria C.

description: Locanda has a great location (Valencia street in Mission). The restaurant is actually pretty big and has more tables at the back. It has a relaxed vibe with great good. The fare is Italian but it is inventive food and not your typical Italian. We tried the fried olives (amazing), the cauliflower (nothing special), mezze maniche (extremely delicious crab pasta - favorite dish), and Bucatini pasta (perfect chewiness, sweet spot of al dente and with fried pork pieces)
author: Doruk B.

description: Overpriced, uneven service but good food. I won't rant about Mission gentrification, but it did shock me that on the wines by the bottle list, red wines start at $60 and there are only a handful before prices soar into the $100's...Then again I'm a cranky former Mission resident. But the ambiance is buzzy, the decor is beautiful, and the food was delicious overall. The tomato salad was fresh, as was the bresaola and fennel. The pasta with chanterelles was truly delicious. But the veal meatballs were so over-salted they were inedible. We told our server and she just grabbed our plates off the table and walked off without saying anything. The kitchen kindly comped us a sorbet because we didn't know if another plate of meatballs would be coming or not. But in general, service seemed overwhelmed and stressed out.
author: Dx D.

description: Ordered the eggs Benedict carbonara and lemon ricotta pancakes and within half an hour I had food poisoning.
author: Priscilla Y.

description:
Totally solid.

Service was friendly and approachable and did a great job of upselling.  

Cocktails were solid (had two mezcal drinks).

Food was delicious.

Fried olives with fontina - delicious and plentiful.   Better than the version I have had from A16.

Little Gems and Cucumbers - refreshing.   Very simple.   Basically large leaves of lettuce with quartered pieces of lemon cucumber.   The tarragon viniagrette was exceptional.

Riganoni with guaincale - very robust flavor.   The actual rigatoni was a little tough, but the flavors they incorporated with that cheese and bacon was delightful.

Orecchetti with sausage - the flavor of this one was more piquant and light.   The sausage was nicely flavored.   The broccoli raab cut through it nicely.   I liked the texture of this pasta better than the rigatoni.  

Squash with brown butter and pomegranate seeds - OMG.   I loved this so hard.  Could eat this every day.

Huckleberry crostata with meyer lemon gelato and bay laurel bread crumbs - gorgeous.   Loved every bite of it.

Chocolate sformato - if you like chocolate, look no further.   Rich and decadent.   Silky texture with enough crunch from chocolate cookie crisp on top.

All in all, very satisfied and happy with our experience here.   Prices are comparable to other higher end eateries in SF, so value is pretty good.   I mostly liked how simple and straight forward all of the dishes are here.   It's kind of like the antithesis of SPQR where I feel the dishes have so much going on, that all the flavors turn into this muddled mess.   

Recommended.
author: Christian C.

description: The food was excellent. The waiter that helped us was very unprofessional to a group of women.
author: Erica A.

description:
The good: Great food! 
The bad: Definitely a bit over priced
The ugly: the staff is extremely pushy and rude AF. This one waitress dropped off a plate and sarcastically said "you're welcome" with strong attitude. Then leered at me like she wanted to kill me. Nice lady

The other staff is also very pushy to get you to buy more. Always pushing to get drinks or order more.
author: Matt L.

description:
Delicious! Glad to finally try it.

My cousin has been raving about it for years. Totally agree!
author: Valerie C.

description:
Delicious brunch! 

Great service and amazing food. Locanda has a charming ambiance and professional staff. We had the pancakes and the eggs Benedict - both must haves! It was a little pricey, but definitely worth it! They also take reservations, which is extremely convenient.
author: Sophia H.

description:
So after reading the review I came in expecting a decadent meal. 

The wine choices are great. 

The food was really not worth it. We got the fusilli and the rigatoni. And both missed the mark.
author: Farhan A.

description:
Salt overload!

We ordered the grilled fish and the fish and the sauce/beans it was in were both so crazy salty it was inedible. Other people in our group ordered the Bavette Steak which was really tender and cooked perfectly but the salad it came with was unfortunately doused in salt. Luckily the waitress was great and really understanding. She automatically offered to take it back and either have the kitchen remake the dish or bring us the menu again to look for something else.

We did enjoy the fried olives and the orecchiette pasta. Drinks were also good. Pizza Bianco  was basically just a focaccia/pizza like bread with some oil and salt. While not expensive, it felt like more of a bread they would give you for free. 

Too bad about the food bc the place has a cool vibe and good service but most likely will not be back.
author: Kristine D.

description: Girls night out, weekend of the 21st. Lovely setting, was booked and lively. Wait staff friendly with right amount of attentiveness. Food delicious: black cod collar, grilled red snapper, may fave was a squid-ink pasta. Cocktails well-made, though one friend who doesnt drink much had hers adjusted, which worked out fine. Got a little loud but out table was near a wall so we were ok.
author: Christina A.

description:
Their brunch menu is the best thing you'll see this Sunday!!! Had the Eggs in Purgatory and I just couldn't get over how delicious the tomato sauce was!
A very raw yet rich ensemble of spices and herbs give such a nice kick to the tomato base, and the pecorino gives it just the right amount of creaminess. The eggs are baked perfectly with runny yolks - just the way I LOVE it!

My friend got the lemon-ricotta pancakes - the cutest little pancakes I've even seen.
Strongly recommend the place if you're looking for a fusion brunch menu that won't burn holes in your wallet. 

However the wait can get a little crazy on the weekends, so it might be a good idea to reserve a table beforehand.
author: Subarna B.

description:
One word: carbonara

Awesome atmosphere with awesome food. I daydream about the carbonara. Perfectly al dente and so delicious. It is amazing. Pasta portions are a bit on the small side but plenty if you add an app or two.
author: Gabrielle D.

description:
Not impressed

Lets see:

Starters:
JEWISH-STYLE ARTICHOKE  - over fried to a crisp
LLANO SECO PORK PATE -  - too heavy - it even looked processed

Entrees:

Fish of the day - whole cod fish.  I asked for it grilled which it was.  But after sitting in a bed of spinach, I think my fish was swimming. 

EMIGH RANCH LAMB SHANK:  It would have been nice if they trimmed off some of the fat first.


Would we go back - No
author: Mark S.

description:
Great to see more brunch options that take reservations! Locanda is great for dinner and did not disappoint for brunch.

RESERVATIONS
Easily made for 4 at 10:30am on a Sunday by calling in just one day in advance.

THE SERVICE
Great service, very friendly and funny.

THE COST
$139.31 before tips for 2 coffees, 3 drinks, 4 entrees, and 1 side. A reasonable brunch for four.

COCKTAILS
* Apis ($12) - 5 stars
Loved this! My perfect light, refreshing, herby drink. 

BRUNCH
* Burrata ($12) - 4.5 stars
Burrata is always great, but I loved that it was served on grilled pizza bianca crust. Great for sharing too, as it comes out in 4 pieces.

* French Toast ($15) - 4.5 stars
Very, very, very nicely done. Incredibly soft and moist

* Eggs in Purgatory ($14) - 4.5 stars
Excellent. The spicy tomato sauce was great, and again that grilled pizza bianca crust, was the cherry on top.

* Eggs Benedict "Carbonara" ($17) - 4 stars
I only tried a bite, but my boyfriend enjoyed this!

* Berkshire Pork Saltimbocca ($17) - 2.5 stars
I think our server recommended this as a unique brunch dish, which it was, but to me it seemed like a very hard and dry "prociutto" under an egg. Not much going on. 

* Eli's Hashbrowns ($6) - 3. 5 stars
Good stuff, but (subjectively) very crispy and very salty.
author: Ziyan C.

description:
A group of girlfriends and I decided to do brunch on Labor Day weekend. It was between Locanda and another spot. Since the other spot didn't take reservations, I voted for Locanda. (I hate waiting when I'm starving.) My gf made a reservation for a party of 5 for Saturday, September 3rd at 12:30pm a couple days earlier.

*NV borgoluce valdobbiadene brut, prosecco superiore, veneto, italy ($14)
*White peach bellini ($11) ×2
*Aperitivo: campari, orange, lemon, prosecco ($11)
*Gran classico spritz: gran classico bitters, lemon, prosecco ($11)
*Four barrel coffee: buena vista, guatemala ($4)

They don't offer bottomless, so we just ordered one drink each. All the brunch cocktails looked sweet, so I just got a glass of bubbly. It was perfect as I seriously only like a couple drops if juice in my mimosas. It was nice and dry.

*Lemon-ricotta corzetti pancakes: creme fraiche, blackberry conserva ($14)
*Eggs in purgatory: two baked eggs, spicy tomato sauce, pecorino, grilled pizza bianca ($14)
*Eggs benedict carbonara: two poached eggs, prosciutto cotto, pizza bianca, hollandaise cacio e pepe ($17) ×2
*Two coastal hill farm eggs and grilled zucchini: cortez bottarga, brown butter ($14)
*Berkshire pork saltimbocca: fried egg, la quercia prosciutto, sage, white wine ($17)
*Eli's hashbrowns ($6)
*House-cured bacon ($6)

The bacon here is delicious! Super flavorful and meaty. And such a huge portion for $6. You get six pieces! The pancakes were a favorite of mine. The perfect size as they are about the size of a silver dollar. Perfect with the fruit and creme fraiche. Not too sweet. You don't even need syrup (even though they give you some). They managed to stay light and fluffy. For the main, I got the eggs in purgatory. Good as I love tomato sauce, but if I was a big eater, I'd need more food. The portion wasn't very big. I tried a bite of everything else. Good savory dishes if you want eggs in the morning, but none of the other dishes really stood out.

I'd come back again for the bacon and pancakes. And maybe try another savory dish. Bring on the bubbly as well!
author: Elena N.

description:
Pretty good Italian but small portions. Price is 2x what it should be and service could use improvement (our waitress was indifferent and uninterested in our meal). They charge a 5% cover yet we did not get any bread. Not a relaxing dinner environment, loud music and loud acoustics. 
I was in Italy for 3 weeks last month. I miss being able to dine without your check slapped on the table the moment you take your last bite of food.
author: Jane L.

description:
Locanda knows its shit. How else would it have thought to batter and deep fry cheese-stuffed olives that even olive haters can't stop eating? 

The tortelli and bavette steak are also winners, so much that I licked my plate clean and forgot all about my diet. Freaking Italians are killing my beach bod!
author: Suany W.

description:
Don't get me wrong, the food here is pretty tasty. If you're here for happy hour, the drinks are pretty good too.

My issue with this place is the price for the portion of food you get.

We started dinner with the artichoke small plate which, at $7, seemed like a decent deal - until it showed up. I expected a grilled artichoke, but what we got was a grilled artichoke stem. The top half of the artichoke was missing. I'm not sure what they did with it, but I was looking forward to eating it. Anyway, it tasted good, but it was a lot of money for an artichoke stem that we finished in like three bites.

Next, my wife and I shared the spaghetti dish which contained a "whole lobster". The dish tasted good, but there's no way an entire lobster was in there. I saw the two claws and maybe some knuckle meat, but the lobster tail was nowhere to be seen. $46 is a lot of money for a single plate of spaghetti, but with a whole lobster it sounded like a decent deal. It wasn't. We were disappointed and underwhelmed. 

Unless you've got money to blow, skip this place and check out one of the many other amazing restaurants in the Mission.
author: Cory D.

description:
Thank you pork on pork brunch goodness. I got the pork saltimbocca so literally a pork paradise! It was the first meal of the day so why the hell not! 

It was pretty packed for brunch on a Saturday morning but we opted for bar seating. The bartender was friendly and attentive. We got our drinks and food quickly, perks of the bar. I loved my spritz!!!!!! The cocchi based one was awesome! I loved that it was as bitter as the aperol based one. Definitely check that one out! 

The food was delicious. It's a brunch win.
author: Alicia C.

description:
I wish I'd discovered Locanda earlier? Why? Because I am in LOVE with their pastas. They cook their noodles perfectly al dente, maybe even a bit more al dente than other places and I absolutely love them for it. We tried both their carbonara and bucatini and both were totally on point - with tasty sauce coating each noodle. We also had a burrata appetizer, which was good - but mostly because burrata is the best - but I think they added too much olive oil. We also tried some pork jerky that was made in-house. MEH. I would pass on this. Lastly we had the grilled corn as a side and this was also fantastic. It reminded me of mexican corn, but off the cob. 

Will definitely come back, and pretty much just for the pasta!
author: Lily C.

description:
i was super excited for brunch at locanda since eater sf said that it was one of the hottest spots for brunch right now. ive been to locanda for dinner, years ago, and really enjoyed their offerings, so i was pumped. arrived on time and was seated immediately - right by the door. yikes. the restaurant looked fully booked for sunday brunch - makes sense, since it's the mission on valencia and everyone loves to brunch. i ordered a cocktail right away - had a really long night the evening before and needed to clear my head. the aperitivo was pretty delicious! but then...it went downhill from here.

ordered the pizza bianca to share - four bites of burrata, herb jam and olive spread. not bad, but steep at $11 for a brunch app. we then ordered the french toast per recommendation from the waiter, and the tripe alla romana. i didnt even try the french toast cuz the color looked off, and it wasnt fluffy and beautiful like i expect decadent french toast to me. my friend was not a fan of the buddha's hand, so we only ate 1/3 of this dish.  such a disappointment. the tripe was pretty good - tomato flavor and good mix-in's - pancetta for one.  but..the portion size was pretty small, and some parts of the dish were cold. what. i didnt get that.

overall, super disappointed with brunch fare at this spot. boo! not sure if i'd come back for dinner either :( $48 after tax and tip pp. yikes!
author: Christina L.

description:
We came here for brunch on a Sunday - I made reservations the morning of - but I would recommend them so you don't have to wait.

The best part was the sticky bun the three of us got to share. I wish we had a 2 way split.

I got the eggs carbonara Benedict, my man got the pork saltimbocca (he said the pork was tough) and my other friend had the same as me - but subbed out the pancetta for a tomato.

It was all okay- it really all just sounded better on the menu than it was. The focaccia my benedict was on was hard to cut through, though I will say my eggs were perfect and runny.

Been there, done that, moving on from here.
author: Amy W.

description: We loved everything we ordered - pasta, carrots, bread. Impressive service. Fun whiskey flight option.
author: Vicki L.

description: Great food, nice atmosphere and service. Eggs Benedict, Berkshire Pork, French Toast were all amazing. Some of the best I've ever had.
author: Kevin D.

description: Everything about our Locanda experience was 5 star.  Don't miss the daily fish special.  We had the Pompano, grilled whole and filleted tableside.  It was fresh, original and whole...a seriously savory, succulent and wonderful prepation.   Also, try the creamed kale....a sleeper!   Service was first class, prompt and intelligent.
author: Max K.

description:
Locanda has a very claustrophobic hostess station, you walk in and there's a podium, the front door, and an orange curtain giving you about 12 square feet of room for you and your date to stand while people are trying to get by, or you are waiting for the guy in front of you to pick up his takeout order.  Once you get past that, the restaurant itself is quite nice and spacious, with interesting art on the walls (at this time, they seemed to have a "hand clutching birds" theme).  The back room had a beautiful central floral arrangement and lighting fixture.

Aperitivo and Basil Cooler (non alcoholic) cocktails were good but a bit sweet.

Pizza Bianca - plain bread but so good, nice crust, fluffy on the inside. 5/5

Crispy fava beans cacio e pepe - very peppery. Beans were lightly tempura fried but still quite greasy. Got a piece of the Jewish artichoke in it by accident and so glad we didn't order that because the texture was not great (crispy but not digestible - see my review for A Cote in Oakland... if unchewable artichoke is the new trendy thing, please count me out). 3/5

Lamb ragu with radiatore - tasty but a little bland.  It could have used a flavor punch and/or the brightness of a fresh herb.  It wasn't great to look at either as it was a white pasta in a red sauce with no decoration.  4/5

Trout was the AQ fish and we got the last one (sat down to dinner at 7:30 on a Friday night, one of their busier nights for the market fish). It had small bones like any other trout. We got it grilled, served with spinach and capers, and didn't need all the sauces that came with it. It was served whole, which made deboning it ourselves a bit of a challenge, but I figure it's all part of the experience.  The meat of the fish was absolutely delicious.  Tender, perfectly cooked, not salty like the fish skin and side greens. 5/5

Dessert was the best I've had in a while. It was an angel food cake, warm and breaded with brown sugar, with dollops of pistachio syrup and a scoop rhubarb gelato. Rhubarb gelato was very clean in flavor and great accompaniment to the marshmallowy cake. Candied pistachios added a nice crunch. 5/5

Service was good.  Our waitress was friendly, excited and passionate about the food, knowledgable in giving us advice on what to order, and the plates were cleared fast.
author: Christina G.

description: Cool ambiance. Bartenders were very nice. Reservation was at 1:30. Felt rushed and almost like my Table and I were brothers. The food was great, but service has to be great for me to return.
author: Erika D.

description: Good brunch. Great service. Had the eggs Benedict carbonara - delicious. Bloody Mary wasn't spicy enough and a bit too sour. Too many solid options in the city to come back - not an inventive menu. 3.5 stars
author: Raj S.

description:
Locanda was superb on every level - food, atmosphere and service.

The burrata pizza bianca was simple but delicious. Belfiore burrata lightly topped with olive oil and sea salt - yum.

The bucatini all'amatriciana was excellent. Al dente bucatini and a delightfully flavorful sauce.

I finished my meal with a refreshingly light blood orange granita. It was the perfect balance of citrus and cream.
author: Stephanie C.

description:
Came here on a Sunday around 5:30 and the place got pretty busy quick, but there is definitely space in the back to host a party.  Our server was very nice and informative. 

Supposedly known for their Jewish artichoke. I thought it was okay. About 3.5/5 nothing too amazing.

The Pizza Bianca however... was amazing, and may be an understatement.

We also got the porchetta and the bucatini that night along with several cocktails. And the cocktails were great as well!
author: Wesley L.

description:
I've never dined at this restaurant up until last night. It's quite interesting and for a week night, was full of people. The restaurant is pretty big in size and has a very calm yet hip feeling inside.

I'd classify this restaurant as mostly Italian food. They have several pasta dishes and some entrees. 

My group and I ordered a couple of salads and several pasta dishes and the Babette steak to share. All of them were fine.

Our server was on top of it. My water cup and drub glass were never empty and she gave great suggestions as well

What really made my dinner experience is the pineapple rum dessert. The taste of it reminds me of the Baked Hawaii from Liholiho. They're similar in taste but still has a distinct difference.

If I would ever comeback to Locanda, I think it be more for the dessert and not so much for dinner.

P.S I'm not sure if it's just me, but seemingly, this establishment has a certain requirement for their servers.... Let's just say that you'll do a double take on their waiters. 


Food: 4/5
Ambiance: 5/5
Service: 5/5
author: Jan R.

description:
Still good but probably since 2011 when I was last there, it has fallen a little behind in the wow factor. It's a solid neighborhood restaurant but now the city in general has really upped its game.

Radish and anchovy butter (3/5) - I found it hard to eat more than 1 or 2 bites of the raw radish with the flavor of the butter to either be too concentrated or too light at times 
Pizza Bianca (3.5/5) - tasty and simple but nothing too special
Jewish style artichoke (4/5) - still a nice bite and novel preparation of the vegetable
Lamb ragu (4/5) - unique flavor profile and a hearty portion
author: Victor W.

description:
I keep coming back here! So glad they serve brunch now too :) 

Came here with a friend today for brunch and was able to make a last minute reservation on open table last night. This is my second time coming here for brunch. Items I've tried:

-L.E.S Bagel Plate ($19): I loveee smoked salmon and usually can't resist when I see them on the menu. It's good but probably not the most special item on the menu
-Eggs Benedict Carbonara ($17): Classic but sooo good!!! One of the best eggs Benedict I've had. Super creamy but it doesn't feel too heavy. Nice touch of citrus in the sauce
-Eggs in Purgatory ($16): Two baked eggs in a spicy tomato sauce. Pretty good but not my favorite at Locanda
-Housemade Bacon ($6): Love the side bacon here! Definitely recommend getting it for the table to share
-Hashbrowns ($6): Mmm love hashbrowns for brunch. Crispy shredded potatoes. The best kind!

Locanda has officially become one of my favorite brunch places in the city (along with Foreign Cinema). Will be back!
author: Crystal W.

description: I was exploring mission today and stumbled on this restaurant. The drink was amazing... But I ordered the French toast. It was a bit of a disappoint. The French toast was soggy and I could only eat the outer crust.
author: Sheralyn F.

description:
Fast and patient waiter service. I like watching the busy open kitchen with the open grill and oven work. Orechette pasta with munched sausage with spiced artichoke side is filling and so deliciously saucy. Get the pizza-rolls filled with mozzarella for appetizer; it tastes like pizza. 

I was on a first romantic date night on a busy Saturday night. Good idea to get a reservation. Atmosphere is casual wear but I like to dress up in a classy cocktail dress on dates.
author: Susan T.

description:
Holy hell. No reservation walk in on a Saturday night and got seated. Must've had a cancellation. We got lucky af. Drinks were perfect. Apps were yummy, but a tad underwhelming. 

The entrees! OH MY GEE. The orecchiette with sausage and kale ... beyond amazing. I CAN'T EVEN. 

Steak Bavaria - Jesus the mashed potatoes and frisée just put this incredible steak over the top. 

Blistered peppers - simple & sumptuous. 

Really fabulous meal. Can't wait to come back!!
author: Whitney M.

description: Out of all the Italian restaurants in SF, I had to pick this one. If I've said it once I've said it million times - I have NO issue paying for a meal. However, I'm an experience junky and experiencing non-friendly wait staff who add items to your bill without your consent and giving patrons portions that my kids would laugh at, all In an overcrowded joint where the food isn't even exceptional, I think not! Best thing I had all night was a drink which frankly I can't even remember what it was called. Never would I step foot in this place again.
author: Kelli S.

description:
We had planned a birthday celebration at the restaurant for 8 people and when we arrived, we realized that the restaurant put 2 tables together right next to the entry door.  It was a regular San Francisco night, cool and windy.  One of the hostesses had to keep a curtain so it would not be blown over our food.   The restaurant was full and the tables could not be moved on another place.

The food was fine, not great.  All pasta dishes wer al dente, border line undercooked, but it was consistent for all dishes.  One of us tried a veal dish that was definitely the star of the night, it was delicious.  Overall an average Italian Roman restaurant for the price.
author: Alex B.

description:
Always amazing experience, food and service are very consistent, especially the bartenders!
good job!!
author: Mina O.

description:
What a lovely trendy Italian spot! This was definitely a solid 4.5 for me. The food was delicious, and I would love to come back again the next time I'm in SF. 
5/5 food
4/5 ambience 
5/5 service 

Winter Chicories: [5/5] Caramelized squash roasted to perfection and served with pomegranate seeds and a root puree. I love squash and any type of veggie really, so this was a delicious way to start off the meal. Very rustic and comforting. 

Bucatini: [5/5] Thick chewy bucatini noodles in a silky tomato sauce with guaniciale. My boyfriend loved this dish. It was very good as a bucatini amatriciana dish, I just prefer pasta dishes with more vegetables or meat. Definitely order if you're a huge fan of this dish. 

Lamb scottadito: [4.5/5] I'm a die-hard pasta lover so whenever I go to Italian restaurants, my eyes are glued to the pasta section - I rarely look at the meats. However, my boyfriend wanted to order this and I'm SO glad we did! The lamb was amazing and definitely the highlight of the meal since I didn't expect much. The dish comes with two small lamb chops/lollipops that have been seared to perfection. The rosemary and other herbs/species are heavy-handed and absolutely delicious. There was a decent amount of meat and also a strip of fat along the bone - so yum. My only complaint would be that it was too salty. But even then, I'd still order it again. 

Bombolini: [4/5] I had expected the bombolini to be filled with jelly inside, but instead these were mini doughnuts that came with jelly and whipped cream on the side to dip in. They came out piping hot which I appreciated. They're not as fluffy as other bombolini I've had in the past - it's texture was much more like a cross between traditional American donut and a cake donut. Either way it was still a nice way to end the meal. Next time, I'd probably try the chocolate torte though. 

In sum, this was a great spot in SF to get trendy Italian fare at a good price with great service. Definitely recommend.
author: Cassie T.

description: It's been a good experience every time I go. I've been there for drinks (many times) and dinner (a few times) and I've had a lot of fun. The food was very good. It's a bit noisy and you need to be patient if you want a seat at the bar. The service both at the bar and at the dinner table was good and friendly.
author: Larry J.

description: This place continues to knock it out of the park. Excellent fresh pastas, seafood and a very well crafted wine list.
author: Greg S.

description: We had a fantastic meal Sunday meal with family to celebrate daylight saving time. The service was equally as fantastic. Still thinking about the lamb chops this morning...
author: Allen R.

description: Great atmosphere, food, and cocktails. The pasta dishes are delicious. Service was friendly and attentive. Since we still happened to be here for the 2018 New Year countdown, they handed out complimentary glasses of champagne, which was a nice touch. Would recommend and will definitely be back to try another pasta dish.
author: Rise G.

description:
We were celebrating a special occasion, which we mentioned to our server Sarah who then made it a point to ensure that we two women had an exceptional evening. But it went beyond Sarah, from the minute we were greeted at the door every member of staff was super lovely.

The food is the best both my foodie friend and I have enjoyed in a long time and recently we've dined at some pretty toney places that were disappointing. 

I have memories of the Jewish-style artichoke in Rome and Locanda's did not disappoint. The meatballs had us asking for additional delicious char-grilled bread so we could wipe the plate clean, and we did! The asparagus and blood orange was a sublime combo. We shared the Rigatoni all Carbonara - heaven in our mouths.

We had the Italian sparkling to kick off the night and followed with the Costa Graia Cesanese Piglio Superior, which I'm still dreaming of today. My friend had affogato for dessert and I had a glass of Malvasia.

Thank you, Locanda, for making my first day as an American truly memorable! 

We will definitely be back:-)
author: Lorraine F.

description: Absolutely loved this place.    The server was completely knowledgeable and there wAs no problem serving the wine we brought. She made recommendations that were amazing and she did not rush us in any way!!!!!!   The doors opened at 5:30 and there was a line to get into the Resteraunt on a Sunday night! Wow!!!! 5:30 but that was the only time we could get!!!!!    Even the early bird dinner was do worth the early time - Ha ha! I tasted everyone's dish and it was fantastic. This is a picture of the artichoke and it was amazing! We had whole chicken, pasta, fish stew, and the asparagus soup. All was excellent.
author: Julie L.

description:
The fried olives were much better than I expected. They were amazing. The pasta, though, was kind of a let down for me. Under seasoned (and no salt on the table) and a little too al dente.  It was really a bummer because I don't eat pasta michael and thought this would be a good place to go for it. 
The drinks were fab tho and the dessert was worth it- blueberry cobbler.
author: Sally J M.

description: Three words: TODAY'S WHOLE FISH. Locanda's whole fish (prepared in two ways - Acqua Pazza or Grilled) reminded us of being by the sea on the coast of Italy or Greece. Love the simple grilled fish in olive oil, lemon, and capers! So good!!!
author: Angellica Y.

description: Came here for brunch on recommendation of Eater SF and it was phenomenal. Cool and different selections from the norm. Delicious and last-minute space and they take reservations. I'll be back soon!
author: Andrew K.

description: It may be in the Mission but the food is definitely Italian cuisine at it's finest.  The pasta is all home made and cooked perfectly.  Eight of us ate family style and ordered everything on the menu -- including the deserts.   Each dish was prepared perfectly and delicious.
author: Gary N.

description:
I fancy myself a pretty adept pasta chef, and usually hate to fork out $20 for the kind of basics served at Locanda -- bucatini all'amatriciana, carbonara, lamb ragu, etc. I usually leave hip pasta joints thinking: I can make this myself.

Locanda's pasta is on a whole nother level, though. The bucatini and radiatore were so perfectly dense and al dente, and the sauces were so flavorful, that they easily beat many of the meals I'd had in Rome.
author: Ken H.

description:
Excellent Italian!!! 

Appetizers: The fried olives are insane and I don't even care for olives so that's saying a lot. The Jewish-style artichoke was also a winner (kind of the belle of the ball as well in terms of presentation). 

Bread served warm and buttery (mmmmmm...)

For dinner we ordered six, yes SIX pastas and shared between 5 people family style. Each pasta was incredible! Highly recommend you go with a large group so you can do this too.

Dessert certainly delivered an excellent ending. I definitely ate beyond capacity. 

Staff was really nice. No one rushed us or made us feel like we needed to clear the table. Ambience is great for low key conversation.
author: Neesh Q.

description:
Amazing cocktail menu and tantalizing appetizers. Haven't been too thrilled with the entrees, but hey? I love small plates. I have a blast coming here with friends and ordering a ton of apps and washing them down with cocktails made with love.
Fried olives= unique heaven
author: Noelle A.

description:
Reservations were made early and we were seated promptly when we arrived. It's a very happening and busy restaurant, seems to draw the happy hour crowd then straight to dinner. We were seated right next to the entrance, but it didn't feel obtrusive at all. Service was great from start to finish.

Fried olives & artichokes were great starters. I usually don't eat olives, but these were delicious especially with the melted cheese.

Rigatoni was decent while the lobster linguine was the best. It's a nice restaurant to meet friends/coworkers or bring a date and there are lots of bars next door.
author: Roll N.

description: Came for brunch. Amazing hash browns. Loved the carbonara Benedict. Super comfy bar seating. Friendly service.
author: Roxy L.

description: The oricchiette with lamb ragu was so good, we ordered a second. The cauliflower with Sicilian chili, oregano and mint was delicious, as were the smoked mashed potatoes. The coppiette (smoked pork jerky) was the only thing we ordered that wasn't on par with the other menu selections.
author: Jeff B.

description:
MANGIA, MANGIA, MANGIA.......

Some things are worth waiting for. LOCANDA is one of them.  I'd have to say this is a place that should be on everyone's list to visit.  The dishes range from good to stellar.  

Party of 12 - Friday Evening. Celebrating my sisters birthday. We are a rowdy bunch! Well what I mean, we are, when we are dining and drinking, and enjoying ones company.  LOCANDA just makes one feel comfortable. Its decor is beautiful. Hip and trendy. 

Now onto the most important part...the food.
We had a multitude of dishes, since they are tapas (small) but adequate portions for our group. We started with either Cauiflower soup, or the Early Girl Tomato salad w/balsamic vinaigrette. I chose the salad.  Plenty of Focaccia bread and Locanda's Pizza Bianca Bread. Addicting!  Array of beverages, from white or red wine, prosecco, champagne to San Pellegrino or ginger ale. 

We enjoyed a couple of appetizers. The Jewish-style Artichokes, fried till perfectly crisp & tender. Fried Castelevetrano Olives, lightly breaded with fontina cheese in the center. YUM!  

Next a variety of dishes family-style, we shared the following:
Fettuccini Rabbit Sugo - perfectly al dente. Lots of rabbit.  Rigatoni alle Carbobara, typical Roman dish, with guaciale, egg, pecorino, ; black pepper. Stellar!  And the third pasta dish,  Bucatini alle' Amatriciana, a classic pasta dish executed flawlessly. The addition to guaciale and peperoncini add alot to the dish.
We also shared the Panchetta Wrapped Guinea Hen Leg. Crunchy skin, very moist!  One of my favorite dishes!  Grilled Halibut Collar (Special) - Skipped (don't care for halibut).
Bavette Steak w/ roasted radicchio. Tender & tasty. Loved it!  
Roman squash and tomato confit.
Grilled corn. Sweet chili, ricotta salata. Delish!!

Dessert:  We brought the birthday cake, classic St Honore Cake that LOCANDA was happy to help cut and serve. And sing!

Service was fast & impeccable.  We had several people serving our large party.  This is a happening, busy place, so it does get LOUD in there.  Our servers made sure we were satisfied with our experience.

Have to say, my heart belongs to their pasta dishes.  All were stellar. They really do pasta well!  Portions are reasonable, not tiny but not large either. 

Given that LOCANDA is the sister restaurant to Delfina, I'm not my surprised that this Roman-themed restaurant is just as good.   This is a place to go to celebrate a special occasion, job promotion, or tax refund. About $95 pp (incl tax & tip).
author: Janet T.

description:
Locanda is the BEST!!  They are my favorite Italian restaurant in SF.  I've eaten dinner there 3 times so far, and food, drinks, service, ambiance and location, I love everything about them.  (This review is only for dinner because I've never tried their brunch.)  

Antipasti, pasta, fish, all we had so far were GREAT.  Their pasta dishes are best in town imho. Also their grilled (whole) fish of the day is a MUST-HAVE if you like fish.  I've eaten it 3 times, and every time they cooked it SO PERFECTLY.  It's quite a big dish.  But because my partner is vegetarian, I once couldn't eat it all on my own.  Then, they put it into a box, and it was still tender and tasty next day at home.  (Eating grilled fish at home without cooking/cleaning is such a treat!)

Their drinks are great too.  I like their cocktails.  Also their wine flights are delicious and quite generous.  Wine by the bottle is reasonable too.

I can't wait to go back!
author: Akiko O.

description:
This was our first time at Locanda, for my birthday dinner, based of a suggestion from a friend. Thus I had no preconceived notion or judgment about Locanda and in fact was looking forward to a pleasant time. And in fact all and all except for one major factor our server was helpful and pleasant. This particular evening the menu featured a prix fixe dinner as an option featuring a selected menu by guest and visiting chef Sora Anna Dente described on the special menu as internationally recognized and "Queen of Roman Cooking". She was seated at a table across from the kitchen. We were told she would be circulating about the dining room greeting patrons throughout the evening. For those not wanting the entire prix fixe meal all of her special menu items were available on the regular evening menu as individual options.We opted to order of the evening menu and one of our selections was her dish, the others not.

One observation was, that from the time we passed her on our way to the table until we left she sat at her table talking with her companion getting up only once to take a photo with a party at a table almost next to hers. She never circulated the dining room greeting patrons as every table that evening was told as they were first approached by their servers. I don't raise a big issue with this as I don't know her as a chef and it didn't matter to our dinner but why tell every patron excitedly about her and that she will be circulating to meet patrons when she would not. From my direct line of site to where she was sitting I saw her talking to her companion and yawning several times. As a visiting chef presenting a menu of her creations she really should have been in the kitchen supervising her dishes at least occasionally to make sure the kitchen was serving them properly. This aspect was lacking most evidently because the signature dish of hers we ordered Fettuccine and Chicken Giblets $21, although edible and not unpleasant was pretty blah, the house made fettuccine noodles were greatly overcooked, there was a very scant amount of giblets which gave the dish only a hint of the giblet flavor leaving this dish basically a very small portion of overcooked noodles in a creamy tomato sauce with a few small pieces of chicken giblets and crumbled cheese. And it was under seasoned too boot thus pretty blah. And the portion size very small for the $21. The "Queen of Roman Cooking" sits yawning while her signature dish comes out of the kitchen like this? Hmmmm.... Overcooked pasta? Hmmm....

We started the dinner with one order of the housemade Coppiette (Roman Style Pork Jerkey)$2.50 /pc. Neither of us cared for the flavor which was very mildly medicinal. In fact as I ate more what came to my mind was ever so slightly that flavor of Chloroseptic.

We also started with the SHAVED ARTICHOKES - grilled ricotta, wild arugula, avocado $14. Another quite small portion.... The dressing had a lovely flavor based I believe on a nice olive oil however it was such that it rendered the wild arugula quite gloppy against the crisp shaved artichokes and there were at most 2 small pieces of grilled ricotta and possibly one thin slice of avocado. A very small salad not unpleasant to eat but poorly executed for $14.

The dish that ended up a complete fail and brings my rating from a 2.5 to a solid1is the pasta dish MEZZE MANICHE - dungeness crab, tomato, fennel $26. Once again the flavor was quite nice. You could definitely taste crab flavor although it was very hard pressed to find much of any crab meat itself. A few small shreds possibly? The pasta was slightly overcooked, but nothing to complain about and the portion was decent. ( Although with a Roman Chef present one would expect all pasta be perfect) What caused this dish to be a total fail was the presence and quantity of crab shell mixed in with the pasta. My partner's first bite had a small piece of shell, oh well, it's crab and those things happen. But the pieces became more and more and larger! Larger like break a crown or tooth larger. Half way through her dish she said she was afraid to eat it and was picking carefully through each bite. At this point one of the serve staff came by to deliver a drink and he asked how everything was. We showed him the crab shells and he smiled shook his head yes and just said "Yeah". At the end of the meal when our server came to clear the plates we showed her the crab shells and commented on how many and large they were and she just shook her head yes. Random and plentiful pieces of hard shell mixed and hidden within a pasta dish that could choke a patron or break a tooth gives Locanda a rating of never returning for me.

We graciously declined dessert and went to Dandelion instead.
author: Steven B.

description:
Locanda seemed to have fallen off my radar of places to eat, but when a friend and I were looking for a place to eat dinner with about a one week notice, Locanda had great availability.  After doing some recon work via a co-worker who lives within a stones throw to Locanda, I concluded that the experience at Locanda was something to get excited over.  I snagged a 5:30pm reservation for two, and enjoyed sitting right by their kitchen area and away from the drafty door.  Since she's a fellow foodie, we decided that we should split everything and try as much as possible.  Here's what we had:

Appetizers: 
Jewish-style Artichoke: I'm not a huge fan of artichokes, but this came to us complimentary! After having read about this, I was excited to try it, but was sort of underwhelmed with the lack of taste it had.
Locanda's Pizza Bianca: Honestly, I had no idea that this was just some sliced bread with olive oil and salt.  I truly thought it was table bread.  When the check came, I almost panicked that we had been charged something that we didn't get since I assumed that "pizza" implied more than just bread, olive oil and salt.  Oops. I guess it was good? Not sure I'd be down for paying $4 again though.

Pasta: 
Tonnarelli Cacio e Pepe: Locanda's well-known pasta dish that has made an appearance on 7x7's Must-Eat List for 2015 was delicious.  Of all the things we ate that night, this was the best dish we had.  It wasn't the absolute best pasta I ever had, but I was certainly inspired to eat my allotted portion.

Mains:
Bavette Steak: I was all set to devour this until I noticed that it was cooked a little more "rare" than I would have liked.  While some of the pieces of meat were fully cooked (and delicious), other pieces we received seemed a little blue.  I also made the observation that the meat was sliced a little raggedly.  The sides that came with weren't bad, although I didn't really touch the escarole.

Berkshire Pork Saltimbocca: My friend chose the saltimbocca, and we both struggled to finish this.  The dish itself was very salty! The thinly sliced pork was good, but it wasn't without needing a cup of water between bites.

Dessert:
Meyer Lemon Shaker Crostata: My friend is a PHENOMENAL baker so it was really interesting to get her take on the dessert.  She enjoyed the Meyer lemon slices within the filling, but found the crust of the crostata to be somewhat lacking.  The crust seemed to be a little on the soggy side when we ate it.  My take on it was that it was a little too sweet where the panna didn't seem to provide enough balance to the rest of the crostata.

Service wise, everything was great.  I guess with all the hype that I had heard around Locanda, I was expecting more.  I definitely think that what we had was good, but for everything else that's within Locanda's proximity, it might be worth checking out some of the other places before stopping here.
author: Lisa I.

description:
Pasta sourced for Delfina's?  I think this group should stick to pizza, their core competency.  Don't know why I keep giving this group of restaurants so many chances but they have disappointed on so many fronts and so many times!  
For dinner last night, we went for their appetizer: Oregon Bay shrimp - overpriced and more deep fried crust/dough than the shrimp itself.  Whatever shrimp was in it was every part of the shrimp but the shrimp itself!  For 10$. That's a RIP-OFF. The cheese board, whatever fancy name it went by had grapes on it, harvested from maybe last year(?)and 6 almonds ....come on ....justify the price you are charging the customer, the jam and marinated whatever, was tasteless.
The pasta...al dente- does NOT mean under cooked!!!  If you define yourself as a pasta place, learn the art and science of how to cook, serve and sauce this great Italian creation, don't overcharge, raise expectations and disappoint the clientele on every front!!!
The only reason I can give this place 3 stars is the 'Maine Lobster' that was edible, well cooked and met our expectations out of anything we ordered there!
Service was excellent.  Ambiance nothing to shout about.
author: Chitra J.

description:
It was ok. 

I've been following on Instagram, watching their pastas and hearing about their great cacio e pepe. The pastas were just ok. We had the cacio e pepe and alla Amitriciana. Both pastas were cooked perfectly but lacked "kick" in the taste department. They were just ok. 

We had their version of the Roman artichoke. Not great. Wrong variety was used in my opinion. Too many leaves and not enough heart. I also think that artichokes are best in CA in the spring. They should offer it only then, and be more seasonal. 

Things we liked: fried olives. Prosciutto with flatbread. 

Things we loved: Service. Vibe. Atmosphere. Radish and anchovie butter. Signirilo (sp? - like broccoli greens).  The amaro offerings. 

I really wanted to love this restaurant. But the pasta fell flat.
author: Frankie G.

description:
When I first met Locanda, I only acquainted myself with her beverages. What a great bar she has, and what great drinks her bartenders have poured over the years. In the last couple of years, I've always found my way to one of the tables, and I've never been disappointed. Moreover, this is the only Italian restaurants at which I exclusively order pasta. It's always amazing.

Variety and consistent excellence.
author: Michael B.

description:
Just out of a Champagne pre-party at a friend's new SoMa loft, eight of us took Locanda Osteria by storm last Friday night. Maybe it was our comraderie, our borderline (?) drunkeness, or our waitress' awesome service. Whatever it was, we had a blast! 

Fuzzily thinking back, Church cocktail(s) made a big impact. Absolutely delicious with Aperol, gin, Cocchi Americano and lemon! They packed a potent punch.

The grilled Jewish-style Artichoke appetizer was a revelation and so good we had to re-order. Not to be passed up!

The grilled leg of lamb entreé was perfectly cooked medium rare (see my photo, you don't have a choice, but medium rare is my fav). It was excellent, served with escarole, anchovy and ceci.

The shared special of the day was a stunning, humongeous whole codfish which we immediately dubbed The Whale. Poached acqua pazza, it was eaten down to the bone, even the eyeballs LOL.

For some funny reason I can't remember what desserts we ate. As we stumbled out to our next destination, I paused to think even though my playground is now NYC, my hometown still rocks like mad thanks to places like Locanda.
author: Jerry C.

description: Do you like expensive Italian food? This place serves a lot of pasta and no pizza. I wonder why. Well, I decided to have the lasagna($20) and a side of smoked mashed potatoes($5). I also got the lime lemon basil drink. I paid around $35 for all this food. It was a good meal. The lasagna could not be just plain old lasagna. This lasagna had a different color. The lasagna noodles were green from nettle. The whole thing had a unique consistency. This ain't yo mamma's lasagna. See pic. The menu is very interesting and it seems authentic. We came here with 20 people to celebrate Guy's birthday. It was his choice to come here. Guy had the crab pasta. Some other people sitting near me also had the lasagna and brussels sprouts. I also tried some of the fried onions. Those were good. One person brought out the executive chef for Guy to meet. I'd say he does a good job. This is a high maintenance restaurant with a nice interior.
author: Denise C.

description:
As an Italian I have to say that the food overall is average, and some dish below average, and the pasta dish sizes are strange. We order 3 different pastas, Bucatini alla matrisciana, cacio e pepe, and spaghetti with octopus. We order half portion of cacio e Pepe and regular size the other two. The matrisciana pasta was almost the same size of the half size of the cacio e pepe, basically small, and the spaghetti with octopus much larger. I feel they have a lot of room to improve in the kitchen.
However, great job to the pastry chef, the deserts were very good.
author: J J.

description: I really like this place. I've been taking my friends here for special occasions for years now. It's affordable enough for me to treat them, and the food and atmosphere is just so nice it really feels special. I don't drink really, but the drinks here are yummy enough that occasionally I'll have one. The pasta is my favorite. Very well portioned and very rich. It's so fun to see the meat coolers and the wood burning grill. Definitely make a reservation because this place fills up. Highly recommend.
author: Shana A.

description: Food is great, service is superb, and drinks are plenty.  Atmosphere is cozy and relaxing.  High end food service in the mission.
author: Nilu S.

description: This was our first dinner out and the perfect place for us. Trendy looking, and delicious! I love smaller type of portions. To many people go by omg there's so much food like that makes it better lol. I personally rather a smaller dish when I go out. Anyway I highly recommend the rigatoni carbonara. just skip the fresh ginger drink lol........ unless you are into that...
author: Crystal P.

description: Perfect fit for the Mission. The cocktails, fried olives, bavette steak, lamb chops were all on point. They have a Bourbon Flight for only $20!
author: Sarina A.

description: Went with a large group. All of the shared appetizers were amazing, especially the bread.
author: Julian W.

description:
I love the pastas at Delfina so I was pleasantly surprised to find that Locanda is a sister restaurant (which was much easier to book reservations). I was able to easily grab a table 2 hours ahead on a Sunday evening. 

We had the Tonnarelli Cacio E Pepe, the Bucatini All'amatriciana, the Radiatore "pecora E Pecorino" and the Casarecce. 

The Tonnarelli seemed to be very popular (it was recommended on the 7x7 must eat list apparently) and it was a creamier dish with spaghetti cooked al dente. It was chewy and cooked just right without being too heavy despite the cheese (in my opinion).

The Bucatini and Radiatore were both tomato sauce based pasta that tasted a bit similar but equally delicious. Different pasta were used and the Radiatore had lamb ragu while the Bucatini didn't contain meat but the sauce definitely had its similarities. The Bucatini was slightly spicier though with the usage of peperoncini, while the Radiatore used mint for a fresher and lighter taste. I would suggest getting one of the above instead of both.

The Casarecce seemed to be a seasonal dish and it was a spicier dish with pork. I absolutely loved the sauce, it was so good and I wish I had bread to dip into the sauce. They used green tomato in this dish, which is less common but excellent. 

The alcohol selection was also quite vast. There was a great variety of cocktails and the wine we tried (a red from Tuscany) was really good. The portions at Locanda are a bit small, especially given the price, but it was really delicious and we didn't find any misses with the pastas that we tried. The atmosphere was also really wonderful - very casual and trendy but cozy. Overall, a great restaurant in the Mission with good-quality pasta that can still be easily booked on short notice.
author: Michelle Y.

description: Locanda pulls through again. I enjoyed a nice fine meal with my friends and this is definitely a place to visit for fine Roman/Italian food. It is best to order many dishes and share. I would say the standouts were all the pasta dishes, especially the Beef Tortelli which I would leave on the menu. The Steak Bavette is amazing and goes well with a fine glass of Cabernet. Out of the side dishes go with the cauliflower. I usually like the Jewish artichoke, but it was a bit disappointing this time around. A little over cooked and to crispy. The ambiance is wonderful, and I would suggest sitting up front in the restaurant where there is more action. Our server Aaron was very nice and attentive as well as the other staff. Great music, mostly alternative which is great and hip. The only other things I would suggest to make this place even better would be to upgrade the wine list a bit with more California wines like Pinot Noir from Kosta Browne and Seasmoke. Some Cabernet Sauvignon standouts like Caymus and Duckhorn. Another thing I would suggest is if you see customers waiting by your front door freezing in the cold and the crazy wind like we had yesterday, then to please let us in and wait at the bar. I know you open at 5:30pm, but if we are 5 to 10 minutes early and freezing outside, then please let us in. You would have ended up getting another sale at the bar by us ordering drinks...Think about it. Overall, we will be back...
author: Mark L.

description: This is apparently the sister restaurant to Delfina, which I'm personally a huge fan of (their pasta is some of the best I've had). We came here for brunch with some friends (they take reservation for brunch). I got the eggs benedict while my S.O. got the egg in purgatory. We got a side of the hash brown (which is bomb) and the sticky bun. Overall, meal was delicious. However, the portion was a bit small. We shared the sticky bun and hash brown, but looking back I probably should've gotten the sides for myself on top of the eggs benedict (and I'm a pretty small Asian lady).
author: Sharon L.

description:
Love Locanda but the portions should be on a children's menu!

Food-great
Drinks-great
Size of portions- appetizer size


We had dinner on Friday night with friends.  Atmosphere is great, and the food and drinks were great...

However...

When I pay $38.00 for spaghetti with lobster, I should be able to take more than 3 bites.

Truly an appetizer sized portion but with a full entree price.

The other pasta dishes extremely small too.

If you want food good , good drinks, and really small appetizer size entrees you'll love it here.

You will go home hungry though!
author: Dr. Octagon O.

description:
Got reservations a few days before NYE! Yay...I was so last minute this year and lots of places book up quickly. Also been wanting to check Locanda out, so this fit perfectly for us to have a low key New Year's while still getting out into the world. Took Bart from the East Bay and it's an easy walk from 16th and Mission station. 

We started with wine and beer for the hubs, and some of those Castlevetrano fried olives....Oh had those in Rome. So delicious and crunchy gooey amazing, who knew a cheese stuffed green olive deep fried could be so off the hook?
Next up we split the cauliflower with black truffle oil soup, so tasty you had to mop up every drop with your bread out of that bowl (of course politely, not to look like a heathen).
And I think on the bread note above, my husband ordered some kind of bread with cheese baked in it? kind of focaccia style to me.
Now again we shared our pasta dish (trying to leave room for our entree). We ordered Caccio de pepe. Al dente spaghetti pasta mixed with pepper and parmesan cheese. I do like my pasta cooked a bit more at home, but it was delicious and again glad we shared.
I ordered Steak with garlic mashed potatoes, the steak coming medium rare....wow...very rich and perfectly cooked. "Someone's" fork kept migrating over to my mashed potatoes....
My husband opting for the scallops, I tried a bit of one. The sear very nicely done.

We were really full, but being the last day of the year we just had to do it. Order desert....So we went balls to the walls Tcho Chocolate gooey deliciousness with ice cream and caramel....oh that caramel....WoW, MMM, Oh stuff it in. We did it!
Excellent meal. I have no idea how much the bill cost, sorry hubs. Happy New Year!
author: Susan D.

description: If you want delicious Italian seafood and pasta... this is your place!!! Pizza Bianca! And their whole fish aqua pazza style are to die for! Some of my favorite pasta is their lobster pasta so creamy and delicious! Definitely one of my favorite restaurants in the Mission!
author: amy h.

description:
Came here for restaurant week and ordered the Belfiori Burrata, Bellwether Crescenza Tortelli and the Blood Orange Granita.

Belfiori Burrata - Amazing. Very simple dish - slice of baguette with oil and then a huge heaping of burrata on top. 

Bellwether Crescenza Tortelli - The black trumpet mushroom and pine nut filling in the tortelli was creamy and delicious. Not heavy at all. Highly recommend. 

Blood Orange Granita - This was a real disappointment. The blood oranges on the top were too bitter for me. It left me digging for the granita on the bottom of the bowl.
author: Janice J.

description: Beautiful restaurant, great ambiance, excellent service. The food on the other hand , not very good at all, surprisingly. Not only is the pasta overpriced for the small portions, but it simply didn't taste good. We ordered 3 pasta dishes including their "popular" carbonara and we all agreed that the only decent tasting dish was the bucatini. The only good thing I can say about the pasta (and I love my pasta) is that is was cooked perfectly al dente. It wasn't bland or overly salty it just had an unappealing taste to it we didn't enjoy and agreed we could all easily make a better carbonara at home. The table next to us agreed that the carbonara they had was not good, but that the fish was good. Perhaps this place is not about the pastas but more about the meat based dishes. The jerusalem artichoke appetizer wasn't good either, bitter and dry. Nevertheless we had a great time enjoying drinks and enjoying the ambiance. It was worth it just for that.
author: Rumi R.

description:
Ambiance, inventive drinks and Italian food done right.
We tried the house made jerky, which was everything I hoped it'd be, with a smokey delicious flavor.
Look for the pizza bianca...which is Burrata on a toasted crostini. For entrée I had the pork chop which was on point
author: Stephen C.

description: I've been hearing amazing things about this place for years, so was looking forward to having brunch today. When we arrived for our 1:30 reservation, we were promptly informed that the kitchen closes at 2pm. That seems like a tight turnaround to me, but whatever. The place was maybe 30% full and our party of 6 was seated at a 4 person table, therefore quite squished. When we asked for an empty  table next to us to be pushed over, we were told those tables were being removed soon.
