A few minutes later they removed them and replaced them with a different type of table. Which apparently we were not welcome to use either. Food was average, minus one star for less than good service.
author: Tracy B.

description: Share all pasta dishes and pick a few main dishes (fish is a must) with sides! Order a side of their pizza which is essentially focaccia and soak up the sauces!  Bartenders and wait staff know their stuff! Front door service outstanding.
author: Kimberly D.

description:
Left a holiday party after some snacks and needed some carbs on a Saturday night. Walked in and found the meal not exactly memorable.

The al dente moments +'s:
+ RADIATORE - lamb ragu, pecorino, mint for $20. Pasta cooked perfectly and sauce was tasty. I would order it again on someone else's dime.
+ Nice high top seating that was available on walk-in Saturday prime time for dinner
+ We gave our feedback on the rigatoni (see below) but did not expect a comp. Server took the dish off our tab. Thanks.
+ Great dim setting for intimate dinners or groups.


The not so al dente moments -'s:
- LOCANDA'S PIZZA BIANCA - olive oil, sea salt $4. What? It was over salted and just bread. Again what? This should have been complimentary. I was expecting more for $4 and living in SF, this appetizer was not acceptable.
- RIGATONI alla CARBONARA: pass. Pasta was cooked perfectly but that creamy cheese white sauce did no good. Scraped it off and dug for those bits of guanciale (cured meat) and it helped but there wasn't enough of those bits amp the taste. At $19 it's a huge pass.
- Our server greeted us and disappeared. We waited 10' and got someone else to take our order.
- Tables closely set that you can hear the couple next to us going through their first date chit chat

Overall it's a nice place but the two dishes and their prices just don't compel me to return. 2.5 stars.
author: Yiven C.

description: I LOVE THIS PLACE, BOOM!!! My fiance brought me here to our first dinner date 2 years ago, and 2 years later he arranged a 2nd anniversary dinner with the amazing staff the same night he later proposed to me! Not only is the food absolutely mouth-watering, but the ambiance is also fabulous without being too pretentious, and the staff offers the best customer service! Heart you forevs Locanda!
author: Mona M.

description: The food is alright, the customer service not at all. Not worth the price or the wait.
author: Maria Luz M.

description:
Food was flavorful and dishes that I can't recreate in my kitchen.
There were some flaws with the food and (especially) service.

1) LOCANDA'S PIZZA BIANCA with TRIPPA alla ROMANA:
basically warm bread drenched in sea salt olive oil with pancetta, ceci, mint, pecorino. I really liked this combo because the bread was good and Trippa all Romana had full tomato flavor with chewy tripe. Highly recommend this combo. 

2) RADIATORE "PECORA e PECORINO"- lamb ragu, pecorino, mint
So salty I couldn't have more than 10 bites. The chef perhaps forgot that pecorino is a salty cheese? They probably salted both pasta and cheese, therefore the dish became incredibly salty. Again, flavorful and the lamb chunks were good.. but so salty.

3) ORECCHIETTE- cotiche sausage, broccoli raab, capers, parmigiano
AGAIN SO SALTY. Salt pasta. Salt soup. I dont know. 
The sausage chunks were good- but again, the chef forgot to taste or something. Honestly, between two pasta dishes, orecchiette was the most interesting and delicious one. 

I would return back to the restaurant if they make the dishes less salty. 

Proportion wise, they were very honest and generous. 

Service: our service was very cold and not attentive. We had to ask several times for water and  extra dishes. Also, since we ordered only 3 dishes (?), the server was not happy.
author: Sue K.

description:
Loved this restaurant. Food was spectacular. I had the spaghetti with lobster and it was one of the best spaghetti dishes I've ever had. Friends had the Bavette Steak, which they raved about. We had the fried veggie appetizer and olives, which were yummy.

Service was also really good. We were in a bit of a rush and they got our food out within 15min. Wine recommendation was also really great! 

Really enjoyed the experience and have a feeling we will return soon.
author: Natalise K.

description:
Drink: The Prince (bourbon drink)
Meal: the sausage orecchiette
Dessert: Chocolate budino and cappuccino

Everything was fantastic.
author: Diane W.

description: I came here a while back when it had first opened and I was extremely underwhelmed. I recently came back for brunch and it was delicious! Amazing pancakes and hash browns. Great cocktails. I will definitely come back for brunch and may try dinner again.
author: Rude G.

description:
Everything was delicious! Expensive and small portions, but delicious. Get the fried olives for sure, pizza bianca is pretty much like a focaccia, nice sprinkle of salt and drizzled with olive oil.

We ordered two pastas: carbonara and mushroom tortelli, both were good but for $19-21/ea for the size of your fist portions...it's overpriced for what it is. 

Service was perfect, ambiance is great for date night or casual night with friends. Love the open kitchen and seeing the pork jerky hanging. Definitely worth a visit.
author: Angela L.

description:
I was a little disappointed! My sister hyped it up as the best pasta in SF so I went in with very high expectations, but the rigatoni alla carbonara I ordered was extremely creamy (too much so) and the guanciale (cured meat) was SO salty. I ended up just eating the pasta and leaving the meat, which is something I never, ever do!

We also ordered bread to start, and that was also just okay to me. I wouldn't order the bread again, just because I don't think it's worth it to spend money on bread that doesn't WOW me.

I wouldn't oppose coming back, but next time I will make sure to opt for a pasta with a meat-based sauce. Service was great!
author: Kathy L.

description: This place is hit or miss.  I've had great meals here and I've had very mediocre meals. Ate here this week and it was subpar. The cocktails were nice, the cheese plate was a joke and the pasta was forgettable. Annoying how you pay ridiculous prices for pasta and it's not even great.
author: A Z.

description:
Appetizer: LOCANDA'S PIZZA BIANCA ..4 - olive oil, sea salt. Super yummy appetizer. I would recommend. 

Entree: ANCETTA-WRAPPED MARY'S CHICKEN - Anson Mill's farro, legumes..25. I love chicken and this was a good entree but not the best I had. I finished it all up though lol
            FISH OF THE DAY[varies]- I had this fish another day but and it was good and light. But I would go for the chicken next time. The chicken is more mainstream, packed with taste and more filling. 

CHOCOLATE-RICOTTA BUDINO- ladyfingers, espresso caramello, Garnett cherries..9. It was a pretty good dessert. 

The service is awesome. Not waiting long periods for food or service. Our server was amazing. Very attentive, friendly, professional and knows his food. I was pretty impressed. 

All of the food I had here was great. The bartender recommends wines for us and we always had awesome wine to pair with our food. 

I never booked a reservation although I suggest it. Even if we walked in, we never really had to wait long but one time we almost waited on a Friday for about half an hour because it gets packed especially during dinner or weekends so plan ahead. 

The ambiance is nice and pretty chill, low lighting and romantic. Great for dates. 

I really like how they're open later than most restaurants. Primary reason why this is my number one choice around this area. Well that and the food & service is always great. I literally have nothing to complain about.
author: Jill H.

description:
I went last night and really enjoyed the place. It's really pretty inside and I love that the kitchen is in the open where everyone can see the chef's working their magic. 

Our server was really great and had an awesome personality. And I liked her eyeliner.

I went with my boss and co-worker and we ordered quite a few things among the three of us. I would say that the Bianca Burrata- (grilled pizza bianca, crushed herbs, tons of delicious burrata cheese on top) was my favorite appetizer. Unfortunately, I can't remember the name of my pasta entree, but it was absolutely heavenly. It looked like miniature raviolis and had a seafood stuffing that included shrimp. The serving size was a bit small. With a dish that delicious, I seriously think my hungry ass could have eaten 2 bowls, easily.

Overall, great experience and I will need to come back for that seafood pasta dish!
author: Liz M.

description: Let me tell you the Brunch here is freaking awesome! If you're a vegetarian like me babe...this  place hits the spot. The LEMON-RICOTTA "CORZETTI" PANCAKES are the best. Seriously I feel welcome and comfortable here; a place I can always be myself and enjoy my food.
author: G M.

description: Tight quarters but very delicious Italian food. They make their own focaccia bread (called Pizza Bianca). The melon and prosciutto was so tasty. My pasta all'Amatriciana was oh so good. Great service.
author: Lana B.

description:
Locanda is your typical, overpriced, yuppie dinner date. Everything is yummy but not necessarily mind blowing. To be fair, I am definitely not a pasta connoisseur so the complexities of the dishes here are completely lost on me. At some point during the meal, I wondered if the $22 noodle was that much better than my typical Barilla and Prego... Al dente and all. 

In all seriousness though, I really enjoyed my squid ink pasta. I would skip the rigatoni next time. 

Oh and we ate some $12 foccocia bread that had some arugula on it.
author: Xinxin W.

description:
Service was pretty bad.

The bus boy dropped part of our food to one of our guest, didn't say much and came with a small plate to replenish what he dropped. My friend's pants were soiled.

The food came 40 minutes after we ordered.

The taste of the food is good, but the quantity is small and the price is not cheap.

Ambiance was good, nice decor.
author: Anita J.

description:
I got off the plane from Southern California and decided that I would stop by here and grab a bite to eat. Afterall, it's on the 7x7 magazine as one of the best places to eat. 

I started off with the chicken liver mousse. It was okay. Not the best I've ever had, but not the worst either.  There was a strange layer of fat on top of the container of the mousse.  It came with some bread too. I really prefer softer bread than the hard bread that was given. 

I then ordered the 7x7 suggested item - the tonnarelli "cacio e pepe".  I should have taken the advice of some other yelpers and not necessarily ordered this item. It was really peppery by the end of the dish and definitely too creamy.  There was no real depth and flavor so each bite tasted the same and I wasn't entirely pleased. Not bad, but not great either. 

I wanted to try a dessert so I ended up ordering the chocolate torta.  This was chocolate cake with some delicious bourbon mousse. It was sprinkled with some olive oil and sea salt. I do like some salty aspects of my desserts, but I think I'm partial towards disliking olive oil in my desserts. Just not my thing. 

Overall, I had great service, was able to have a great dinner.  It wasn't too bad costwise, but I also decided not to get too many drinks. I could see how it could get expensive though. 

Protip: chocolate torta was my favorite part of the meal even if I didn't like the olive oil. I could avoid it since it was around the plate. Otherwise delicious!
author: Nina Y.

description: Pretty sure my experience here was as the guest of an agency, the food was very good as I recall...I struggle a bit, the wait staff made certain my wine glass was never empty! Lovely atmosphere, great space in San Francisco for a larger group...they have an antechamber off of their main room...classic section of town, North Beach area I think...
author: J.C. B.

description:
After walking inside and being dazzled by the beautiful and sultry interior of Locanda, I joined my friends who were seated at the bar. I was having dinner and drinks with them but would also recommend this as a nice date place. All of the waitresses were super nice and made recommendations from the menu throughout the night. We ate so much food...

For drinks, I had the License #1 which has apple brandy, rye, dolin blanc, cardamaro, and absinthe. Great if you are looking for a strong, solid cocktail. If you want something more refreshing and fruity, get the Rosso Rubino which has vodka, grapefruit, and fennel... I still think that fennel in a cocktail is a strange concept.

Anyways, we started with the Fried Castelvetrano Olives and Locanda's Pizza Bianca, both of which I could not stop eating. The Jewish-Style Artichoke and Burrata were quite tasty too. I'm sure their menu rotates every few weeks or months, but if the Guinea Hen or Acqua Pazza is there, I would order that again. Otherwise, everything else we ordered was also delicious! Our smorgasbord included the Pancetta Casoncelli, Early Girl Tomatoes, and Garden Lettuces Misticanza. For sides, we got the Smoked Mashed Potatoes with Peppercorn Butter. That was amazing. I was not a fan of the Peas and Shoots, though.

Overall I would come back here again. Not all the time... but definitely enough to try their new dishes!
author: Stefanie C.

description: I have never seen lasagna bolognese look so pretty, taste so good and not be overwhelmingly heavy.  Wish we had a picture of how pretty it looked.  Also the black cod and clams were delicious.  Everything tastes so fresh and was served beautifully by attentive, professional wait staff.  We also sampled the halibut crude , the curly salad, and the white pizza which was more like fluffy, toasty bread.  Can't say enough good things about Locanda.  The decor is comfortable, casual and urban.  The service very team-oriented.
author: Susan G.

description:
Perhaps a little pricier than it ought to be, Locanda serves a strong lineup of classic and rustic Italian dishes.  Probably the dish that best exemplifies this is the Tonnarelli Cacio E Pepe, which is literally Rome on a plate.  The Carbonara also earns top marks for flavor and authenticity.

Oh, and the buratta is gorgeously creamy and has perfect texture.  Absolutely get this as a starter.
author: Bryce B.

description: Had an interesting time here. I had just got off a flight and dropped my suit case home. I was pretty hungry, so I went here because it's close by. Soon as I walk in, I meet a couple girls who were quite fun. They invited me to drink with them, and then we randomly ended up having dinner together. I think their company made the experience better, but the food was not bad either. I ordered their lamb pasta, and it was good, but perhaps a little dry. They also had these fried olive balls that contained melted cheese, which I couldn't resist trying, despite my dairy allergy. Needless to say, they were delicious.
author: Sam S.

description: I've been to Locanda four times and the front of the house with reservations, seating, guest flow and people management leaves huge room for improvement while the back of the house with kitchen, food, drinks and table service continue to be stellar.  If you don't care where you sit or when, and don't mind being jostled between the bar and a breezeway until they are ready to seat you, this is a five-star establishment
author: David B.

description:
Revolving door of servers, extremely long wait times, mistakes and forgotten orders, generally poor service. Good food if you are more patient than we were.

Locanda came highly recommended to us from a colleague in the restaurant industry. As a chef who studied in Rome, he referred to Locanda as the best Roman food in the states. We were looking to have dinner with a couple who lives in the area.

My girlfriend and I arrived at 7:30pm and checked in with the hostess ahead of our 8pm reservation. We went to the bar for drinks while we waited for our friends. The cocktails were delicious and the bar service very good.

Our friends arrived at 8pm and we notified the hostess that we were ready to be seated. We were not seated more than a half-hour later. A waiter noted that we had been waiting for some time and was kind enough to bring us a couple of snacks, but still, this was a very long wait to be seated for a reservation.

After being seated, I ordered a 2011 Piedmont wine for the table. The waitress brought out the 2012 vintage to serve, and when I asked for the 2011 vintage as was on the menu, she brought out the 2013 vintage. She then had a gentleman who was more familiar with the wine list come and help select an alternate wine (he was very helpful).

We waited at the table over 20 minutes before our order was taken by a different waitress.

Our food came out relatively quickly after ordering and was good. We ordered two pastas (orecchiette and carbonara), the short ribs and an appetizer. The orecchiette was particularly well received. The pastas were cooked perfectly.

While a waitress did come to check on us, she did not check on our wine glasses and I ended up pouring for the table. We had to ask the waitress to clear four glasses we had brought over from the bar.

We waited about 15 minutes between dinner clearing and when we had dessert menus. We ordered dessert (afogato and a cake-like dish that paired with a Jura wine) and a glass of grapa. The desserts and grapa arrived but the Jura was forgotten. We had to ask for the Jura and waited a little over 5 minutes for it to arrive.

Sadly, despite excellent food and drink, we left with a very negative impression of Locanda. We waited more than half an our for our reservation, we had a total of three waitresses weave in and out, we waited very long to order, a different wine was brought out from what we ordered and was on the menu, we waited a long time to order dessert, and overall the service was poor. We spent about $120 at the bar and about $280 at dinner. Based on our experience, we would neither return to Loconda nor recommend it to our friends.

I shared my feedback with the manager who kindly offered to send me a gift certificate, however despite responding with my address I never heard back. The gift certificate wasn't necessary, but the gesture was enough for me to give the restaurant a second shot. That ship has sailed.
author: Jeff C. J.

description:
A group of us were here for brunch a few weekends ago, place looked nice and menu is intriguing.  Since it's our first time, we were curious on some dishes.  we expected our waitress to explained and recommend, but she did neither!

She was inpatient.  Got a big attitude and appeared unwilling to serve.  Consensus of our group thought she was a bit rude.  

So food came, yes some dishes were tasty but some of us think portion is a bit petite.

But, what tick me is when our waiter reluctant to refill hot water our tea.  Hard to flag him down esp, our waitress already disappeared.  I saw him yap and laugh with other waiter while bar back kept on telling him the drink is ready.  

All of us were wow by this brunch experience and we are so looking forward to come back to spend $$$ - Not.
author: Tkd K.

description:
Unbelievably small portions of mediocre, overpriced food.

We left hungry, mad that we'd been taken advantage of and with the rare inclination to leave a Yelp review. 

Don't waste your money.
author: Rachael W.

description:
Locanda is a hood favorite. I could live on their focaccia bread, crispy on the outside, slathered with just enough olive oil, and soft and fluffy on the inside. I'm always surprised by their unique veggie pasta offering, basically whatever veggie is in season. 

The last time I dropped in for dinner, I had bucatini with mint, ricotta, and fava beans. Wow!!! Every. Single. Time.
author: Gabriela W.

description: This restaurant is outstanding. We arrived on time for our 5:30 reservation and were seated immediately. Within 10 minutes, the restaurant and bar were full. Our server (Kaitlin) guided us through the menu and wine, making excellent recommendations. My husband had the Rigatoni Alla Carbonara and I had the Bellwether Crescenza Tortelli. The pasta was phenomenal in both dishes, cooked to perfection. My Tortelli, with black trumpet mushrooms, pine nuts and mint was perfectly balanced and excellent. My husband's rigatoni was so good I thought he was going to eat the bowl - just the right amount of creamy with outstanding flavor. And the best part for me was when Kaitlin let me know I could have a half-order, since I don't eat a lot!!  Excellent food, service, and ambiance!!
author: Robyn W.

description: Wonderful atmosphere.  Excellent service.  Thus, two stars.  The food was ok, but do not go there if you are hungry.  In fact, eat before you go so that you can enjoy the atmosphere they've created.  $85 bottle of wine, not so good, and in wine country.  No bread and oil on the table, the menu states that there is an extra charge for olive oil, the portions are MINISCULE and the preparation is just adequate.  The Fritto Misto was tiny and gooey with grease.  What they fried was unrecognizable.  I still don't know what it was.  We didn't leave as we were there with other people; had we been there alone, we would definitely have walked, New Year's Eve or not.  Neither my husband nor I have "Sucker" tattooed on our foreheads.
author: Felicia C.

description: The place quickly fills up despite it being Sunday evening, and has a great atmosphere. The food is delicious - some great pasta dishes, and the lamb cutlets main is exquisite. Service is friendly.
author: Benson L.

description:
I came here with a group of friends last night and had been DYING to try the pasta here. It did not disappoint!

Ambiance: We were able to get a reservation for 6 a few days before, which was nice. Very cute restaurant and vibe.

Drinks: Great happy hour deals! $6 for a glass of wine and $4 for a beer. I got the glass of red, and at the table we got 2 bottles of Chianti, which were delicious. 

Food: SOOO much food. 
Fried Olives: fried olives stuffed with cheese- 5/5
Pizza Bianca: Basically just bread. but i love bread so it was good- 4.5/5
prosciutto appetizer: the prosciutto quality was amazing. However, I wish something more came on the plate than just prosciutto. I put it on top of the pizza bianca though and it was delicious- 4/5
Tomato salad- eh. it was really salty- 1/5
In terms of pasta....
Bucatini- saw lots of yelp reviews so we had to get this. it was cooked al dente but was really good- 4/5
Orchiette- not my favorite. I don't love sausage- 2/5
Crescenza Tortelli- AMAZING. Could possibly be the best pasta I've had in SF. Still not as good as Italy, but nothing will be. We got a second round of this and I would definitely order it again- 4.5/5
Rigatoni alla carbanara- The Pancetta in it was amazing! It was really good, but nothing super special -4/5

Overall-  I want to come back and try the "cacio e pepe" pasta, and also get the Tortelli again!!
author: Jenna G.

description: Locanda is truly one of my favorite restaurants in the city.  The rigatoni alla carbonara is perfection, as is the leg of lamb, and anything involving their bread.  Definitely make a reservation though, otherwise it can just feel really crowded and unpleasant.
author: Salini N.

description: I went here for my brother's birthday. My favorite part would have to be the fried olives with cheese, the mushroom pasta, and the juicy steak and mashed potatoes! I would definitely give this place a 5 star rating for how good it really is!
author: Asher D.

description:
I was so excited to finally get a reservation at Locanda (which I made a few weeks ago to get  a table at a normal dinner hour). I'd heard a lot of hype and positive reviews and gorgeous intagram pics so I couldn't wait. 

I must say I was disappointed with the food. I'm a vegetarian so I'm wondering if because I wasn't able to order any of the meat I missed out, but I feel that it should be pretty easy to get an amazing pasta dish minus the meat. 
What we ordered: We started with the fried olives and the early girl tomato salad. They were both great, especially the tomato salad which had fennel, arugula, and crustini soaked in tomato juice. It was a great start, but the pastas were a let down. I got the cacio and pepe which is one of my all time favorites. I recognize that it's not the most exciting pasta dish and there isn't a lot to go off, but that should also mean it's really easy to get right since it's not very involved. However, it fell flat. It was lacking pepper and cheese--which is basically the entire dish. My friend ordered the linguine with anchovies and it was insanely fishy and the padron peppers totally dominated the lightness of the pasta. For dessert, we got the semifreddo which was good, but I didn't feel the need to finish it. 

Our waitress was great though! I brought my own wine and she commended me on my taste and talked about her knowledge of the vineyard and the vintage and made some recommendations based on the bottle. Additionally, my friend had almost half her pasta left over (saw a lot of comments about the portions being small but I thought they were perfect) and she asked to get a box. Somehow her box got thrown away and the waitress felt so bad she asked us to stay for a few minutes while the chef made her a new one. This was such a kind gesture and definitely not what we expected! 

I'd give Locanda another shot for brunch since I know it is very popular. But I don't think I'd go out of my way for dinner especially given how many amazing Italian restaurants there are in the city.
author: Sophie S.

description: 4 stars for the pasta dish - I got the Casio e Pepe. Really flavorful, pasta is chewy and good texture, however it felt just a tad too plain. Dessert was definitely 5 stars. I got the semifreddo and it was fantastic. Creamy, crunchy, chocolate all in one. Seriously do yourself a favor and get this - it IS that good.
author: Connie S.

description:
First of all I am a thirteen year old, well traveled kid who likes writing good nice reviews for places like this one. I am amazed at the detail of this place. When they opend up they must have wanted this place to be one of a kind because that is what it is. I like how if you need to wash your hands fast and there is a line they have sinks out Side of the actual bathroom but don't worry; the urnals are kept behind walls of course. I like the tiles which kind of remind me of a subway. Not these tiles they used here. No. The ones they used here are way nicer. They remind me of a upscale subway. Their drawings are handmade and I am not going to give up their secrets so you'll have to come in to find them out. I love open kitchens so that Is what makes this place so special to me. Even though I am not old enough to go to the bar it still looks pretty nice and so does the bartender. Lol. 




 Too bad I was not feeling good because the food was amazing. The pasta was nice and rich and buttery. Perfectly cooked I could ell it for a mile away. All of my guests also liked their food. Even though my dad makes a killer lamb ragu his was no match for the one tonight. In my opinion they make the best pasta in the world. The Shirley temples were also killer well if you like strong cherry flavor. I like how they prepare the bread by sprinkling olive oil on it. It really brings out the flavor. 

I would recomend this place to anybody who wants a good Italian meal. I will be back soon.
author: Ford W.

description:
Are you one of the growing number of alcoholically inclined SF night-lifers with money to burn but little or no taste(buds)? If so, then please be their guest and leave the real reasons to go out for a meal to the rest of us.

The chef is either a sadist or just bought shares in a salt mine: the sodium levels are off the charts! And this is from someone who has at least 6 varieties of salt in her cupboard and delights in the porcine meats!
author: Josephine M.

description:
Going to an Italian restaurant and not ordering pasta or pizza is like going to a strip club with blindfolds. A total *beep* tease. Who does that?

Last week, I swore off refined carbs (yes, again!); white flour to be exact. However, as I was scanning through the food porn on Locanda's page, I couldn't stop fawning over the Burrata Cuscini. There goes my one week of carb sobriety (again). More on that later.

As the sister of the wildly popular, Delfina and Delfina pizza, Locanda seemed promising. While the cocktails and service were spectacular, the food was very underwhelming. As many reviewers had mentioned, the portions are small for the price point (expect to spend around $60-$75/person which includes one cocktail). I don't mind this at all as long as the small dishes pack a big punch of flavor. They didn't. And while nothing was bad, nothing really stood out either.

F O O D
*Jewish Style Artichokes ($8) - 3 STARS
http://bit.ly/11dd16g
I'm not sure why people are raving over this app. It's just a duo of fried artichokes topped with a generous chiffonade of basil and sprinkled with sea salt. An aioli would have been nice to spruce it up. 

*Chilled Beef Tongue w/ Celery Leaf Salsa Verde ($9) - 3 STARS
http://bit.ly/10nfJKZ
Beef tongue is my favorite offal and after having it prepared this way, I think the only way to enjoy it is in small chunks; as they would serve it at a taqueria. When you chill and slice it thin, beef tongue loses its intense rich beefy goodness and ends up tasting like a standard cold cut which is exactly what happened here.

*Grilled Salmon Collar ($21) - 4 STARS
http://bit.ly/18kWrI2
A special of the night, you can never go wrong with what the Japanese and many chefs coin as a prized part of the salmon. Simply grilled, the salmon collar's skin was crisp while the flesh was fatty and rich. Make sure to devour the fins too; they're like crunchy chips with a nutty flavor. I was hoping for an Italian twist to this popular Japanese dish but there wasn't, it was served with a side of olive oil, salt, and a chili sauce.

*Burrata Cuscini w/ Lobster ($24) - 3 STARS
http://bit.ly/13LZ9BL
The most highly anticipated dish of the night was also the biggest disappointment of the night. I adore burrata for its milky smooth, creamy consistency but the burrata cruscini was more like mini raviolis with no bite to it. The lobster chunks were cooked well but the sauce needed cream or something to boost the richness the burrata was lacking.

We also ordered the Leg of Lamb ($27) which Mr. NSS dug into before I could take a pic. I thought the dish would be more like a slowly braised lamb shank but it was sliced and served medium rare. Mr. NSS thought the lamb was just OK while I found it to be a bit chewy and underseasoned.

S E R V I C E
The entire staff was awesome, friendly, and down to earth. Our waiter was knowledgeable and attentive. Food service is slow when it gets busy so it's best to come for an early dinner.

A M B I A N C E / D E C O R
Contemporary urban sheek meets country rustic vibe with a brown and ivory color scheme, an open kitchen, and wooden furnishings. Love it.

Locanda is great for dates but make sure to come only with reservations. 

P A R K I N G
Valet parking is $12.

While the food at Locanda is not worth coming for in my opinion, DO stop by for their amazing cocktails. The Church was buzztastic: http://bit.ly/10OxcHH and SO appropriately named. After a couple of those, you may just end up at church...repenting your wildly drunken sins. ;)
author: Cherylynn N.

description:
Let me start out by saying that I am a big fan of Locanda and have had a number of excellent meals and cocktails here. That said, I think it has lost something recently. 

The first hint was that I was able to get a reservation on both a Friday and Saturday eve at 7:30, just the day before. Unheard of in the past. 

The food was very good (Artichokes, Burrata, little gem salad dressed just right...). The concern for me was with the meal timing and the impact on the food, and our overall feeling of being rushed. 

I was dining with just my husband. We ordered three antipasto dishes and two pasta entrees. All three starters arrived at the exact same time. This meant that the burrata and artichokes were stone cold by the time we got to eating them. Again, both were delicious but less enjoyable because they sat in the table longer than they should have. The server brought our mains to the (small) table before we were completely done with the starters. This not only made for the awkward "dish dance" on the table, but the feeling again of being rushed. I should say at this point were we're only 30 minutes in on the meal. We weren't lingering. 

I think Locanda's strength is their pasta dishes. Both were very good (I had the Lobster, my husband had the Lamb ragu). The disappointment came with the fact that  lamb dish did not taste as if it was freshly made, rather that it was kept warm for an extended period of time, except that it was Luke warm and lacked that "just out of thee kitchen" freshness. My Lobster pasta was fine. 

On the plus side, our waitress was very good, the cocktails were also very good, and their wine selection was superb (if not a little pricey). 

All in all, we expect more for the cost and certainty for the reputation. We will certainty go back with the hope that our recent experience was an exception rather than the new rule. Past meals have been quite good. I will update this review when we do.
author: Janet P.

description:
We were not particularly impressed with our meal at Locanda this week.  The service was good but the food was mostly mediocre.

My friend and I shared several dishes.  The only one we really liked a lot was the Jewish artichokes - they were quite tasty!  For mains, we got two entrees to share - the rockfish special prepared in the aqua pazza style (basically a whole fish in a broth) and the salmon.  Neither was very flavorful and we were a bit disappointed.  At over $30 per entree, we expected more!

We thought we could end the meal on a better note by ordering dessert, and decided to share the cherry tronchetto.  However, it was a cake-like dessert that was just okay and nothing special.

Overall, our meal was expensive but quite average.  I won't be hurrying back to Locanda for dinner anytime soon.
author: Barnali D.

description:
I had a wonderful dining experience with jason. He walked us through his favorite dishes with confidence and erudition. The food was amazing and was expedited quickly. The ambiance was relaxing and made for a perfect intimate date-night.
We ordered:
-COAST HILL FARM EGG & ASPARAGUS - Cortez bottarga, brown butter (Recommended)
-ORECCHIETTE - cotiched sausage, broccoli raab, capers, Parmigiano
-CAPPELLACI "due CARDI"- cardoons, artichokes, mint (Recommended)
-PANCETTA-WRAPPED MARY'S CHICKEN - Anson Mills polenta, grilled turnips (Recommended)
-BORLOTTI BEANS with COTICHE 
-CASSATA "TRE LATTI" - ricotta, lemon curd, nut croccante (Recommended)
author: KM N.

description: We had our company holiday party back in December... the food was just ok ....
author: Subodhani M.

description:
I had high hopes for Locanda. I know it's sister restaurant to Delfina, a restaurant I adore, and I'd always heard excellent things. But after last night, all I can say is "meh."

Admittedly there were a few contributing factors as to why I wasn't as impressed as I could've been. 

#1 - Our reservation was set for 8pm, and we weren't seated till 8:30pm. I understand things happen, so my date and I just ordered a couple cocktails at the bar: the Camelot (gin, cynar, cucumber, lemon) and the Emmanuel II (bourbon, nardini, cappelliti, lemon), both of which were tart, balanced and delicious. Honestly some of the best drinks I've had at any restaurant in the city. Also, the bartenders were incredibly attentive and gracious, and provided us with some of the best service of the evening.

#2 - We booked during SF Restaurant Week. The $40 dinner menu on the website advertised such tantalizing items as an anchovy appetizer with lemon and parm, as well as a Dungeness crab pasta with fennel and uni butter (I checked the menu again the morning of my dinner and these dishes were still listed; as of today -- perhaps after our conversation with their GM -- it has been updated). My boyfriend and I sat down having already decided what we were going to order, only to discover that the anchovy app had been replaced by a garden salad and cauliflower soup. In lieu of the crab pasta, meanwhile, was a pork saltimbocca.

Again, I know that there's a disclaimer saying the menu is subject to change. But I couldn't help feeling a little bit swindled? The hostess and GM were incredibly nice and professional about the whole thing, but noted there wasn't anything they could do. Regardless it left us with a bad taste in our mouths.

#3 - Our waiter seemed kind of aloof. He was nice and kept our water filled, but would neglect to take away empty glasses or plates for awhile, or get us going onto our next course. He also tried to give us the wrong check at one point, lol. Not a huge negative, as I don't think his heart was in a bad place, but he did seem kind of ditzyish?

#4 - All that aside, the food was hit or miss. The burrata on grilled pizza was kind of bland -- and trust me, I'm a HUGE burrata fan. The pork saltimbocca, on the other hand, was far too salty, and the meat was tough. The mushroom tortellini was the highlight of my evening: stuffed with goat cheese, flavorful and rich. I just wish there were more mushrooms.

The desserts (black pepper wine granita, and chocolate cake with kumquat gelato) were also wonderful. Wildly creative and not too sweet.

Our whole meal ended up coming out to about $140 including 2 cocktails each + tip which seemed overpriced given our mediocre experience. All in all, while I enjoyed certain parts of the evening, I don't know that I'm in a hurry to ever return (except for a drink).
author: Tiffany W.

description:
We had reservations, but ended up having to wait 20 minutes until a table was open. The staff handled it very well by checking in with us from time to time and offering the fried olives (which were delicious) to snack on while we waited. 

The pizza bianca is not a flatbread with cheese (for all you CPK and Cheeseback Factory lovers) - it is a crisp bread with olive oil and some seasoning. Maybe it was because I was starving, but it was a great starter. 

The pasta came out immediately upon finishing the pizza bianca. We didn't even have time to order wine first, which was kind of annoying. But the server was excellent at quickly coming over to us and getting wine to us, so we weren't without anything to drink with the course for more than a few minutes, at most. 

The pasta is legit. Cooked to perfection. Both the guinea-hen pancetta casconelli and the bellwether crescenza tortelli were delicious - not too saucy, but very flavorful. 

If you're craving fancy pasta, this is the place to go. And if you're sensitive to the service quality, the staff won't disappoint you.
author: Derek B.

description: Food was amazing!! So good. The desserts were a bit weaker, would go somewhere else next time. But entrees are really good. The service was probably the weakest part of the visit.
author: Zee S.

description:
Wow wow wow. That's all I can say. (Well, I'll actually say more.) But that was my takeaway from a dinner last night at Locanda. It was almost completely note-perfect. We started with a fantastic bottle of Chenin Blanc, and that set the tone right away. Then the food started coming and it was accompanied by our oohs and ahhs.

STARTERS:
Jewish artichoke - an artichoke completely fried so that the whole thing is edible. And it was delicious!
LIberty Duck ciccioli - flavorful shredded duck (maybe it had been confited?), with arugula, and the amazing pizza bianca (bread). The duck had so much rich flavor. It was really wonderful.
Pizza bianca - one of the best starter breads ever. Olive oil so good it tastes like butter, and sea salt. Delicious.

DINNER:
Cauliflower soup - I wasn't terribly hungry, so between the apps and the sides, this was my "meal." It was incredibly good soup - smoky, rich, and gone in a few seconds.
Short rib cappelleti - my friend's husband's pasta. It had celery and cocoa nibs in it, which added some cool flavors and textures. The tortellini-like pasta filled with short ribs was amazing. Clearly, they put high-quality meat in this pasta. 
Orecchiette - my friend's pasta. House made sausage, broccoli raab, and capers meet housemade pasta in another winning dish. The flavors, like everything else, went together perfectly. I am so glad my friends liked to share!
Brussels sprouts - roasted well, with delicious crumbly bits of pancetta.

DESSERT:
Baba Rum Tropicale - my choice and the only thing that didn't wow me. It was good - but not fantastic. A sweet syrupy mix of pineapple and mango sauce, with whipped mascarpone and some type of sweet bread (maybe a brioche?).
Chocolate budino - beautiful chocolate, great vanilla ice cream. Simple, yet right.
Hazelnut finanzario - the winner of the desserts. Crumbly financiers, sitting in a pool of candied pear sauce and the incomparable candy cap gelato. (If you don't know what candy caps are, you'll be even more amazed after you have the gelato and then do a Google search. You would never guess that THAT is the flavor in this gelato.)

All in all, a wonderful meal. I will be back.
author: David B.

description: I tried Locanda for the first time this evening and was thrilled. Bar staff was attentive and offered a complementary appetizer which was a very nice flatbread. Our server was Kaitlin and her menu suggestions were spot on. I had the grilled trout and it was served perfectly. I will definitely be back. Thanks Kaitlin!
author: Kevin D.

description:
Maybe it's the fact that I had the amazing opportunity to dine in Italy recently. Or maybe I had high expectations because it is the sister restaurant of Delfina, but I was so not impressed with the food at Locanda. 

We started off with the prosciutto, which came with about 8-10 slices and warm, soft, lightly salted bread drizzled with olive oil. Not a bad start. 

Next, we decided to share 2 pasta dishes: fettuccine with chicken-prosciutto meatballs and rigatoni alla carbonara. Portions were on the small side, and the taste did not make up for it. Meh. The fettuccine was the better of the two - perfectly cooked pasta and tasty meatballs, but the chicken and prosciutto flavors weren't very distinguishable. I was really excited to try the carbonara, but was left disappointed. The pasta seemed undercooked, the consistency of the sauce was not creamy (almost like it was left out too long), and the guanciale was way too salty. 

The service was great, but the food won't bring me back. I'd much rather go to Bella Trattoria or Tommasso's for Italian in the city.
author: Stephanie G.

description:
Monday, I went her with 2 friends for the restaurant week menu.
The food was good : soup too salty, the chicken was good and the dessert very good !
 It was 8:00pm when we finished the dinner, we received the check, they took away the glasses and water and they ask us to continue our conversation : UNACCEPTABLE in a restaurant like that ($250 bill !!!). You remember that, and it makes the experience not good.
It was the second time, but I will never come back :(((
author: Arnaud M.

description:
I give Locanda 2.8 stars and I SO wanted to give it five stars. 

We had a reservation for 6 o'clock and arrive roughly at 5:50 PM--- I immediately told the hostess that we both had a long day and we would love to just grab some snacks at happy hour and a cocktail before 6 o'clock -- if that wasn't a problem.  She informed us "actually that she had a really tight schedule and it really wouldn't work." No problem!  

We were seated immediately and with in less than 10 seconds of getting our menu, A server came to our table and asked us if we were ready, "ready for a drink I thought?"  We had decided at that point to go ahead and get a bottle of wine as we were celebrating.  I informed our server that I had a few in mind, but I would value her opinion on my selection based on our menu choices.  I never got this opinion. 

After we asked for a few minutes to decide,  A gentlemen sat down next to us, ended up sharing his entire appetizer with us, getting a cocktail and having his second course--***before*** our waitress came back to take our drink order--- roughly 20 min in a completely empty 610 crowd, not including bar. 

So the food--- I ordered our appetizers of cauliflower soup and a puntarelle salad (Caesar) to be split--- they brought both apps out completely separate; they did not split them per our request.  Fine, but we did ask:(  when the appetizers were dropped off our glasses were completely empty ---  neither the server nor the food deliverer filled up our glasses of wine. Also, not a big deal, but this place demands this level of service as their cheapest bottle is roughly 50$. 

Food: Salad was amazing, crunchy, not too much anchovy, nice tang but rounded and did I mention crunch!! Well done chef--- also the cauliflower soup was superb with salted capers, olive oil and a delectable (would argue it is not vegan) creaminess that makes you feel warm in foggy San Francisco. 

Next the entrée was delivered and the server delivered it conveniently separated, however, it was the same pasta dish, same portion??? --- meaning they screwed up our order.  She informed us that would promptly deliver our other entree so we could eat together, oops--- We both finished our initial pasta, not empty plates but wanting to save room, when they dropped off the other pasta dish, Cacio de pepi, not separated and I actually had to grab his arm to suggest boxing other meal so that we had room to eat. The tortellini was terribly salty and we both felt we could not taste the butter sauce, promised mushroom winter flavor and our toasted pine nuts were completely washed out by the salt!!!  Yikes, I am southern but, sad:(  and I make fresh pasta every week and am in awe of greatness--- not. Greatness. The Cacio de pepi was chewy but sauce was superb.  

Lastly, we went for a meringue dessert-- sugar that melts on tongue is a better description!!  No.

They also did not being our dessert wine pairings, but quickly took the uneaten dessert away, no question as to why we didn't eat it and no question as to where our $8x2 dessert wine pairing was?  

We informed our server and she said, "I am sorry you found this sub par." They comped an entree and took off the dessert, but an apology and a let's try again would have been much nicer plus hey, what a it that dessert wine? 

Don't review much but honestly tired of extreme prices for "your welcome to be here" and a  "ugh welcome to our restaurant" attitude--- not to mention the "we're so busy pushing people through here, no! We cannot accommodate your cocktail." Also, we had to ask our server for our boxed up to go food bc they forgot:( 

So, I don't know why everyone loves this place, but I think there is impeccable Italian, friendly service, a manager that apologizes directly-- plenty more for your 150$ plus Thursday night in San Francisco!  

Like puerto allegre across the street!!
author: Bonnie Marie J.

description:
Locanda is another gem added to this already quite lucky neighborhood.  The extend the superb quality originated by Delfina with another small but select set of modern Californian-Italian dishes.  

Like most good places these days, the menu evolves but there are some fixtures.  The Jewish artichoke is definitely worth trying, a must for artichoke fans.  All their pastas are delicious, fresh and bursting with a small set of distinct flavors in each one.  I think I've tried just about every one and never had a disappointment.  And for their contorni, don't sleep on the smoked mashed potatoes.  They are the bomb dot com.

Service is fairly polished without being pretentious.  They have their act together.

Great for a weeknight bite.  Expect a long wait on the weekends.
author: Saminda W.

description:
I'm a fan of Delfina so when they opened up a sister restaurant with a rumored kick ass cocktail menu, I made sure to bookmark, bookmark, bookmark!

A year later after the bookmark, (what took me so long?!) our group walked in on a Friday night with no reservations. What do you know? it's our lucky night! 

I should probably be sick of pasta after two weeks in Italy, but the pasta was calling my name. Locanda's carbonara will transport you back to Rome: guanciale, pecorino and black pepper. A bit too much on the pepper, but I like that they use real egg to make your pasta really creamy and as expected, the pasta itself is done exceptionally well!  My friends loved their chestnut and sage agnolotti, so maybe I'll try that next time.

The Jewish style fried artichoke is a nod towards Venice's influence and I can't complain! The pizza bianca is more of the crunchy pizza instead of thin style.

Now, their cocktails! Remembering that Aperitivo cocktail makes me lick my lips twice, I sooo want to prolong the memory! it's made with Campari, orange, lemon and topped off with prosecco. The bitterness of the Campari with the acidity from the citrus and dryness from the prosecco is the perfect palette opener. While the Smoke and Spice is a manly man's and will warm you through with gin, vermouth and scotch.

We had multiple people serving us, bringing entrees and clearing plates. This is a happening, very busy place so it gets loud inside, make this as a destination with a couple of friends than a one on one date. 

I'm definitely coming back to sample more of their cocktails as well as their pasta. Mangia, mangia, mangia!
author: Janice C.

description:
We had an interesting experience at Locanda for Sunday brunch, where the server who greeted us initially was a bit abrupt and inattentive, but our main server was 
excellent. Also, perhaps it's just a personal preference, but I was not a big fan of the coffee served. 

I had the aperitivo as my beverage, as did a few others in my party, and we all enjoyed it. My main course of pork saltimbocca was good, but after trying my friend's Benedict carbonara, I wished I had chosen that. The hash browns were perfectly crispy and excellent. The drinking caramel with bourbon to conclude the meal was a delightful finish on a windy Sunday. 

All in all, a pleasant brunch experience.
author: A J.

description:
Came here last night for a friends birthday dinner- Locanda is one of his favorite spots, so it was a given. He was unimpressed with our table for a group of 5, way in the corner in a booth- but I thought it was just fine. 

I ordered the Resolution cocktail- it wasn't quite to my liking, so our waiter very kindly offered to change it, but birthday boy had already initiated a trade of beverages, to his vodka/cucumber/lime cocktail. Still a nice gesture from the waiter- who gave us great service the whole meal. 

The bread was phenomenal- salty and a little buttery and flavorful. We had bone marrow, artichokes, and an arancini special, with mozzarella as they had run out of the crab ones. All delicious, smallish portions. 

I had the Bavette steak medium rare, and it was definitely more on the rare side than medium- but decent flavor. AMAZING smoked mashed potatoes (must try) and treviso- very bitter and a perfect complement. Everyone enjoyed their food- the crab pasta and guinea hen were big hits.
author: Rhian M.

description: This is the SF restaurant experience you want to have. Amazing flavors from sweet to savory. Rovi was a superstar and helped us out to make the night happen. Lots of Peroni and amazing food. Hope to see you soon! Thank you!  PS. If you are too sensitive to noise and a better than average time beware!!!
author: Paolo R.

description: I just wanted to thank the staff at Locanda for making my friend's birthday brunch so enjoyable yesterday. They could not have treated us better. As I waited for the birthday boy to show up, they made sure my questions about the menu were answered (my servers were VERY knowledgeable about the food - they told me that they actually have a staff preview/tasting for every dish they serve just so they can impart information to the customers). They patiently walked me through all the gluten-free items, never ever letting it show what an inevitable pain-in-the-ass this surely must be to have to work around everyone's various food needs. (This is a *very* gluten-free-friendly place for those who keep track of this stuff!) My coffee cup was always filled at the perfect time. The food was very very good. The fruit plate was absolutely picture-perfect which almost never happens, so colorful and cascading like something staged for a movie. I most especially appreciated the service though. I'm not someone who can afford to drop a lot of money on fancy food, so taking my friend out to a special brunch was an occasion for me. It really meant a lot to me that they were not cavalier about their popularity - they did not take our business for granted but instead were really earnest, kind people who made us feel pampered. Thank you, Locanda!
author: Heidi-Jane S.

description:
The definition of pretentious craptastic Italian. No gnocchi, chicken Parmesan, or other classics. 

Menu selection is essentially lasagna, olive oil pasta, and tomato sauce pasta for $20+.

Portion size: approximately 5 bites. 

That said, as far as extremely basic pasta goes, it was good.
author: Sean C.

description: Great pasta, great service. Had gnocchi and many other dishes and not a bad one at all! The church and the 20/20 drinks were easy perfect summer drinks. Highly recommend this place
author: Ant J.

description:
This place was recommended to me by a trusted SF local, and i loveeeee me some pasta, so i was pretty pumped. 

The vibe is cool, the food was pretty dec.. like, i would definitely go there again.  But the service was ... not even shitty, it was just weird.  I'm convinced our server was on drugs. He was very awkward and kind of out of it (ie. we asked for water and he gave us empty glasses and didn't come back for 10 minutes when I had to politely ask for water again).  I kind of didn't understand the behavior, it was the end of the night and the place was pretty empty, so he definitely wasn't being pulled in 1000 different ways.  Then again, it was the end of the night,  maybe he was just burnt out.  Either way - three stars because the food didn't blow me away enough to outweigh the weirdo server.
author: Jen A.

description:
The Place is very nice! We were 4 people, we ordered the Jewish style artichokes  & tomato salad which was great! But unfortunately the bread was too oily!! 
The main course was pretty small and the price is pretty expensive..but the food is good.
author: Regina L.

description:
Updated review:
We've been coming here for two years and prices keep going up and up! Bucatini used to be $14 and now $19. They used to give out the bread (pizza Bianca) for free but now $4. Still great food, just getting too expensive too fast! 



Love, love, love this place! 
I selfishly didn't want to write a review because more people means higher price and difficulty in getting a table, but since I am now moving to the suburbs and sadly won't be able to frequent this place, I'm okay with that. 
Apertivo is a great drink, that I'm thinking of serving at my wedding as a signature cocktail. 
We LOVE the bucatini. There were many nights where we both got this. The pizza Bianca (which used to be free) is also great. 
Everyone is so nice here! They recently introduced happy hours which is also great. 

Only thing is parking can be annoying...
author: Sora L.

description: Dried Tortellinis and trumpet of the death mushrooms from a supermarket, and I would bet the tripes were a can. Good wine selection and nice service with a special thank to Zack, but there is no cook in the kitchen and despite a nice design the place is way over rated and the menu way overpriced. It's been a long time I spent 90 bucks to be disappointed. The package and decorum is important but please current and future customers of Locanda, taste the food and know how to recognize hand made  pasta to commercial dried one...
author: Kevin C.

description:
We've been twice, and it's been a great experience each time.

The stuffed olives are amazing, the pasta is great.

Not a huge fan of the high tables, as the chairs aren't that comfortable.
author: Olivier L.

description: We went here for the 1st time tonight. We're regulars at Delfina so we've been told by our Manager friends there (Amelia & Sam) about this even before they opened. They're Roman inspired dishes that are completely different from our typical pizza/meatballs Delfina dinner nights. Sam works here now so we thought we'd give her a visit and try the dishes. We had a 5:30pm reservation. We got there 15 minutes early so we decided to walk around. We got to the door and the line was long! Turns out, it wasn't just us who made the 5:30 reservations. We got seated at a quiet table (per my opentable request) so it was nice - we were closer to the kitchen too so I could see when our dishes come out. We got there and Sam, our dear friend and the GM warmly greeted us. She started us with a complimentary Rosé. Yum. We got cocktails too. Church for him (aperol, gin, cocchi americano, lemon) & Rosso Rubino (vodka, grapefruit, fennel, lemon). Both light and refreshingly good! So now: the food. My BF loves to eat so we always order in bulk. Lol. We started with the Fried Olives, Earl grey tomato salad, Fried Bokchoy & La Quercia Prosciutto served with their famous pizza Bianca (aka bread). All these came out beautifully. Each dish has its distinct taste. For entrees: we had the Lamb Ragu and the Lamb Scottadito. Sam also gave us a taste of their Cornish hen and sausage pasta. WOW. Incredible. The pastas here for sure are a Must. For desserts: we had the CHOCOLATE BUDINO (lady fingers, Marsala zabaglione, salted chocolate gelato) & APPLE ALMOND TORTA (nocino milk jam, figs, pink pearl apple sorbetto) aka bread pudding - their version. Both were super delicious - my BF and I inhaled each plate. I have to say though: from the friendly staff, the romantic ambience, the delicious, well balanced meals, yummy cocktails and the super sweet Manager they have (Sam - she's quite attentive and knows how to take care of her customers very well) this place deserves a medal for overall top performance. This is definitely a good spot for a night with some friends or a nice date night with your beau. We will definitely come back!! For our friend Sam - the restaurant looks amazing! We're so happy for you. This place ROCKS.
author: Anna Y.

description: I ate Brunch here, the server was helpful, she let us know they ran out of corned beef hash, answered our question, attentive, warm, staff was too.  Best poached eggs ever!!  Good quality produce, meats and side salad was delicious. We had Ham n eggs over bread with hollandaise on side.  I'd go again and for dinner too.
author: Lisa M.

description:
Awesome dinner spot in the Mission. Great food, delicious wine and very attentive staff. 

I don't think you can go wrong with any of their food options, but we had the fried olives, fettuccini and the fish of the day and chocolate cake dessert.  Their wine list is pretty extensive; brownie points for having a Portuguese wine on the list! 

The service was impeccable and it's nice to see that every one of their staff is focused on making the best dinning experience for their customers. 

No doubt that I'll be back!
author: Juliana S.

description:
For appetizers, we orderd pizza bread and fried olives.  The pizza bread was just bread w olive oil, it tasted so so. The fried olives is quite good. 

Entree, we had the Carbonara pasta (Guanciale, egg, pecorino), the lamb ragu pasta, and grilled seabass. They are all really good. The Carbonara has delicious junks of bacon to crave for.  The sauce for the grill seabass goes very well w the seabass and the herbs. The lamb ragu is quite good also.

For dessert we had the lemon tart and the ice-cream cake. These are the happy ending for us. They taste soo fresh, light and really delicious!!!  

Staff are nice and friendly.  Our waitress gave us very good recommendations on what dish to pick. We definitely come back here again.  

Why one star off? Because its food overall is not at the excellent level yet. ;)
author: Uyen N.

description:
Your bog-standard hipsteraunt: noisy open kitchen; decor like a Scandinavian sauna the early 90s; pretenses of menu tradition (e.g. Italian), but mostly just gimmicky New American in disguise; mediocre body-less wines by the glass; sticky-sweet artisinal cocktails; doting, quirky, but clueless service; and mouth-dryingly overseasoned mains. And I loves me some salt.

I had heard their (bavette) steak was better than Cockscomb's steak -to- share, but this could not be further from the truth. The Locanda steak was sinewy, undercooked, and overseasoned. Its classic au poivre green peppercorns were lost atop. The smoked mash was too pureed, and therefore starchy and baby-food-ish. Their bucatini was too al dente, and its red sauce with bologna was too thin and sweet. (Think Chef Boyardee.) The Locanda veggies were actually very well done, the best part of our meal (e.g. shoots and greens).

One of the servers dropped a napkin on the floor in front of us, and then folded it back into the pile of clean ones. Which was nice.

Extremely overrated.
author: Ben G.

description:
The Mission is filled with fancy restaurants filled with hip interiors, priceyish foods, and a large collection of alcoholic beverages. I'm glad that out of all in the Mission, my cousin and I went to this one. 

Probably wouldn't have gone here if my doctor didn't give me a generous Christmas gift card and it was for my cousin's birthday, for as many people in the city, I'm content with a burger and some tacos at a bar down the street from my house. But, thankful to explore the culinary finds of the city!

This place is pretty and simple on the outside, just a sign and curtains to cover the windows, Urban Outfitters/Pottery Barn/ Simple Pinterest Chic on the inside. They have  a beautiful bar to to welcome you to the establishment, and a crazy tree with glass bubble chandelier thing as the centerpiece to their cozy restaurant. Would suggest this place for intimate gatherings among friends, and dates as well! Can get a little loud inside because the place is small and people are drinking and going off on wine tastings.

Note: Make reservations! Helps us out a lot, since it can be a full house. 

We tried a few of their wines, and got a couple of glasses. I am more of a beer person, so my knowledge of wine is very limited. I appreciated the waitresses recommendations, who had pretty accurate descriptions of what we were tasting.

You are automatically greeted at the table with some water from their fancy logo covered bottles and some butter cheesy bread to start. My cousin got their red snapper special and I got the lamb chops. The special was the whole fish, and was more and enough for my and my cousin. Extremely flavorful, filled with veggies and seasonings. Amazingly light and filling all at the same time. The lambchops were amazing! IF I went here again I would get the chops. Came with greens and a chickpea blended sauce which complimented the meat and greens well.

For dessert, my cousin and I shared the passion fruit tart with the banana ice scoop. Maybe because I have the sweetest tooth ever, this was my favorite part of the meal. The crust was buttery and flaky, with the tart balancing it out, and the ice cream to bring it awn down. So good! Also came with a candle melted on the plate for the birthday girl. 

The service was attentive and extremeley helpful considering that we weren't familiar with the cuisine. Thank you for your hospitality!

Overall, had a bawm experience at this place! Would consider taking my family out here for a night out in the city.
author: Kristine T.

description: This restaurant is awesome. I love the food in here. I dont remember what I had. The server was nice. The drinks were awesome. The environment in there was good. I sat by the kitchen. It was a little bit warm there. I would like to go back there sometimes if i were in town again. It was one of the restaurant picks for 5 nights.
author: Mark T.

description:
Authentic perfect service. & delicious Italian food-- this is Locanda. The  early girl tomato salad is near perfect,l. The excellent server Sarah noticed that I couldn't decide which pasta, or meat to order  she asked if I'd like to order a half portion of each. Of course!-- this is smart-selling lady who encourages new customers to order more without being pushy. 
Locanda is lively but not too loud. And unlike Beretta, it feels more Italian.
author: Scott F.

description: I came here for brunch on a Sunday. Their take on the menu doesn't include the regular and plain bacon and eggs. All their dishes are unique, presented very beautifully and was very delicious. Definitely make a reservation because they'll make you wait for a long time or turn you away otherwise.
author: Leo M.

description:
Mediocre, overpriced food, tiny portions, pretentiously difficult-to-translate menu, and waitstaff that is never around when you need your water filled up, but plops the bill on your table before you're done eating your dinner and then visits your table every 30 seconds after that to nudge you to pay said bill...A huge disappointment!!

My partner and I went here for our anniversary.  The interior decor was pleasant and the noise level reasonable enough to have a good conversation without shouting.  I was sure I'd picked the right place.

We started with the "Sonoma" Lamb Carpaccio (with puntarelle, salt - packed capers, parmigiano).  It was tasty once I added some salt, and this was the highlight of our dinner.  

We moved on to the Pizza Bianca...which was not a pizza of any sort.  It was toast with a veeeeeery thin, tasteless scraping of pureed garbanzo peas and almost indiscernible shaving of tuna essence with a drizzle of lemon oil.  The taste was so subtle that there almost wasn't any.  Again, this required salt to be palatable, and at around $9, I couldn't believe I'd just paid that much for toast with half a teaspoon of bland hummus!

For my main course, I ordered the Rigatoni Carbonara.  I love usually love carbonara, it's something I often order at restaurants...and it rarely disappoints.  I hate the flavor of black pepper, however, so I specifically asked them to refrain from adding that atop my dish before serving.  When it arrived, guess what was heavily smattered all over my pasta?!  Needless to say, I didn't feel at all bad about immediately returning the dish to the kitchen, since I was really clear about this when I ordered, and it was a make-or-break issue for me.

My partner had ordered the Radiatore Pecora E Pecorino (pasta with  lamb ragu, pecorino, mint), which was tasty, but the portion was tiny!  At almost $20 for a bowl of pasta, you expect to be presented with an ample portion...but apparently this is one of those newfangled restaurants where you HAVE to order and consume all three courses of dinner, or you'll still be hungry when you're finished!!

My partner and I nibbled at his dish until mine returned from the kitchen, this time sans pepper.  No one offered us any grated cheese to sprinkle on top of our pasta.  That should've been my first warning.  This "carbonara" tastes NOTHING like any carbonara I've ever had!!!  It was bitter, bland, and in a thick, frothy sauce that I was informed is pre-made (ie, not to order).  Um, Locanda, that's NOT carbonara!!!  There was no buttery flavor, thick egginess, delicious saltiness, or anything else I've come to expect and enjoy from a pasta carbonara!  If you are used to ordering spaghetti carbonara in Italian restaurants, be warned that this is not what you'll get at Locanda!

To help you understand how bad the taste was, my partner saw my crest-fallen face and quickly offered to trade dishes with me (yes, this was incredibly sweet of him!).  I gratefully accepted his offer, and while he admitted the carbonara was a definite disappointment, he didn't find it as inedible as I did.

We both finished our miniscule pasta portions, and hastily ordered dessert, for me, the TCHO CHOCOLATE-CUSTARD BUDINO  ( with nocino dulce de leche, walnuts, cocoa nib croccante).  This was basically a gelatin-like custardy mass atop a thin round of cake with a tiny pile of candied walnuts and candied cocoa nibs with a spoon of super-foamy whipped cream.  Again, I was disappointed.  Tcho is my favorite brand of chocolate and I'm VERY familiar with all the milk and dark varieties, of which I partake regularly.  Sadly, this confection barely tasted of chocolate at all, leaning heavily instead on the sweet, thin caramel flavor.  My partner tasted my dessert and agreed.  For $9, this was an overpriced, tremendous let-down.

About two seconds after we received our dessert, the female server plopped the bill down on the table with a saccharin smile.  She then proceeded to revisit our table EIGHT TIMES over the next ten minutes in an attempt to see if we had put a credit card down yet.  Um, we weren't finished with dinner!!!  This is not some dive-y diner, this is supposed to be the latest hipster-foodie incarnation of fine dining...so it is INCREDIBLY RUDE to pressure diners to pay the bill before they are done with dinner.  When you've ordered a bottle of bubbly and your bill is $130 for two people, you expect a little patience and good service to enjoy your meal.  If the server was waiting to get off of her shift, that's one thing...but SAY that, don't keep nudging us passive-aggressively.  

After we paid, any and all service stopped to our table abruptly.  Our server never came back to us, not even to offer to retrieve my coat, which she'd insisted on taking when we sat down.  Oh, well.
author: Amy L.

description:
Tonnarelli Cacio E Pepe - in a word-  underwhelming. I was expecting something more complex and with more flavor. 

Radiatore pecora E Pecorino - This lamb ragu was much better than the Cacio dish. The lamb was moist and paired with mint. The pasta was thick and al dente perfect. 

Expect crowds and not a lot of personal space here. :)
author: Henry W.

description:
Prosciutto w/focaccia - awesome fat and wide thin slices.  Clean and delicious, perfect balance of salt and fatty ness.

Grilled pizza bread - didn't wow much.  

Tripe tomato sauce - fantastic, tender, well seasoned.  Wish it was spicy tomato sauce like way back at In Canto.

Bucatini guanciale - loved the al dente to a point it was hard and chewy.  Good flavor enhanced by the pork.

Fettuccini rabbit sugo - a bit over seasoned and salty.  Pasta too soft after tasting the bucatini first.

Whole grilled trout - surprising moist and had a natural fish flavor, not over powered by seasoning.  Came along with chili sauce, salt, olive oil and lemon of which we only used lemon.

Service could be slightly more happy and attentive.  Should of asked if the plate of food is done before refreshing plates even we say yes to new plates.  New plates can be on the side and not swapped if food is not done.

Overall I had an enjoyable father and daughter night out.
author: Kevin L.

description: Went back recently for brunch and it was pretty fantastic. I like brunch menus that serve up things that I can't make.  Eggs Benedict in carbonara sauce was very good, as was their bacon. Hash browns were very unique.
author: Eric C.

description: I've been here a few times when in San Francisco and it's always a great meal. Amazing pastas, interesting starters and excellent main courses. Excellent service by Aaron, twice now, who makes you feel like you are the only diner in the room.  I like Delfina, the sister restaurant. But I really love Locanda
author: J D.

description: Average at best. The service was fine.  The wine was very good.  They also made a surprisingly nice old fashioned.  But the food I felt was just average.  We had both heard great things about Locanda unfortunately it didn't live up to the hype.  We ordered the jerky (not either of our "thing"), salad (nothing great really) and one pasta with lobster and one bucatini.  Both pastas were average.
author: Amanda P.

description: Great food and great service. A wine menu that is great and not a NAPA valley vintage in sight. If you are in the Mission or Castro areas, try it, but bring your wallet.
author: William C.

description:
Delfina was my favorite restaurant when I lived in SF so I was really looking forward to trying Locanda. Although not bad, it was disappointing since I like delfina so much. Service here was pretty good. We had to wait awhile for our reservation since the table before us was lingering. It was the table in the window, which got pretty chilly.

I can't remember what my friends ordered but two of us shared the lamb carpaccio, and two pastas. The warm pizza bianca was pretty good but the lamb carpaccio tasted too greasy - not sure if it was from the meat or the added olive oil. One pasta was with dungeness crab, the other I think was the lamb ragu. I sampled a couple of my friends dishes as well, including another pasta dish. The texture of the pasta was soft and overcooked for one of the dishes, and undercooked and hard for another. I prefer my pasta just a touch softer than al dente but I think only one of the pastas was in the realm of al dente. I did enjoy the flavor of the pasta dishes, but the ragu was very salty and the crab pasta did not have very much crab in it.

The friends I went with love this place but the two of us first timers were not impressed. Although the food was good, there are just so many other places I'd rather go to at this price point. Like Delfina.
author: Lainy C.

description:
That was one amazing Birthday dinner. Here was how it went:

The CSO of my company took me out for a birthday dinner. His first choice of course would've been Zuni's but since they weren't open on Mondays, we settled for his other favorites. Here at Locanda.

PARKING:
Normally parking in San Francisco is horrid. Since Dr. Jorge Garcia (Doc) made reservations, we decided to do the valet thing (when I said, 'we' I really meant 'he' -i would've gotten there 30 minutes early and drove around looking for parking). $12.

LOCATION:
At 6P, the place had nice tall windows which you can see the inside. It was well lit with yellow lighting; already alluring my senses to it (Doc sure knows how to pick it). I couldn't wait to get inside.

INTERIOR:
We entered a cute little modern day interior and furnishings The tiles on the walls, hanging lighting fixtures, well lit (but not crazy lit where you felt everyone is staring at you) and quiet conversations amongst the groups that was dining there (minus us -I think we were a bit loud- well, I was probably).

CUSTOMER SERVICE:
It wasn't crazy busy so we were able to pick any table upon our arrival. Doc liked the idea of being able to stare outside the window (I guess just in case I was boring to converse with or something hehee). We were greeted by a pretty waitress who seems to be really drained of energy or something (couldn't seem to crack a smile). I didn't think much of it at the beginning figured she's probably be a hard nut but will crack eventually. Unfortunately, the entire time she was serving us, not a single smile (hence, the four stars).

FOOD:
Was I surprise that the food was delicious? Nope. Doc's taste in food is impeccable and I trust his selection 110%. (let's see if I have this right...) We had the Coppiette, Burrata, Bellwether Crescenza Tortelli, Liberty Duck Breast and Brussels Sprouts. These selections weren't exactly the healthiest, but definitely full of flavor. I do not believe there was a single dish that was unsatisfying (compliments to the chef, er chefs).

VERDICT:
The food was delish! Unfortunately, my income doesn't allow me to splurge on such quality foods, but it is definitely great for a dinner date. I recommend you to at least try this spot once. Have patience with Stella though (she's very pretty, just doesn't smile often as she should).
author: Cathy N.

description:
I'm overall disappointed. We went with high expectations

I went with my family. The place is nice and looked cozy in the photos. When we were there, the place looked like the photos but it hasn't good acoustic and it's hard to hear people in front of you.

We made a reservation, so we only waited 10 minutes. You can wait inside seated at the bar enjoying good drinks.

I ordered bucatini a la matricciana, my wife regatoni a la carbonara and my son kid pasta (penne with pomodoro). We ordered and the plate came fast (good!). My wife's pasta was cold and we need to ask them to warmed it up. They brought a new plate, so that was good instead of warming up the same dish.

We needed to ask for cheese, In all Italian restaurants always I have been asked if I want extra "oleo" or Parmesan cheese. Here I need to ask and they brought a thimble with only one spoon of cheese.

The pasta was OK but didn't worth 20 bucks.
author: Juan C.

description:
We passed this place and walked in on the off chance they'd have a table as it was early evening. They did, despite it being already pretty packed for 6pm.

Our server was really friendly and explained the menu and what she recommended as being particularly good choices.

Food came quite quickly but was well cooked and we really enjoyed our meal. I had the Bavette Steak and my friend had a vegetarian option and both were tasty. 

The best thing about Locanda we thought was the atmosphere, apparently the cocktails are great too but we didn't get to try those
author: Conrad N.

description:
Wish I could give it a 5! Really nice cocktails, loved the apertivo. The wine selection was nice and not too over priced. 
The flat bread with burata appetizer started off the meal and it was delicious. Loved the salad and the lamb main course cooked perfectly. The cappuccinos hit the spot. They did not rush us even though we were an early seating. We got there at. 5:30 and there is really no excuse for full trash cans in the bathroom. Were the bathrooms cleaned? Where was the manager checking to make sure the house is ready to open on a Saturday night?
author: Chris C.

description:
HORRIBLE dining experience here tonight. Literally the worst service I've experienced in...forever. The reason for the 2 stars is because frankly, I still love their food. But given SF is full of stellar Italian places, and Valencia is one of the best dining streets, the horrible service is a dealbreaker. GO ELSEWHERE.

Granted, we had a party of 6. But we paid for that by having a late reservation (8:30) on a Monday night (end of a long weekend).

We had to wait 33 minutes for the table. Literally, we stood at the bar. For 33 minutes. We checked with the hostesses 3 times and at no point in time did they offer us drinks or even bread at the bar despite the fact that it was getting close to 9PM and any normal person would have been STARVING.
