The waitress tried to push drinks on us twice.  Jeez, we're tired and starving, we dont want drinks! and she then took 24 minutes to bring out the one non alcoholic drink someone ordered. Literally, my friend's tea came out right before entrees. Nice job there. What were you doing? Collecting the firewood and building a fire to heat it up in the kitchen? We got the bread pretty fast, thank god. But it had such deep pockets of oil that I had to request paper napkins to damp them. It was like getting a pepperoni pizza from little Caesars. Come on.

The staff did try to "make it up" to our group by giving out freebies of probably leftovers in the kitchen. Fried olives. And then fried onions. First off, we didn't come to an Italian restaurant to eat fried food. And secondly, olives and onions? Seriously? Thanks for the "effort". The olives remained untouched because frankly, none of us like olives. We ate the onions because the portions for our entrees were so small that a couple ppl were still hungry afterwards. 

We ordered the fettuccini with rabbit (delicious but the portion was so small it didn't even cover the bottom of the plate), rigatoni carbonara, lamb ragu, smoked salmon salad, and a beans appetizer. Again, LOVE the food here. Can't get enough.

It took about 20 minutes after our meal ended to get out of there. No wonder the group before us were delayed by 33 minutes. It's not the diners, it's the service! Our server was about as hospitable and attentive as an evil step mom.

Recommend going to delfina, flour+water, beretta, range, foreign cinema, any of the great places around the area over locanda. Maybe good for drinks, but meal service is insufferable.
author: Alice Z.

description:
Every meal I have had here is always top notch. My most recent visit was so great I had to submit a review.

The bread served with the prosciutto was heavenly. The gulf shrimp cuscini was wonderful with a nice hint of truffles. And though we worried we would not have room in our stomachs for the lamb chops scottadito, one bite immediately erased any concern and only the bones remained.
author: Frank R.

description:
Locanda is like the Beretta of Upper Mission. I don't recall seeing a store logo or sign, and embarrassingly walked into Bar Tartine (next door) by accident. I realized my mistake only when I picked up the menu to order. Oops. I had my expectations leveled after having recently been to Bar Tartine, and been quite disappointed. Can't believe it took me so long to realize I was in the wrong place!

The food at Locanda ranged from good to freakin delicious. I would highly recommend the side dish (right now it's peas and pea shoots with mint), and both pastas I tried were amazing (pillow pasta with shrimp and crescenza with mushrooms). Amazing. While the food overall was on the expensive side, it's nothing different from what you would get at Beretta, Delfina, and the like.

Some things I would skip - the pizza bianca fell a bit short in my eyes because it tasted like an extremely buttery flat bread with a (generous) side of bone marrow. I expected an actual pizza. It was pretty good though. The short ribs were so tender it was unbelievable, I just wasn't a fan of the seasoning. And I can't say I am a big fan of artichokes, but it was cooked perfectly. 

They serve cocktails (the tequila one was good! But not as strong and complex as B&B), and have a decent wine list. Overall the service was great, and the food and drinks were delicious. Make sure you have reservations. I can't wait to come back!
author: Jess C.

description: I went here several times before they changed names, and enjoyed it every time. The food is unique, fresh, and delicious. It's also great for groups... have attended a few birthday dinners here.
author: Diana G.

description:
I didn't fall in love with what came after Jewish artichoke ($7 buys you a half...more, please!) & squash blossoms (sprinkled w/ cheese--a salty, savory delight.)

Drink: Nonna del diavolo..."rye, strega, ginger, lime, seltzer." I thought the last three ingredients would make for a light, refreshing beverage, but the rye & whatever strega was, turned it into a heavy, bitter, reason-I-don't-love-cocktails type of drink. 

Entree: literally, forgettable. Pasta with mushrooms & a brown butter sauce. I think. Again, I vaguely recall the dish being overly heavy & not complexly flavored. 

Dessert: his soft chocolate cake was great. My pinenut tort was weird...too much pinenut & not enough of a sweet element. 

I can't call myself a fan & I can't say I'd return. Unless it's strictly for deliciously-fried appetizers.
author: Fancypants X.

description: Came here just for drinks and they were really good. I had the agromiele which reminded me of Beretta's Rattle Snake cocktail (SO GOOD!). Bartenders were great as well. Will have to come here to get some food as well.
author: Laura D.

description:
Pretentious
Over priced 
Yuppie *&^*

How is it that brunch now costs $50 a person !?!??
It used to be that $30 was still overpriced and too much.

I hope all of these overpriced "design forward" places go out of business and the landlords realize that they can't be charging $10,000 for a storefront on Valencia.  That's why a salad is $15 and they are too stingy with ingredients to actual feed you a full meal.  If I'm spending $50 I don't want to leave hungry.  And strangely these places only pay minimum wage to the staff.  Give me a &^*-ing break.  Go back to LA, New York and Paris and let us have the San Francisco we used to have.

Plus they might as well have said  "&^uck you" to my dietary restrictions.  A place this "nice" should be flexible and creative about substitutions and alternatives.  Sure if I want to spend another $6 on top of my $14 I could get some carbs, but the potatoes are loaded with butter and gluten.  No other options.  Taste this hot buttered white bread wheat filled pane italiano. baby.
author: aaronium c.

description: Went here for dinner before a show at Stage Werx. Service was excellent. Didn't care for one of the dishes (Sardine fusilli-- too fishy) and they brought a different one with no problem. Delicious mushroom tortellini. The artichoke and arugula salad was bright and unusual. Verdicchio wine was delicious. Would go again. Plus they got us out and to the theater in time.
author: Julie S.

description:
High-marks for the decor and ambiance alone! Locanda is situated in the heart of Valencia, so I think its inevitable that there's always a crowd inside. We had reservations for a Friday night with friends, and from the moment I entered, knew we picked a winner!

Really interesting cocktail options - the cumquat paloma was delicious and the +1s enjoyed their trio whiskey flight. That fried artichoke appetizer though...just do what everyone says and order it. Also tried the veg/ricotta salad, which wasn't much of a salad, didn't bother me though!

Also tried the carbonara - I never want bacon any other way. Seriously, how do they do it?! The sea bass was also lovely. Definitely didn't need dessert but in the spirit of the weekend, opted to split the chocolate budino = love at first bite.

Loved locanda and hope to be back soon!
author: Brianna M.

description:
It was a great pleasure to have dinner at Locanda.  We loved the ambiance and thought that the service was gracious and effective without being intrusive.

The room is pretty loud; the four of us had to raise our voices in order to carry on a conversation.

I liked everything that I ate and drank, with the possible exception of the "bread," which I experienced as pieces of greasy fried pastry that were delivered to us piping hot and dripping with oil.  (Has the baguette lost its mojo?)  I ate four or five slices of the greasy "bread," so you can infer that I made my peace with it.

I drank two "on tap" wines by Sheldon of Sonoma.  (The "Fearless Leader & Sippy Director" of the winery is named Tobe Sheldon.)  The wines were a chardonnay and a cabernet -- I liked both of them and didn't detect any off-taste from the tap.  I ordered an "corrected" affogato as dessert and imbibed further alcohol because of the correction.  The affogato was delicious and made me happy.  (I tend not to eat many desserts.)

The food:

As a starter, I had the chilled nervetti with celery hearts, Calabrian chili and Buddha's hand.  Only when I placed the order did I find out that nervetti are what our server called beef tendons; online, I find the definition "pressed beef cartilage".  I'm not normally a cartilage guy, but the salad was wonderful!  I thought that the chili worked very well with the other components of the dish.

I went with the Berkshire pork spareribs as my main dish -- this was the top recommendation of our server.  I liked the ribs and wish that there had been more of them.  Next time, however, I'll try something different.

There will definitely be a next time!  We liked Locanda and would be happy to return with friends.
author: Kenneth R.

description:
The Stolls and Chef Anthony Strong sure knocked it out of the park. Initially I had gotten a reservation somehow that was a week before they were open. Annie Stoll herself gives me a call notifying me with the mistake. Damn, I guess I couldn't sneak into the staff training dinner :) She however let me have the pick of any spot on opening night so I rescheduled to be in the thick of it.

Larger and much more bustling that the many times I'd been to Delfina, the atmosphere was definitely abuzz and many were our and dressed to impress. The space is a mix of rustic and modern. Behind the host station is a small seating lounge which opens up to a bar area, with a long bar along the front left of the restaurant, followed by the pass and half of the kitchen which is open. A number of tables surround the back adjacent to a service station and the closed part of the kitchen and plating counter.

As we arrived sharp for our resys, a bevy of attractive hostesses seated us by the kitchen. Now I never went to Ramblas but I remember the previous space, Pinxtos, and realized I was sitting in the exact same area when I was here years ago. Weird deja vu! 
After receiving our beverages and perusing the menu we ended up with:

-Chinotto
-AGRO UVE - Grappa, Peach, Lemon, Egg, Bitters
-PIZZA BIANCA - mortadella 
-SHORT RIBS - Chinotto marinade
-TRIPPA - tomato, mint, and pecorino
-NERVETTI - Arugula salad
-SWEETBREADS - Fried artichokes
-TONNARELLI CACIO e PEPE - pecorino, black pepper, basta
-BUCATINI all'AMATRICIANA - guanciale, tomato, peperoncini, pecorino
-GULF SHRIMP AND BURRATA MEZZASOLE
-BAVETTE STEAK - radicchio Trevisano
-RHUBARB MARMALATA CROSTATA -buckwheat struesel, fior di latte gelato
-SANT'ANDREA MEZZANO - cow's milk (Friuli)
-CANESTRATO DI MOLITERNO - sheep's milk (Basilicata)
-2006 Sergio Mottura "Muffo", Lazio, Italy
-Amaro Lucano

They're definitely killing it at Locanda. Everything we had was stellar. I'd say I enjoyed this more than the various Delfina trips (though I will always have a soft sport for the Tripe dish there more). We  had a huge spread and still so many more things I wanted to try. As Roman influence goes on Italian cuisine, you don't see it all that often here and SPQR, Ideale, Lupa and Delarossa maybe the only other significant plays in that arena. All of our servers were awesome and took great care of us. On top of that, there were definitely some lookers (especially our own Ruby!). It was hardly noticeable that they had just opened. The flow was very well maintained. A new winner in the ever popular and crowded dining scene in the Mission.
author: Kim N.

description: One of my favorite and reliable places for a satisfying meal. The fried artichoke with duck egg was one of my early favorites, as well some their pasta dishes. The dining area is cozy and compared to other restaurants, doesn't get too loud and you can actually have a conversation with people you're having dinner with.
author: Yin T.

description:
Good food, great service, the server was VERY knowledgeable about the food and chef preparing it so that was good.  The server forgot our bread but other than that no matter how busy that restaurant got everything was piping hot and brought out when it needed to be.  Water glasses remained full and we never poured our own wine.

We got a little bit of everything on the menu.  I wouldn't recommend the $21 "OXTAILS alla VACCINARA".  It was not as flavorful/different as our waiter described. I would say it's closer to a family pot-roast that mother's make at home than a restaurant quality meal.  It was edible but didn't look it. When the bread finally did arrive it went perfectly with our Poached Duck Egg & Asparagus.  And the simple light dish that was the CARCIOFI CRUDI was perfect for cleansing our pallets in preparation for the homemade pastas.  I would HIGHLY recommend the CUSCINI - Gulf shrimp blended into raviolis on top of burrata pillows. Magnificently done.

The restaurant itself is beautiful and the bathrooms are well designed with communal faucets joining the two. A+ for design an layout of the space.  The kitchen is clean and visible which is always nice when you dine. The chefs although trendy are clean and seem to know what they're doing.

Good job Locanda.
author: Kevin J.

description: I highly recommend this place for brunch. All the food has such good flavoring. The hashbrowns... wow! The staff was incredibly nice and helpful.
author: Scott K.

description: Favorite spot if in the Mission. Perfect cocktails. Homemade pasta. Cheese-filled fried olives. Great service. An environment that looks like a NYC hotspot in the middle of San Francisco. What's not to love?
author: Ted L.

description:
You know what they say... "When in Rome, do as the Romans do." Well, I have yet to visit Rome, but til then, I'll do as the San Franciscans do and eat at Locanda, a busy resto in the Mission serving up Roman cuisine! 

This is the perfect spot for a well-rounded dinner experience. Start with craft cocktails at the bar, make your way to your table (rezzies rec'd), pop open a bottle of red and straight up feast on anything that catches your eye. For my table of four, that was almost everything on the menu. 

Apparently, you haven't truly dined Roman-style until you order Tonnarelli Cacio e Pepe, a classic dish which consists of only four ingredients: pasta (tonnarelli), Pecorino Romano, cracked pepper and salt. As simple as this dish is, it was one of my faves of the evening. We also rounded out our meal with grilled pizzas, the whole fish of the day, and Jewish-style artichokes. My ignorant palate was introduced to sunchokes earlier this year on a Texas farm, and since then I've been kinda obsessed with the many ways you can eat these healthy lil' suckers. But fried? As they Roman's call it, "Carciofi Alla Giudia" was uh-maze. 

Service was superb, atmo was unique, and the open kitchen delivered a nice dose of energy into our dining experience. I'm a fan and can't wait to go back. (And hopefully experience Rome one day.)
author: Farrah A.

description: The service was very slow and the food was too salty. They serve tiny portions and it's just too expensive for the value you get...big disappointment.
author: Timur A.

description:
A few friends and I have recently started a dining club, well, let's be real. It's an eating club. We started it as we had this never ending list of restaurants with our significant others that we weren't really making a dent on, so the ladies decided to combine those lists and conquer. We kicked off our "Eating Club" at Locanda and couldn't have been happier.

For a Wednesday night at 6:15, the restaurant was moderately full and not too noisy, even when it became more busy. You must get the prosciuttio, and if you are a pasta lover, please note: they serve half dishes of the pasta, so you can order less and try more dishes!

The rock cod special of the evening was delicious although be warned, it is the "whole fish" so if this is not your style of dining, perhaps try one of the pasta or meat entrees as your main.

Everything was fresh and delicious, the wine menu is well rounded, and I would highly recommend Locanda for either a romantic date night, girl friend catch up, or even just a few cocktails and bites at the bar.
author: Simone P.

description: Booked a company holiday dinner here last December, and it was amazing. Beautifully coordinated thanks to their responsive and helpful team, perfect atmosphere, and beyond delicious food! Thanks team Locanda!
author: Priya B.

description:
So I give this place two stars because the place looks cool and the waiters did there job. I was apprehensive going there because most things in the mission are pretty reasonably price for good food but I'm always willing to pay for good quality. 

This place was such a let down.

I went in last night as a group of 4 and ordered the lobster spaghetti, corn, some sort of sausage and pasta plate, chicken, and prosciutto.

The Prosciutto was good but the bread accompanied with it was super salty and wasn't good with the meat. But the meat alone was great.

The lobster spaghetti was really good but a bit cold.

The sausage pasta was the worse thing I ever ate at an Italian restaurant. It was incredibly salty (and I'm a person that doesn't mind salt) and also kind of cold.

The Chicken was mediocre, nothing amazing but not awful.

The corn was good but overly expensive. You can get the same thing from the street vendor for a better price on Mission if you literally walk outside and down the street.

Everything was either okay or really bad. And everything except the chicken and corn were loaded with salt. 

I won't be coming here again and suggesting people go to North Beach if they want Italian.
author: jessica c.

description: Enjoyed a brunch here one Sunday. I had the "eggs in purgatory" which was quite delicious. It was a nice mix of a breakfast food coupled with spicy marinara sauce reminiscent of a rich pasta dish. The apertivo cocktail is light, flavorful, and unique. Good coffee too. We arrived right at 11 and had no problem getting a table without a reservation.
author: Patrick F.

description: The pasta here is unbelievably delicious. Do not miss the bucatini. It is the best outside of Italy. The only thing on the menu I don't like is the anchovy butter but everything else is worth trying. Delicious cocktails and friendly staff, too.
author: Beee N.

description:
Came to Locanda at the recommendation of a friend.  There was a group of about 8 of us and we all decided to sample as much as we could...ordering everything to share.  Our waitress was so accommodating and went above and beyond her job to offer detailed recommendations, her own personal opinions, and was ridiculously friendly.  The Manager, Nick, even came around multiple times to check on us and make sure everything we had was to our liking and even provided his own recommendations for drinks and cocktails.  The service, needless to say, was superb.  The whole setup of the restaurant is super cool, as well...an open kitchen, awesome bar, and tasteful, modern decor. 

Everyone ordered different cocktails, all of which were special, unique, and delicious.

The FOOD (everything was FANTASTIC): 
Appetizers:  the Sonoma lamb carpaccio (to die for), fried olives, fried pig ears, and pizza bianca. 
Soup: the butternut squash (i could eat a whole bowl of the friend sage they top it with) 

PASTAS / ENTREES  -- every plate was scraped clean---
Rigatoni alla Carbonara - creamy, rich, and the pasta was cooked perfectly. 
Bellwether Crescenza Tortelli  (mushroom and sauce on this is soo good!)
Radiatore "pecora e pecorino"  - a bolognese-type sauce that was fresh, light, and full of lamb 
Orecchiette - sausage with broccoli raab - tasted just like the one I used to order in Rome. Perfect.
Pancetta-Wrapped Mary's Chicken - the pancetta was crispy and the chicken was so moist. 
Side: Roasted Brussel sprouts w/ Prosciutto (this was my friend's favorite dish)

DESSERT (everyone was stuffed but we ordered it anyways).  The Manager was so awesome, he even sent us out the Affogato Corretto to try :) 
Warm Tcho Chocolate Budino - GET THIS NO MATTER HOW FULL YOU ARE.  YOU WONT REGRET IT 
Semifreddo (this was my favorite) 

Overall, a fantastic dining experience, wonderful service, unforgettable food, and wonderful ambiance.  The only thing I don't like about Locanda is that there isn't one closer to Santa Cruz.  Bottom line: Go here. You won't regret it.
author: Casey S.

description: What a treat!  All the appetizers we ordered were superb and the quality of the pasta dishes was outstanding.  One of my new favorite places now.
author: Cakes A.

description: All my expectations were lived up to at Locanda. I had the bavette steak and the swordfish- both were amazing and I highly  recommend!
author: Alyssa R.

description:
This place is completely overrated.

Portions are small and not enough for a dinner. I walked out the door still hungry. If they like offering small portions they should price them accordingly and explain that those dishes are not enough for a main.

We brought our 11 week old son. We had to place the stroller next to a cold air draft.

Ambiance is very yuppie and nice if you like that style.

If you eat out 5 times a week and like hanging at a bar worth a try. If you have something special to celebrate or are looking forward to a really nice date night don't go hear. Absolutely NOT WORTH it.
author: Philip B.

description: My friend and I had an amazing dinner last night at Locanda.  Jewish Artichoke was superb...even better than the Carciofi alla Romana I had years ago at Piperno in Rome.  We both had the BELLWETHER CRESCENZA TORTELLI - hedgehog mushrooms, mint, pinenuts    which was OMG good.  Finished with  RHUBARB-STRAWBERRY CROSTATA - black sesame gelato ... black sesame gelato!!!!!!!!   We started with vodka, of course.  Dinner ran about $63 each with tip 4% health for SF, etc. per person.  A truly memorable dinner.
author: Toby T.

description:
Finally got here to try the food for a belated birthday / early Valentine's day dinner. I'd been here previously for drinks while bar-hopping my way through the Mission a few years ago, but had been keeping an eye on the menu for awhile.

We arrived on time for our reservation and were seated pretty quickly. The tables are crowded in together, so be careful when moving in and out of your seat. 

We ordered cocktails first (there's some *amazing* options), followed by two entrees (caceo e pepe and lamb ragu) along with two sides (smoked mashed potatoes and carrots with burnt orange). We also ordered a glass of wine each with our meal. 

All four food items came out in a decent amount of time (it was pretty busy on a Thursday evening) and we jumped in with excitement. Everything was delicious, winners in their own right. The pasta was cooked perfectly, the mashed potatoes had a hint of smokey flavour along with the great taste of peppercorns, and the carrots were unlike any I'd ever had before. Despite the serving sizes being decent, we finished all four dishes with nothing left over. 

Only drawback, our waiter forgot to bring out our wine order! As we were close to finishing up our food, he realized it and rushed over with the two bottles, apologizing profusely. I get it, it was busy, easy to get distracted. I was glad he noticed in time since I did want to taste the wine with my food. He comp'd us a glass of the wine to make up for the mistake, which was nice.

We went over the dessert menu but nothing really jumped out at us. We had plans for dessert elsewhere anyway. 

If you're looking for really friendly and outgoing staff, delicious food, unique cocktails, and a great atmosphere, you can't go wrong checking this place out.
author: Cassandra J.

description:
Dinner for 2 Friday night. Can't recall the exact craft made cocktail but it was good. Subtle flavors and packed a punch.
Started with Jerusalem artichoke hearts as an app. So good and crispy that we had to order another.
For our entrees we had the bavet re steak. It was outstanding-one of the best steaks I've had, and I have had quite a few over the years. We also had the tortellini which had a light broth. 
The spring peas and shoots with speck and crime fraiche was full of flavor.
In a city full of great dining options not to mention some fantastic Italian restaurants, Locanda is one not to be missed.
author: Jon D.

description:
Wish I could give 3.5, but probably slightly better, so rounded up - 3 would not do it justice.

Food is delicious - just have to know what to get. Some dishes are a bit overpriced, others well worth the premium for the uniqueness of the amazing flavor. The lamb bolognese, Jewish style artichoke and flourless chocolate cake are all perfect. Lamb chops are also done flawlessly.

Service - hit or miss...I've had great service here, and, well, lousy service where everyone from the hostess to the waitress to the tender barely pays attention to you.

Ambiance - pretty cool, quaint little spot. Nothing too fancy, but kind of hip - just right.

All in all, with all the competition around, on my rotation but not my favorite in the city.
author: Jason C.

description:
I was only here for a pre-dinner cocktail so I can't comment on the food. All the more reason why I need to come back.

But the cocktail selection was very good. A little pricier than I would like but delicious nonetheless. The bartenders take their time to show the artistic process that comes with making a delicious cocktail.

Can't wait to come back here!
author: Juan T. K.

description:
Really loved our dinner and experience. We sat at the bar and Ivan was awesome. Great cocktails and recommendations. He was so fun to be around and made our experience feel special. 

Happy hour until 7pm! We ordered way too much food and left stuffed/happy! 

Ordered pizza Bianca (must order) and tried the burrata (outstanding), mixed greens, mushroom tortelli, spaghetti, and rigatoni carbonara. Our favorite was the Bianca and tortelli (drool). 

Must go! Supposedly Thursday they have special gnocchi...so if you are like us and love those potato goodies...go Thursday.
author: Candace D.

description:
Ordered:

Pizza Bianca - crusty bread with olive oil and salt.
Fried olives - delicious

The Carbonara - not remarkable
The Raddiatore was delicious with an incredible lamb ragu
The Bavette Steak - despite being medium rare was also surprisingly tough. The mashed potatoes though - to die for. 


The setting was the most disappointing. It was incredibly hot and the staff seemed to be rather thin. We sat in a two top with two other twos surrounding us. I would come back if someone invited me.
author: Christine Y.

description:
Locanda is alright. Another classy restaurant in the Mission District of SF, close to the 16th/Mission BART, along the ever-so-lively Valencia St.

Focaccia bread was an excellent way to start the meal. Warm, and as much as you like!

The lamb was cut semi-thin, and was tender and juicy. Accoutrements to the dish included chickpeas, whole shallots, and lettuce (sure?). The sauce blended everything really well. An enjoyable dish.

What killed if for me was their side of Broccoli Raab. The mushiest order of vegetables I've had ever! Might as well have pureed it into a thick sauce for a dish. Hell, digging in with a fork did that for me. $8 - ok, I'll pass next time.

Drinks were ok. Strong and favorful.
author: Kevin J.

description: Arrived today off a flight from Australia and popped in to Locanda for dinner at the bar. Fabulous staff and wicked food to match. Steak Bavette, medium nice and peppery with a hint of smoke. Best. Highly recommended.
author: Mark C.

description:
There's countless ways to describe this hipper (not to be confused with hipster) side of the restaurant scene in the Mission. Though, it's simple enough to sum it up in a few words: modern dining with Mad Men inspired cocktails.   

My friend and I went here and played gastro-roulette where we let the waitress pick out some of her favorite unique dishes for us. The waitress was not only wonderful, but also incredibly intuitive. We were served Jerusalem artichokes and oxtail along complimentary bubbly for their second anniversary.  

What pairs nicely with oxtail, surprisingly an old fashion. What tops one old fashion? A flight of old fashions each uniquely made with different whiskeys, sugared rims, and bitters from exotic parts of the world. We rolled out of Locanda with full bellies and smiling faces.
author: Melissa P.

description: It's OK. The wine was good but the pasta was pretty blah. Nothing fancy and a ton of carbs for not too much taste.
author: Andra G.

description:
We first ate at Locanda a few years back not long after it opened, and while it was fine, we weren't super impressed. The food seemed kind of ordinary & the drinks were so-so.

Since then, though, some friends of ours have adopted it as their favorite restaurant in the Mission, and after a recent trip to Italy, we decided it was only fair to give them another shot.

And WOW, so glad we did. The dishes were unique & interesting but still fairly authentically Italian, and we enjoyed them all. The wine list was excellent, and our server made perfect recommendations. We enjoyed a couple of tasty cocktails & an amari flight as well. Now I want to go back!!
author: Angela B.

description:
The service was great and everyone there was very friendly. Unfortunately though, the food was just OK at best. The ribs were very expensive and overly salty and smokey. One of the pastas looked and tasted like spaghetti-o's, however the linguini was very good.

Food is just kind of hit or miss.
author: BettyLou H.

description:
Recently came here again, and I was sad to find that the oxtail entree was no longer there. We ordered the Linguine with Clams and the Whole Fish Acqua Pazza.

The Linguine with Clams was not what I thought it'd be. I was hoping for more garlic and white wine, but their sauce was a little too sour. It also had this bitter pepper flavor that I didn't like. I normally love Linguine and Clams, but this one was not my favorite.

The Whole Fish that night was cod, and it was cooked pretty well. The fish was soft and tender, but it could've used some more seasoning. There was a light tomato based broth that had an herby highlight from oregano. Although the broth was pretty tasty, it would've been better if the fish had more salt or something. With some more seasoning, the fish would've paired better with the broth.
author: Nei N.

description:
I hate bread, I'm not a fan. There are other means of carbo intake. 

I love my rice, I love my pasta.  Bread is just a filler but let me tell you about these astounding home made focaccia bread last night. The best carboliciness to ever hit these hips.  They're mind-blowing. I just wanna get neked and lay on a mattress of soft pillowy focaccia just so I can slowly chew on the airly rosemary cloud!  I wanted to ask our waiter for a 3rd order but had to hold my tongue.

Come for the eclectic ambiance filled with the sound of an adequately orchestrated fast-paced open kitchen and order up a vodka drink (I asked the bartender to throw some juniper & sage into my vodka and bam! best cocktail du jour ever).  Get the duck egg appetizer and use that airy foccacia bread to soak up the yolky goodness.

I had the lobster & spaghetti, 1 1/4 lb of succulent lobster meat toss with some spicy jalapenos in a light tomatoes sauce... molto delizioso! 

My only qualm; wine on tap?!  Say it ain't so.  Wine with a screw cap I can fathom but on tap?!

Mama Miaaa...
author: Lo-an L.

description:
I ended up at Locanda randomly on my last night in SF when I just happened to be in the neighborhood. I'm not sure I'll ever be in that neighborhood again. 

I started the Aperitivo, a blend of campari and citrus enticing enough to make me stay but a little too sweet to make me linger. 

But I did linger for the next course...and the next because the menu just looked so good. You can't go wrong with a coat of golden breading on Fried Artichokes and Veal Sweetbreads, but there wasn't even a dipping sauce to dress up this plain dish.
The Bucatini all'Amatriciana's interminable lines of mediocre pasta with tomato sauce was about as fresh and cheesy and as a pick-up line. But before you get too bored, it does incorporate an element of surprise. You do occasionally encounter a jaw-breaking cube of rich bacon-esque guanciale.
The there was the overly-sweet Chestnut-Ricotta Agnolotti. These little packets of sugary paste lay it on thick, but chestnut and ricotta is all sweet, with no savory notes to balance it out. I'd be lying if I didn't say they quickly become gag-worthy when you're barely half way through.

Locanda talks a good game, but be careful not to fall because no real talent, innovation, or craft lies beneath the cheesy surface. As sexy and exciting as this modern, mood-lit little place seemed at first, I see no reason to come back for seconds.
author: Kelsey C.

description:
Wow, this was a bit of great dining that I have been needing. 

The Jewish artichoke and a burratta version of their pizza bianca started out the meal. Something about the burratta gave me the impression that even their salt was impressive? Yeah, that well balanced.

The Radiatore, lamb ragu, was fantastic. The meat was so supple and full of flavor, smooth, delicious. My wife and I loved it. The sommelier made a great wine recommendation that paired well with both this and the Bavette.

The Bavette, so I've seen others remark that it was a bit rare. I have to agree and actually think the cut of meat requires just a little less purple inside. Still a delicious choice for a main. It paired especially well with the carrots, which with the salsa verde, had a good kick to set off their natural sweetness.

Just awesome!
author: Jonathan D.

description:
Locanda is definitely one of my favorite places in SF. Delicious cocktails, and yummy fresh pastas. I always look forward to being able to get a table.

If you're driving, I would highly recommend, as street parking in the Mission is extremely difficult. 

Grab a cocktail or a wine on tap while you're waiting.

One of my goals is to someday be able to sit in the window booth. Looks awesome!
author: Uyen D.

description: What a tremendous Italian treat! We had the smoked mashed potatoes, corn soup, pancetta-wrapped chicken and more. Executive Chef Eli is talented and creative. Spend an evening here and enjoy!
author: Royce C.

description:
Amazing food and super friendly service! Deep fried olives, artichokes, prosciutto all awesome choices and of course any of the pasta! This was all very affordable  considering the quality of the food!

I'll be coming back for sure!
author: Richard N.

description: We went here and really enjoyed ourselves.  The food was good and the service was nice.  However, because of the TV sitch, we won't be going back.  It's sad that a restaurant like this would put up a TV.  Whaaa?!
author: ML ..

description: Another mediocre brunch in SF. I've lived here for 6 months and I guess I should take a hint and lower my expectations.  I came here at 12:45 for a reservation and the hostess told us we could wait at the bar.  15 minutes later she asked if we just wanted to eat at the bar since our table wasnt ready.  There was only 1 seat available so we declined.  Also that's why we made a reservation why would we want to eat at a bar with no chairs available. Moving on we ordered the eggs and purgatory and a sticky bun.  We asked for our sticky bun first and it never came. We got the egg dish and both me and my friends eggs were completely raw.  They apologized and remade them.  They also said we could have a round of bellinis on them which was nice.  An hour later we never got our sticky bun and cancelled the order.  The waitress seemed very green and was surprised our order didn't come (isn't that your job??).  All in all food was just ok but won't be back since the price point doesn't match the crappy service.
author: Diana D.

description: Some of the best pasta I've ever had, the bucatini in particular was so flavorful. Great service, ambience & wine.
author: Anish A.

description: Came here for Restaurant Week and were not disappointed! We had reservations and were promptly seated. Our waiter Justin was fantastic; he helped us navigate through the drinks menu, and his recommendations did not disappoint. We tried the set menu as well as off of the regular menu, and spent dinner arguing whose dish was the best. Personally, I think it was mine - the tortellini, which would just melt in my mouth. One of the better burratas we've had and a unique cauliflower soup. The desserts were also stellar. The weakest part of the meal was the saltimbocca - not the meat itself, but the side dish of greens, which was presented as a pile on an additional plate, almost like an attempt to make you feel healthier since you just got a dinner plate full of meat. Restaurant Week or no, we will be back!
author: Convict T.

description:
I have never been disappointed by this greatness! I've been here twice now and the service is perfect, couldn't ask for better. Even though it was so ridiculously busy, the server never forgot about us and always gave a little visit.

My only complaint here is the portions... very flour + water esque.
I do like it here more than flour + water though.

The cocktails are good and so is the food.
author: Carleen W.

description:
I came here twice in one weekend.


FIRST TIME (5 stars)
A dear friend recently got engaged, so to celebrate, we met up here for cocktails and dessert. The place was packed, even on a Thursday night, and we were told it would be a 45-min wait for a table at the bar. However, we ended up only waiting 20 mins, so yay! 

We got The Bad Seed, Business Thyme, Hemingway and Il Profesionale (for drinks), and the Warm Chocolate Cake (for dessert). The cocktails here are absolutely gorgeous. Pretty colors served in old-fashioned, speakeasy-era martini glasses. They make you feel like Daisy Buchanan (that's a Great Gatsby reference for those of you who got more useful college degrees than English Lit). Thyme is one of my favorite herbs, so I'd definitely recommend the Business Thyme if you're into that. Otherwise, The Bad Seed is great for that fruity, citrusy flavor with a little bit of agave. The chocolate cake was a dream. Perfectly moist, warm, soft cake served with earl grey, almond and cocoa nib croccante and cool, creamy almond milk gelato. A fantastic combination of the traditional with a unique, creative twist.

Our server was very attentive and friendly, yet understood when to leave us alone (two girls discussing one's upcoming wedding = many, many hours of girly chatter).


SECOND TIME (3 stars)
A couple of days after my first visit, I was entertaining a good friend who was visiting from Boston. Somehow, we wound up in the Mission that evening with one of her friends. They wanted booze, so I suggested Locanda, which was right around the corner and which I knew had great drinks and food.

This time, we were seated immediately. However, the cocktails were kind of a dud. In an attempt to try more things on the menu, I went with one of the cocktails with Campari in it (cant remember the name). I was assured by the waitress that it would be sweet, but upon tasting it...It most certainly was not. There was way, way, way too much Campari, making it extremely bitter. Now, I got my bartender's certification last year, so I know how to read a cocktail menu. I expected there to be some bitterness, but not that much. I ended up sending the cocktail back and asking for my friend's cocktail, The Aperitivo. It also had Campari, but it was much more diluted--way sweeter and far less bitter.

For entrees, I got the Bucatini all'Amatriciana. I have to say, I was really surprised and disappointed by how small the entree portions were. It wasn't possible to know that from my first visit, since we only ordered dessert. All of our entrees would easily be appetizers at a less fancy restaurant. The Bucatini was cooked well, with chewy al dente noodles and a creamy tomato sauce. However, the guanciale (unsmoked Italian bacon) was so salty, it actually hurt my teeth after a while. It was definitely a case of less is more.

Despite the bad first cocktail and the disappointing portion sizes, I would have still given this second experience 4 stars if it weren't for one thing: our waitress. She was bad. Just bad. You ever go to a service place--like a restaurant, clothing store, etc.--and encounter that employee who's in a foul mood and just refuses to be friendly, gracious or even pleasant to talk to? They're not rude or insulting, just cold and unsmiling no matter how nice you are, and nothing you say will penetrate that icy exterior. Well, that was our waitress. If she'd hung a sign around her neck with "I DON'T WANT TO BE HERE!!!" written in neon pink, she couldn't have been more obvious about how unhappy she was to be working.
author: Josephine L.

description:
Yum! Came here for a girls dinner- 
We of course had to try to Fried Artichoke dish - so yummy. We also had a few of the pastas which were very good- I apologize for not remembering the names. We also had a fish dish which was very tasty. Our waitress was very nice and gave some good recommendations. Would looove to come back!
author: Nicole S.

description:
Amazing birthday dinner for the BF.  We arrived 15 minutes early and got a drink at the bar (the Nonna del Diavolo was refreshing and perfect for the really warm evening we came on).  We were told our table was ready exactly on time for our reservation and had a great table by the window.  The ambiance of the space was great, very open but cozy at the same time. 

Our waitress helped us navigate the wine menu, with great descriptions and recommendations based on the price range and taste preferences that we had.  We ordered the prosciutto to go with the house bread (so deliciously light) as a starter.  For the pasta course we ordered the Bucatini all'Amatriciana, which was perfectly al dente with tiny pork cubes that were extremely crunchy and flavorful on the seared side, and tender and juicy on the other.  For the meat course we ordered the grilled halibut collar, that was huuuuge and perfect to split for two.  It came with a variety of condiments, but was absolutely delicious on its own.  

We opted out of dessert, but the waitress brought over complimentary cookie bites with a candle that were the perfect ending to our meal.  A great location for a date or celebratory dinner, I highly recommend based on the service, food, and cocktails & am looking forward to returning to try other dishes on their constantly changing menu!
author: Raina D.

description:
Had reservations at the place next door to Locanda on my birthday.  Upon being seated, looked at the most limited menu I have seen and decided that I didn't want fish or offal and that we had to leave.  Disappointed.

Redemption next door at Locanda.  They could take us, the waiter was adorable and incredibly helpful, and everything we got was awesome.  Drinks... lovely, three different pastas for three foodie girls and each of us thought a different one was best.  Love it when expectations are exceeded!
author: Katy S.

description: We really enjoyed the food but unfortunately, our waitress Nelly was absolutely terrible and ruined the entire experience for us.  My fiance and I wanted to take my mother (who is visiting from Seattle) to a nice dinner on her last night in SF.  She could care less about taking our order.  We sat at our table for at least 40 minutes.  She'd occasionally walk by but refused to look in our direction - and this was at 9:45pm/10:00pm (i.e., not peak hour).  She was equally unpleasant throughout the dinner.  We had quite a few dishes that we didn't finish; she packed it up for us and when I looked, she had mixed all the dishes into one single box.  This includes fish, pizza, vegetables, etc.  Our whole table was shocked.
author: Chantal H.

description:
Minus : Food was decent but totally overpriced for a cuisine that is banal and unoriginal. Atmosphere was cosy at first then got really loud around 8pm.
The plus :  Didn't have to wait long for the dishes and waiter was nice and very attentive. 

If you really want to enjoy excellent food go next door to Tartine ans try their carpacio (omg!!) or Zuni. 

Antipasti : 
trippa a la romana : pretty blunt 
The lamb carpacio : wasn't cut thin enough didn't much flavor either although the mint touch was nice. 

The radiatore pecora (The lamb ragu pasta) : again had nothing really special, wasn't bad either. It just leaves you rather indifferent 

The broiled lamb rib were good and juicy. The veggie  accompaniment was good too actually and they had flavor ! 

Deserts : Forget about the desert menu .... The affogato was so disappointing that we went straight to dandelion for a tiramisu and another chocolate wonder ...
author: Ar M.

description:
Went here again, this time on halloween evening.  The whole staff was dressed in coordinated Grease-the-musical costumes.  The food was even better than the first visit.

Also, they have a really impressive Italian wine list, matched probably only by Flour + Water (which makes sense).  Clearly some of these wines are being imported direct, and they now have a selection of around 15 different ones by the glass, including (the night I went) a whole Alto Adige flight. 

So, upgrading to 5 stars.
author: Josh B.

description:
Some things are well worth waiting for and given how long I've been trying to dine at  Locanda, I'd have to say this is a place that should be on everyone's list to visit.

I met up with a friend on a weekday night to catch up and check out a restaurant neither of us had been to before.  Luckily for me we both have a similar sense of adventure when it comes to food so he trusted me to pick our meeting spot.

We were seated in the back dining area, right in front of the kitchen where the chefs were cooking our meals.  Perfect!  Tables were spaced fairly close to one another, but not so close that I could hear other conversations.  

I started my meal with the mixed green salad with a balsamic vinaigrette.  The greens were fresh and greens were perfectly dressed.  My friend ordered one stick of the Coppiette, their version of pork jerky, and it was quite good.  You could tell high quality meat was used and the flavors of smoke and spice were pronounced, but not overly so.    He also ordered the carciofi crudi, a salad of artichokes, ricotta, arugula and avocado, a salad that he really enjoyed, and this is coming from someone that usually prefers foie gras to anything that grows out of the ground!  

For my entree I ordered the rigatoni alla carbonara, a typical Roman dish.  The sauce of egg, pecorino cheese, pepper and guanciale was delicious!  I used the focaccia (you have to ask for it and believe me you WANT to ask for it) to sop up some of this creamy and rich sauce.  For dessert I had the sheep's milk yogurt budino, which came with roasted strawberries and candied orange peel.  It was light, almost like a custard cake.  

Many of the dishes looked so delicious that I would love to try all of them.  The Jewish style artichokes looked amazing and is something I would order on my next visit.   Portions are reasonable, as are the prices.  They make their own pasta and cure their own meats (they can be seen hanging in the kitchen).   They have a good selection of cocktails, beers and wines available.  Service was really attentive and our servers made sure that we were satisfied with our experience.   Given that Locanda is the sister restaurant to Delfina, I'm not surprised that this Roman-themed restaurant is just as good.
author: Melissa L.

description:
Food and service were excellent. Unfortunately both were overshadowed by the cold draft each time someone opened the door. Be careful not to sit by the front door on a cold night.

Flatbread, artichoke, pasta and cocktails were all delicious.
author: Ryan T.

description: Fantastic Italian restaurant -- this is a must-go place if you like good pasta (reminded me of my trip to Italy) and well-made drinks. I went on a whim on a weeknight and was able to get a seat at the bar. I ordered La Bella Confuzione (bartender's choice) and he did not disappoint. I'm allergic to vodka, nuts and apples, but the bartender worked around my high-maintenance requests with a smile. The Rigatoni Alla Carbonara was so good I wanted to lick the plate. If Locanda wasn't such a classily establishment, I would have.
author: Alison J.

description:
Nice dinner for four on a busy Saturday night.  Walked in for 6pm reservation and the place was already packed to the brim!  Valet service for $12 which made it easier for us rather than having to circle around the Mission for an impossible parking space.

If you don't drink alcohol, highly recommend the Ginger Soda which was really tasty.  Starters prosciutto and fried olives were gobbled up in not time. Chicory salad had parts I couldn't chew and fried artichoke seemed rather small for $8 a piece, though did enjoy the little piece that I had.  Shared two entrees of pasta as primi -- they were small plates: rigatoni carbonera and a spaghetti tomato sauce dish that I forgot the name.  Rigatoni was a disappointment -- felt really heavy and just salty, but the bacon saved the dish. They were delightfully crunchy pork-belly like morsels that I couldn't get enough of. The other pasta dish had the same bacon in it, but not fried and didn't taste as yummy, but the pasta itself and suce was devine.

Lamp chops, steak and fish were all prepared quite nicely.  Bombolinis were good for dessert; cookie plate not as impressive and affogato got good reviews from our dinner companions. 

All in all a great night out.  Good attentive service and great buzz in the restaurant. Service was a bit slow between primi and secondi, but we were ok waiting since we ate so much appetizers and pasta so it was actually a welcome respite to wait for the main course.

With so many other restaurants in the Mission, I will try others before returning. Though may just pop in at the bar and order a nice drink and bar snacks.
author: Stephanie L.

description:
Words have difficulty describing how I felt about the meal my wife and I had here unexpectedly one night while visiting San Francisco.  This was definitely one of the five best meals I've ever had in my entire life, and for sure the best pasta I've ever had.  We called about 15 minutes before they opened and were able to score a reservation for right away.  I'm not sure if this is a place that tends to fill up quickly, but when we arrived, there was already a bit of a crowd waiting to get in.

We were seated in a corner table.  Our server was very friendly and great about explaining all of the specials and the menu.  To begin with, I had the Nonna Del Diavolo cocktail, which was delicious.  If you are a fan of Rye, I would give this a whirl.

To begin with, we had the radishes and anchovy butter.  Now, I've never had anchovies before, so I was a little nervous.  I must say, I was pleasantly surprised!  The anchovies gave the butter and radishes a nice umami flavor that really worked well!  

For my entree, I ordered the orecchiette with sausage, broccoli raab, capers, and cheese.  It was DELICIOUS.  The pasta was clearly made in-house, which I should have just assumed.  It was perfectly al dente.  I also tried my wife's short rib ravioli, and, let me tell you, words cannot describe how incredible it was.  Perfectly juicy and creamy.  I'm salivating just thinking about it.  

To end the evening we had a small cookie plate that was just the perfect size, not too big, not too small.  I will tell any and all of my friends who go to SF to eat here.  I cannot wait to have it again when we go back to San Francisco some day!
author: Kevin C.

description:
My husband and I came across Locanda during a recent vacation to San Francisco (we live in Omaha, NE) - it was open at the time we were walking by and the menu looked great, so we figured we'd give it a try for an early dinner, not knowing what to expect (though we did know its affiliation with Delfina, etc., which had come highly recommended to us). 

We left having eaten what was one of the best meals I'd ever had, and easily the best pasta dish that I had ever had. First off, they're also well-known for craft cocktails, and although I wasn't feeling like one on this particular evening, my husband did try their Nonna Del Diavolo (rye, strega, ginger, lime, seltzer), which was excellent. As a starter, we got the radishes with anchovy butter, which we really enjoyed. Radishes with butter and salt are undeniably trendy right now, but I still liked it, and thought the riff with anchovies was a cool twist and not something I would have thought of. We also tried the roman-style pork jerky, which is cured in Campari, so you know it's gotta be good - it was. Very unique and worth trying for just $2.50 a piece. 

My husband had an orecchiette dish with sausage and greens, which was wonderful - you just can't beat homemade pasta like that. But the real star of the show was my entree, the short rib ravioli, on this particular night served in a sunchoke velutato sauce. THIS is a meal I will also remember and as I said earlier, the best pasta dish I've ever had. Their menu changes frequently, but I highly recommend trying anything dish with short ribs - they were perfectly cooked, melt in your mouth tender. Portions are smaller than what you'll get at most places, but this is a quality over quantity kind of place IMO, and the quality was superb. I left feeling full but not overly stuffed.

For dessert we shared the cookie plate - a nice, light bite after a heavier dinner. Overall, a wonderful experience with fantastic food and great service, too. I will definitely be highly recommending Locanda to other friends visiting SF and will make a point of it to stop on my next trip there.
author: Hollyanne F.

description: I normally don't take take the effort on writing disappointing reviews, but this was just shocking. Ordered an $18 main course pasta on the menu. There is no filter in this picture, no adobe photoshop neither is it a joke... This is the portion that is just got. I mean, I'm sorry I might taste good but this is very... very disappointing. Almost looks like they give me an indirect message to go on a diet. Very disappointed and absolutely no value for money for me and the group.
author: AJ J.

description:
I brought my boyfriend here to celebrate his birthday and was able to make a Friday night reservation at 7pm without a problem. The restaurant was great about putting out a menu that had "Happy Birthday" written at the top of it. The ambience of the place was a bit noisier than I had hoped for. It was fairly crowded since it was a Friday night and due to the large number of people, it felt a bit stuffy. 

The wait staff was very friendly and accommodating. I called ahead to ask that they bring a dessert with a birthday candle out right after our meal. The meal came out fairly quickly, and we were in and out of the restaurant within an hour. 

I was not extremely impressed with the food. As a vegetarian who is also lactose intolerant, there were not a lot of meal options for me. My boyfriend ordered the fettuccine and really enjoyed it. However, the portions here are very small.
author: Catherine C.

description:
Good food but similar to all of today's NICE RESTAURANTS in that they charge way too much for 6 ounce plates of pasta.  $19?  Really!

To eat well here I would need to order two plates of pasta and leave with a $40 tab plus tax and tip no drinks or apps......total tab $55.  For pasta?.

No thanks.
author: Bill M.

description: Best anniversary dinner ever. From the moment we entered to the moment we left, everything was perfect. The bavette steak was perfectly cooked medium rare inside with a nice char on the outside, pungent treviso atop smoked potatoes. Can't wait for our next visit.
author: Eric S.

description: I wanted to try Locanda for awhile, and finally got the opportunity to this last week.  Sadly, it was a disappointing experience. The service was interesting...our server seemed very aloof, and not too inviting--long day maybe? I can let that slide.  However, to simply put it, the food was just bad. Everything was so salty! We got the burrata, bucatini, and one other pasta dish that lacked real depth in taste. This place is pretty pricey as well for three dishes and 2 glasses of wine we managed to rack up a $130 bill. Cute space, but if you want some great Italian food with a twist head to Cotogna or elsewhere.
author: Nicole B.

description: Sunday dinner... Antipasti, chicken liver crostini - ok, lamb carpaccio - blah... Pasta, Cacio e Pepe - overwhelmingly salty... Main, grilled fish - salty as well... Desserts - ok. Total bill for 2 - $170. Waste!
author: Andrei R.

description:
We went to Locanda with my girlfriend and two other friends that were visiting SF. We heard great comments about Locanda and decided to give it a try. 
We were really disappointed with our entrees. My friend and I got the Sardines Fuccille. The dish had no taste and was tiny. I had to order some Parmesan cheese to put some flavor on it. I am a really knowledgable about pasta as my dad is a chef specialized in Italian food and I can really tell this dish was poor. 
As for the desserts, we ordered the mascarpone pudding and the chocolate cake. The waitress came back saying they run out of them. We changed for the apple crumble. Again, no taste at all. 

In general the service was ok, the atmosphere great, the bar had good drinks but the food was totally below expectations specially for the price you pay for it. 

In conclusion, really bad value for money. Go only there with a date and get the drinks. The only good thin about it.
author: Hernan G.

description: Love their food, love their drinks and service. Sadly they just put up a giant tv showing sport events that no one seems to watch. Thought this place was better than that, there's a sports bar one block away if thats what you're looking for.
author: Gustaf E.

description:
The food was good except for the Jewish Style artichoke which was almost inedible. The heart was ok..  The leaves were overly cooked.  It was like trying to munch on some overcooked barbecued corn husks.Linguine with fresh local anchovies, shishito peppers, breadcrumbs....this was a good dish although the anchovies tasted a bit over the hill. The lamb chops were delicious and worth going back for.  The guy liked the short ribs.  They supply you with very oily foccaccio and wonderfully fruity and garlicky olive oil for dipping.

Acoustically, the place needs help.  It is ear splittingly loud inside Locanda.  We had to scream at each other to have a conversation.....So if your're looking for a nice, mellow place to have dinner, this would not be it.  The service was strange, with very very long waits between courses and no explanation as to why.
author: Bleep S.

description: Very cool Roman atmosphere! Food does not disappoint. The cured meats are delicious. Most main course plates are good. Some mains are so-so.
author: Tina L.

description:
Good food, drinks, and dessert. Slightly pricy for small portions but I liked it. the bread was good too. For the pasta we got, I literally wanted to eat the entire plate even though we were sharing and this was my second meal within two hours. It was that good. 

Even though I came with friends this time, I definitely want to take my boyfriend here on a date. I love the ambiance and I think he'd be impressed by this place =)
author: Connie Y.

description:
My husband and I stopped here for a drink before dinner. I loved the casual yet trendy/chic ambiance. Our bartender was also super sweet and helpful.

I loved my Nonna del Diavolo ($10, rye, strega, ginger, lime, seltzer) drink. It was so refreshing and did not skimp on the alcohol.

My hubby splurged for the Old Fashioned flight ($20, rye & demerara, bourbon & maple, scotch & honey), which was distinctive and delicious. 

Next time, we'll be back for food!
author: Jess L.

description:
Items Selected:
Grilled Pizza Bianca
Grilled Pizza Bianca with house mortadella and pickled ramps
Rigatoni alla Carbonara - Guanciale, Tully Doici Egg, Pecorino, Black Pepper
Pancetta-Wrapped Guinea Hen Leg - White Polenta, Grilled Turnips
Flavorosa Pluot Almond Torta - Blueberry Swirl Buffala Gelato, Nebbiolo Plum Sauce

Admittedly sampling the Cal-Italian scene heavily on most of my trips to The Bay Area and having found greatness to be more consistent here than elsewhere in the States it was the largely the Roman style of cuisine that originally piqued my interest in Locanda and after several intriguing afternoon sessions at the conference my Monday double-feature dinner would take me back to the Mission where always beckon but the early-summer menu could not be ignored.  Open just fifteen minutes when I arrived and as yet unfilled it was in the warm sun of the front window that I opted to sit and although the long, narrow space was amped up with unnecessary music the room never grew too loud - a serene effect unlike that of Delfina, Cotagna, or A16 despite the high ceilings and substantial wood.  Seemingly a bit more of a 'locals' place than other highly praised places of the ilk it would not be long after seating that my menu was delivered and chatting up the charming server about several indecisions an order was placed - her recommendations matching my predispositions letter for letter and leaving me in wait as I grazed on glistening pillows of warm bread with a second board soon arriving draped in nutty peppered pork invigorated by bright pickled ramps.  Already impressed by the charcuterie it was within moments of my finishing the mortadella that my al dente primi arrived and although pre-mixed in the kitchen with yolk already beginning to thicken the quality of the guanciale could not be ignore, a small portion going a long way and leaving ample room for the substantial secondi of force-meat stuffed leg beneath crisp pork atop toothsome polenta sopping up the bird's juices.  Never one to skimp on sweets but in this rare case with eyes on my appetite's future it was between a duo of selections that I debated and again turning tableside for recommendations my assumption proved true, a rich almond and cornmeal cake as soft as pudding arriving five minutes later with slight grassy notes from the gelato proving a deft foil to sweet stone fruits.
author: Michael U.

description:
Locanda delivers on multiple levels.  It's rare to find a restaurant where each menu item consistently blows you away like Locanda does. The chefs have put immense efforts to ensure each dish has unique ingredients that artfully compliment the other flavors in the dish, keep the menu fresh & interesting, and make for a superb delivery!   I don't exaggerate or hyperbole when I say there is a superb delivery here----  to put it lightly, the food kicks ass here in a way so many other would-be fine/semi-fine dining restaurants cannot add up to.

   So often, after I pay the huge bill of some fine restaurant, I think something like, "Well, that was pretty good... not exactly amazing considering the price though!"--- Locanda left my entire party talking about the food and how great it was.   There is also a bar which serves craft cocktails with skilled bartenders making the drinks, which adds to the fun.

Of what we ordered, the most memorable dishes include (in English as I remember, not as written on menu): Green tomato soup, Lamb Ragu Orchiette pasta, Steak Au Jus ****MY FAVORITE*****,  Lemon/Garlic King Salmon, grilled little gem salad.  Friend loved the octopus but I don't like it, and the radishes in anchovy butter was a bit odd.... not my ideal item, but certainly memorable and different.

Definitely recommend you check out Locanda--- it's a hidden gem that deserves more recognition than it has gotten so far.
author: James M.

description:
This is a review of the bar only.  I've actually never eaten here.

One word. The Prince.  If you're into whiskey and bourbon, you'll thank me.  Best cocktail on Valencia street. Easily.
author: Chima N.

description: This is one of the best Italian restaurants in SF!  I always get the burrata bread as a starter - then would recommend any of the pastas, or the bavette steak (or the pork chop.)  The service is excellent.  This place is very modern Italian, so if you're looking for something more traditional, I'd head to North Beach.
author: Jenn T.

description:
Meh, over rated and over priced. There are about a million options for Italian food in SF and I was really underwhelmed with this meal. I went with four friends and we shared everything, the asparagus and brussels sprouts side dishes were far and away my favorite. The carbonara was just ok, the crab pasta was good but not great. I'm more than happy to spend a decedent amount of money on good food and good wine but I just feel like their food wasn't that great. 

The waitstaff over all was nice and engaging. The sommelier, however, was a total pretentious prick. He could not have been less helpful. The wine list was comprised solely of Italian wines which is great, but not being as familiar with Italian wines we asked for help. He seem bothered to be at our table and kept making condescending comments; I was not a fan of his.

Overall, ok food with a decent environment but with all the choices in SF this just did not hold up to the competition. No need to go back again.
author: Lizzy U.

description:
The only thing I liked was the pistachio avocado salad - very original.
Although I will say that the salad looked like a green slop, so not very enticing until I took the first bite.
After that it was downhill.
The fried onions were too greasy.
The 'blanco pizza' was terrible - creamy and tasted like mayo on dark toast - seriously.
The lamb ragu is definitely not worth ordering - ever - very little flavor and sauce - very dry and the amount of meat in my portion was minimal - If I can make a better lamb ragu then I give the place a poor rating.
The pasta that went with the lamb was a very poor choice - maybe in a saucy version, it may be interesting but it made the meal very heavy on starch rather than lamb - the lamb got lost in the dish - bad chef.

The dessert choices were chocolate cake and cheesecake - the manager needs to fire the pastry chef right away - the flavors were off balance. just like the meal.

I  will not go back.
This place will not last very long unless they change the chefs.
Good opportunity for a better foodie place in the Mission once this place closes.
author: Faisal M.

description:
This place sets the bar as a prime illustration of the new wave of restaurants that have hit the SF scene. We have all come to expect incredible food quality, passionate creative chefs, and beautiful decor. But what has excited me the most the last couple years has been the focus on the little things, particularly the return of the well made cocktail. Yes, you can make your jokes about mixologists all you want, but the fact is that when you see your initial order (typically a drink) have meticulous detail and love poured into a glass, it sets your ego on fire and you begin your evening on cloud 9.

Locanda, in my opinion, is the new bar that all others should strive to meet or exceed. Their service is Nordstrom like, with subtly like bar transfers to your table without asking, the drinks are surreal, the pastas are not earthly, and the service continues to surprise throughout the meal.

Decor and atmosphere are perfect creating a lively ambiance.

Oh, and a wood fire grill in the open kitchen, fabulous!
author: Darin A.

description:
I give this is a solid "meh". Appetizers were good, dessert was excellent, entrees bland and the service was not very good. Plus, our table was back in the corner, next to the arctic wind.

They wouldn't turnoff the A/C (even though it was 43 outside), so they threw a scarf over the vent on the floor under our table. This did nothing. I put my messenger bag and giant wool coat over it, which made it bearable. However the lip gloss in my coat pocket was frozen by the end of our meal. (Seriously)

Our waitress was great when she was there, but that wasn't very often. We had to flag random people down for water (twice). It wasn't event full house - I think our spot in the frozen corner wasn't helping. 

Considering all of the above plus how hard it was to get a reservation at a reasonable time, I won't be going back.
author: Rachel R.

description:
I have wanted to come to Locanda for a long time because my former roommate raves about this place, and she's a great cook. So I finally made it over and just finished dinner here with a friend that is Italian, and it got his seal of approval! He was impressed by the authenticity of several Roman dishes. We had:

-Bianca Burrata: I liked this a lot - deliciously creamy burrata.
-Artichoke: Very tasty
-Puntarelle: My friend was impressed by seeing this item on the menu because puntarelle is hard to find he said. The dish was lovely - it's a crunchy, celery-like vegetable but more mild. I don't usually eat anchovy but it was light and not overpowering at all. 
-Tonnarelli Cacio e Pepe: This was actually the most mediocre. It was a bit bland and the pasta was meh. 

Overall, I was quite full and we had a very nice meal. I'm glad that I finally got to try it!
author: Veronica H.

description:
My wife and I went to Locanda after hearing some rave reviews from friends. Our friends didn't lie.  The food was absolutely fantastic, along with our server. 
Starting off with deep fried olives stuffed with fontina cheese to their white pizza as starters. The salad was comprised of beautifully prepared and seasoned vegetables along with ricotta cheese. We opted for the fresh fish of the day (cod) grilled. It was spectacular. Flavorful, wonderful seasoning.  Overall a great experience.  We will be back!
author: Harold B.

description:
Locanda has consistently impressed me with their delicious offerings.
The fried olives and Jewish-style artichoke are must-haves, and no matter the dish you order for your primary course, I'm sure you'll be satisfied. I've been here three times now, and I've been delighted each time with the dishes I've ordered.
author: Jonathon W.

description:
Good food and value!

The appetisers are big enough to share four persons if you just want a taste. Had the steak entree which was cooked and seasoned perfectly.
author: Alberte K.

description:
We loved the environment from the moment we walked in - the hostess was friendly, and the bartender was energetic and smiling, taking our drink order immediately and leading us to guzzle down more than a few fabulous drinks. We sat down at precisely our reservation time, and were accosted (gently) by the waiters/waitresses seconds after each drink ran dry. An easy way to pay the bills Locanda! But the drinks were DELICIOUS, so I didn't mind...

The FOOD. 
FRIED OLIVES: meh. I had a different idea of what these would be like. It seemed very...frozen food section.

JEWISH STYLE ARTICHOKE: an artichoke fried to the edge of burning. Very little flavor. More like a crispy, near-burnt, bunch of artichoke chips. Which is what it was. Poor ordering on our part. At $7 per tiny artichoke, not at all worth it. 

RIGATONI CARBONARA: decent, and with tiny bits of decadent guanciale (think delicious salty FAT with salty crispy bacon on top). It wasn't too soupy like others have described, but certainly wasn't up to Rome standards (but what can be?). We ate all of it. Rich and satisfying. 

BUCATINI AL AMATRICIANA: another Rome favorite - and again, what can live up to bucatini in Rome? This dish was again saved by the greedy bits of pork fat, which (what a surprise) can elevate just about any dish. 

Overall, decent service, not outstanding - good at refilling drinks but not at checking up on their patrons during the meal. I did not enjoy the appetizers in the slightest, and the pastas were solid, but not mind-blowing.
author: Sylvie C.

description: This saved our night   After dining elsewhere and not being able to eat  the food we came here.  Loved everything.  Great service and comfortable.
author: George B.

description:
I tried the Shaved Artichokes, Rigatoni alla Carbonara, and Grilled Corn. The pasta was great, and I really liked the corn (made with sweet chili and ricotta salata), but all the portions were really small -- I'm pretty sure my friends were still hungry afterwards. I loved my cocktail, the Church (aperol, gin, cocchi americano, lemon)! Beautiful presentation and soo delicious! 

Overall, great atmosphere. It's a little pricey for the portions given though, which I didn't really expect in the Mission. Head over to Delfina (same owner) instead to fill your tummy with more generous portions!
author: Rose Y.

description: Excellent food and service.  We had the fried olives, escarole, and radishes which were all really good.  I had the Dungeness crab pasta with uni butter (I was sold on the uni butter) which was fantastic and well worth returning to have again.  The bread was also very good. So glad I finally got to try this place!
author: Debbie L.

description:
My visit with friends for dinner today re-re-inforced my opinion on Italian restaurants in SF: skip them. Anything that tastes equal to less good than decent Italian pasta from the supermarket prepared correctly with a decent sugo from a jar is not worth a restaurant visit or $17+ for a small plate. The "RIGATONI alla CARBONARA - guanciale, Tully Dolci egg, pecorino, black pepper" were undercooked, showed the hard edges that happen when you over-do the microwave and the sauce was curdled, almost dry-stuck and had an off taste - an absolute no-no. Al dente is right - "al dentiste" is too hard. The "BELLWETHER CRESCENZA TORTELLI - chanterelle mushrooms, mint, pine nuts" - easily went back as well uneaten; my daughter loves tortellini - she calls them "huggies" because they hug their "arms" - not these ones. I tried them - not something you want to eat.

The server was extremely supportive (as if she knew this may happen), took both Italian dishes back and brought me a great American style rare cooked steak - that was really good meat. She brought a big steak knife; 15 seconds later the next server took it away, the next server brought it again and I had a decent dinner. I was even asked if all was OK now. 

There are many excellent Latino restaurants from basic to exclusive allover the Mission - make the pasta yourself and explore how great good pasta with simple ingredients can be at home.
author: Flo B.

description:
Great spot. Cozy atmosphere and very friendly staff.

I had the orecchiette (probably spelling it wrong) with broccoli rabe, capers, and sausage. It was delicious. The Jewish artichoke appetizer was also delicious.

The cookie plate (chocloate espresso and coconut lemon macaroon) was lovely. 

Really enjoyed this place.
author: Nicole G.

description:
Awesome spot! It's a small spot, so by the time we left it was pretty loud.
Started with a margarita on the rocks. It was super yum
First course: Artichoke, great flavor
Second course: Lamb Ragout, excellent
Third course: Pine nut slice of pie, very good

Also tried my friends Cauliflower soup which had amazing flavor! Portions are smaller than probably normal, but it worked for my size of appetite that day.

Overall, great place! I'd recommend to friends.
author: Stephanie S.

description:
I can't say enough good things about locanda. Finally reviewing after eating dinner there as opposed to just visiting the bar. 

Dinner was fantastic - warm bread and brussel sprouts to start. Pasta with broccoli rabe and sausage was so wonderful (and so hard to find in sf!)

Now for the bar. Bartenders are so knowledgeable and friendly.  I love how they'll listen to your feedback and then get creative on your next drink. Most recently tried the steam shandy - excellent!  Oh, and old fashioned flights..
author: Christine O.

description: I went there with a bunch of friends (total 6). We ordered cocktails (the church and the prince), and steak, lamb, pork chop, Mezze Manichei and one other pasta dish that I don't recall. My pork chop was extremely salty that it wasn't edible. When I asked for some bread because the pork was too salty, she asked me if I want to order something else. I declined her offer with a hope that the bread would neutralize the salty pork, but it didn't help. I managed to eat 1/3 and stopped. My friends didn't say much about their dish either. We also ordered BOMBOLONI and they were OK too. I had a really bad stomach afterwards, and didn't eat much for the next few days to recover from it. Very pricy and just not impressive in any dish we ordered.
author: Jade J.

description:
It is amazing how so many good ingredients and ideas can be assembled to such ill effect.  The cocktail menu is famous, and is one of the most uninspiring famous cocktail menus I've looked at in a while.  We decided to try their "flights" of Negronis (aperol, luxardo, campari) and Old Fashioneds (rye, bourbon, scotch).  Two of them (aperol, and shockingly, scotch) were drinkable.  Everything else was unpleasant, some in interesting ways and some in uninteresting ways.  I felt like I'd just judged a mediocre episode of Top Chef: cocktail.

We expected to be a little more comforted by the food.  The halibut appeared to have once been a delicious piece of fish, rendered bland and uninteresting by its tour through the oven.  The borlotti beans were good, as borlotti beans are, but no better than the ones I make at home.  The pastas were pleasantly toothsome, but not terrible memorable.  A side of peas and shoots was treated as an afterthought.  

This surprisingly uninspiring array was accompanied by an even more uninspiring series of wine-pairings.  We wanted our server's advice.  We begged for our server's advice.  (If there's a sommelier around, he/she wasn't in evidence.)  Our server delivered up three glasses, one of which was so awful we rejected it out of hand, and most of which were shockingly unpleasant when paired with their suggested dishes.

The prices and the vibe suggest that you are in an excellent, trendy establishment.  But something misfired for us.  Repeatedly.  

This is the Mission.  Go elsewhere.  At random, if you must.
author: William B.

description:
Been excited to try this place out for quite a while, as a Delfina spin-off it had to be pretty good right? Well...mostly.

Set in the dank and dirty Mission (I always feel like I'm in Tijuana when I venture here) which I like to label the gourmet ghetto, this place has a nice clean and hip atmosphere - perfect for hipsters aka wannabe cool people who truly have little substance.

Anyhow, the food was pretty good and I give it some major props for having valet because even though I'm not worried about walking around this 'hood, I still would rather have my car close by than park blocks away and possibly have my car peed on.

The jewish style artichokes was very tasty in the sense that artichoke is generally nasty. They made it pretty good with its salty flavor. I wouldn't order this again if I came here but it's worth a one time try (and more if you truly are dying for it).
