The lamb ragu pasta was absolutely delicious if you're into the whole lamb flavor and tomatoes. Dessert with the apple zeppole was definitely worth it too.

I give this place three stars because it's pretty good. Not one of my favorites but still good...and definitely not 5 star for me.
author: Julia P.

description:
Yay! Another favorite spot in the Mission. Locanda is definitely a popular spot for mission hipsters. I've been there a few times now, and I must say I had a really great first impression on my first visit.

My friend and I split the tripe and the grilled ricotta/arugula salad. The tripe was super  delicious and comforting. The tomato sauce that came with it was sooo yummy! They know how to make sauce ;) The texture of the tripe was perfect too; not too chewy.
The ricotta salad was good too but nothing special. I had also tried the oxtails and the fried sweetbread/artichokes, and both are wonderful.

For the primi, we split the linguini with the dungeness crab. The pasta was cooked perfectly, and it had a pretty good amount of crabs. However, this is not my favorite pasta dish in the menu. My favorite is probably the fettuccini with rabbit sugo. It was more flavorful because, again,  they know how to make sauce!

And for my secondi, I had the fish. I don't remember exactly what kind of fish it was but it tasted great; cooked perfectly, crispy skin. The fish dish was pretty light so I would recommend this if you want to order the pasta but you also want to try their non-pasta dishes.

The cocktails are great here too. The bar closes at 1 am! 

I don't think Locanda has the best pasta dishes in the city but it's  definitelly one of my favorite spots in the city.
author: Sam M.

description: Great atmosphere. Food is ok but definitely over priced maybe the location. If you are not too picky on Italian food but look for great atmosphere and service, it's your spot.
author: Tracy D.

description: The service was great, all the waiters were really nice and made some recommendations. The food itself was really good too even if it was kind of expensive for what we had in our plates... My husband was still hungry at the end of his meal! But overall the place looks nice, the service is great and the food is amazing so I would definitely recommend this place.
author: Claire T.

description:
I got to try a few of the apps and some pasta. The service was really good but I felt the food could have been tastier. 

The highlight of the meal for me was the prosciutto plate with the fresh baked bread. The bread was really good, but its kind of hard to mess up something like prosciutto. 

Overall It wasn't bad but I am not in a huge rush to go back.
author: Joshua K.

description:
Solid, really solid. A great blend between a traditional trattoria and an upscale foodie restaurant. 

I really enjoyed the charcuterie and the wonderful cheese selection. A nice wine mix as well.

What made this place, I am a sucker for good service, was the extremely attentive table service and the host who got us (a walk-in two top on a busy Wednesday night) table in less than 5-minutes.
author: Wayne C.

description:
I had heard great things about this place and was excited to eat here. The ambiance is really fun for a weeknight and I got to sit against the window which I always like because it gives you the best view of what's going on inside. 

We had a pasta dish, some vegetables and another dish (the fact that I can't remember shows that they weren't incredibly noteworthy). The real showstopper was the whole trout (see picture). Now that's something I'd come back for! Anyplace that grills fish with the head and tail on wins major points.
author: Cath L.

description: WOOD GRILL This is the over riding theme Almost everything has the familiar wood grill smell & taste.... Fish, turnips, chicken, potatoes & of course now my clothes. This is not stated on the menu so ask specifically if you care.
author: K. M.

description: As good as it gets... Truly! Went with one of my favorite foodie couples and pretty much tried everything on their menu.  I know there are plenty of fantastic options in the Mission and this would be one of the top ones to try in my book.  Drinks, atmosphere, cuisine... the triple treat place.  You can't go wrong with the pastas, definitely have the flat bread, and if you are into prosciutto that melts in your mouth then by all means, order two.  I'm still looking back at the meal and I promise you, it's the not all the El Guapo talking.
author: Zin M.

description:
I'm Italian-challenged. I had NO idea what most of these menu items were.  Luckily, our server was kind enough to make a few recommendations for us, and we weren't disappointed. Here's what we had, in English--

Appetizers:
-Salad with grilled ricotta cheese and avocados. Surprisingly refreshing. This was a bit more "Californian" than Italian.
-Fried Artichokes and Sweetbreads - Loved this one. By the way, do sweetbreads remind anyone else of chicken nuggets?

Pastas: 
Spaghetti (tortelli?) with some milk-based sauce. Simple, yet great. The pasta was done al dente, just the way I like it.
Also had the lamb radiatore (yet another pasta shape). I love gamey meat, and this lamb sauce was very flavorful. Usually, mint is used to lessen the gamey-ness of the lamb flavor, but I felt like the slight hint of mint used here actually enhanced it. Loved it!

Fish:
Salmon - Not overcooked, and moist on the inside. I actually prefer it even more rare, but it was pretty good.

Cocktails:
Church, Business Thyme, Ciociara. All solid.


Nothing we had stood out as special, but it was a solid meal. A bit pricey after all that we ordered, considering the relatively small portions, so I'm not sure how often I'll come over here, but the place has a great vibe and I wouldn't mind revisiting, eventually.
author: Kazu O.

description:
This place is pretty yummy!
 Front desk:had two awesome ladies who were super friendly! 

Our server was in top of it- the food didn't come out too fast when we placed our orders, which was one thing I was concerned... Still eating appetizers and chatting and the main course swings in can be overwhelming and not as enjoyable. She was super attentive, and I never had to ask for anything.

Bar: drinks were awesome. Guy was super friendly as well. 

Overall an awesome experience, will def. be back
author: Nadine F.

description: We enjoyed a great Christmas Eve feast of the seven fishes in the intimate setting at Locanda. Customers and staff all seemed to enjoy the event. House made  panettone (dessert) was so good we bought one to take home for Christmas morning.
author: Jeff N.

description:
Though the service is hit or miss, Locanda is one of my favorite restaurants in the city. Cool yet low-key vibe, typically creative yet wholly enjoyable food that walks the line between Haute fare and Italian comfort without ever meandering into "heavy."
before a night on Valencia with your crew, this is a great place to start your night.
author: Ross S.

description: Dinner at Locanda whole fish cook aqua pazza is fantastic and a must have. Make sure you bring a date or someone you feel comfortable to share this dish as it way to big just for one person. The cauliflower soup with chili oil was a great starter as well. It was savory , warming and just satisfying. It was a great dinner out and truly enjoyable and worth the struggle of parking.
author: P C.

description: The last two visits to Locanda were simply wonderful. Exceptional service, great wines and pastas, and the grilled whole fish is to die for. You get what you pay for at Locanda. Courses are paced perfectly, the food is excellent, and the service is top-notch.
author: Mona B.

description: Food and drinks are just fantastic. We had a large party of ladies and our server couldn't be more on it and fantastic .I can't even remember the best dish because they all felt that awesome.The drinks are delightful.I can't wait to come back here hopefully sooner than later.
author: Lauren V.

description:
Wow! It's been a long time since I had such good food eating out. Seriously good comforting food from start to finish. And not that pricey either. 

Breakdown:
- 4 women
- 4 glasses of wine (single glasses)
- a bottle of wine brought with us + corkage fee $18
- shared starters - sweetbreads, jewish style artichokes x 2 (only 2 per order), salad
- shared mains: mixed grill, lamb ragu pasta, rabbit sugo pasta
- shared sides: dragon tongue beans, charred peppers
- shared desserts: chocolate cake, straus yogurt budino
total: $73 per person including tax and tip

Everything was delish but I highly recommend both the sweetbreads and the artichokes. I know not everyone is into sweetbreads but I swear, if you didn't know what you were eating you might never guess. 

It's that good. 

The jewish-style artichokes were also amazing. I've never had them prepared that way before. I enjoyed the mixed grill but my heart belongs to the pasta. Both were amazing. Desserts were good too but if I had to do it over again I might pass up dessert to finish off the pasta plates.
author: Jean K.

description: Had a wonderful meal here the other evening at their Sicilian night! They featured some classic Sicilian dishes and Aetna wines. Having been to Sicily I have to say they did a fabulous job. Brava Delfina!
author: Sandy G.

description: Food was delicious but service was poor. Wait staff not at all friendly and incorrectly took our drink order for which we waited an additional 15 minutes to arrive, and when it finally did after asking for it, it was wrong. Ordered a side to accompany a main dish which arrived as we were finishing our mains. Disappointing overall.
author: Ali C.

description:
Our party of five strategically invaded Locanda. We love efficiency so three friends arrive early to grab seats by the bar and their reward was cocktails (which the latecomers paid for including yours truly). Team spirit tastes like gin.

Locanda is crazy crowded in a good way. Two eye candy bartenders (both tattooed & wearing suspenders) were attentive, answered our food and beverage questions. 

Out of the appetizers & entrees shared, what made me groan were the Jewish style artichoke (creative play), the pizza bianca w/ bellwether ricotta & fava beans (love fava beans), the rabbit sugo (juicy and flavorful) ,and the lamb ragu (warm & inviting).

Out of three desserts we tried, nothing stood out, definitely bypass.

For drinks, my favorite was the bourbon & maple (smooth and easy)  from the old fashioned flight.
author: Sophie C.

description: Overpriced mediocre food. My pasta was hard not al dente. The steak was salty. The lobster was slightly rubbery. Oh and the meat in my pasta was scarce almost like bacon bits instead of whatever it was supposed to be. Our experience was so awful I had to make some sort of review. I've lived in NY and had better street vendor food. The appetizers were ok if not the best part of the meal.
author: Ted E.

description:
Still love this place and will keep coming back. 

Great cocktails, really lovely and seamless service, the apps were delicious (the oxtail suppli and fried olives were amaze). 

However, I do think their pasta has gone down ever so slightly in quality. They are still good, but I used to inhale their pastas. Now I'm like.. this is a solid orecchiette. Some were a little salty.

They welcomed our toddler and were super accommodating with our slightly larger party despite the crowd and the small spaces.
author: Subie C.

description:
One of my new favorite restaurants and I go out to eat. alot!!

My friend and I decided not to make a reservation and just try and get a seat at the bar. We got there around 6:30 on a Thursday night and lucked out because we only waited about 10 minutes before a couple left. 

The food was delicious!
What we ordered:
1) Jewish artichokes - if you like artichokes, you will love this. Crispy and savory.
2) Duck egg w/asparagus - My friend's fave dish. The egg was delightful and the butter sauce was good. Dip your bread in the leftover egg + sauce mixture. You won't be sorry.
3) Pizza bianca. 3 choices but we got the one with califlower. Delish! A little spicy too which i enjoy. If you dont like spicy food, maybe you should get one of the others..
4) Entree - Rigatoni alla Carbonara - Super rich. I mean, honestly, I couldnt finish it. It was sooo thick and meaty even though you couldn't really see the meat in it. I think it was the sauce. Really heavy and might make you sick if you eat it all. Just saying.
5) Entree - Bavette Steak - $26?? Um sorry not worth the price. It was good, but not $26 good. Plus the sauce tasted like hot dog. Don't believe me? Try it. 

All in all a good meal. Next time I go, i might pass up the entrees all together or at least try another pasta. The appetizers and small plates were the WOW-factor for me and this restaurant. Plus, with all the food we got plus 2 drinks ($10 each), the bill came out to $102 for 2 people!! Everything adds up. You order this and that and booom, a fatty bill so be careful.

Will have to remove a star for the price. Sorry! :(

BUT what I really really appreciated from this restaurant was the customer service. World class. The bartenders were really friendly and looked like they really really enjoyed making drinks :)

Also, as we were walking out, a gentleman stopped us and said that he worked for the sister restaurant Delfina and wanted to let us know that there was a stabbing in the area recently and wanted us to be safe. That made me feel really good because they honestly care for their patrons.
author: Cicely T.

description:
Thinking to have something special for dinner on Sunday, we ordered takeout from Locanda through Postmates.  Words cannot describe how sad we were when the food came.  The portions are TINY TINY TINY and slopped into large paper takeout containers (no, not even the wax lined ones) that make them look even smaller.  Miniscule, beyond small portions.  The sauce soaked into the containers, so icky.  Food has never looked so pitiful.

We paid $70 for three dishes that would all fit on a single plate TOGETHER.  A cheapo lunch plate from any neighborhood Chinese place (two options and rice) gives you more food than OUR WHOLE MEAL.  Booooo.  We've never been so disappointed and mad when getting food from what's supposed to be one of the best restaurants in the city.  Sure, it's "typical SF prices" for the food, but each of the dishes is 50-70% smaller than a typical portion size is, even in SF.

The one pro is the taste...kinda.  We ordered an app: TRIPPA alla ROMANA, a pasta: RADIATORE "PECORA e PECORINO, and a "special": BERKSHIRE PORCHETTA.  The radiatore tasted pretty good - the lamb was well cooked and tasty, the pasta was meh.  The porchetta too, though a bit fatty and not all that well composed.  You can't enjoy it much when there's just a bunch of fatty meat and nothing to balance it with.  And I like fatty meat.  I'd pass on the trippa next time...while the sauce was tasty and the tripe tender, you can only eat a couple bites before you don't want to have this anymore.

Sigh.  Locanda, we had high hopes, but you've let us down :(  You've got to put out larger portion sizes and pack your food in better containers.  We don't expect great value, but we do expect to be full at the end of the meal.

Yelpers - take my advice and go eat somewhere else if you are hungry.  If you want to try interesting Italian-inspired dishes and don't mind following it up with a real meal afterwards (burger, burrito, pizza, anything!), then head over to Locanda.
author: Connie L.

description:
This is a nice spot in The Mission that gets pretty busy. I'd get a reservation or you might get lucky with a spot at the bar.

The food and drinks here are exquisite. Just for the food, I would give this spot like 4.5 stars. The only thing I didn't like about it are the portions. Perhaps this is just the American in me speaking, always wanting more. I mean, I ordered 4 items (2 dishes and 2 beers) just for myself, and I wasn't really full. Basically what I am saying is that you might not be full after this meal so if you're super hungry--so plan accordingly.

I ordered:
1) Jewish Style Artichokes - Not worth it, nothing unique (maybe just an interesting presentation, but for sure not worth $8).
2) Linguini (dungeness crab, lettuce and sorrel) - It was good, the sauce was yummy, but the portion wasn't as big as I hoped. Worth $23? No.
3) The complementary Pizza Bianca was awesome.

Anyway, they had some pretty awesome beers and cocktails. Try the Smoke & Spice Cocktail--it smelled/tasted like inhaled anesthesia!

The service sucked. The servers were very apologetic about everything that happened but that doesn't change the fact that there is bad service. We got our food very late and even the people sitting next to me, who arrived after, got their food first. There were also lots of other little mistakes so that made the experience weak. I guess this is what happens when it's busy, but still.
author: Marlon T.

description:
Christmas dinner with my girlfriends!
8:30 reservation on Friday and we were seated promptly. Seated in the back corner of the restaurant, there was a very cold draft coming from what I think is an A/C machine? It was weird. We asked our server to be reseated and basically thought I was retarded for wanting to move. Anyways, got seated closer to the front of the restaurant. Much better! and no draft! He could of been nicer though- jeez.

Started with some cocktails and the jewish artichoke (Focaccia came along as well). The artichoke leaves were delish. The meaty part was eh.

We shared the Brussels Sprouts, Lamb Shank, and Rigatoni Carbonara. Sprouts were cooked perfectly. Shank was fall off the bone. Carbonara was ok. The sauce was kind of gluey :(

Overall, it was ok. Not memorable by any means. Don't think I would come back.
author: Angela D.

description:
WOW WOW WOW. Blown away. I'm not one to 5-star a place upon my first visit (or Yelp a first time for that matter) but this experience was perfection from start to finish in every manner, so...

I had my reservation for 2 months and was counting the weeks. The service is top notch: hostess beyond friendly/professional and our server was very helpful with the simple YET sinful menu, i.e., "Holy smokes. Everything looks GOOD. What do I order?" Our server i.e. navigator to the rescue.

My dinner date and I did the sharsies game and here's what we ordered, all fantastic: Jersualem artichoke, pizza bianco w/fig + prosciutto (OMG... incredible), grilled sweetbreads with chicken + artichoke (my first time - INSANE), whole wheat spaghetti w/pecorino + nettle + olives, rigatoni carbonara with prosciutto (very light and tasty) and finally... a plum tart with vanilla gelato (to die for). 

I have another reservation in September and I'm already salivating. Thank you Locanda - keep up the *incredible* work - both front and back of house.
author: Meredith R.

description:
Love this place. One of the best bar services in SF. Cocktails are top 5 in SF. Food never disappoints. Jewish artichoke, fried olives, any other recommendations from the bartenders are always amazing. 

AND, you can usually get in with a little notice. 

Always my fav. Keep it up wonderful staff and kitchen!
author: Jenny M.

description:
I came here with some friends to have a birthday dinner and had a very good experience. The restaurant is attractive and friendly, and the wait staff was helpful.

As for the food, I had relatively high expectations having just come back from a family trip to Italy, and the pasta here definitely met the mark. We tried a few different pastas, and each had a very unique and interesting flavor. The table's favorite was definitely the agnolotti. The pasta portions were somewhat disappointly small, but I suppose that is what I ought to expect from this sort of restaurant. But our stomachs were filled anyhow by the amazing bread they serve... although this "bread" is better labeled as more of an extremely buttery and salty focaccia. Not that I'm complaining, they were delicious.

We also had a fruity, creamy spongecake dessert that was delightful. It provided a few perfect bites to end the meal.
author: Danny H.

description: The food I had was jaw-droppingly good, shared with 4 other friends. Thought I was pretty privy on Italian wines til I saw this wine list. Learned so much, had an amazing experience, great staff and again, superb ambiance!
author: Ann L.

description:
This review is mostly for the bar.  We stopped here for some post-dinner drinks on a Friday night and were lucky enough to steal a couple bar stools.  

The ambience is really lively and warm, which I really enjoyed.  My boyfriend and I end up staying for quite a while, sampling some of their delicious cocktails!  The bartenders are all very attentive and amicable.  Even though we had just eaten dinner next door, we couldn't help but order a couple of their bar snacks.  We tried the copiette, which is basically a strip of pork jerky, and the tomato salad - both of which were really tasty.  

Good vibe, friendly staff, and great cocktails - I can't wait to come back and try it out for dinner!
author: Juliana K.

description:
Solid Roman Italian cuisine. I could not stop eating the radishes with anchovy butter; the freshness of the radishes pair nicely with the briny smoothness of the butter. The bucatini and rigatoni dishes were lightly sauced and perfectly al dente. 

The restaurant has a buzz and energy. It's certainly a worthy option for a night out in the Mission.
author: Michelle F.

description:
Solid good restaurant. Tuesday evening and wanted to catch up with one of my good friends. 

Had: 
*Jewish style artichoke (crispy fried and lovely, looooved the heart of it, yummm, no wonder it's all over the Yelp reviews as you MUST try it) 
* Fried egg with smoked pancetta (this was also really good, you break the fried egg over the lettuce and pancetta and mmm, it also hit the spot) 
* Rigatoni alla carbonara (heavy from the cream and egg yolk but this is expected from carbonara, I wouldn't have it any other way, took some home to the bf and he loved it too) 
* Grilled corn (niiiiiiice side, smokey grilled, loved it) 
* Ricotta fritta (mmm, gone in seconds even though we were tilting full). 

Nice service, our waitress answered all our questions, drinks were a-ok - overall, good solid dining experience and would be back if I'm in the area.
author: Maile N.

description:
DID I JUST READ "WARM LAMB TONGUE??"
(4.5 Stars)

Osteria = wine and simple foods. Somebody better update wikipedia... Lamb brains, lamb tongue, pig cheeks (awh piglet), rabbit (awh thumper).... yah my eyes were not deceiving me. On another note, there were some unforeign dishes like pasta. And when i mention pasta, "interesting" pasta and also fresh made pasta noodles (awesomeness). Kept my meal vegetarian =)

- Food, F'n delicious
- Portions, booshie style (smaller servings)
- Prices, on the higher end
- Service, on point (they knew their stuff)
- Ambiance, simple, elegant, and "hipster"

Looking at the menu prior to our dinner i said to myself "fried lamb brains and artichoke" Then I saw that the menu changes up EVERYDAY and another day saw "warm lamb tongue". But they must be doing something right if they are getting all these HIGH RATINGS.

Workaholics need a life too. It's been awhile since I've had one of these "homegirls night out" and we've decided to put on some heals, get some dinner, and kick it! One of my girlfriends threw out Locanda and this has been booked mark on yelp for some time for me. Finally, a chance to indulge. We were in the right spot, the atmosphere was defiantely the kind of crowd we were looking for.

We arrived, good luck getting reseverations the day of and the day before. We chanced it and did a walk-in. 1-1.5hr wait, no place to wait but between people's tables. Is it worth it? we were destined to find out. Such a beautiful restaurant and love how the staff can wear whatever they want. You think walking into a venue like that the staff would be uniformed; but that's what i love. Definately, they are the touch and taste of the mission. As people may call it "hipster" as i call it "dopeness". Not sure why people are bitching int heir reviews about noisy level, when is a restaurant suppose to use a 6" inch voice?

HEFFER-STYLE STATUS.

Didn't try anything off the walls. My palate was not for it but did try new amazing dish that have put this place on the top list for me. Sorry, forgot to take pictures.

PIZZA BIANCA - this was one of the best breads i've ever had served before a meal. SO GOOD. Best damn carbs to stuff my face with. I can't explain it, you just have to go there.

JEWISH STYLE ARTICHOKE ($6/each) - We ordered this because just about everyone yelping was mentioning it. And thank god we got some. This was SO delightful. Finely sliced fresh basil resting ontop of a medium-sized fried artichoke. The artichoke was perfectly fried and the crisp on the outside reminded me of a potatoe chip! aaaahhhh i'm craving one right now.

INSALATA MISTICANZA ($9) - 12 greens, aceto, xvoo. This salad by far blew my brains away. It was SO fresh and tasty. And healthy!!! It even had squash blossoms in there that made my salad look so pretty AND yummy.

FIORELLINI ($16) - ricotta, fiorelli, and squash blossoms. By the time it was time to order the main dish, i was stuffed with all of the above items. I was expecting more pasta for my portions but it didnt bother me much because i kew what kind of setting we were in. My pasta was freshly-hand made, shaped into flowers and stuffed with ricotta. OMG YUMMY!!!! It had a creamy light base with squash blossoms. Sorry to sound so sexist but I'm going to admit it, this is such a feminine dish =P

I had anticipated to get some dessert afterwards but i was pretty stuffed from the above items. 

Will I be back? Y-E-S. Who wants to be my date!!! haha
JABA APPROVED.... Until the next review.....
author: Jane A.

description:
Saturday night, the place is packed, but our table was waiting or us, a lot of places lately get it wrong and make you wait anyway even with a reservation.  It was a bit noisy and lacked ambiance, it's a fun place for dinner with friends, not a date night.  

We start out with cauliflower pizza and salad, followed by oxtail and rabbit sugo.   The pizza was light and interesting with great flavor combination, it was more of a flat bread and a great portion for two.  The salad with feta was nice, nothing too special and a bit salty. 

The oxtail was great, falling off the bone, great flavor and braising.  It would have been nice to have some sides with the oxtail for the price.  The rabbit sugo and fettuccine was nice, the pasta was home made, tender, delicious, the rabbit was nice but could have been more tender, and the portion was quite small.  I would expect the other pasta dishes to be great here, and will be coming back to try more of them but they're just not entree size.

We ended the meal with espressos and then moved on to the bar for a Manhattan and scotch.  I love having the full bar at a restaurant, sometimes a glass of wine is just not enough.

I'd definitely come back for another visit with some friends.
author: Inga W.

description:
What hooked me on Locanda is also somewhat of a drawback...I'll explain.  The SO and I were in SF for a night before heading to wine country and were meeting a friend at Locanda before planning to head to Foreign Cinema for dinner, as soon as I walked into Locanda the charcoal grill scent sold me and I told the better-half we should just eat there, it smelled that good.

So, we ended up eating there and it was great.  I would highly recommend the Roman Style Beef Jerky as a quick appetizer, it's cheap and very good...and not something you'll see at a bunch of restaurants.  Two of us had the Radiatore Pecora e Pecorino (aka - Lamb Ragu) as well as Petrale Sole "Scuola Vecchia" - the Ragu was delicious and just the right size.  The presentation of the Sole was gorgeous, and the mussels to go along with it were a nice addition as well.

I have to say, the bread was the highlight, warm and light, covered in Olive Oil - wow - best bread I've had in a long time.

To go back to my opening statement, the food was great, so was the atmosphere and the smells.  However, once you leave the restaurant and head home you realize how much you smell like heavy smoke.  Remember the days when bars weren't smoke free and you'd have to come home and wash all your clothes and shower before turning it as you'd reek of cigarettes?  It's kinda like that, granted the smell is much better (and the food makes it worth it) but I wish it wasn't so overpowering.
author: Lowell P.

description: Everything was amazing. The staff went out of the way to make us happy. The food was absolutely amazing.  The octopus was beautiful as well as the tomato salad. Overall an amazing experience.
author: Steven C.

description:
First, I love the decor in here -- warm and romantic.  Secondly, I LOVE the cocktails -- perfectly balanced and mixed, and who doesn't like giant ice cubes.  Get any one of their spins on a negroni and you'll be happy.  Both the hostess and the waitress we had were definitely warm and friendly, which is not a given in the popular places on Valencia. 

My boyfriend and I split the following:

The asparagus app with the poached egg.  Nearly licked the place it was so good, and the deliciously oily pizza bianca to help soak it up pretty much made the dish.  Whatever that vinaigrette is on the asparagus, it should be bottled and sold.

The carbonara was warm and comforting.  I would have thrown some pepper on it, but I like it like that.  There were nice big chunks of smoky pork, which is always welcome.  It was definitely rich and one portion was more than enough for two people.

Finally, the mixed grill.  I would get this again for the blood sausage alone, which is delicately spiced and has a gorgeous moist (not crumbly!) texture.  The spare ribs may be the weak point because really, there's only so much you can do with spare ribs.  The sweet breads have the most interesting preparation -- never seen them on skewers before, but it works.  And the quail is deliciously and moist.

I would come back here just to drink or for dinner.  The popularity of this place is well deserved.
author: Rachel K.

description:
I am shocked at myself for doing this but Locanda gets the first 5 star rating I have ever given to a restaurant.   Every single thing about the evening was perfect, from the cozy table, to the amount of chair space between other tables, water refill, superb wait staff, and then....the food.  Damn.  I felt lucky.  

I'm from the North East so I am totally biased about Italian food. It usually is loud and big to match the personalities back east. Again...Daaamn

Veal saltimbocca -  positively sublime
Rabbit sugo - packed with bunny! scrumptious  

Appetizer of warm Lamb's tongue had levels of flavor that kept making me smile with every chew. 
The sweetbreads seemed bland until I noticed the slice of lemon to squeeze over them and then BANG the flavors popped like a crazy scary jack-in-the-box, only good.  

Portions seemed so small, yet I left full. Go figure. Very very very pleased.
author: B B.

description:
We love Delfina and Pizza Delfina. So naturally when we learned of Locanda's opening awhile back, we knew we had to try it. Making a reservation is easy. Just go on their website and book the available timeslot. As easy as Open Table (minus the 100 points). 

We had the following:
-Jewish style artichoke (crisply deep fried) 
-Bucatini all'Amatriciana (pasta dish with beef cheeks) 
-Tonnarelli Cacio e Pepe (vegetarian pasta dish with HEAT) 
-Patate Affumicate (oven roasted mashed potatoes)
-Ricotta Frittata (Dolci. Fried ricotta balls *drool*)
-Complimentary Foccacia bread

All were recommended by our awesome waiter. He had a way of making 
us salivate as he went on with his description of each dish. A+
author: Esther A.

description:
Date & Time:  Thursday April 28, 2011 @ 6pm Opening Night
Dining Companion:  The Husband
Scene: Mish 20-40 Something Couples- Girls in Flowy Spring Tops w/ Leggings & Boots Accompanied by Guys in Checked Shirts 
Vibe:  Energetic
Music:  Fun PlayList w/ The Black Keys
Decor:  Urban Meets Rustic.  Open Kitchen, Cut Crystal Chandelier & Edison Lighting, B+W Tiled Walls & Curtains in Main Dining Room, Recycled Wood Floors +Tables & Brushed Aluminum Philippe Starck Stools @ The Bar.  Communal Table, Bench Seating & Tables for Small Groups
Service:  Pretty Hostesses, Friendly Attractive Staff:  Ethan Back from Coachella is Awesome & Adam is Equally Awesome
Imbibe:  Peroni Beer & Cucumber Limeade
Devour:  Poached Egg & Asparagus for Starters, Carbonara w/ Guanciale, Egg, Percorino & Black Pepper, Bavette Steak, Side of Fagioli Cotiche(Beans) & Molten Chocolate Cake
Total:  $87.05
Note:  Brought to You By the Couple of Delfina
author: Genevieve Y.

description:
Went here to treat a friend to a belated birthday. We enjoyed the following:

fried duck egg
oxtail
casarecce pasta
a itatlian ratatouille-type dish - I can't remember the name
and numerous manhattan-esque drinks custom-made by the bartender

Everything was excellent - especially the oxtail! Service was on point and the ambiance was wonderful. I really like what the design team did with the place - the former Las Ramblas. There was an airy quality and the noise level was quite low.

Anyway - I'm chomping at the bit to get back to this place. You'll have to make reservations way in advance. Guess word's been out about this place.
author: Art O.

description:
I'll start by saying I think Locanda has 5 star food.  And while I know some people think that should be the only criteria by which to rate a restaurant, I believe that fine dining is an experience, one for which I am paying for well in excess of the cost of food and labor.  All of this is to say, the service is unnecessarily bad.

What do I mean by unnecessarily?  First, clearly these folks have a bit of experience running a classy restaurant, so even though this particular joint is new, they are not new to the business.  Secondly, the table right next to us (who were seated after us), was getting amazingly attentive service.  It's like they were rubbing it in our face.  I believe the folks next to us were brought bread, wine, and more wine, and were checked on... before our server bothered to even greet us.  The tables were really close, all he would have had to do was pivot, didn't even need to take a single extra step.  We got the distinct impression from the get go that he did not care for us.

But, we tried not to allow his snubbing to ruin our meal.  I thought the Jewish artichoke was great, the fava bean spaghetti inspired, and the ricotta fritta we had for dessert just a joy.
author: Linda L.

description:
I just LOVE Locanda.  I first popped into this restaurant on it's soft opening night on my first night out in the Mission when I had freshly moved to the city.  I was then, and have been ever since, at the beautifully subtle flavors in the pasta dishes, the unique cocktails, the service, the lovely atmosphere, and generally the lovely quality of the meals I've had there!  Both alone and with my fiancé.  I've also brought my parents there for dessert at the communal table.  Love this place!  I think we both probably hold this as our favorite place for a nice meal in the Mission.  
Expect hipster bartenders with tattoos, artisan crafted everything, amazing flavors, interesting cuisine and a really cool, hip atmosphere.
Couldn't be more pleased that I randomly happened upon this place years ago, and that it's still thriving now!
Go Locanda!
author: Gillian K.

description:
(See pics)

More of 3.5 stars for the drinks and appetizer.

A quick note on the reservation. When I looked online as well as calling, I learned that they only have a very very limited number of tables for reservation, like 20% or fewer. When I got there around 6pm, it was 10% full even there were no reservations available until after 10pm. Also, you can sit at the communal table without a reservation. So it's best to just do a walk-in.

Some places are just great for certain dishes and you can't apply the same expectations to the related restaurants. Meant to come here when I heard about the same Delfina owners and had similar expectations as their pizzas.

The bartender's choice of gin drink was simple but was very good, a great way to whet your appetite. The pig ears salad was very refreshing, light with perfect vinegar taste to it. The baked slices of bread was totally excellent. I was definitely hungry and ready to taste the main course.

But the lamb Scottaditto was on the dryer and a bit overcooked that it was burned. It's also a very small portion (2 pieces out of the rack.) The Cesanese pairing which was okay. The great wine pairing guy did give me a Spanish tasting which turned out to be a much better choice.

The cherry Crostata (pie) was okay and the local Four Barrel coffee was very good as usual

I hope to come back and try other dishes such as the pastas. For now I will continue enjoying their delicious pizzas at their other joint.
author: T L.

description:
Had an awesome experience here a few months back. Everything was fantastic. Rabbit, Jewish artichoke, fried olives, duck egg, pastas, wine. Great server. Interior is beautiful, too.

Looking forward to eating here again next time I'm in San Francisco.
author: Brad B.

description:
I'm very picky with Italian food. And this place is the first italian one in SF with really good quality cuisine.

Try: artichoke, osso bucco, ...
author: Philippe M.

description:
When walking in this restaurant, it looks like the interior designer from the store Anthropologie was hired to decorate this restaurant as well! Everything is chic and trendy, including the light fixtures and wallpaper. 

We ordered the fried artichoke heart - this was INCREDIBLE!  I did not know that artichoke hearts could taste so wonderful. The chopped basil on the bottom gave the dish flavor some OOMPH. I would get that again.

For pastas, we shared the Fettuccini rabit - this was a great pasta. I don't think I had tried rabbit up to this day, and it was actually yummy. i felt bad for eating little Peter Rabbit but it was delicious. Another pasta we ordered was Bucatini all'Amatriciana, which our waiter described (in Italian accent!) as a classical pasta. Everyone at the table liked it except for me - the pasta was borderline crunchy! I think I am more of a soft-pasta girl. Also, the cheese was overwhelming me. After eating these two, we decided to order one more since we were still hungry - Rigatoni alla carbonara. I thought this one was pretty good. I wasn't crazy about it though.

For entree, I had the Kampachi. I was looking forward to this fish because not a lot of restaurants serve Kampachi. However, when I took my first bite, it was plain. I tried dipping it in the sauce, but the sauce was also plain. I honestly was extremely disappointed. I salted that fish like crazy in order to get some flavor out of it, still tasted "meh." My boyfriend and his parents got Lamb and Steak though, and those tasted a lot better than mine. I would suggest those if you made a reservation. 

For dessert, we got a fried Ricotta cheese dish, which I really enjoyed. It had a bit of sour taste on the outside, but also sweet from the cheese.  I loved the affogito (not sure how to spell it) - vanilla ice cream drenched with an expresso shot. It was delish!

I wouldn't return. The artichoke was great, the pastas were so-so and the dessert was great. Big things are missing - aka the entrees!  Not worth the price. Eat at Barbacco instead.
author: Jocelyn L.

description:
This restaurant is an insult to San Franciscans. Don't kowtow to restaurants who try to trick you into tolerating ridiculously overpriced and tiny portions of "meh" food because they fancy themselves a high-end eating establishment. Sub-par quality food, rude and incompetent management, and high prices- stay away Mission-ites and San Franciscans, in general! 

First, we ordered the raved-about Jewish-style Artichokes. Seriously, Yelpers? I always trust your judgment, but our table of 6 found them laughable. They were shriveled up, fried to a burnt crisp, and then doused in salt. Gross. They were also tiny. One $8 'choke was the size of my fist, with most of it being the inedible stem. No thanks, Locanda. 

Then came the Stracciatella in Brodo which claimed to have oxtail in it. I even asked the waitress to clarify whether it was similar to an oxtail stew, to which she replied, "Yes." When it came out, it looked and tasted like egg-drop soup in beef broth. Like the kind you get for free at a Chinese restaurant. And no oxtail! Not one shred. It was $9 beef broth with scrambled egg. 

My tablemate ordered the $27 grilled leg of lamb. When that came out, it consisted of 4 strips of lamb on lettuce. I clarify- $27 for 4 THIN strips of lamb and wet lettuce. Are we getting punk'd?  Where's the leg? Doesn't a leg have a bone?At Locanda, it doesn't.

The rest of the table got their pasta dishes, which was 2 cans of Chef Boyardee split into 4 portions. Enough said. 

The manager arrived and I still don't know her name because she never offered it to me. She came over, bent down, and stared at me. I expressed my concerns, and she proceeded to tell me how wrong I was about everything. She even gave me a complimentary Italian lesson on what "stratcciatella," "brodo," "and leg of lamb" means. Wow, thanks! She also told me their food is comparable to the surrounding area. That's hilarious mainly because it's not. Sure, $27 is a comparable price, but broth, boyardee, and meat scraps are not comparable in quantity or quality. I'm not sure why she even bothered coming over. She didn't offer to fix anything; she only encouraged me to order another laughable dish. 

Save your selves, your wallets, and your sanity, and go to any other restaurant in this area: Picaro, Limon, Delfina, Foreign Cinema, Luna Park, Maverick, etc., etc.

/endrant
author: Annie C.

description:
My friend and I stopped here before heading to dinner on a Friday night.  The place was crowded but not overly. We found a seat at the bar and enjoyed some fabulous cocktails. The bartenders were friendly and knowledgeable and were shaking those cocktails away. 
The food passing by looked and smelled delicious.  
Cool vibes, delicious drinks.
author: Lisa T.

description: A mouthgasmic experience! Food was rich, flavorful, and makes me want to come back for more. The burrata pizza Bianca reminded me of my childhood and my mother's homemade toasted bread with the most sensual, creamy, buttery taste. Struck up a conversation with the folks next to us, and we had a fantastic time. All the food was fresh and bursting with layers of flavor, fantastic wine list, and top notch service. We will definitely be back.
author: Mary O.

description:
Locanda is great ! Maybe a bit overrated... But I definitely enjoyed my first dinner here! 

Trippa alla romana is so good! My first time eating tripe and the texture wasn't bad at all plus the sauce was fantastic! 

The leg of lamb was nice, a bit too rare for me but I didn't specify how I wanted it so next time I will. 

The hen wrapped in pancetta was so delicious and juicy! Would recommend that over the lamb. 

We also had a nice pasta dish.. Orecchiette which was of course cooked perfectly. 

The old fashion sampler was awesome! I loved them all ! 

And we had a fantastic red wine... Terre nere Etna rosso - yum :)

Service was great, nice ambiance and overall very good meal!
author: Shanna N.

description:
Locanda deserves a solid 5 stars for checking off the checklist of things I love and expect in a restaurant, and then for going the extra mile. 

Reservations:  I called early Saturday evening for reservations that night and Austin was friendly and candid.  He said it was going to be tough and that his first table wasn't until 10:15, but if they could get us seated earlier they would.  Well, they did.  

Service:  Our waitress was friendly and knowledgeable.  When I asked her a question about the menu that she didn't have the answer to, rather than make something up or blow off my question, she offered to go back to the kitchen and find out.  None of that, "I'm a know-it-all and you're an idiot" attitude that plagues the SF restaurant service industry. 

Food:  From the first bite of the fried artichokes all the way through dessert, Affogato Correto, everything was amazing.  I lived in Rome, Italy for two years and even though I wouldn't call their Italian cuisine totally "authentic", I definitely wouldn't say it was a mistake and get creative by putting a spin on traditional dishes like "Carcioffi alla Judea".  The food was amazing.  

Drinks:  I did something I rarely do and ordered one of their specialty whiskey drinks.  Can't remember what it was called but it was delicious enough to have 3.  

Ambiance:  Lively but not loud, warm but not homely.  

I'll definitely be going back.
author: Ted T.

description:
Best meal in recent memory!  We had a reservation for 5:30 p.m.  We were greeted and promptly seated at a window seat.  We did our homework so knew what we wanted to try.  

The four of us did family style dining which allowed us to try more dishes.

We ordered the following:
*Jewish style artichokes - of everything we had, this was my least favorite.  My fellow yelpers are off on this one.
*carciofi artichoke crudi salad - fresh.
*lamb tongue - yummy yum yum.
*guinea hen leg- crunchy skin and very moist meat.
*trippa (tripe) - wow, nice tomato base sauce to complement the tripe.
*fettucini with rabbit - al dente and plenty of rabbit meat.
*lamb scottadito (2 thin chops) - grilled perfectly.
*grilled halibut collar- flaky.
*warm chocolate cake - dark rich chocolate.
*Ricotta fritta - very memorable.  Deep fried and yummy lemony sauce.

Plenty of delicious focaccia brought on a cute cutting board.  And ask for more to dip your trippa sauce in.

Beverages - house made ginger ale and one bottle of blond beer.

Great dining experience.  Wonderful service and great food.

Plates and flatware changed frequently.  

Our only con - the noise level was like a bomb.  And the background music was unnecessary.

Total tab including tax and tip $240.00.
author: Shirley N.

description:
I'll start with the good, just like our meal did.
The "pizza Bianca" option we chose, the one with prosciutto ( there are some other options ) was really good. It's basically just a few pieces of bread and a few pieces of prosciutto. And they go together wonderfully.
The wine was not memorable, and my mixed drink wasn't either.
The bad part was the entrees. By comparison to the chicken, the steak was superb. Although on its own, it was actually kind of chewy, not very tender, although the taste was good. The chicken, though, was atrocious. It was undercooked and rubbery. "It tasted like a bunch of plastic," according to my friend, who also says "I come from the chicken country" ( Poulet de Bresse ). The "bacon wrapped" part seemed like it wood be a great idea, but it didn't make up for the lack of cooking. I don't mind chicken skin, but my friend who prefers to avoid the fatty chicken skin and likes her bacon crispy, was displeased by the thick, slippery, watery "bacon skin" area. "It was so watery that it removed all the taste."
Anyway, this seems like a nice place for a drink and a pizza Bianca, but not for chicken or steak.
author: Nick B.

description:
I wouldn't quite call it Italian. More your typical SF Californian cuisine using Italian components. 

The fried sweetbreads and artichokes were fantastic. Tender halves of artichoke hearts were the taste of spring mornings, gently enveloped in a delicious, almost airy, crisp. Tossed in the mix were the sweetbreads; they too resided in these perfectly seasoned golden pockets.. The sweetbreads were soft yet bouncy, with a salty creaminess that reminded me of steamed fish milt. Scattered were fried sage and capers, all consumed and without a trace.

For entree, I had the grilled lamb leg with chickpeas and lettuce. Lamb had never associated with the word 'light'; yet somehow, this dish was exactly that. Pink, juicy slices rested on top of mashed chickpeas, adorned by pale emerald greens. It was flavorful yet delightfully refreshing at the same time. The disappointment though, was that the lamb was not well seasoned. It sounds ridiculous to say that it tasted too much of lamb - but it did. And I love gaminess. But this is just a bit single-noted. 

M had the prosciutto wrapped rabbit with gnocchi and grilled lettuce. The prosciutto became too smokey and overpowering; while god, we hardly tasted the rabbit. It could be a piece of chicken and it would have tasted the same. The gnocchi was actually deep fried, which was interesting but not as good as regular creamy gnocchis. 

It was a delightful meal. Not the rustic affair I had anticipated, but a simple, refreshing Californian twist on some old world components. There were small details here or there that needed to be a bit more balanced. Though for the price, I'm not sure if I'd come back.
author: Fiona S.

description:
Love this place!

The staff are wonderful, the food is crazy good and the drinks are stellar!
author: Justyn L.

description:
Buon Gusto!

Small plates, huge flavor.
Chock full of light, bright whites, metals and woods. Modern Euro space.

The space is casual but the food is equally as serious as its older sibling, Delfina. Anne & Craig have done it again.

Dig your fork into at least one dish from each section of the menu, shared with good company. Perfectly executed from scratch. Expect nothing less.

Don't miss:
Revitalizing cocktails (yes, it's possible. Just add crystallized ginger.)
Jewish-Style Artichoke: Fried til perfectly crisp and tender.
Brodo: Skatewing & ceci (chickpea) in broth.
'Lane': (pasta) Rabbit sugo, dandelion greens
Grilled Halibut Collar. Like butter. Looks simple but it's more than meets the eye.
Marmalata Crostata w/buckwheat streusel (crumble) and fior di latte gelato.
Four Barrel Coffee & Mr. Espresso in La Marzocco

Reservations on their site but walk-ins welcome.
Get in now. Bound to be another hot one.

Dinner for two with drinks ~$100 + tip
author: Alissa A.

description:
Locanda has upped it's game, a good restaurant is better than ever.  Great food.  Great service.  Great venue.  

Bucatini with firm and very salty guanciale came with peperoncini and pecorino.  They let me have a half order of the nicely al dente pasta which served as an appetizer and let me have the very large, whole trout as my main.

A baked one and a half pound trout was absolute perfection.  It came with some lovely roasted peppers and with olive oil and a dipping sauce on the side.  The trout needed nothing but me to consume it.   This plate is the main reason for my five star rating.  It was wonderful food treated with respect by the chef and by me.   

My server was everything you could wish.
author: David D.

description:
You know a place is popular when you can only make reservations right when it opens or closer to closing time and Locanda is definitely one of those places but it was worth it.  The atmosphere here is really cool and it was bustling all night long.  I enjoyed a few cocktails to begin with and enjoyed both of them.  The first was a gin drink with one huge block of ice in it and the second was the Ciociaria which had a great flavor.  

We ordered all of the plates to share and I would highly suggest this as you get to taste a larger portion of their menu and this is one menu you'll want to try.  We started off with the Jewish style artichokes and I'm not an artichoke fan but I enjoyed them.  We also got the pizza bianca with cauliflower and the duck egg which was my favorite of the starters.  Then we shared the Rigatoni alla Carbonara (which was my highlight of the entire meal) along with the linguini and rabbit saddle which was also very tasty and definitely different.  

For dessert we finished off with the cheese plate and a tart.  Great drinks, friendly serves and excellent food!
author: Blake B.

description:
Any restaurant that can pull off gluten free pasta options gets a gold star (or four orange-ish/red stars?) in my book. 

The menu is confusing, most of the food terminology was over my unofficial foodie head. We asked the server for some advice and she went through, line-by-line and explained everything. I wonder if she gets tired of doing that? I would...but I digress. 

From her thorough walk-through of the menu, we deduced we would start with the shaved artichoke and peas and shoots appetizers. Being gluten free these days, my options were obviously cut back but for my main option; I went with one of their pasta dishes but opted for the gluten free noodles. I was "wowed" and even raved about it to my friend who was not eating the gluten free version. I was emphatic about it, "Try this! Try this! It doesn't even TASTE like gluten free." Hesitantly, she forked a bit of pasta into her mouth and said, "Oh. Yah, I can definitely tell it's gluten free." Crestfallen, I realized that perhaps I've been gluten free long enough that I can't even recall the difference in taste. That doesn't mean it didn't rock, though, because it did.

Delicious all around. Solid place to enjoy a lovely evening out in the Mish.
author: Julia N.

description: One of my favorite places in mission. Food is outstanding.  Services is fast and impeccable.  Tried almost all of their starters and few entrees and it doesn't disappoint my tummy. Will keep coming back for more.
author: Claudine V.

description:
great laid back and dim ambience, with ample spacing between the tables. 

Great food and wine -- will be definitely be back soon. book ahead or walk in for bar seats. 

On a super hot day (like the one on 9/1/2017), this is one of the only places with air conditioning. Even though it's barely discernible on that date with the oven fires up, it's still better than the other restaurant. Score a table in the front with the window open if you come here after 7.30pm on a hot night after sun down. 

Great service. Attentive and fun staff. 

FAVORITES:

jewish style artichokes - they marinate and poach the artichoke first and then deep fry the top. Amazing. Impossible to do it yourself at home without the right tools and patience - let them take care of it for you in the restaurant. 

fettuccini with raabit sugo (fantastic pasta)

Heirloom tomato with creme Fraiche - the homemade creme fraiche is light and fluffy. It's topped with marjoram which is quite unusual with tomato, which gives it a slightly nutty layer to the flavor. 

summer thyme cocktail - very summertime appropriate and balanced. 

SOLID:
Liberty Duck - half braised and half roasted. Flavorful and tender. 

Blistered pepper - watch for the little green ones that can be a bit spicy but the large red peppers are divine with the caramelized onions. 

So-so:
duck egg was a bit too salty for my taste

great selection of wine by the glass. I ordered Bruno Grimald 2007 Barolo and it was excellent. A Rina Nerello mascalese red wine from mount Etna was excellent (by the glass) - it had depth of flavor with rounded minerality. Great from first sip to the last.
author: Rebecca C.

description: Great service. The wait staff is extremely attentive but the food was bland and had an unusual texture. Avoid the Purgatorio at all cost!
author: Jennifer W.

description:
I'm a fan of both of the Delfina restaurants, so this was a must-try on my list on a short business trip. 

Pizza Bianca olive oil, sea salt - We were first served the house bread (kind of similar to a foccacia), topped with olive oil and sea salt. The bread had a nice chew, with just enough oil and salt to keep things interesting.

Jewish Style Artichoke - Now this was fun. Apparently this is a classic dish from the Jewish area of Rome - an artichoke deep fried and topped with mint. The interior was meaty and the exterior crispy, quite tasty. I liked the mint, which added just a little bit of brightness to the dish; a lemon wedge added some welcome acidity.

Bucatini all' Amatriciana guanciale, tomato, peperoncini, pecorino - I thought this was a very good version of the classic. Expectantly so, the pasta was perfectly cooked, leaving just a bit of chew to the pasta. The guanciale (cured pork cheek) imparted a little richness and hint of pork flavor, while there was just a little bit of spiciness that crept up on the palate. It was borderline too spicy for my mother, but I found it just right.

Radiatore "Pecora e Pecorino" lamb ragu, pecorino, mint - Excellent dish. I really liked the radiator-shaped pasta as it clung to the ragu so well. The pasta almost had a spongy texture because it had so much sauce, and really made for some good bites. The ragu was rich and meaty, and I thought the cheese added some nice flavor too.

Rigatoni alla Carbonara guanciale, egg, pecorino, black pepper - I liked the rigatoni's chew and subtle flavors of the egg and pecorino, but I found this pasta to be a little bit less exciting than the previous two. Still, a good rendition of the carbonara.

Guinea Hen Leg al spiedo - A guinea hen leg was deboned, then wrapped in spices, lardo and proscuitto. Sounds good? It was delicious. Really tender and moist with exceptional flavor. The skin was crisped up really well too, and the meaty flavors were balanced well with some bitter greens and lentils. Probably my favorite dish of the night.

Warm Chocolate Cake maple syrup, walnuts - The cake was warm and really soft, with an almost pudding-like interior. I liked the extra depth of flavor from the maple syrup, as well as the contrast of the whipped cream.

Locanda met my expectations (which were high, given the pedigree and buzz). I found the meal somewhat similar in style to one I recently had at Cotogna, but I think I'd give a slight edge to Locanda (though, I tried a limited number of items at both).  I thought the pastas were very good, and the only entree we tried was a memorable one. I look forward to trying more of the menu items sometime soon.
author: Darin L.

description:
It's all about where you sit. I've been here twice, and was splashed on both times. The first time, it was specifically by the drunk dudes that set next to us. Rather cramped in there to begin with.

Their food might have been fantastic. It's certainly not what I remember them for!
author: Garett T.

description:
The food here is really good. I've been several times. The portions are not huge, but that doesn't bother me.

My Favorites (in no particular order): 
Fried Olives
Jewish-style Artichoke
Rigatoni Alla Carbonara
Radiatore "Pecora e Pecorino"
Grilled Whole Fish (Acqua Pazza)

The restaurant is somewhat noisy but not out of control. 

My only complaint is that the service is consistently slow. There is a fairly long wait time to order, and in between courses. The servers are all extremely nice and skilled. I just don't think they're staffed up enough.
author: Michael T.

description: Locanda is always great, delicious, nice bar options, awesome bread, service, all of it
author: jon s.

description: Super slow service. Way overpriced food. Good cocktails (but get ready for wait for them).
author: Kate W.

description: Very average meal at Locana.. Stopped in for a 9:30 reservation and the entire experience was just ok.. and not worth the price. We got the pizza bianca and fried olives as an appetizer. the pizza bianca was overly salty. fried olives were tasty. For our main we shared lamb ragu and salmon. both of our mains were very average and not worth the value. barely tasted lamb in in the lamb pasta and the salmon dish was poorly prepared. Salmon was sloppy and in way too much sauce. overall a poor experience given the $$. In an area of the world where there are great food options, locanda should be low on the list.
author: Kyle W.

description:
*On our quest to try 52 new places in 52 weeks.* 

Last night my husband and I and two other couples came here for dinner. We called in the morning around 11:00am and we're "lucky" to get a 10:30 reservation. Which in the city can be expected, so no worries on that note.

The alcohol was superb. My husband and one of the guys each had the whiskey flight and I heard them say "delicious" more than once. One couple each had a glass of a local red (I won't be able to remember what it was) and they liked it so much they tried to get a bottle. But since all they had were magnums at $120/pop that idea was quickly rejected. I had the "Church" cocktail which had gin, aperol, and lemon. It was SO tasty, big, and only $10. Really good.

The food was...as Yelp! says...a-ok. We had the duck egg (which everyone likes), the Jewish Artichoe (also good), and some other apps that were good, but nothing to write home about. I had the bucatini, which was good, but it didn't blow my hair back. My husband had the steak which he thought was good, but lacking in flavor until he put the pickled veggies on top. Not worth the $26.

Good atmosphere, you can actually carry on a conversation, beautiful decor (and bathrooms), and good food/drinks. I think I would come back here for cocktails and apps.
author: Melissa N.

description: Loved this place. Our server was fantastic and really pointed us in the right direction for food and drink. She obviously loves the food there and appreciated the quality of it. The only negative was that we were seated over an air conditioning vent on the floor which meant that even with my jacket and winter coat on I was freezing!! Regardless, I will definitely be back again when I'm in San Francisco and feel like Italian.
author: M F.

description: 4.5 stars. Consistently great! Always get the Nonna da diavolo (spelling?) that isn't on the menu. Amazing pizza Bianca and prosciutto and the lamb rage is always a winner. Can be tough to just walk in do reservations are recommended. They also have great bartenders and waitstaff!
author: Kelly C.

description:
I went here with my boyfriend tonight and was very impressed. One of my favorite dinners. The ambiance is really nice, I love open kitchens. The food was excellent. My starter was the mixed green salad which was simple and light but delicious. We shared the Jewish style artichoke and that was really good too. He had the sunchoke soup which was light and yummy. My main was the walnut cannelloni, so delicious but super unhealthy however who data Italian food for health? Overall, great food ambiance and service. 
,
author: Olivia O.

description:
We told ourselves that Locanda would be the reward for flying across the country and rolling into town at what for our bodies was "12:30am". We were right.

I actually found out about them from an episode of "VICE: Munchies" featuring the chef, and his billing of authentic Roman food with minor reinterpretation was delivered upon really well here.

Starters:  
-Fried Young Fava Beans 'Cacio E Pepe' - super imaginative, and the texture was AMAZING. Plus, cheese!
-Sunchoke soup - you could taste the fresh root veg here, and the addition of radioactive green olive oil dabbled on top was a really perfect flavor. I say radioactive green with only the fondest reverence - this stuff was probably in Italy the day before we sat down at the table and tasted like no olive oil I've had.

Entrees:
-Bucatini - if you're wondering what thick, perfectly cooked noodles and perfectly peppery tomato sauce are supposed to taste like...it's this.
-Veal Alla Saltimbocca - The portion felt a little small, but each pasta pouch had a punch of salty, meaty flavor and it was perfectly done.

You'd also be making a mistake going to the wine or beer list here. The cocktails are just too good to skip. Indulging my ever-present whiskey problem, I had the Nonna Del Diavolo (The Devil's Grandma - you can't not order now that you know) and the Gomorrah - rye and scotch cocktails, respectively. I'm not a cocktail expert but the ginger/seltzer/rye pairing was really new to me - and good. The Gomorrah's more traditional scotch + grappa + aperitivo + bitters mix was the real winner for me. This is what Don Draper would have ordered in Rome.

Team service was great and we were swarmed with prompt water pours, well-paced plates and table checks without feeling stalked. 

The restaurant overall was VERY warm, I think because the city was having a particularly hot week and air conditioning seems to be a dirty word in San Francisco...but this was probably my favorite Italian meal and I've been to Italy (maybe I should go back again and try harder).
author: A.J. C.

description:
This is one of my new favorite spots for a mid to upper level restaurant. We ordered the Jewish style artichoke, Bianca pizza, Walnut and Ricotta canelloni, Crab pasta, and Ricotta torta. Everything was delicious and at typical sf prices ($8-10 for starters, $18 for entrees, $9 for dessert). 

As a disclaimer: this place is NOT authentic Italian but just good modern Italian-inspired cuisine.

We also ordered the Church cocktail (fruity, not overly sweet, gin), the Steam Shandy (beer+liquor=delicious), and the Old Fashioned flight (rye, bourbon, scotch). All of which were delicious and well made. They also use the large blocks of ice so they're not messing around.

The only complaint was slow service at the end of the meal but it also happened to get much busier so can't get too mad about that.

If you come here, just make sure to make a reservation and be open to spending a bit more dough to try the dishes you want :)
author: Mira K.

description:
This is a very chic and well decorated Italian restaurant.   The food is very delicious. Apparently this place is always packed because the hostess told me that guests usually make their reservations to dine here at least 3 weeks in advance.  My friend and I waited about 20 minutes for our reserved table.

Upon ordering our food, we were served house bread and butter.   It wasn't the most amazing bread I've ever had, but it was warm and satisfying.  We couldn't decide what to order.  So much the two of us wanted to try.  Ultimately, we chose the pizza Bianca to share.  For dinner, Thuy ordered the linguine and I ordered the local halibut.

Pizza Bianca: This is not the conventional round pizza.  It is served as 3 separate slices on a cheese board.  Very cool presentation and very yummy.  The sauce is cream -based versus tomato-based.  

Linguini:  Wow, this pasta is absolutely delicious.  It is lite, but packed full of flavor.  The ingredients include crab, lettuce, and sorrel.  I wish I had my own order!

Local Halibut:  This white fish is bursting with flavor.  It is served in a pancetta broth with fennel and clams.  For a fish dish, the amount served was generous and filling.  I dipped the bread into my broth when I was done with the entree.  I loved it!  


Side note: In terms of seating, it was a bit awkward because the table next to us was so close that I felt we were at the same table, lol!  It felt more and more uncomfortable as the couple next to us continuously listened in on our conversation and repeatedly starred at us.    

Nonetheless, I will be back with more friends so we can try everything else on the menu.  This place is a must try!
author: Gloria Y.

description:
This is a 5 star experience if your unfamiliar with fusion Italian dining.   So in other words it's a strong 4

Recommend the fried Olives, they were awesome along with the bread that reminds me of old Rome italy.  The 4 of us got pasta dishes that were all really good but I do agree with the comments the portions were smaller for the price but doesn't mean you can't go back for more :)
author: Frank N.

description:
Locanda was so highly rated by a foodie friend of mine that I wanted to try it for a really long time. It's obviously very popular. I tried earlier this week and was really disappointed. If i'm going to buy pasta in a restaurant, it must be better than what I can do at home. I've been to Rome and almost everything tastes great, even food they sell in gas stations. Not so at Locanda. I couldn't even eat the first lamb ragu i ordered, so i asked the waiter to recommend another. It tasted basically, like Mac 'n cheese with some pork belly thrown: for $18! We ordered rack of lamb and it was really salty.

Tables are crammed together and we could smell our neighbors cologne and perfumes. It was loud.  It was hot, and felt like it needed better ventilation. I was sweating and couldn't wait to leave and get outside. it took for ever for them to get me my bill so that I could bolt out of there.

to be fair, it's not a terrible restaurant as i make it sound, but it's not exceptional either.

Loved the ginger soda and Apertivo drinks. My favorite was the arugula salad and the jewish style artichoke with shredded mint.
author: Bill W.

description:
Amazing food. Went with my wife and friend.

My wife got the Church cocktail: it was one of the best drinks we've ever had.

The artichoke heart appetizer was amazing. Definitely 7x7 Big eat worthy.

Pasta was perfectly al dente. Couldn't ask for more!
author: Christopher K.

description:
Made reservations last friday night here for a fun special dinner, had a pretty good time but was a bit underwhelmed.

We arrived early for our reservation, about 15 minutes and were going to go to the bar for a cocktail but the hostess told us that she could sit us early and to not to go to the bar and then we were sat 10 minutes after our reservation time. A bit annoying but I get it, it's Friday night. We got a great table in the back half or the restaurant so we weren't by the door and awkward people standing over the poor people in the front.

After we were sat, we were given water and ignored for another 15 minutes as we watched other later sat tables getting served. I have now been here 40 minutes after a long week and a special night with out a cocktail. 

Who I would assume to be the restaurant manager came over and took our order realizing we had been ignored for some time, I probably wore the look on my face. He offered us an appetizer that never arrived and then our entrees came.

The entrees which I initially thought were the appetizer because of the size were dropped off and even though small in size they were amazing, I just wish I knew about the portions and would have ordered differently. I had the carbonara and my date had the rigatoni and they were both exquisite. Temperature hot, seasoned perfect, presentation great and all the amazing textures were divine. 

To wrap up the evening a different server or busier cleared our plates and brought the bill. I think a bit overpriced for the experience but now I know what I would do differently next time I go but probably wouldn't be for a while.
author: Craig P.

description: Love your  bagna cauda and that tripe dish, oh my god! Phenomenal, never a let down and always consistent. Also the coctails are so damn good.
author: Danny B.

description:
This place has been bookmarked for a while, but it's too popular to work as a spur of the moment place to dine because inevitably it's always crowded and has a long wait. Unless you arrive at 5:30, which we did, then you're in business. 

We started with cocktails, which were both fun to watch being made and consume. 

The menu features many vegetarian options and the smoked eggplant ravioli didn't disappoint. My dining companion had a green tomato soup that looked divine and  several dishes, including the squash blossom canneloni, piqued my interest. 

Locanda will remain bookmarked. There are many reasons to return.
author: Lee H.

description:
Tried to get a table at their sister restaurant Delfina but wait was too long. They recommended this place and it did not disappoint. Dined here over the holidays.

The ambiance is warm, good for groups and we were seated immediately at a nice table without a reservation for our group of 4.

What we had:
Bread - they provided
Jewish style artichokes - DIVINE! Even my kids were impressed. Tasted like potato chips but yes, they were artichokes and yet did not feel greasy at all. It was a like a beautiful crisp.
Olives - small portion and good but nothing remarkable
Rigatoni - Our kids had this and it was nothing special
Special pasta of the night (cannot remember name) - incredible. So creamy, the noodles were buttery and melt in your mouth
Budino - we love a creamy budino and this one did not disappoint
Plate of cookies - a nice accompaniment to the Budino

Service was great and food came out in a timely manner. Overall we had a really fun dining experience and would come back again.
author: Meg W.

description:
The drinks are the saving grace;

My dish was depressing.  17 dollars for under-cooked carbonara and overcooked bacon. Maybe living in Italy some time ago spoiled me, but this was a depressing dish.  Just downright depressing.  After $30 for a drink and a main course, I was hoping to at least feel a little satisfied in the "I came here starving" department - the portion was tiny.  Not even classy tiny, just insignificant. 

The ambiance is nice, but I grew a little tired of the server forcefully trying to upsell every single thing on the menu.  If you would just let me look at it a minute, maybe I could make up my mind?  I don't blame her - of course, this comes down from management.

Oh, but the bread is lovely!  So there you have it: get a cocktail and some bread. (although I'd recommend just going elsewhere altogether)
author: Noah D.

description:
Dined here tonight for the second time, and one of those spots you always tell yourself you want to visit more but just doesn't happen.   Dinner and service was impeccable.   We ordered:

fried olives - AMAZING!
pasta recommend - also AMAZING
special fish - grilled - perfectly cooked
pineapple dessert - pretty good, would have gone with the chocolate.

Also solid cocktails and wine menu.   great variety of amari, which is not seen often in restaurants.  def will return.
author: Jackie D.

description: We showed up pretty late on a Friday night, so the restaurant wasn't very packed. Everything about this spot was great. If you like mezcal their mezcal cocktails were the best we've had so far. We ordered the artichoke (eat it while it's hot), lamb carpaccio (the fried capers and parmigiano were a great touch), lamb pasta (simple but so delicious), the fish of the day, smoky mashed potatoes (that smoke took it to another level) and pea shoots. Every single dish was so flavorful and left you wanting more, but the portions were just right.
author: Anisha A.

description:
The first time I came here (when they first opened) I wasn't ready to write a review because I wanted to go again, to make sure it was really good, not just hype.  Second time report: awesome!

All the dishes we've tried have been fantastic but the artichoke really is a must!

JEWISH STYLE ARTICHOKE - delicious!  Roasted/toasted to crispy perfection.  Slight burn for a smokey, yummy taste while still maintaining that delicate tangy twist. 

FETTUCCINI -rabbit sugo, cicoria, verjus - I don't like meat that tastes too game-y and Locanda does this just right.  Interesting and not overbearing. 

BUCATINI all'AMATRICIANA - guanciale, tomato, peperoncini, pecorino - it's Italian bacon, come on.

FIORELLINI - ricotta, fiorelli, squash blossoms

GUINEA HEN LEG - pancetta, cicoria - loved it!  BF thought it was a little too salty but I thought it was well-balanced with the greens and beans.

Great atmosphere.  The decor is beautiful and interesting with an open kitchen.  Good mix of guests for people watching - from funky, tattooed "Mission-ers" to the after work crowd.  Service was quick and friendly.  The free bread is delish!
author: Anh D.

description: As soon as you sit you'll get Complimentary pizza bianca, so tasty. For appetizer we tried chilled lamb tongue and it was very good and different. The pig ears salad was amazing! The special Fish of the night was grilled Cod and I absolutely LOVED it!
author: Siavash N.

description:
This place had been hugely hyped by many people, so I was worried it wouldn't live up to expectations. Well, it must really be a solid place because it did!

The service was good -- nothing specific to note (which is a good thing in my book).

Food highlights...
 -- The Jewish artichoke is good and really interesting/difference though it didn't knock my sock soff 
 -- The shaved (raw) artichoke, arugula, and pecorino salad with lemon dressing WAS AMAAAAAZING. 
The foccacia: absolutely out of this world. It is so light and airy, I have no idea how the y do it.
 -- Everyone at the table got pastas. One of them (a tortelli with a very mushroom-y, buttery sauce) was fantastic. Mine was disappointing (lamb ragu). Nothing terribly wrong with it, just underwhelming.
 -- Side of peas and shoots with yogurt...omg, so good. There must have been a ton of butter in this. 

My only complaint was the menu. I'm totally supportive of using words in the appropriate language given the restaurant. But when there are so many non-English words that you have no idea what the dish is about, it's just annoying.
author: Sydney L.

description:
The food at Locanda is superb. Everything from the appetizers (like the delightful Jewish-style artichoke which is crispy on the outside and melt in your mouth tender on the inside) to the pastas (delicate shrimp and burrata ravioli, savory rabbit linguine and more) to an after dinner cheese plate is delicious with perfect textures, perfect tempuratures, and wonderfully nuanced flavors. There's a convivial buzz, and people flow in and out but the tables stay full. With all that going for, you would think they would want the the service to match. There were no big gaffs, just a combination of little things (how long it took to get some bread, not being asked if we wanted another cocktail, not explaining the cheese plate) that added up to a lesser experience. Now to be fair, they serve as a team and some folks were much more attentive than othets. But when I go someplace, regardless of whether they're busy or not, I'm always looking for that feeling that comes when you know you are an honored guest. The places that manage to pull it off are the ones that really stand out in a city full of places with amazing food.

P.S. Make sure to have an appetizer if you are considering pasta as a main course. The portions are on the small side. The house bread is really wonderful. Definitely have a slice. 

P.P.S. If you are driving into the mission, consider using the valet service. It completely eliminates the aggravation of trying to park in the mission on a Saturday night, its well worth  the $10 plus tip. The decor and general ambience are also quite lovely.
author: Nicole M.

description:
Delfina's younger sibling is refreshing. I like the ambiance and it's more hip. Delfina needed something new. I really enjoyed the whole fish. Its a big portion so needs to be shared. I have not had such prep in many places. It's a comforting dish. The only criticism is not all dishes are consistently good and the waif list is too long for that caliber of food but it's prolly bc it's new and it's still hot! I'm hoping it will down a bit so I can go more often. I she  mixed feelings about so many new restos in mission. It's getting sooo gentrified but it's nice to have many new choices. It's a sign of growth.
