I give this place my 4 stars.
author: Foodie4sf E.

description:
Typical San Franciscan snobism about Italian food.
We tried the tortellini, bucatini all'amatriciana and some antipasti. The tortellini are good, but the amount of food is ridiculously small. The bucatini were overcooked and the guanciale meat way too salty. The antipasti and desserts are too expensive for what they are.
author: Alejandro F.

description:
We enjoyed our dinner, the service, and the ambience of the restaurant.  It is refreshing to be among "old folks" in the Mission- as much of the clientele was 35+.

One RED FLAG- we enjoyed 2 glasses of spanish wine, recommended by the waiter, at $16 a glass.  We enjoyed it so much we did a quick look-up and found you can buy the BOTTLE retail for $17.  Is that Locanda's normal mark-up?  Were they Defense Contratcors in a previous life?

I'm all for a business makibng a profit, but come on.  It also made me question the quality of their ingredients- if they are so set on huge profits are they buying inexpensive and low quality ingredients to maintain high profit margins?

A very good meal, but I felt a little taken...so can't give a higher score.
author: Gary T.

description:
Appearance-wise it's great.  It was pretty busy/happening the night we went there.  

The food was gross though!  We ordered the pizza bianca to start - the salt was just glopped on.  Some mouthfuls were completely flavorless and other bites you literally got a mouthful of salt.  Was here with a friend and it actually made both of us feel a little sick to our stomachs.

The next course wasn't much better.  We got the chestnut agnolotti to share.  It was swimming in oil.  We ended up deciding to spare our stomachs and barely ate it.

Fail.
author: Gowri R.

description: My girlfriend and I had the whole fish and lamb Ragu.  Both were amazing.  The waiter was very knowledgable of the menu and wine list.  Open kitchen and decor is very cool.
author: Robert F.

description:
Not sure the words can express how much I enjoyed Locanda. From the minute we stepped in - the entire experience was stellar. This is the perfect place to bring both the foodie in your group as well as the traditionalist. With the recent "hipster" over haul in the Mission - I had begin to loose interest with resturants down that way - since they seem to be all about the "place to be" and less about the food. This redeemed the Mission for me. 
The starters and the variation could make a full meal -  I plan to go back just so I can sample the rest. We have 4 entrees and each had a distinct, clean robust flavor with out it being forced or "too rich". Even the Brick Chicken had just the right flavor and hands-on goodness that made it worth trying. The room is airy which is good because it can get loud when the crowd hits - but I loved that they don't rush the dinner or try to push your meal, have valet parking and is close to public transit. Go Go Go is all I can say
author: Frank S.

description:
Very good and very cute place. Great for groups or date night. Bartenders are super friendly 

It looks like their menu changes seasonally or month to month (?) because what I ordered a few weeks ago is no longer on the menu. Friends and I shared a pate appetizer which was very good. Enough for the 3 of us while we waited for the main course.

I wish I wrote my review earlier because now  I can't remember all the dishes we shared. I remember a pasta with duck, the TONNARELLI CACIO e PEPE, and it was either the pasta with rabbit or lamb ragu. Three dishes for three people was just enough. No one was in a food coma or starving afterwards. Everything was really good.

Highly recommend this place. I can't wait to go back.
author: Terry D.

description:
We came here last Friday night on short notice. There was plenty of seating at 6:00 pm... however when we finally left at around 7:30 the place was packed and there was a line. Definitely worth getting here a little early if you don't have any reservations.

We sat by the door, which was a bit chilly, but they had this great curtain that they used to block the door later on. Great idea. We had a couple cocktails, which were fantastic, as well as a wine on tap which was much better than we would have thought. It was sweet but was much better with food. 

The three of us each had a different pasta. I had the Orecchiette, which was incredibly WAY too salty, the other two dishes were the Linguine with crab, which seemed a bit bland... however that may be because my tastes were in shock from my salty dish. 

We ended the dinner with an assortment of cookies, which were yummy. Overall it was a lovely experience with the atmosphere, food and service. I have no doubt their food is great, I was sad mine was so salty, everything else was great. I would recommend trying this place!
author: Annette D.

description: One of my favorite restaurants to regularly visit.  I love their whole fish preparation, the artichoke appetizer is a perfect way to start your meal too.  The cocktails are a must here.  All of the pasta's except for the carbonara are amazing, but the steak with smoked mashed potatoes is the star of the show here.  Go to Locanda!!
author: Jeff C.

description:
Oh yes, perfect place for a girls night out or date.  Good atmosphere, food and drinks too!  

My friend and I decided to split the dishes and we got the Pizza Bianca with smoked white bass, horseradish and dill as an app.  Double jackpot.  It was so tasty and crunchy.  

For the main dish, we had the Fettuccini with rabbit.  I know what you're thinking... how can you eat such a cute animal.  Fear not, the portion was small and one bunny probably feeds 8 plates.  Ok, that still sounds brutal.  It was delicious tho!  Once again, Locanda was able to achieve such great flavors with what sounds like such a simple dish.  Compliments to the chef, Anthony Strong.

And of course, no dinner is complete without dessert so we had the warm chocolate cake!  Oh me oh my, hid yo kids.  Came with the best whip cream I've ever had along with maple syrup and curried walnuts.  

Left the place with a big smile.  Life is good when stomach is happy.
author: Nho C.

description: We had to come back again tonight after last nights meal. Every where else seemed pale. I wish I knew how to make those artichokes. Sublime is too average to describe them!
author: Sue E.

description:
Well made cocktails, interesting and good food, and always hopping... Fun place to meet someone for a drink, or for dinner/drinks if you can wait.

Food is pretty richly flavored, though done well. Interesting use of seasonal ingredients -- worth asking for the special. Last time got a halibut collar that was delicious.
author: Aki N.

description:
I really enjoy this place, atmosphere, food, beverage.
I prefer sitting at the bar since that's where all the action is and I have a short attention span, so I enjoy watching the bartenders put on a show!  In fact, there is this one lovely lady that does a little extra shake when she makes drinks... I'm not a lesbo but I enjoy watching her regardless.

I've tried a few dishes, pasta, chicken liver, tripe, all are delicious.  But for some reason there is something special about those little fried olives filled with cheese.  It's like my dream come true in one crunchy....then gooey bite.

Melt.
author: S G.

description:
My beautiful fiance, friends and I were walking by this spot on Pink Saturday wearing almost nothing (looking like the freakiest of gays) searching for snacks and drinks. This line-up of smiling folks at the door beckoned us to enter. I had NO IDEA what a refined establishment it was. But they treated us great. It would have been so easy to feel out of place in the class of the place. But because they are people of true class, they made us feel right at home..
Great cocktails! Fresh, perfectly mixed and delicious.
Food was perfect...OMG semifreddo...OMG fried olives!
Wine list, amazing.. and I am super wine snob.
And I can't say enough nice things about the graciousness of the staff.
really, really thank you so much
author: Alice P.

description:
Walked into here on Saturday night at 8pm with no reservation but unbelievably Lisa, the hostess got us seated in 10 minutes. Granted I'm sure this was pure luck but she was extremely pleasant both when she seated us and when we left. 

Our waitress was extremely knowledgeable  and friendly, she never offered her name. She answered all our questions and offered suggestions.

We ordered the Jewish Artichoke and fried olives both were very different and great.

Our entrees are where were they lost us a little. Everything was extremely salty. The halibut came with the skin and tail and had an extreme fishy odor. The yellowtail was ok. Both our pastas were extreme salty and odd flavored. The bread they serve is very nice.

We will definitely give it another try when back in the area soon.
author: Timorie B.

description:
After one of my best friends cat sit my, um, sick cat, I knew that my "take you out to dinner" payback had to be a legit new place.

I had a black uber pick her and her boyfriend up and meet me in this mission gem. The sister restaurant to delfina the food here did not disappoint. 

Some notes:
25.00 corkage (still was charged even though we also all ordered several drinks from them)
The Jewish artichoke is amazing. One per every two people.
Pasta was average. Both the lamb lamb ragu and which ever the other one I ordered  didn't excite me like amazing Italian restaurants do. I would skip these in favor of other apps and mains.

What to wear: While this restaurant is on the expensive side, It is in the Mission and is going to be on the more casual side. I wore heels and a bright patterned skirt and felt like I wished I saved the heels for date night on Fillmore. The interior reminded me more of a really nice lunch place than a super fancy classic place. So I would leave the jacket and heels at home and be hipster  chic instead.
author: Danielle V.

description:
Guanciale
want  a  le ]

Noun
An unsmoked Italian bacon prepared with pig's jowl or cheeks.

Verb
Eat this S.O.B.
author: Isaac L.

description:
We are never disappointed when going to Laconda. Had New Years dinner last night and it was excellent!  

My only complaint is the portion sizes of the apps. They are getting smaller and the price remains the same. Our artichoke was 1/2 an artichoke. 

The service was excellent and the atmosphere is fun to a certain degree.
author: Jennifer M.

description:
Worth the wait.

I ordered:
Tortelli with mushrooms
Radiatore with lamb ragu
Artichokes
Artichoke salad
Steak

This place is up there on my list
author: Mike G.

description:
I think this should be categorized as Roman Food.  It was slightly different from the usual Italian fare.  I enjoyed the tomato salad and artichoke salad, as well as the roman loin jerky, but I can't say the same for the fish.  At $35 a plate the fish was not that interesting.  It looked quite a bit better than it tasted.  Also, I think I ate all of the things on the menu that were not cooked with heavy oily ingredients.. not the place to go for light eating.  
Cocktails were fairly good- try their version of the gin fizz (although at half the price $5 the traditional gin fizz at Cliff House is better)
author: M S.

description:
Visited twice, once for drinks and once for a light meal.  Service was excellent both times.  Cocktails were finely crafted and pleasing, though slightly on the dry side so consider that if you're a sweet drink fan.

Sweetbreads and artichoke app was interesting, but I thought that the batter on the artichoke was a bit heavy.

Be aware that the pizza bianca is not pizza, more of a toast with toppings.  It was great and pretty reasonably priced, but we could have ordered a couple in hindsight.

A tomato arugula salad was good, and the Grilled corn side was fantastic.  Pastas were fine, but didn't wow me.
author: Patrick S.

description: NOT your typical Mission bistro!  Lovely room and ambiance for a nice dinner.with amazingly gracious waitstaff (except for the guys delivering drinks...perhaps scope of job makes them grim?)!  Food is unique and outstanding.  Our server was an immense help in picking and sharing the right dishes to get a real sample of the fare.  The baked fwhole fish with fennel and tomatoes and baby squash was amazing,  Split a couple of pasta appetizers to great effect.  Had an aperitif (something I've been experimenting more and more with) and was delighted by "The Prince", a combination of bourbon, Compari and (I forget) that was amazing before during and after dinner...OK we had three!  GO!
author: Howard B.

description:
Woah excellent. 

I am not really a resturant officiando, and have been happy going to more mom and pop noodle houses or whatever, but my boyfriend is very much into checking out critically acclaimed places. 

After some gentle nudging, we made a date to come have some cocktails and appetizers here, and I will have to say that this place easily topped the list of one of my favorite restaurants in SF. 

The place for starters was perfectly laid out, in a modern and classic 'NY' style, which doesn't really mean anything except its a cool and comfortable place to dine intimately, or with a large group at one of the bigger gathering tables.... or just at the bar, if thats what your looking for! 

The Menu is perfect.  Part of it speaks to my jewish ancestry, which just only sweetens the deal for me. 

The wait staff is incredible.  The hostess smile warmly at you the moment you enter, making sure you feel comfortable, and basically beconing you in the door... A+ for customer service. 

The wait staff is busy, but make sure to give you the one on one attention you need, and area always making the rounds to check in on you, refill your water, and reload you with the AMAZING Pizza Bianca- or whatever the hell is the standard table bread that they bring around....

5 stars all the way!
author: Best M.

description:
They have valet outside for $12...very useful since the Mission is crazy nowadays!

My husband and I have been wanting to come here for quite some time. Be sure to snag reservations way in advance. The restaurant was super packed Saturday night with lots of ppl waiting at the bar.  They have some wines on tap and a full wine list.  We ordered sunchoke soup - which was very flavorful. I also had the artichoke salad, which was healthy tasting!

For the mains, we both tried their pastas. My husband had the lobster, which was quite steep at $26!! I had the pasta with tomatoes, hot peppers, guanciale and pecorino. I liked the texture of mine as well as the taste. I think the lobster one was a bit overhyped and priced.

All in all, it was a good dinner, but not something that made us go "wow". But the food was good, ambiance was good, so I give it 4 stars.
author: Natalie S.

description:
Oh man, I love Locanda.

It's rich (both in food and in it's clientele), but oh so enjoyable.

The ambiance is really nice - romantic and intimate but with a marriage of modern and classic. The music selection is great, too.

The wait staff is great - from the hosts to the waiters and the servers, you do feel taken care of.

The FOOD: absolutely delicious. We always get the bucatini - it has this amazing cured pork cheek that I'm pretty sure they cure in-house (you can see it hanging over the kitchen in a glass curing case). I recently had the lamb radiatori, which was very good. We got the pork saltimboca and that was delicious as well, so rich though that we couldn't finish.

Their menu changes with the seasons, though they have some stables.  The desserts are lovely - rich as well but well executed.  The drink menu's great - we've only ordered the beer and wine. Really good wines.

They close at 10 though, so get there early :)
author: Sara M.

description: Rude staff. They need to learn phone etiquette when they answer the phone.
author: Patty O.

description:
Dear Locanda,

You make me feel like I've made it in San Francisco. 

You feed me some of the best food this city has to offer. Your menu is ever changing, but the pastas are always fresh, flavorful, and oh so satisfying. Your appetizers are classics and true to their Roman roots. Your desserts, like the warm chocolate cake or the fried ricotta, are beautifully made, but taste even better. 

It is with your drinks, though, that you really capture my heart. You have a great wine list and a wait staff who knows how to see into my soul to suggest just the perfect bottle for the night. Your cocktails are amazing and crafted ever so expertly by some of the best bartenders in town. Whether I am sipping on a flight of Old Fashioned, Business Thyme, or Smoke & Spice, Gabe, Alex, and Allen are always there to listen to my aimless rants about life. 

You opened your arms to me, Locanda. For that, I am grateful. 

Your New Aspiring Regular,

Vrushali
author: Vrushali P.

description:
Food was 3 star for taste, but 2 for price - decent but not memorable and it certainly did not merit the prices they were charging.

1. JEWISH-STYLE ARTICHOKES - tiny serving and boring.  The darn thing is double deep fried....DOUBLE deep fried yet still not tasty?  How can that be possible?  You can deep fry anything and it will taste good but this one was a snore

2. ESCAROLE and ROASTED SQUASH - brown butter vinaigrette, pomegranite - another snoozer

3. BAVETTE STEAK - patate affumicate, chicories - the chef did cook the meat just as I ordered so 3 stars for that but the rest that was on the plate I felt was sloppy.  And @ $26...hmmm.....

4. Bread was very nice and tasty.  But you know it's not a positive experience when the best thing you have to say about a restaurant is the bread.

Service was good - courteous and friendly.

Based on the food, I would not recommend to friends.
author: Lev E.

description:
My bf made a quick reservation here for Friday and we hurried on over after work. Cute decor, interesting pictures on the walls, and we got the back corner table that seemed romantic.

Drink choice was THE MISTRESS (Gin, Cantaloupe, Verjus). server mentioned that was a typo and they couldn't make that. he was saying they had this other drink..plum..mint..orange..something overly strong..i thought i'd try it out. looked beautiful, wasn't my type of drink though. Server changed it out for a crisp glass of Soave, no charge on the cocktail *thank you*. Bf got the FERNET NO.3.

Let me start off by stating that I was not impressed with first course, but the fettucini blew me away, as well as one of the desserts.

"White pizza (pizza bianca) omits the tomato sauce, often substituting pesto or dairy products such as sour cream. Most commonly, especially on the East coast of the United States, the toppings consist only of mozzarella and ricotta cheese drizzled with olive oil and spices like fresh basil and garlic. In Rome, the term pizza bianca refers to a type of bread topped with olive oil, salt and, occasionally, rosemary sprigs" per Wikipedia

I wish i knew that so i wouldn't have been excited to try a handmade small 'pizza' with the crushed plum and prosciutto. this was more like a  super sharp crostini with some delicious plum and prosciutto on it. Don't get me wrong, it tasted great, I wouldnt suggest getting prosciutto again because it's not a very elegant thing to try and bite.

2nd bite: we came here for the sweetbreads!! of course, this night, they decided to change it up to fried lamb's brain with artichokes (with fried sage, parsley, capers). the artichokes were perfect in flavor and texture, the lamb brains were a bit too soft for my liking. it certainly needed the lemon squeeze, sage, and capers with each bite. bf enjoyed them :)

FETTUCCINI -rabbit sugo, cicoria, verjus, hands down the best pasta i've ever eaten. the rabbit was delicious, but sparse. for $17 i would have thought atleast another forkful of pasta should have been there. Super simple, bits of rabbit, fettuccini and very light sauce. Amazing.

Also a wonderful dish: 
CASARECCEI - pig's trotter, green tomatoes. pork was cooked perfectly, bursting with flavor. the casareccei was good, but not exciting, the sauce had a nice subtle kick to it. 

desserts
(Sori del Re, Moscato d'Asti, Piemonte, Italy)
Peach Crostata with vanilla gelato. I don't get putting a semi room temp dessert with a cold ice cream (gelato). usually you pair a hot and cold together for the contrast. The peach crostata was good, but to be honest, my bf's vegan peach crisp the other night blew me away..

THE BEST thing here:  
RICOTTA FRITTA (citrus caramel, lemon thyme) GET two orders!! You are ment to pop one in your mouth, drizzled with the lemon thyme and it's just a flavor explosion of perfection and heaven mixed into one.

Around $70 on food, $40 on drinks. I will come back for the sweebreads, to try more pasta, and the ricotta fritta :)
author: Abigail W.

description:
I would expect nothing short of greatness from the folks behind Delfina, but Locanda was even better than I had hoped!

What a great choice to have a Roman-inspired menu, from the Jewish-style carciofi to the excellent pastas.  Everything we had was absolutely delicious and I am still craving the lobster spaghetti weeks later. 

The vibe is lively and fun, with a good buzz in the air, but we never felt crowded or rushed.  I dare say it had a "New York" kind of feeling, which then becomes a kind of stay-cation in itself!  

I can't believe it took me that long to get there, and I am hoping to be back again soon.  You'll find me at the bar with a cocktail and the fried olives (a must-have), or in a dark corner with my face hovering over a plate of the bone marrow, and a smile on my face.
author: Liz S.

description:
Easily the best Italian food I've eaten in sf. 
Radiatore w lamb Sugo was lick the bowl savory and delicious 
Amatriciana was excellent. 
Lobster w fennel pollen served with burrata cascini superb
Dry aged strip w trumpet mushrooms and black truffle... Skimpy on truffle cooked beautifully to temp with a great crisp sear on it.  Bravo
Chocolate cake yum.  

Sooooo good cant wait to go back

update... second time fell flat... not as good or an automatic 5 star review... will go back
author: ari b.

description:
I had made reservations at Locanda for several nights of the week for myself and other colleagues. It took 10 minutes to seat us after we arrived for our reservation. Service was incredibly slow and staff was not very friendly. We ordered the coppiette and fried olives for appetizers. The copiette arrived immediately, whereas the olives required two additional requests. I ordered the halibut as a main. The fish was very fresh and delicious; the bok choy was a bit greasy and wilted. We decided to forgo dessert since we had been at the restaurant for over 2 1/2 hours. We asked our server for a taxi, and were told that we should go stand on the end of the street.
Overall, food was ok, but don't think I would go out of my way to go back here again.
author: Danniella M.

description:
We took some friends here because we had a great experience 2 years ago.  Well...we thought it wasn't as good as the 1st visit.  Sad.  We shared everything.  We tried the Jewish Style Artichoke - still good.  The COPPIETTE - their cured house made jerky - could have passed.  RIGATONI alla CARBONARA - it was ok, pretty basic without a bite of their house made pancetta, RADIATORE "PECORA e PECORINO - tasty and enjoyed the pasta, and BELLWEATHER CRESCENZA TOTELLI - ok.  Lastly we did the cod of the day pan seared along with CHARRED PEPPERS - prosciutto breadcrumbs and BROCCOLI ROMANESCO - anchovy butter
Overall just ok.  

Another bummer is that we were seated by the kitchen so we smelled walking out of the restaurant - clothes, hair & all.
author: Meredith K.

description:
I was hunting for a dinner spot on a Friday night and Locanda happened to have an opening at the time slot I wanted (rsvp system on their website), so we ended up here. This place was recommended on a foodie's blog, so we had relatively high expectations. 

We tried the:
Jewish-style Artichoke - I have to admit I solely got this based on the fact that it was mentioned in so many Yelp reviews. While quite pricey for the small artichoke you get, it was definitely tasty. Not greasy at all, very clean and refreshingly simple.

Coppiette - cured pork jerky. Came as a long strand of meat and heavily smoked. I did not enjoy this at all, we left it alone after the first bite. 

Rigatoni alla Carbonara - very delicious variation on a classic dish. The rigatoni was slightly undercooked, but the sauce is amazing and I *loved* the guanciale (cured pork cheek) in it. 

Acqua Pazza Rock Cod - this is the daily fish cooked "crazy water" style. It was initially a trout that day, but was sold and replaced with a rock cod. Fish is pretty significant (pretty sure this should be a "sharing" dish), poached in white wine sauce. 

Corn (side) - corn kernels with red chile peppers. Fantastic.

Food was great, service is courteous, atmosphere is cozy. Total came out to about $100 for two people (with one cocktail).
author: Linda L.

description:
damn that was some good food. i often stray from Italian restaurants (even though i LOVE italian) because it's too expensive for some pasta and antipasto. but i heard really good things about Locanda. as an osteria (serving wine and simple foods), it's got a laid back sort of environment and an easy menu.

i've read a lot of people's reviews about the carbonara being too salty but personally i thoroughly enjoyed it. the cured "bacon" is cut into chunks and deep fried so that they are crisp and have a substantial bite to it. the egg yolk on the perfectly cooked noodles are silky and luscious. 

i also got the oxtail because i cannot resist oxtail when it's on a menu. it was super tender and had good flavor. even the foccacia that was served to the table was exceptional. 

i canNOT wait for an excuse to go back to Locanda sometime soon. it was one of the more memorable meals i've had as of late.....and i eat out a LOT, so that's saying something.
author: Regina C.

description:
Second stop on my trip to SF Bay and of all five restaurants this was truly the best one hands down. 

We were greeted by a seemingly nerdy hostess wearing Warby Parker glasses. I knew they were Warby Parker because I told her they looked amazing and wanted to know where she got them.

The first taste of Locanda came with their unexpected bread. Brightly colored and with a beautiful silky butter glaze. It must have been freshly painted because a thin film of the butter would stay on your fingers after touching it. And if the bread was a painting for butter then this was a masterpiece worthy of an Italian museum. As light as air but with a taste of heaven.

Followed that up with fried olives stuffed with Fontina cheese. Oh my god! First of all, I friggin hate olives. The only reason I considered this meal was because our waitress recommended it and few weeks ago this Armenian dude let me try one of each of his olives from the olive bar at his store. That taught me that not all olives taste like cr@p. So with that in mind and her recommendation we got these. They were amazing.

Of course nothing can prepare you for cannelloni I got. With nettles and ricotta they were sublime.

After the main course I thought it would be a crime not to get dessert here when everything else was go spectacular. Honestly looking back at the menu I can't even recall which two desserts we ordered because I was so lost in that moment. 

I can't wait to return and relive these moments over and over again.
author: Sanel S.

description: Excellent Italian food. Very trendy and fun place. The bread and burrata are amazing. Must have the radiatore lamb ragu. We had the lamb carpaccio which was awesome.
author: Yasi N.

description:
We visited Delfina's hip n busy sister on a Friday night. As usual she was entertaining a flurry of guests; The hipsters, the professionals, the drunks, the gays, the straights, the puppy loves, the old couples, and anyone else who has the patience or could afford to be in her presence. Locanda doesn't discriminate. She enjoys the bustling crowd as much as they enjoy her style... A rustic meets contemporary type setting with wooden floors and tables in a somewhat dimly lit room, brightened with white walls, while the mirrors give the illusion of spaciousness... Enough that I forgot how much I abhor tight spaces while being bumped around as if in a pinball machine as servers weave in n out of all the standing guests anxiously waiting to be at one of Locanda's dining tables.  This pinball machine's theme? Unmistakably food and alcohol. The experience? Well worth the time you put in at 'insert coins'. Her friendly and competent staff takes ownership of her parties.  It starts at the door, where her friendly hosts greet every guest with the warmest smiles, past the busy multitasking bartenders along the left and servers entertaining seated guests on the right, to the very back where the cooks work magic, teasing our hungers' patience with the aroma of spices and fresh ingredients. The practice of discipline n class is vital during your visit as you can see how one can easily become the "Diva" of a Snickers commercial if not mentally prepared.

We came mentally prepared and yet the three of us nearly fell victim to a Snickers bar moment. Luckily two seats opened up at the bar.  Rather than waiting another 45 minutes on top of the initial 45 minutes, we ditched the dream of having a table for 3 on such a TGIF.  I was more than willing to stand as my beautiful GF and lovely sister from another mister took a seat. We were so famished from a long work day we just fired away.  

Drinks - The bone marrow caught me soooo off guard that I really forgot what I had but it was good... The tequila and pomegranate cocktail I think it was and the cocktail with gin in it. Sorry. If you follow my reviews they are usually much more descriptive but that bone marrow coming up next really did throw me off quite a bit.

Bone marrow - the BIGGEST disappointment I've had EVER with Locanda!!! It was under the small bites section of their menu but if only you saw how small the amount of marrow there was... If it was clothing it would be like labeling a T-Shirt adult S for men but when you put it on, IF you can even put it on, it's actually a petite female T-Shirt size XXS even in petite style.  I wish I had a picture of it for you guys but it was soooo dim in there I didn't want to blind people with that crazy Samsung flash.  On the plate was 2 X-LARGE thickly sliced toasts.  Imagine something like a small espresso stir spoon... Yes, that was all the marrow there was which was able to just tease us by buttering up that one nibble of a corner of one of the toasts.  Brought it up to one of the servers and he says, "That IS (exaggerated accent on the IS) pretty small compared to normal.  It IS (once again he exaggerated the IS) in the small bites section though so it's really a bite." Try a lick buddy. I'd rather butter up a nipple with that Q-Tip of marrow for a more seductive experience. We were pretty much robbed of 7 bucks plus tax and tips. A little bitter. Can't believe I didn't give them 3 stars or less. I still love you Locanda.

Sweetbreads fried artichokes parsley n capers squeeze of lemon - Freakin' delicous.  Fried to a light crispy crusted perfection while still moist and tender with every bite. The artichoke and capers were a nice touch especially with lemon brightening up the deep fried goodies.

Short rib pasta - Little balls of pasta wrapped short rib with a sauce that was probably made from the braising of the short ribs. Gigi M. doesn't eat beef and even she loved it.

Chanterelle pine nuts - Mushrooms are always a must in my books... you can't really mess up with mushrooms unless you really didn't know what you were doing.  Get it if you love the light earthy peppery sweet flavors of the Chanterelle.

Bucatini - Liked it a lot but didn't love it.  They do make the bucatini in house but I've had much better although the tomato sauce was fresh, mildly sweet, and had just the right acidity.  Hard to love it when Tony's Pizza in North Beach has it down to a science.  

Berkshire Pork Panchetta - Crispy skin, fats rendered, tender moist flesh gives you the perfect warm savory bite with all three textures.  That was my fave of the night along with the fish!

Grilled Cod w chicories sea salt spicy sauce olive oil and lemon on the side - grilled with such skill that the flesh was a tender fleshy flaky bite.  I usually cringe when it comes to Americans and fish but they did it just right even for the like of a Chinese.  I loved how they didn't over season it, allowing the freshness of the fish to shine.  

Must try guys!
author: Colin M.

description:
We went to Locanda for the first time on a recent Saturday night expecting great things based on Yelp reviews, but alas, we didn't find many qualities to like 

Quick Overall Review--- The food/drinks at Laconda are good, their service is atrocious, it's overpriced, restaurant basics are neglected, and it is a real chore to visit here. Unfortunately, they are apparently so popular right now, it is a place to "see and be seen", and service levels always seem to suffer in restaurants like that

In Depth Review:
Reservations-- Our group of 8 was looking forward to trying this highly rated dinner spot, so we knew reservations were a must and made them months in advance for a special occasion. 

The "reservation" was basically worthless, as we still had to wait another 30 minutes before getting a table... I've never understood restaurants that take reservations and then force you to wait. If WE had showed up 30 minutes late, do you think they would be happy about it?? Hell no!! (What we observed as we waited was very poor, haphazard table management by the staff)

After we complained about the wait, the manager, who at least was apologetic, finally cobbled a couple of tables together and comped us 2 $5 apps to keep us quiet... wow

Cocktails-- very good, some unique flavors

Service-- exceptionally SLOOOOW, with no sense of urgency, inaccurate, and aloof. We waited long periods of time for food and then some dishes were served cold. I asked for a black napkin after my black shirt got white fuzz all over it from their white napkin and was met with an eye roll from our server, but she did bring one

The entrees for the table came out from the kitchen at different times, often served to the wrong person, and we had to sit an inappropriate amount of time with our food in front of us, getting cold, waiting for the rest of the table to be served. One diner asked for his whole fish to be de-boned, but when it arrived it wasn't de-boned, so MORE waiting and no apology for the mistake. And sadly, the server did not initially comp the apps on our bill as her manager had instructed, and had to be reminded

Food-- The bread is heavenly. Apps (Jewish artichokes, sweetbreads, and fried olives) were all good. The pastas were hit-or-miss, the whole fish was okay, but lacked flavors other than "fish", and the guinea hen was phenomenal, easily the best dish on the menu.

Miscellaneous-- The place is very, very, very LOUD. We were constantly saying "WHAT??", "Sorry, can't hear you", "WHAT??" ... Romantic and intimate it is not

In addition, when we made the reservation, we were told that getting a cab back to our hotel was "no problem". NOTHING could be further from the truth... Upon leaving the restaurant, we asked the hostess to call us 2 cabs. She responded by saying she "guessed" she could do that, but not to expect any taxis to actually show up, since they are "too busy on a Saturday night" to come pick us up.

We also asked the valet staff to help, but they refused, saying it wasn't their problem. (They apparently weren't interested in any tip money from us) And even though taxis were everywhere, none stopped in front of Laconda. SO, we ended up having to walk to the corner and out into the street to force a cab to stop... Not cool... This alone is a very good reason to avoid this particular area of SF on a Saturday night, and take your money elsewhere 

Is Laconda worth it? Sadly, I say no...
author: Steve K.

description:
Anyone who has met me, or who has read my writing, knows that this girl loves a great cocktail. However, it's rare that I'm so moved by some particular drink that I'm compelled to dedicate an entire article to singing its praises. This is one of those occasions.

The Church, currently on Locanda's cocktail menu, is the perfect summer drink. Made with gin, aperol, cocchi americano, and lemon, it's a taste I had never experienced until recently - probably because I was unfamiliar with 50% of the ingredients. The gin and lemon, obviously. Anyway, after returning three times within one month just to order as many as I possibly can, I now officially rank it as one of my all-time favorite drinks. Why? Because it's refreshing without being cliche, substantial without being too heavy, and chalk full of alcohol without being unbalanced.

This cocktail doesn't reek of gin, nor does it taste similar to your standard "refreshing" drinks like a basil gimlet or something girly mixed with Prosecco and St. Germaine. No, this is an original - one that anyone, no matter what your hard liquor preferences may be, would find appealing. It's just like a cool breeze on a hot summer's day, if a cool breeze got you drunk.

Enjoy it while you can.
author: Kelsey E.

description:
I have been back. Many times. And let me say... 

I LOVE THIS PLACE. 

My first experience sucked totally because it was opening weekend and there were a lot of kinks to work out. They have worked them out and boy oh boy are they killing it! Love love love this place. Reminds me so much of NY, so when I get really homesick, I will book a table at Locanda ASAP!
author: Jen D.

description:
Dinner tasted pretty good, except that they poisoned me.  I have a food allergy and I was very definite about the allergy.  At this restaurant, the chef was too busy to let me know what I couldn't eat up front although the waitress did make her best guess. (By the way, the restaurant was not even full and the bar was failrly empty at the time)

I was assured that all of my dishes were ok after I ordered  and they all would be allergen free.  Well, I get home and a few hours later I am struck with either an allergic reaction or a horrible case of food poisoning (the symptoms are quite similar).  I am fairly certain it is allergies. 

I am sure it will pass soon enough, but it really sucks when a restaurant doesn't take your allergies seriously (thank goodness I don't have an epi-pen type reaction) or I would have probably ended up in the hospital.
author: Cat C.

description:
I went here recently with a friend and had an excellent meal from start to finish.  The cocktails were great - I had the Nonna Diavalo, with lime, ginger and rye which was tasty.  We ordered a few different dishes as samplers..  The artichokes were great - we had the fried Jerusaelem artichoke, and also we tried a raw artichoke thinly sliced in a salad.  My favorite was the salad, but both were good.   We also tried 3 pasta dishes - all excellent.  The final touch was the guinea hen which was as perfect as it gets.  Let me add that the waitstaff was top-notch. Our server had a ton of good suggestions and was always at our table, even in a busy restaurant.  It really put the whole experience over the top.

It is expensive, but for a special occasion I would highly recommend it.
author: David Z.

description: Our party had a reservation for 8pm but we weren't seated until 8.45pm. I consider this an unacceptable wait time. What's the point in making a reservation at all? They gave us some complimentary snacks but let's just say, they weren't worth the wait. The food is ok but the pasta dishes are not even close to entree size. I could easily have eaten two - and I am not a large person. The server did mention this to us before she took our order, but this is something that should really be pointed out on the website, so that people can make a more informed decision. We chose a restaurant that we thought was reasonably priced. However, if you want to leave the place feeling satisfied, it works out very expensive. They also overcharged us $50, which we didn't realize till the next day. Overall, I would not recommend it.
author: Bernice C.

description:
Had a horrible dinner @ West of Pecos across the street, and decided to salvage the evening w/ a great pine nut persimmon tart and nite caps.  Too bad we didn't try Locanda earlier!  The dessert was DELICIOUS!!!  Drinks were great and served by super cute bartenders so what's really there to complain about - nothing!

Must go back for dinner in the beautiful space :)
author: Stephanie C.

description: I loved this place! One of my favorite Italian places in SF. The chef was very evenhanded and balanced with his seasoning and delicious.
author: Dimple B.

description:
A friend of mine introduced me to Locanda not long ago and it did not take long for me to fall in love with the atmosphere and become a regular. 
Expect to wait in line for table but at the same time of course, expect great food.
I want to sit at the bar and have a drink or 2 as I order my dinner and that hasnt happened yet, so ya crowded they are but that just means great service, great food and great atmosphere.
author: Kajal P.

description:
We had a partial buy-out of Locanda and hosted a 50-person corporate dinner event. All guests raved about the exceptional food, knowledgeable service and great venue. The event coordinator, Heather went above and beyond helping us organize such a wonderful event. 
 
We couldn't have been more pleased with Heather's recommendation to host our event at Locanda. The positive vibes in the front of the restaurant carried through to the semi-private room in the back where our guests sat. The back room was separated from the front with a curtain, has nice view of the chefs cooking, great lighting and nice long tables for a unique family-style dining. We were confident no detail would be overlooked with Heather's exceptional help and event experience.
 
Overall, we can't say enough good things about the food, service and cocktails. We look forward to hosting another event with them in the future.
author: Caitlin C.

description:
so disappointing. 

no more sweet breads, but had the jewish artichokes, and they were a tad too salty, but pretty good. 

the thinly sliced chilled beef tongue was ok, but the dish didn't really come together for me. 

for our main entrees, there was no style or presentation whatsoever, it looked like a lunch line dollop of food thrown into a bowl or onto a plate. 

the cacio e pepe was a small bowl of pasta with parmesan and black pepper for $14. it was RIDICULOUSLY STUPID.

the lamb ragu tasted like canned pasta sauce with meat dumped over pasta. it was not that appetizing and for $17. 

they didn't have their res or seating done well and split up 2 small tables to put 2 couples, but they did it so that our tables were literally 1 inch apart and stacked 2 inches up. there was a girl from another table speaking so loud we could hear every single word she said. it was hard to have a conversation in this place. 

overall the experience was not very enjoyable. i'd give 1 star to level out its "4 star" rating, but it really deserves 1.5..

Verdict: SEVERELY OVERRATED AND COMPLETELY UNDERWHELMING.
author: Sau y.

description:
Hot, steamy focaccia bread.
Jewish artichokes.
Heirloom tomato salad.
Tortellini.
Guinea hen.
Warm chocolate cake.

Try it. Now. And get a few cocktails to sip on while you're at it.
author: Helen Z.

description:
I'm giving this place two stars because the customer service and waitstaff were great. Bartenders were nice and drinks were good. Our table was ready for us upon arriving. Food on the on the other hand was not so good. The bread was cold and stale, the Jewish-Style Artichoke and  RADISHES and ANCHOVY BUTTER disappointments too.  Both were salty and uneatable which put the final nail in our night there. 

We ended up down the street at Fritz. I'd go back for drinks, but not for anything else.
author: Jay R.

description: The place is super nice but really loud. I liked the food a lot!
author: Léa B.

description:
Locanda is a wonderful place to take a date.  Solid food, an atmosphere which strikes the balance between Nice and Fun, and great service.  I'm a big fan of the cocktails, and the ever-changing handmade pastas are routinely great.  I've been a bit underwhelmed by the entrees in the past so I go for appetizers and the aforementioned pasta at this point.  Anyway, the staff is really what makes the place great.  I always leave feeling looked-after but never pressured, which is particularly cool in that as often as not I'm leaving as they're closing up.  Sorry 'bout that...

------

@Pedro I.

The standard markup for any booze in any restaurant is 300% at the _minimum_.  Restaurants frequently lose money on food in the expectation of making it back on the beverages. Furthermore, on glass pours there is the extra need to compensate for the remainder of the bottle getting dumped at the end of the night (what, you'd rather drink oxidized wine?).  

While it is more than understandable that this strikes you as excessive, it's something you'll see over and over when you price things out in the future.  For example, a 750ml bottle of Grey Goose costs roughly $30.  There's a touch over 25oz in there, so with a standard 1.5oz pour in a cocktail that equals 16 drinks.  Even if you're paying $7 for that cocktail (unheard of at this point) then you're paying the equivalent of $116 for a $30 bottle.  It's even more extreme with beer, especially if it's out of a keg.  I would encourage you to think of it as simply paying for a wonderful setting in which to have a great experience. In SF, with the cost of real estate as well as the minimum wage of $12/hr being what they are, that's exactly what it is.

So yeah, man - if that's the only reason for your 2 stars then you might want to rethink your ranking.
author: Muhammad I.

description: With Matt's help we set up a special dinner for our team of 20 (!) here on a Tuesday evening. Matt was amazing: responsive, organized and helpful when it came to picking out wine, arranging the table and selecting food. The dinner went off without a hitch and complements from the team were plentiful. Thank you so much to everyone at Locanda and to Matt for making this so amazing! Definitely recommend!
author: Shanna T.

description:
Really enjoyed this place.
Came here with a GF on a Wed night, packed by 8pm!

Knowledgable and friendly waiter, nice ambience.

Food on point- we had the fried green beans with parm- $8 very yummy and light but tasty, early girl tomato salad- very refreshing $12, house special of the day, roasted whole bass (I think) with caper and shishito $25, and got the highly recommended pasta with the dried pork belly (forgot the price). YUM! Everything was delicious and prepared with care. Total with tip $40 a person. Pasta portions not huge but getting a few items to split is great to eat in as  multicourse way just like they do in 'Tuscany". 

Yummy complementary foccacia 

I like and I will be back!
author: Petri Y.

description:
I only came here because the wait at West of Pecos was over an hour, and after I wished I'd waited for my original choice.

The atmosphere and service: When I tried to walk up to the hostess stand a girl rushed through the door past me to take Facebook photos of her friend at a nearby table, blocking the entire doorway while the hostess just watched blankly. This is the kind of place where you can expect to be seated practically on top of the people next to you, and as such I was right next to a party of 3 who were so loud I had to shout to my dining companion the entire evening. This felt like I was trying to eat in a club and was the opposite of intimate. Our server was friendly but a little overbearing and continually interrupted us all evening. 

The food: I'm no stranger to nice restaurants, but I also don't speak Italian, so some descriptions on the menu would be helpful. Everything tasted good, but we didn't get very much food considering we spent about $40 a person before tip. I got a veal pasta dish and there were literally 10 pieces of pasta on the plate, with more plate showing than food. The cake dessert was a cube of cake that was about the size of a mini cupcake. 

I'd come back and have an appetizer and a glass of wine before heading someplace else for dinner.
author: Beth D.

description: It seems that everyone loves this place, so not much I can add to the reviews. Tried the Jewish Style Artichokes because everyone here raves about it - it was okay but not the highlight of our meal. Everything else was delicious and so flavorful. We had the Trippa alla Romana (took me back to Italy - tastes just like what I've had in Rome!), Bellweather Ricotta and Persimmons, Mezze Maniche with bits of dungeness crab, and the Huckleberry for dessert. I had a cocktail and he had a beer. We actually got full by sharing plates, but then again, we don't have huge appetites.
author: Zell C.

description:
Damn good food.  
Damn good drinks.
Damn the prices ! ! ! !

Setting: 2 gurlfrendz catchin' up over dinner
I made sure to make a reservation - DO NOT ENTER WITHOUT THIS!

What we had:
1 Calamondini (best. cocktail. ever.)
1 Piedmonte Punch (decent, but the Calamondini was better imo)
1 GL Pinot Noir (my friend said it was good)
1 Artichoke (had to be done -- *so very worth it*)
1 B Stracciatella (I've forgotten what this was?!)
1 Patata Affumicat (smoked mashed potato side dish-fcukin' incredible!)
1 Linguini (OMG OMG OMG - I'm just starting to eat seafood and realizing its awesome-ness. This crab/asparagus pasta dish was buttery goodness!)
-- and honestly? we were full.  we were very verrrrrry full. --
BUT THEN!
Our patient, well-informed, ever so persuasive waiter 'Jack' completely sold us on the: 
1 Ricotta Fritta (and dear sweet mother of all things holy - it was unnecessarily and unforgivably good - i don't give a rat's ass how full you are. You'll have room for this. JUST TRUST ME! I EAT FRIED CHEESE FOR DESSERT FOR GOD'S SAKE!)
-----
total: $95.48 (without tip)

I know I shouldn't be back.
My wallet threatens to run off every time I start feeling nostalgic about this place.

...but how can I? forget you (food)
...When there's always something there to remind me?!
author: Anjali V.

description:
I had dinner here with my husband and some friends, and overall I was impressed. We started with cocktails, which were delicious. 

To start, one of our appetizers was the truffle polenta balls, and they were amazing. We also had the artichoke, which was really good too, but the polenta was the table favorite.

For our meal we shared a few of their pastas family style. I enjoyed them all, although my husband complained that the portions were too small, given the price.

Overall, the flavors were authentic Italian, the cocktails enhanced the meal, and we had a good time.
author: Whitney G.

description:
Had the best meal in a while at Locanda the other night. Great service for kids (somewhat surprisingly).  And the waitresses are almost all very nice (especially with kids). 

The only complaints are the pastas are never as good as I would like - and the valet guy is tough to track down.
author: Carl A.

description:
We ended up here very late one night (after being unceremoniously booted out of another restaurant whose kitchen just malfunctioned). We arrived a few minutes before closing and the restaurant was packed, so they had every right to refuse to seat us. But the hostess and wait staff were beyond accommodating. We asked them if they wanted us to order before we sat, so that the kitchen could fire our dishes and close up- but they said "no, we aren't going to rush you". That, to me, is above and beyond good service.

The drinks were amazing. They have a fantastic collection of rum and they make their own ginger beer. I would go back just for the rum and ginger beer.

The food was really good- not amazing, but good enough to go back for. The deep friend olives were delicious and the pastas were cooked perfectly.

Also, the space is beautiful.
author: Nina M.

description:
First time and definitely not the last! Not only is the food exceptional, but the wine list is AH-mazing. I went here with my sister and got seated right where the food comes out. If this if your first time going, I recommend that same table. You could see all the dishes coming out and the chefs hard at work.  While your waiting and sipping on some drank (lol) you're served  house made toasted bread drizzled with olive oil and sprinkled with sea salt. 

FAIR WARNING: Don't get full off of that delicious bread you will want to save room for dessert! 

To start we had: 

VEAL CASONCELLI alla SALTIMBOCCA
paired with a red, Cantina Damiano "Silene", Cesanese, Lazio, Italy
What is this velvet? This deliciousness simply melts in your mouth leaving no room for conversation. 

OXTAILS alla VACCINARA with the INSALATA MISTICANZA (12 greens, acetto,xvoo) 
paired with a wine from Spain: I forget which one it was, but it's the only red from Spain by the glass. 
It's like butter BUT better! Putting your fork to cut through these is not hard work at all.  After all, didn't we just work 8 hours? It cuts through with a butter knife. Now that's how Oxtail is done.  I highly recommend eating the oxtail with a salad because it's very flavorful.   


FRIED DUCK EGG "al LIONESE" - smoked pancetta
paired with Leone Conti, Sangiovese, Emilia Romagna, Italy 
Always love me some poached eggs and this was on point.  The pancetta complimented this rich tasting duck for sure.  I have to admit, paired with this wine made it FANTASTIC and me wanting more. Unfortunately! 

So my sister and I looked at each other like we needed to be rolled out. I said we have to have dessert to complete our dining experience, so without an arm pull, we did and it didn't disappoint.  

For dessert we had the CIAMBELLINI ASSORTITI ginger, cocoa nib, espresso paired with the flight of three (two kinds of Fernet Blanca).I forgot the last one. The dessert alone will have you drooling on its way out, but the flight of trio put this in its place and makes your meal complete. I definitely recommend this to all!
author: Tiffany B.

description: The highlight of a foodie's trip. Excellent food, service, ambiance, decor and value/price. Inventive farm to table Italian cuisine. The fried olives, the pork chop, the ciabatta bread, the Jerusalem artichokes were OUT OF THIS WORLD. This place is a must.
author: Mario C.

description:
WOAW! Over $100 for diner for two? Thank goodness I didn't pay ;) 
The food was good the drinks were better, I had the Church. The food wasn't filling though, I'm glad we had cheese and bread at the mixer before our reservation.
I'll go back, but just for drinks, I would go back for diner only if the bill isn't on me. his girl is on a BUDGET in  this New Mission District, HA!
author: Claudia G.

description: Perfect modern Italian restaurant. Try the "olive all'Ascolana" (stuffed olives). Great ambiance and food in the Mission district.
author: Roberto P.

description:
**3.5 Stars**

Great food, but a bit overpriced.

The Linguini with dungeness and sorrel (24) had the unfortunate issue of having several shards of crab shell strewn throughout the dish. For paying such a premium for a fairly small portion, I'd expect it to be nearly flawless in that regard.

The complimentary Pizza Bianca is quite delicious and is topped with a high quality olive oil, - ask for when the next batch is coming out as it's best just out of the oven.
author: Kevin N.

description:
Very good. I flew to San Francisco and while on the plane I read about this place in Food and Wine. Had a chance to go that night. Weird right?  I got there just before 6pm (it opens at 5:30) and it was already jammin'.  We got lucky and snagged a table for two. I would recommend reservations. We got a great table location and waitress. She knew her stuff. 

The weird thing is the Food and Wine article focused on the cocktails. They are plentiful, unique and good but the real rave is the food. They cure their own meats and make their own sausages in house. 

The blood sausage appetizer was good. The highly recommended artichoke salad was okay. The  orecchiette pasta and the whole cod entrees were superb. 

When in SF go here. Bottom line. You'll love it. So many more things I need to try. Can't wait until I'm back in town.
author: Marc A.

description:
I had a lot of fun at this place. I was already a few sheets to the wind and so was happy to explore this expensive-looking place. 

We seated ourselves at a high table, with myself being a tad worried about the elevation. The waiter promptly appeared, and took our reservation. The service was really good here, with rarely a delay. I was impressed.

It is very, very rare that I encounter something completely unknown on a menu, but it happened here. It is the 'Fried Castelvetrano Olives'. They take olives and fry them. Wow. They were so, so good.

I had the Old Fashioned Flight for $20- three smallish glasses of Old Fashioned made with three different liquors: rye & demerara, bourbon and maple, scotch and honey. The rye/demerara was divine, bourbon was tolerable and the scotch stank. But I am glad I tried them and I was not too proud to drink all three.

I would definitely go back to this place again, and again.
author: Vic P.

description:
I gave this restaurant four stars because the food was wonderful.  I did not give it five for two reasons.  First, we asked for bread and we were not told there would be a charge for it.  No big deal, just would have been nice to know.  Second, my husband and I ordered the same thing.  I couldn't decide between two pasta dishes, so our server suggested a half order of one of them.  When our food came, we assumed that she gave me a half order of both.  My serving had half the meat (we counted meatballs and pieces of other meats) and I had exactly half, with much less pasta.  I commented on how exact they were in their servings.  The bill came and I had been given the full order, but, no evidence of portion control.  

It is a beautiful place, though very noisy.  Lots of energy and action.  The menu is creative and has dishes you will not see anywhere else.
author: Patti R.

description:
I really don't get the hype...  Maybe it's the restaurant du jour effect the mission district is so good at creating, that on a Tuesday night this place is jam packed?

I always applaud the concept of these new places: cute decor, homemade pasta, reasonable price.  But lacanda added a little too much of something to that equation and threw off the entire balance. That little something is salt.  

It began with some attitude on the phone when I called ahead to find out corkage.  I was put on hold for 5 minutes then whoever answered it spit out $18 and hung up.  Well rudeness is the epicenter of hipster culture, and I am used to even ruder Chinatown waitstaff, so, fine, I'll take it.  

But I won't take it when the food offends me.  The amount of salt in my carbonara was enough to cause hypertension.  And the bone marrow pizza...  albeit yummy, as I can be partial to bone marrow, calling it pizza blanca is just so...  pretentious.  The Jewish artichoke was the only good dish, but in tiny portions.

Desserts...  decent.  Not a fan of fried ricotta.  Chocolate cake was good, but have I ever had a bad chocolate cake anywhere?

Overall, underwhelming.
author: Jiajia C.

description: Where to start...I really enjoyed the Matador cocktail. It didn't look like much when served but it had a good amount of tequila. I don't speak Italian, so when it came to the menu I was kind of lost. Per recommendations from the server, I tried the pasta with sausage. Still can't say the name but the dish was delicious! For dessert I would recommend the one with espresso. Yum!
author: Justin C.

description: The best meal I have had in a long time.  Started with the warm squash/chicory salad and then a pasta dish - tortilla with crezensa cheese.  Yum!
author: Annie B.

description:
This has got to be one of the best restaurants I have been too in a long time.

Everything was delicious!

Pizza Bianca was the best possible way to eat cauliflower- and now the only way I will eat forever now!

The pasta was unbelievably al dente and delish- I am salivating now just thinking of it!

Eat the carbonara and tomato-based sauce pasta! They were amazing- maybe a little bit too much bacon in both (or perhaps we picked not the right combination) but that is all I can fault them on.

I want to fly To San Fran already just for this meal again! 

My husband just recalled that this has got to be one of his best he has had AND enjoyed in a long time!
author: Tamara S.

description:
Locanda is definitely the sexy new joint in the Mission. It's been up and running a little over a year and is doing fantastic. I would best describe the cuisine as "New Roman Italian with California Ingredients".  Cool vibe, long waits, dim settings, service spot on, food equally good, drinks stole the show.

What we ordered:
- Jewish Artichoke aka fried artichoke
- Fava Bean Flatbread - excellent, 3 big pieces
- Slow Roasted Local Salmon - caught that same morning from Half Moon Bay, cooked to perfection (served pink), on a bed of veggies and oil
- Mixed Grill - a bunch of different meats that my friend best described as "good". He said it all tasted very good, cooked well, but wasn't over the top.

Their drinks are amazing here, the only problem is they go down too fast. Definitely have fun with their cocktail list. Our server Jack was also extremely attentive, knowledgeable and patient. He knew his menu and was great with recommendations. 

Bring your wallet. It's expensive.
author: Jessica A.

description: One of these places where everything is just right, the food, wine list, prices and ambiance but for some reason it's not exceptional to get 5 stars.
author: MICKY T.

description:
I always wanted to go to Locanda. It turned out to be a huge disappointment. The waitress was full of attitude and wasn't attentive at all to begin with. It took us for ever to get the order taken. For appetizer, we ordered the prosciutto with focaccia and jewish style artichoke. The proscuitto was overly salty compared to the ones from La Ciccia, Press Club or Sotto Mare. I asked for balsamic to go with the focaccia - because it was dry, chewy and overly olive oil soaked (you will see servers POUR olive oil onto the dry focaccia right before they serve the bread). I was told that they don't have balsamic. Hello?! An Italian restaurant has no balsamic? The waitress probably noticed my disappointment and brought out sherry vinegar from the kitchen. With appreciation, I don't think any waiters or waitresses at an Italian restaurant will simply think balsamic can be replaced with sherry vinegar.

We had the lamb chop and king salmon. The king salmon was good but the lamb chop was overly salty. 

Not sure if this is their one night off. Definitely have to rethink before I would go back again!
author: Yina M.

description:
In short: "Don't believe the hype".

Incredible long wait, even though we had reservation. Poor service. Disappointing food. 

We had 8:30 PM. reservations, arrived at 8:20 PM. got sit down at 9:00 PM. and waited until 9:30 PM to get four pieces of bread a.k. the Pizza Bianca. By 10 pm the main course had still not arrived. 

Total of our bill $100 = Four pieces of bread, one bowl of pasta with tomato, a very salty piece of hen and glasses of vino bianco that weren't chilled. 

We won't come back. There are too many good restaurants in the city to be coming back to this place. 

Learn from ZUNI CAFE !!!
author: Isabel P.

description:
Who knew finding a place to have dinner with old friends in the Mission on a Tuesday night would be so hard? Long waits at Monk's Kettle and Tartine led us here instead.

To say I really liked it is kind of like saying I really liked having braces: you're better off for it afterward but the act itself is not all that great. That's how my belly and tastebuds felt after Locanda. I wish the fried olives had bleu or goat cheese in them, how amazing would that have been? How about the same for the Jewish-style cauliflower? If you're gonna bread and/or fry stuff, might as well stuff it too. 

There was nothing wrong with my leg of lamb and my friend's crab linguine but I'm not in a hurry to get back to Locanda.

One more thing: they make some stiff cocktails. One more Business Thyme and I would have passed out on the BART and woken up in Oakland.
author: Andre L.

description:
The ambiance and service staff are both great. However, I was pretty displeased with the value of the food. We ordered a total of 3 drinks and the whiskey sampler, pasta as an appetizer to share, he got the fish of the day (grilled), and I got Mary's chicken. The total was over $140. The bread at the beginning of the meal was DELICIOUS, as was the carbonara pasta we shared, and my partner loved his fish. However, stay away from the chicken. You don't get much and the greens it comes with taste really weird. It also comes with some square shaped green things that are disgusting. Overall, the pasta and seafood is good but very pricey, as are their $12 drinks.  

We went on a Tuesday and it was packed when we left around 7:30, so good luck getting a reservation on a Friday or Saturday. I think there are plenty of other places you're better off going to for a date before considering this place.
author: Sofia M.

description:
3.75 Stars. The ambience and the scene is really good and you will have a good time. The food was solid but it fell short in some areas. Consider it over hyped but still a fun place to go. Great wine list. the waiting staff is quite accommodating and friendly. Super nice people.

Jewish Artichoke: Very good
Grilled Endives: Best dish of the night
Lamb Ragu: Very good
Pasta with white sauce and Panceta: very good
Fish of the day: A-OK
author: Lo F.

description:
We celebrated a gfs birthday here and they gave us the table in the front by they window.

A friend suggested that I order the Church as my drink.  VERY well made drink 6 stars :)

We ordered:

JEWISH - STYLE ARTICHOKES: 4 stars  it was good not mind blowing
FRIED CASTELVETRANO OLIVES: 0 stars for me bc I hate olives but friends said it was good
GRILLED PIZZA BIANCA - crushed burrata, olio verde, mint: 4 stars very tasty
BRUSSELS SPROUTS - smoked pancetta, capers: 3.5 it was good but i wish it was a lil crisp
LOBSTER AND BURRATA RAVIOLI: 5 stars so creamy and delicious
AFFOGATO CORRETO - fior di latte gelato, espresso, Amaro Cio Ciaro: 3.5 starts.  I only had a bit and it was good but didn't wow me.

All small portions... would dine here if I plan to go out afterwards because I don't want a heavy dinner.

I thought we were suppose to receive complimentary foccocia  but we didn't :(
author: Anne-Mary P.

description: Good service but food was OK. The first pasta dish was dry and we had to send it back. Better places in SF for Italian for sure.
author: Nehal M.

description:
This was my first time to Locanda.  Great food, nice atosphere.  My only complaint is that most of the menu items need some explanation - if you're not versed in Italian.

Great portions.  Dishes well seasoned.  Nice wine selection.

I had the Oxtails alla Vaccinara.  Delish!  I could have gobbled the dish up like BBQ ribs!

I would suggest you take a look a the painting hanging in the back of the restaurant.  It's of a hand holding baby birds/chicks.  It looks like the hand is strangling the birds.  LOL.  Poor little birdies.  Slightly disturbing if you're drunk.  :)

Cheers!
author: Brian V.

description:
-The food was delicious! Of the items ordered, the shrimp cusini was especially outstanding. 
-The drinks were nicely crafted. 
-The service was fantastic. 

I would go back, especially to try out the charcuterie.
author: Brenda T.

description:
We spent a great evening at Locanda.  We tried to get a table for weeks and couldn't.  We called last minute and got a table an hour later.  It was a cool place, nicely decorated.  The waitstaff and service were excellent.  I knocked over a glass of wine and our waitress topped everybody off.  We were served some excellent pizza bianco to get things going.  My only real complaint about the restaurant was that there was a dearth of reasonably priced wine.  A $40 bottle of primitivo, chianti classico or Malbec would be welcome.   The appetizers were mostly great- we enjoyed the Roman style artichokes, fried olives and proscuitto.  We tried the radishes with anchovy butter because we couldn't imagine what it would taste like.  It was the restaurant's only miss.  Main courses were very good to excellent.  The pork saltimbocca was excellent and flavor intense.  The cuscini with shrimp was really good.  Grilled fish was good.  We really enjoyed the desserts.  The almond torta and chocolate bread pudding both had their fans.  

Really fun evening at a very good restaurant with excellent service.  Looking forward to going back.
author: Joel S.

description:
Locanda, the self-dubbed osteria (a misnomer that the 99% should find particularly offensive), evokes the dark-furrowed androgyny of high-end fashion boutique - from its shabby-chic patronage to the tasteful, grayscale art. 

I've little quibble with the nibbles. The appetizers are well-conceived, tasty, and priced to please: to wit, a deep-fried strand of artichokes and sweetbreads ($12), the do-not-miss lamb's tongue ($12), a hearty trio of oxtails ($22), and a fried duck egg on simple greens ($12).

The pasta mains ($14-$18) are a little more troublesome - enough to peg the dining experience at 'wholly mediocre'. 

Locanda's saving grace (unexpectedly, given low-corkage-fee BYOB) is its bar, which deserves four stars on a standalone basis. Drinks are beautifully designed and delivered; take a chance on the barkeep's choice, if you find yourself in the unlikely scenario that nothing on the menu inspires. 

My advice: skip dinner, stick to the bites and the bar.
author: Liz C.

description: So so stoked that we finally dined here! Such a great experience, from the service to the drinks and food. Order the whole fish - grilled. They serve it with an incredible house made chili sauce. You heart and tummy will be so full of happiness and everyone else will be looking at your fish like all jealous. Can't wait to go back to try the pastas!
author: Chauanh D.

description:
Decided to try out this new hip joint that apparently is the new Delfina rival. It ended up being a 20 minute wait on a Sunday night around 9pm. 

We decided to grab a cocktail at the bar while we waited for a table. They promptly gave us water, and served us right away. The cocktails here are excellent! With several specials, they conjured up some wonderful mixtures. You can also request one by the bartender based on your likings. 

An arugula with artichokes & avocados tossed in a very light dressing was a good starter (can't remember the name). They start you off with warm toasty bread as well (which I thought was a little too buttery & salty to my liking). 

For my main dish I had the Linguini with dungeness crab, lettuce and sorrel ($22). The Linguini noodles were fabulous- as they tasted fresh and yummy. As for the rest of the dish, it lacked a little umph. It was lightly flavored, but unfortunately  I'm going to have to say I was really bored of the dish by the end of my meal. And it didn't help the main dish took surprisingly longer than expected... Left me a bit crabby (har har). 

The service throughout the meal was good. The waiter was kind enough to explain the dishes and refilled our water when possible. 

Now as for the decor- I was a little confused, yet amused by it. The front of the restaurant was very modern like and the back seemed more of a 70's, retro feel with grandma's curtains along the wall. Definitely a different feel in the back than the front. 

Overall, I think Locanda could use some improvement. I won't brush it off entirely, as I have yet to try the rest of the dishes, and there's always room for improvement. 

P.S. A plus in my books is that there are hooks at the bar to hang your belongings. I see this more often now, and I'm glad places like this have it!
author: Catherine O.

description:
The restaurant was crowded and nice. I liked the appetizer. But for main course We ordered lamb chops . This was a huge mistake. We had not had this much fat in our plate for a long time. The two chops didn't have more than two ounces of meat combined. 
All and all I was happy with ambiance, with service and the pastas we tried. But the meats they use are of the cheapest kind.
author: Baha H.

description:
One of my go-to places. 
The food has always hit the spot and the cocktails are spot-on. Not to mention they have a great wine list. 
Can't go wrong here when you're in need of some quality food or just hungry :)
author: Vivy S.

description:
From the house-made bread and the cocktails coming from the bar to their attention to deliciously constructed dishes... Hands down, my go-to restaurant in the city. 

There is something something utterly satisfying about their Bucatini all' Amatriciana. Chunks of crispy guanciale and a deeply spicy red sauce. [Must make another reservation soon...]

Have never been disappointed
author: Michael C.

description:
I've been anxiously wanting to try this restaurant out for months.  After countless walkin attempts with way too long of waits, I finally had dinner here tonight.  Got here early, 6pm...and getting seated was no issue at all.  

The service was great.  The food was kind of underwhelming!  So sad.  Dont get me wrong it was good, but nowhere near the hype I'd heard from friends.  

We started with the prosciutto and fig app which was tasty but lacked something, couldnt put my finger on it.  For an entree, i ordered the lobster mushroom linguini.  It was aiiiight.  It was almost a bit too cheesy, and trust me I'm a cheese BUFF.   

To sum it up, the overal ambiance of the place was great, but I wouldnt go back for the food alone.
author: Gohar J.

description:
A group of us hit Locanda on Monday night and I'm disappointed that I can "only" give it 4 stars as I was there about a year ago and it was one of the better meals I've had in SF.

We decided to start with the tripe and bone marrow. The tripe didn't have the depth of flavor as my previous visit but the bone marrow was spot on. For entrees we had the salmon, lamb ragu, rabbit sugo and guinea hen. The salmon was a bit bland but both pasta dishes and the bird were excellent. I'd highly recommend any of the three if they are on the menu as it changes daily.

Unfortunately the service was probably the most disappointing part of the night. I think out waitress forgot about us after she took our orders.

Also, watch out for the d-bag hipsters flying by on their fixies. They're bent about Locanda valeting cars in the bike lane and one of the passive aggressive tools flew by and kicked over the valet sign nearly hitting my sister.

Overall it was a really great meal but with the poor service and the average salmon I'm going to stick with my 4 stars.
author: James K.

description:
Locanda. I wish I could love this restaurant.
I was so excited to have dinner here since I like delfina.

I had homemade ginger ale. It was really tasty, super crisp, dry and hot. I guess the best ginger ale in my life; also it was the best high light in my dinner at Locanda too. 
We were party of 2 and had 2 kinds of pasta and 2 entrée.  It took two hours to get our entrées. It was like one hour one dish, one hour one dish..... 
Service was super slow but server didn't care how much we had to wait. We were just watching our next table turned twice completely. Also we had to ask a couple of times our server to bring bread, dessert menu, check. So frustrated...

Oh by the way, the food was just ok...
author: Spinof P.

description: Because I just wrote a negative review about another restaurant, I felt it is only fair to write one about a place I've had 2 wonderful experiences.  The service here is amazing, despite how busy the place can be.  Every single dish is delicious and the servers are great at recommending delicious wine.
author: Jack M.

description:
I know it's a fine line to tread when it comes to pleasing the uber picky SF foodies.  We want authentic food that lies within our comfort zone, we want cool decor that doesn't look like it's trying too hard, we want a wait staff that's easy on the eyes but not so beautiful you think they think they are better than you. 

Alas, Locanda seems to be a bit lacking when it comes to balancing these key factors to a good restaurant.  

First and most important: food.  The entire menu is in Italian, which serves as a nice boasting vehicle if you are trying to impress a date that you have travelled to Italy and knows the difference between bucatini and fettucine.  But for us commoners, it takes work and courage to not feel like a complete illiterate. 

Upon the description the waitress gave us on the bucatini with peperonci, our mouths watered because "pasta with meat sauce" (in layman term) sounded awfully familiar to what we had at Seven Hills a few months ago.  The flavorful meat and silky noodles.  Oh my.  Half of us caved in and ordered the same thing. 

Unfortunately the bucatini was good, but definitely couldn't compare to Seven Hill's version.  The pasta was a bit too al dente and the meat sauce was too salty and fatty to finish.  

Allow me to segway into this topic of saltiness: why so salty?  A couple of weeks ago I had dinner at 54 Mint, an Italian restaurant I loved and my friend's pasta carbonara was too salty too.  She, more outspoken than I, let the waiter know and soon the manager came and explained that it's a Roman thing and a lot of SFers couldn't take it.  So are we just wussy health nuts? Or should Romans be watching out for their arteries?

Anyway, let's bring the story back to Locanda and talk about the appetizers.  Since every yelper seemed to have raved about the Jewish style artichoke and pizza bianca, we tried them too.  Artichoke was good or "tasted like fried chicken" as one of our friends claimed.  But it felt like it could have been anything deep fried.  I wasn't sure if I could taste any of the artichoke essence in the dish.  The pizza bianca was more like bruscheta where you spread the bone marrow onto the bread yourself.  It was okay. 

For dessert, the ricotta fritta yelpers seem to like was good.  Warm chocolate cake was good, but I have yet to see any well-reputed restaurant messing up chocolate cake.  And it sorta made me yearn for Pizzeta 211's chocolate cake.  good sign, bad sigh?

Price was reasonable.  Plenty of food for $35 per person including tax and tips.  Ambiance is beautiful. I liked the decor a lot.  Good looking waitstaff and an energetic crowd.  hard to believe it was a mere Tuesday night when the restaurant was filled with people. 

So, yes, despite the over hyped food, Locanda has no issue continuing its popularity.  I only wish it was as justified as Delfina's.
author: Candice B.

description:
