Had a really nice dinner here last Saturday night. Service was attentive, but not to the point where it can get annoying. The cocktails were really, really good and reasonably priced at $10. 

We ordered the fried olives and a crab soup (not sure of the name b/c the menu online has updated), which were both outstanding. The rigatoni and bucatini were also fantastic. I'm surprised by the reviews claiming portions were too small; ours were perfect. It's not freakin' Olive Garden.

Will definitely come back again for dinner or even just drinks.
author: D H.

description:
I love Locanda. It's easily the best Italian restaurant at its price range. Wayyyy better than Delfina.

The kitchen is straight up New York--- you can watch them work and they look like flowing water. There is not a flick of the wrist or any single motion that they do back there that's not contributing to their cooking. They make exceptionally delicious new Italian dishes.

On a night that I spent about three hours here, one at the bar and the two at the table, it was one of the best restaurant experiences I've had so far in SF. My guest, an elite pastry chef, was enthralled with their fried lamb brain. When his boyfriend finally joined us we ordered another plate on the spot. I'd never eaten brains of an animal before because.... well... it's brains. But I'm so glad we got the dish!! The brain bites were well seasoned and crunchy on the outside and the inside was melty--- it tasted like lamb foie gras. That's the depth of the skill of the chefs at Locanda, they could probably serve me something in a bucket and I'd love it.

Oh, so, speaking of serving dishes in buckets, could Locanda serve their rabbit saddle in a bucket? Like fried chicken? That would be a hit restaurant, LFR Locanda Fried Rabbit. I inhaled it, I wish I could eat it every day. The flesh was so juicy and tasted like rabbit but didn't have the gnarly gaminess that usually comes with the meat.

One thing though, they say they have "pizza". No, what they are serving is not pizza, but it tastes really freakin' good nevertheless. 

The service was fantastic the second time. The first time we had one primary server and a handful of other servers bringing up dishes and describing them. It's kind of cute and if it's efficient I guess that's how they like to work. I know they pool tips anyways but I like to tip based on one server. Old school.
author: Lisa Q.

description: I thought this place was just ok.  I had high hopes because I love Delfina and its affiliates but found myself disappointed with the food.  We shared a bunch of appetizers and all were good but not necessarily outstanding.  We had a Carbonara like pasta dish and a pasta dish with short rib meat.  I thought the noodles were too al dente and the price for the portions were high.  I think if I had the choice to go eat some good Italian there  are places I would go over this place.  I should say the service was good and given our larger boisterous group, he was a good sport.
author: Kirsten M.

description:
Yeah this place looks pretty cool, it's true, at least until you get close enough to see the clientele that it attracts, at which point you realize how lame the neighborhood is becoming. Food is mediocre, though the fried artichoke was pretty money, but quite overpriced and yuppy-ish. Servers may be decent, they had some good drinks, and they're totes fancy. 

But seriously the major problem with these guys is their insane plan to have valet service blocking the bike lanes. If you move to Valencia you don't need valet service, there are plenty of parking lots within a few blocks and there's a train that runs through about 2 blocks away yall. Don't support neighborhood busters like these guys, if for no other reason than the crowds they attract, but the valet thing is another level of lameness. 

Fight the power.
author: billy m.

description:
Walked in to Locanda solo on a weeknight around 9pm to grab dinner. Busy, but not full. Plenty of open tables. Host immediately made me feel "welcome" by insisting there were no open tables and bar seats were the only option. No one sat down at those empty tables for the 45 minutes I was there.

Got a similar put-off vibe from my server. Needed to attempt flagging down several times whenever I needed something. Seriously people, do I smell funny? I'm just trying to buy your food.

Speaking of which, it's "meh." Mediocre and too expensive, and unremarkable when there are so many other options in San Francisco, and doubly so when those other places don't play the aloof service card.

Also noticed that their valet blocks the bike lane on Valencia, which is needlessly annoying for folks.
author: Sean K.

description:
The food and drink were high quality and really delicious, but this place is definitely overpriced.

to drink i had the "business thyme" which was a gin cocktail with thyme, honey, and lemon.  awesome. the cocktail was really delicious and refreshing, but youd be surprised how long it took them to make 2 cocktails!  

for dinner, we started with the carciofi crudi which wasn't anything more than an arugula salad with grilled ricotta, avocado, and a few pieces of sliced artichoke on top.  for my main course i had the crescenza tortelli.  delicious! the pasta (including the filling) was so tasty and the sauce and mushrooms were awesome.  small portion, though, for how much you pay.

service was ok- a little slow, but friendly.  decent experience overall.
author: Lisa C.

description:
first off, the food was really good here. I do think the portions were smaller than expected but to be honest, I think that perception may be based on the fact that the plates are too big for the portions.

the reason for the 3 stars: the service. throughout our meal, the waitress seemed disinterested in our table (at best). we waited more than 5 minutes once sat just for a glass of water. when she did pour the water it splashed all over the table. when we asked questions, we were met with a borderline - rude indifference. we ordered a bottle of wine and when our food came out before the bottle, we had to remind the waitress we had not received our drinks yet. she did not offer a "sorry" "it will be right out" or anything of that nature. 

the food was good but I'm sure food like this can be found elsewhere with much better service to accompany it.
author: Megha A.

description: Got the leg of lamb and was served extremely undercooked pieces that were inedible and chewy. Told the server that I could not eat the dish and was told I was wrong in that I didn't understand what properly cooked meat should look like. They brought out another dish that was cooked perfectly and actually very tasty, but I felt like the bad guy. Bad experience.
author: Curtis L.

description:
tl;dr: way too much salt. For the price, I expect something more refined.

Had the fried olive appetizer. I didn't know it'd be breaded and fried, but oh well that shouldn't be a problem... except the breading was decently salted. The salty delicious olives were taken to a virtually inedible place with the breading. This begun my Locanda Journey Into the Salt™.

Got some fluffy bread free with the meal, but also extremely salty. We asked for some olive oil and balsamic, but they only had oil. It was great oil, but couldn't save the bread from the salt.

Ordered the carbonara and a lamb pasta. The carbonara had delicious, crunchy bits of pork belly in it, but was overall too salty to eat. I know pork is salty, this was way beyond the natural flavor from the meat.

The lamb was delicious. Just a tad more salty than I'd like, but totally edible.

I think a great solution would have been way less salt in the food and some delicious sea salt at the table. Then patrons can salt to taste. I noticed they did not offer pepper or alteration of any kind. I just hope the feeling isn't "we make it so perfect there's no reason for offering an alteration", because that's just not the way the human palette works.
author: Kelly J.

description:
Awesome place. A bit of an older crowd, I must say. But this is, after all, a class place, so I guess that makes sense. Despite the older vibe, the music was young and fun (Beck, Indie Rock).

I tried:
FRIED CASTELVELTRANO OLIVES
JEWISH STYLE ARTICHOKES
CRESCENZA  TORTELLI with black trumpet mushrooms, mint, pinenuts
WARM CHOCOLATE CAKE almond milk gelato, cocoa nib croccante, earl grey

All the dishes were delicious. My only regret is not getting a salad since I ate all the fried food (not really complaining! Just saying). I would definitely eat here again.
author: Amber K.

description:
Pasta perfection.

Also burnt orange carrots, fava bean pizza, Jewish-style artichokes, crab soup, chocolate cake, grapefruit cocktails and slow-roasted strawberries perfection.

But it does start with the pasta. A rabbit ragu. A mind blowing creation.

Design includes baskets of artichokes. And candles in sardine containers. In other words clever, subtle and perfect.

Less than $50/person to sample all this brilliance. We weren't alone. Place continues to be packed. Deservingly so.

One of my favorite meals of the year. One of my favorite meals of forever.
author: Jason B.

description:
Awesome.  Best pasta I've had in SF since the early days of Quince.  The Jewish-Style Artichoke (lightly fried) is deserving of the hype -- a really unique preparation that is both unusual and delicious.  I had a bite of the "cacciatore" which was actually a game hen cooked over a wood fire -- perfectly tender and unbelievably tender.  For dessert : the budino.  Light and fresh, yet simultaneously complex and decadent.  The one cocktail I sampled (Business Thyme, with gin/thyme/honey/lemon) was solid if not spectacular; the rest of the list had several tempting options.  Service was friendly and fast, but they otherwise left us alone and didn't try to rush us out the door after we were done with our meal.  Overall, a great experience, and I look forward to going back.  

Btw, there was a steady flow of surprisingly good mid-90s tunes on the sound system while we were there (can't remember the last time I heard a place play the Sneaker Pimps).
author: Andrew E.

description: Hipster joint with a cool, low key and very SF vibe. Simply lit, tables close together, communal bathroom and excellent servers. Ultra personable and very attentive. When asked what the server would order she instantly spouted off 3 meals and explained each one and why she liked it. I like that! We had a huge party and she took the time to give me her attention to make sure I got something I would like. I like that! Warm, friendly and aware of our needs, she filled every glass when it reached less than half, and kept an eye on all plates to see that there wasn't more of anything we needed. Yeah, that's JUST the service ;) The food? DELICIOUS. The host ordered one of every appetizer in the menu, each one was different from the last, creative, and colorful. Fruits, meats, veggies, flowers, herbs, breads & spreads- what a menu. The entrees are divine, (I wish I would have ordered mine sans meat) but! It was well worth the experience. The drink menu is very different in a kind if aromatic way, mine was fresh, tangy , sweet and minty with a lavenderish undertone. I know, sounds weird, not so though! Most def a recommendation, this place does not disappoint.
author: MsMichele P.

description:
Sorry Locanda, that I had to dine here whilst jaded with the dining scene. The food was good, but just.. nothing special in my opinion. I guess it's because there wasn't a dish that I'd want to come back for? I wish we had tried the Jewish-Style Artichokes that everyone is raving about, but instead we ordered:

-Grilled Octopus (Puntarelle, Potatoes, Olives, Marjoram, $15): Good, but the octopus wasn't quite as tender as I like and have had in the past. I also felt like the potatoes were out of place, and wished there were more olives instead.
-Fried Castelvetrano Olives ($6): Pretty good. The breadcrumb crust was crispy, and the olives were tender and stuffed with cheese.
-Rigatoni alla Carbonara (Guanciale, Egg, Pecorino, Black Pepper, $15): Eh.. the rigatoni was good, but the sauce need a little more salt. However, the chucks of guanciale were SUPER salty, and too big for the dish. I would skip this.
-Chesnut-Ricotta Agnolotti (Amaro, Sage, Brown Butter, Parmigiano, $17): My friends really liked this dish, but I felt like I've had better pastas in the past with a brown butter sage sauce. I also didn't like the hard texture of the agnolotti.
-Oxtails alla Vaccinara ($24): Pretty good, but on the salty side. I felt like this dish was really plain, since it just had 2 large pieces of oxtail and 1 small piece, and then maybe 4 pieces of sliced celery? However, still one of the best dishes of the night.
-Roasted Squash (Brown Butter, Calabrian Chili, $8): Pretty good, but nothing special.
-Red Rome Apple Zeppole (Apple-Angostura Caramel, $8): Disappointing. There were five tiny zeppole balls, and a tiny drizzle of the caramel sauce. It had a good apple taste and the caramel tasted good, but the presentation really sucked. Not worth $8.

Overall, I had higher expecations, which has been my problem when dining at restaurants lately. However, since I had been looking forward to trying Locanda, and they are always so packed, I expected more from the food and presentation. Also, the service was only decent, and we had to flag our server down a couple of times. We also had to request foccacia, which turned out to be only so-so and on the dry side. In any case, I doubt I will be back to Locanda with all the other dining options in the Mission.
author: Amy D.

description:
I realize I can be a picky person and when I went to Locanda I went with a particularly picky friend so naturally we asked for a few customizations. Sure, its a new place but they really had some issues making these changes which was strike number 1. 

I did like that they had open bar seating so I was able to fight and secure some seats within minutes which was a plus since the reservations were totally booked. 

What we got:
Califlower Pizza Bianca
Carciofi Crudi - grilled ricotta salad
Crescenza  Tortelli - I added some spicy red sauce to this
Bucatini all'Amatriciana 

This pizza bianca was a little unappetizing. There was a lot of the creamy sauce that really overpowered any of the other flavors. Minus one. Grilled ricotta salad was a little mild so I asked for some bread on the side (which was excellent) and ate them together to improve the overall flavor. The pastas were probably the biggest fails for us. Yes, homemade pasta, love that, however the sauce and the flavors were just not working so well together (especially since they wouldn't let me customize!). 

I do appreciate the bartenders being so friendly and trying to accomodate us so A+ on the service but below average on the food. Sorry guys.
author: Raina B.

description:
I'll keep this short...  

The Food:  Good but nothing spectacular.  For similar cuisine categorized as  "spectacular" you should go to Flour & Water.

The Service:  Surprisingly Bad.  Uninformed servers, painfully slow order response times.  (had to ask multiple times for someone to take our drink order, then showed up after our salad course had arrived.).  

Atmosphere:  great!   Very nicely done room, beautiful cross section of people dining and perfectly managed lighting, sound & surroundings.
author: A R.

description:
Locanda is one of (if not THE) best new restaurant to open in the midst of all the construction and openings on Valencia. Why? Let's start with the bar. The cocktail menu is great - rotating selections, some good standbys, but the drinks do tend to veer a touch to the sweet side for my liking. No matter, with a huge wall of about every apertif and liquor imaginable, and a head bartender that knows his way around the whole thing, ordering off-menu is as much a boozy adventure as it is delicious. There's plenty of delicious salty snacks to go with the drinks as well, the fried olives (filled with cheese!) are particularly great for soaking up that third mezcal-based concoction you probably didn't need.

The decor is worth mentioning as well - they're trying to channel Rome, and do a pretty damn good job of it. The lighting and flooring toward the back of the restaurant tends to look a bit cheaper compared to the rest (especially the neon-esque wall lighting), but the tile walls, vintage concert posters in the bathrooms, and exposed kitchen are all very well executed - understated and well-designed without trying to hard.

Service and food continue the trend - knowledgable waitstaff, great wine list, and food that really hits the spot. Only complaint about the food is that some dishes can get a little oily, and the carbonara is a bit on the salty side (but I mean, come on, it's carbonara). The complementary "pizza" (focaccia) is phenomenal, doubly so if you get the non-complementary appetizer version grilled with toppings. 

All-around, an awesome swiss army knife of a place - drinks at the bar with snacks, dinner, or even a nightcap after eating elsewhere, you'd have to try really hard to go wrong with Locanda.
author: Judd B.

description:
We got the famous artichoke, it was a bit greasy.

Other than that, delish! I had the crab pasta. It had nice big chunks of tender juicy crab. Boyfriend got the rabbit pasta. Also very good. We got a broccoli romanesco to share.. whoooa trippy dude! In the buttery kind of way.

All in all a great meal. Interesting offerings to titillate your palate far beyond your normal Italian experience.

One word of warning: the menus are in Italian so if you don't hablas you'll have peek under the table at your phone the whole time. Or ask the server what everything on the menu is.
author: Rachel H.

description: One of my favorite spots in SF.  Hands down.  The Church cocktail is the best on the list.  All of the food is fabulous, but plates can be a bit on the small side.  So go ahead and order an extra dish to share with your table.  The jewish artichokes were perfectly fried and insanely good the other night.  I also had the pasta special, which had pecorino cheese and black pepper.  it's a personal favorite in general and they executed on it flawlessly.  Also the pasta with the beef ragu should not be missed.  However, everything is excellent, so order with confidence.  You'll have a great meal for sure!
author: Polly M.

description: One of my best friends favorites spots. Everything we ordered is yummy and the staff is super nice.
author: Rebecca S.

description: An offical GNO--I haven't seen my dear friend in ages so we decided to come for dinner here. A friend recommended the restraunt to me ofand it did not take long for me to fall in love with the atmosphere and become a regular. We made reservations a couple days in advance, we wanted an early dinner so had a couple drinks and ordered our food. The food is so fresh the pasta was so fresh, the cheese was so fresh and smelled amazing, the vegitables tasted so fresh. They have great service and atmosphere.
author: Semira J.

description: Truly some of the best food I've ever had!! Everything was perfect. They flavors were so complimentary to each other. Nothing was underwhelming and nothing was overwhelming making everything just a perfect balance. Very creative combinations that were great in texture and taste! Can't wait to go back!
author: McKinley Y.

description: Locanda is a World Class Italian restaurant that could hold its own with Rome's best.  Excellent pastas and appetizers, creative delicious deserts, fantastic service, and a comfortable buzzy room with a nice energy.  Main meat dishes are solid but not as creative and differentiating as the pastas or starters.  Reservations are nearly impossible but worth it when you get one. Parking sucks too so use valet service.
author: John L.

description:
one of my favorites.

super consistent quality. great service.
authentic Italian food.


try the jewish artichokes!
author: Julian H.

description:
One of our Favorite restaurants! Warm, attentive, professional wait staff! They are very helpful in choosing food and wine. They always make us feel welcome.
Excellent food! I love the pastas, the porchetta is delicious, recently had the petrale sole which was a different preparation than I've ever had before --- it was amazing. Jewish artichoke - not to be missed. Chicken liver pate is wonderfully flavorful. and the list goes on...Valet parking in the mission. Couldn't ask for anything more from a restaurant.....
author: D H.

description: Ok - just got charged $11 for a WELL vodka soda. Their drinks are $11 so I thought that a well drink would be less than that - I mean a well drink is less than that anywhere, right? And the well vodka was NOT good. Worst. $11. Vodka. Soda. Ever. Don't drink here.
author: Suzie S.

description:
METALLICA WAS SITTING RIGHT NEXT TO US! 

Yes, James, Kirk, Lars, and Robert were sitting next to us last Thursday night taking pictures and enjoying Italian food at Locanda. INSANE! This is far the trendiest California-Roman restaurant on Valencia and goes head to head with Flour + Water. You know these restaurants are the shit when other chefs come to eat here after work. They play great music, foodies everywhere, an extensive bar, and a modern setting. If its the same owner as Delfina, you will certainly be impressed! I will save you time and get right to the chase. We were four people and had gone to Dalva just before for cocktails. What we ordered was the perfect amount. Just take in mind that the plates are small and you have to order at least 2-3 appetizers. Have some wine, cocktails, or a "Mexican" coke. Here is what I recommend (5 mini stars for my favorite): 

L' Antipasto:
JEWISH STYLE ARTICHOKES *****
PIZZA BIANCA
**The bread they serve is incredible!!!!!! *****

Il Secondo:
VEAL CASONCELLI  alla SALTIMBOCCA
FETTUCCINI - rabbit sugo, cicoria, verjus*****
CAVATELLI- Ravioli filled with shrimp and burrata *****
CRESCENZA TORTELLI - chantarelles, mint, pinenuts

Il Dolce: 
RICOTTA FRITTA - citrus caramel, lemon thyme *****
WARM CHOCOLATE CAKE -maple syrup, curried walnuts

You will be mind-blown, trust me.
author: Stephanie M.

description:
It is with a very sad heart that I'm writing this, unfortunately, Locanda seriously underwhelmed. To the point that I'd not recommend booking. It could have been an off night or perhaps just what my date and I ordered but the food was seriously lacking.

BACKGROUND: 
I'd heard wonderful things about this resto for quite a long time from a number of people I trust before finally making the journey to experience it for myself. I/we was/were super excited and, on entry, thoroughly expecting a great meal. 

THE FOOD: 
My date and I chose to share a number of dishes: 
LA QUERCIA PROSCIUTTO: WAY over salted. It so overwhelmed that none of the natural flavor came through and no amount of wine or water helped. 
PIZZA BIANCA: Nice flavor, well presented but it was rather stale (maybe over toasted and left to sit?). The actual taste was really nice and I could see this being wonderful if done properly. 
RIGATONI alla CARBONARA: Pasta was prepared nicely al dente, the overall favor was good but the guanciale was rubbery and the predominant seasoning was salt (see comments on prosciutto above). 
BERKSHIRE PORK SALTIMBOCCA: Lovely flavor and great taste while hot. As it cooled it became rather difficult to handle and seemed more like a breakfast ham. Again, a lot of salt though within context this was not make or break here.
SMOKED MASHED POTATOES: Pretty tasty. 

SERVICE: 
Overall very nice and exactly what I expected from a restaurant with the reputation Locanda has. Team service, good explanations. Two minor comments: 
1. staff seemed overly hurried as if they were understaffed or trying to turn the table while also providing good service. Not sure if it was either of those or something else but it was noticeable. 
2. The table next to us had a tasting menu and when I inquired with a server, he sort of blew me off mentioning that it came from an app partner. Fair enough, but the menu looked far superior to what we were eating and if it was available I'd consider coming back to try it. 

THE WRAP: 
Could have been an off night, could have been the dishes my date and I ordered, it could have been that we rubbed someone the wrong way, or anything else. However, based on last night's experience, I would not recommend booking here. There are so many tasty places in the city, better to try somewhere else.
author: Alan T.

description:
There goes the neighborhood!

I am upset with Locanda. Why? Because I walked in on a MONDAY night at 6pm (3 people in my party) and the hostess was like "do you have a reservaaaaayyysun?" Um, no. It's Monday night, do you have any openings? "Computer says noooooo". Then she proceeded to tell me it would be a 1.5-2 hours wait. I believed it, because the place was full. Full of pink-shirt-and-loafer Marina folk.  Unacceptable. I mean, a Mission gal should be able to go out for dinner in her own neighborhood on a Monday night. 

The other reason I'm upset with Locanda is that during the day, the restaurant is a sterile, granite-slab-cold, shades-down dead-spot on Valencia street. Come on, throw us a bone and do lunch so even if we didn't make a reservaaaayyyyshun  maybe we could at least get a pizza or something. 

I will update this to more stars if I am able to get a table one day (assuming the food is good)
author: Darcy V.

description:
So good.  Went twice this week.  First time had the:
- shaved artichoke - excellent, great salad with some unique flavor.
- pasta with achovies - if you like achovies this is a winner.
- brocolli romanesco - just a side dish but I love this vegetable from outer space.
I also tried a bit of the pasta with sausage which was very tasty but probably better split since it was a little salty.

2nd time:
- jewish artichoke - ok, but not exciting.
- fresh greens side dish - ok if you want something light with your dinner.
- pasta with some sort of pork from the pig jowls. This was amazing but glad I was splitting it since the meat had a very strong salty taste that was excellent but could overpower if you ate too much.  It was almost like a good bacon.
- grilled trout with that brocolli romanesco - grilled in their wood over this was among the best fish I've had.  They served us a giant portion of perfect trout.  There was enough meat for another 2 people.

Bonus is the wine list.  Lot's of unique italian wines.  The staff is extremely knowledgeable.  They also make sure to give you options at various price points.

Extra bonus, they tell you the prices when they tell you the daily specials.

Also, the bar is a very good place to hang out.  Excellent and unique mixed drinks with top ingredients.

Valet at $12 for the night is a good deal in that area.
author: Ric S.

description: The fried olives was  definitely the star of the night. It was not overly fried and not salty. I would  definitely go back there again. The duck breast wasn't my favorite duck dish I ever had and I definitely regret getting it.
author: Kevin L.

description:
Great place for a good variety of fresh pastas and appetizers! It seems like the restaurant gets pretty busy, so I'd suggest making reservations here beforehand. 

Went here last Sat night with a friend around 7:20pm without a reservation. We had to wait about 40 mins, and we were seated promptly at 8pm on an actual table and not the bar. 

I was super craving pastas that night, and everything on their menu sounded amazing.  Locanda started us off with some complementary, perfectly toasted focaccia bread glazed with light olive oil. Then we proceeded to order the following:

APPETIZER
Pizza Bianca w/Smoked Bass, Horseradish, and Dill for $9 (4 stars): To start off, this is not to be confused for actual pizza because it is NOT. It's more like large pieces of crostini topped with various ingredients. Despite having a dislike for horseradish, I really enjoyed this dish! I really had my doubts... but the flavors of the smoked bass and horseradish complemented each other very well, and the thinly sliced dill on top made each bite very refreshing. Great start to the meal!

MAIN DISHES - THE PASTAS
Linguini with Dungeness Crab/Lettuce/Sorrel for $21 (4 stars): Delicious! Linguini is not my favorite pasta, but combined with dungeness crab? I'M THERE. The pasta was slightly wider than the average linguini noodle (probably why I liked it), cooked al dente, and there were tons of pieces of fresh crab meat in the dish. I ate the entire thing up, but I think I would've liked the sauce to be a little less oily. I was also thrown off a couple times by some small pieces of crab shell in the dish. Still tasty though!

Radiatore with Lamb Ragu for $17 (rating: NA): My friend ordered this, but I had one bite. The texture of the pasta was good (Flour + Water was still way better), but I thought that the lamb flavor was a little too potent for the dish. Although I'm a huge fan of lamb, the flavor of the lamb seemed to detract from the other flavors of tomato, pecorino, and mint. It was still good though, and my friend devoured it all.

Both of us really enjoyed our food, but I definitely think the service could've used some improvement. The service was a little sporadic... Our waiter was super slow at times, especially when taking our orders and giving us the check. But he did come back pretty often to fill our water glasses. 

To wrap up -- Locanda, your food impressed me (even though your service did not), but I still look forward to coming back and seeing what other types of pastas and appetizers you have to offer!
author: Jennifer L.

description: Wonderful service, nice vibe (not as hipsterish as I'd read, we fit in fine as women of a certain age). Good food -- the artichokes were perfectly fried but not that tasty, I've had better in Rome, the heirloom tomato salad was delish, the lobster/pasta enough for us to share as a main course.  Terrific waiter who guided us to the right wine selection, and the right amount of food to order without over-ordering....will be back.
author: Robin W.

description:
Wow!  Talk about amazing.  Locanda has been on the list of restaurants to try and I'm so happy that I did.  Came here a little after 5:30 and was surprise to see that the restaurant was nearly filled already, even though it had just opened.  

The food was amazing.  I tried the linguini and clams and also their aspargus with poached duck egg appetizer.  Both were utterly amazing and very thought out.  I loved the bread crumbs in both dishes and the sauce and flavor to both dishes were fabulous.

Definitely going back to try new and re-eat old loves.
author: Anna V.

description:
Whole fish of the day.  Get it whatever it is.

Smoke 'n' Spice cocktail is worthy of Local Edition.

If you skip the chocolate cake or the budino I will weep for you.
author: Mike D.

description:
Had a disappointing experience at Locanda last night. Fantastic space, great bar, hip drinks and friendly bar staff. After the drinks, the night went south. What started as a birthday dinner out with my partner (we were so excited after waiting over a month for a res), ended with a lousy table near the door, aloof service and food that was nothing special. 

As an italian, I was excited to have some authentic Roman cuisine. Instead, we had food that was ordinary. The grilled carciofi was really tasty with arugula and ricotta salata and the house bread was really good. But it took over 30 minutes to get the amatriciana that could have been prepared at home and it would have been just as good. The fish and bavette came later and by that time we were just plain hungry. Beef was ok and the fish was dry. Didn't bother with dessert since we had been there for over 2 and a half hours by now and were so under whelmed it didnt seem worth it. 

I know that owners of the "hot spots" have the advantage in the short term, as most of the younger $$ is spent in a place to see and be seen in. However, I'd encourage them to consider an important business principle - it is a privledge to serve your customers as opposed to acting as though it is a privledge for your customers to have the opportunity to spend an evening at your place.   

Next time we'll skip the expensive, trendy place and stick to a great neighborhood restaurant like Vega in Bernal , with great food and friendly service that appreciates us locals.
author: phil b.

description:
Dinner here was AMAZING! We were a party of 8 gals-- reservations are a must for any size party. They could only fit us in at 9:30pm but it worked perfectly. We strolled around the Mission, got to a packed Locanda at 9pm and hung at the bar. Great service with a smile-- tasty cocktails, great people watching, awesome decor. We were sat in the back area and ordered almost everything off the menu. Every dish was cooked to perfection- from the pastas to the lamb to the hen to the fried olives (YUM) to the artichoke, butternut squash soup, and of course, the desserts!... I could go on and on. The only complaint I would have is the bone marrow dish had hardly any marrow in one of the bones... but that was minor. Our server.. wish I remembered her name.. friendly blond gal with bangs and a "mom" tattoo on her finger.. was SUPERB. Seriously, top notch. 
Oh yeah... it was CRAZY HOT back where we were sat, they said they couldn't do anything about it as the kitchen is exposed right there -- at least I was dressed appropriately (layers/tank top)-- some of my friends had to go outside a few times from overheating. I can't wait to come here again. Girl's weekend 2015?!
author: Emily C.

description:
LOVE this place!  Came with a friend for the first time, so he decided to ask the server to have the chef make our menu for the night.  Nice surprises!

What came out were:
- heirloom tomato salad
- prosciutto with a spicy spread on bread (wasn't sure of the name, but was good)
- mushroom tortellini (really good)
- steak 

Everything was really good and I liked the experience that every dish was a surprise!  The server paired each dish with a different drink, where we had wine and couple of different mixed drinks.

I would love to come back soon to really look at what else they serve on the menu.
author: Nancy S.

description: One star is for the service and another for the space. The food was a disaster and extremely overpriced. I truly don't understand how this place got so many positive reviews. If you had any idea of what a fine Italian food should be like you wouldn't give this place more than 2 stars. I ordered the pancetta wrapped chicken and got a flavorless dish made of the worst parts of the worst chicken. Cheap, fatty, chewy chicken wrapped pieces swimming in a too-liquid sauce. I also tried my friend's carbonara that was no different in its quality than the one you can get at Trader Joes for quarter of the price (except maybe that at Locanda they cooked the pasta al dente as it should be). The smoked mashed potatoes dish was ok, but paying $9 for it was way too much (+tax +tip +5% that they shove down their customers throats just because they can). If you're ever in the area, I'd recommend to just get a nice taco from a nearby authentic Mission taqueria.
author: Eric K.

description: The ambiance and location are top notch; the aperitivo cocktail was delicious. Unfortunately, the food was underwhelming. We were a party of 4 and dined November 2013 for my partner's birthday dinner. The oxtail soup was sour or had too much lemon and left a tart aftertaste on my palate. The crab fettuccine was recommended by the Italian server with long hair and glasses who milked his Italian accent to the max! 3 of us ordered the crab fettuccine due to his suggestion and we were all disappointed. There were so many crab shells in the dish and contained too much lemon juice. Spitting out crab shells should not have been part of the dining experience. If it weren't for my partner's birthday, we would have sent all 3 back. The ricotta bread pudding was dry, bland and just sad. The chocolate budino was average. I will not be returning for another mediocre meal.
author: Kevin C.

description: I got the fettuccine with rabbit sugo and brocoli raag. Delish!!! Also they seem like putting brocolini in a lot if dishes which is awesome to someone like me who loves and can eat it all day long. My husband got the cuscini. The creamy sauce tasted like lobster crame sauce. It's pretty much shrimp ravioli in a very delicious way. Just be prepared, the first bite can be pretty peppery. The chestnut crepe and flour less chocolate cake deserts were the perfect finale for a great dinner experience!
author: ally l.

description: Everything we ordered was great. Highly recommend the lamb carpaccio & steak.
author: M. G.

description:
We walked into Locanda after reading numerous reviews of how great is was.  I found it to be quite the opposite.  

We tried to call and make a reservation and could not get through.  Open Table was not much better so we decided to walk in and see how long the wait was.  The hostess exclaimed that she had a table right then, but it was way to early for us to eat.  We inquired about an hour later.  She explained that she did not have a table at that time but could put us on the wait list.  We were then told to check back in 45 minutes.  We offered to give a phone number with our name but she did not want to be bothered. 

Upon our return 40 minutes later the same hostess could not find our name and asked us again if we would like to be on the wait list.  The wait list would be another hour wait.  Of course the level of agitation rose.  No food and now another hour wait, I think not.  "Forget it," was the response to the hostess.  She scrambled and said  "Wait I'll be right back."  We were then seated and were not given menus for about 8 - 10 minutes.

When the menus finally came we ordered an appetizer, salad and two entrees.  We were sharing the app and salad and let the waitress know this.  Neither was split between us and when we requested a spoon to help split it between two plates we never received it.  Even better than that we received a dessert menu before our entree came.  We told the waitress forget it and just get us the check.  Miraculously, the entree came right out.  I will admit the food was completely underwhelming, so I cannot even describe it.  

There was no service recovery! Never again.
author: Megan P.

description:
I went back with the hubby and I had prepared him to experience the best. We were seated immediately without a reservation, which was incredible and beyond my wildest hopes. We ordered the same drink I had last time, which was in a whiskey glass with ice, this one was different. 
Appetizers were fantastic. The lamb is so loved last time, was absolutely not the same I had, which was very very very disappointing.     I had the special that night which was the veal braised for 8 days. That sounded fantastic it was awful, overcooked, chewy awful!!!
We won't come back for sure, this place lacks consistency.
author: Carpe D.

description:
The food is tasty. Tasty, tasty, tasty. I liked all the dishes we had. We had a pretty wide sampling of the menu. But instead of listing everything I'll just let you know what I remembered to be great dishes: duck egg appetizer, any of the pastas, slow roasted salmon, and the desserts (ricotta fritta and warm chocolate cake). Please note that the menu constantly changes due to the season. I feel like this place is an easy five stars because anything you order will look and taste great no matter what. There are interesting takes on certain dishes. It's something you can't get at home or anywhere else. Instant gratification in my book.

The interior is quite handsome with their chalk ash colored tables and semi minimal decor. It's like the place was created by an indie rocker, minimalist, and italian chef. The first thing I noticed was their striking piece of art depicting one mirrored wolf. Take a gander in the bathroom and you'll find that the mirror is made to resemble a window (it kinda feels like someone can peep in). These slight touches make the visit feel different and unique.

The only problem with this place is the noise level. It's as loud as a Chinese New Year parade when the dragons and firecrackers go off, but the noise is only coming from 25-40 year old trendy San Franciscans. There aren't many minorities or old people here. But if you can stand the sound, you'll be rewarded.

-----

Louder than a drunken mob but the tasty food is worth it.
author: Michael H.

description:
A great first experience at Locanda. The food was delicious and the service was good.

I went with a group of four and we each had a different pasta for dinner. I opted for the octopus pasta (nonsoni) -- it had a pleasant seafood taste without being overpowering. My friends' dishes were also good: the carbonara sauce had a great bacon flavor, the lamb ragu was delicious, and the anchovy pasta had a great blend of flavors.

Locanda also has a decent cocktail list. Their Smoke and Spice is great for anyone who appreciates a smoky Scotch.

They were also highly accommodating of reservation changes: I had to change the group size twice and they did so without any hassle.
author: Glen G.

description:
Came here for a birthday dinner so we splurged on cocktails, a bottle of wine, an appetizer, entrees and dessert. Overall, an enjoyable experience. We got here kinda early (7pm dinner) and it was quiet to start, but as dinner progressed, it got super loud and echo-y.

I started with a paloma and it was good, but I did not care for the salt on my glass...I would have preferred some sugar. We split a plate of the fried sweetbreads and artichokes, which was good, but I wouldn't mind a little more coarse salt sprinkled all over. And maybe a larger slice of lemon, but I lovelove lemon spritzed on fried goods. A pleasant surprise - deep fried capers! Genius.

Birthday boy won with his choice of Lamb Ragu...the mint was a perfect and refreshing addition. My anchovy and pepper linguine was great, but super heavy and oily for a Friday night.

Dessert was fried ricotta and I LOVED the honey and thyme. Who knew thyme would be awesome as dessert??
author: Karena Q.

description: The fried artichoke (gluten free) was a favorite. I also liked the lamb chops. Will be back again.
author: Bea K.

description: One star off for the slow service. But the food, the vine & the location are really, really nice.
author: Ili V.

description:
I came, I saw, I ate, and then I went to the burrito place down the street. 

Locanda has underwhelming food at overwhelming prices. The staff is condescending to boot. Hopefully this place won't stay in business for long with so many other amazing options in the Mission.
author: Stephanie C.

description:
After all the hype and being heralded as one of the top new restaurants in SF, I was EXTREMELY disappointed.  And after paying $90 for a dinner for two, we still had to get food up Valencia to calm our hunger afterward.  And I've had more than my share of fine dining where I leave hungry but at least I leave impressed by the food and service.  Not this time.

Service was cordial but we had to ask for bread every time and our second entree came out at least 10 minutes AFTER we had finished the first entree we were sharing.

The cocktails are strong.  I recommend the Smoke and Spice.  Despite its great taste, the Jewish-style artichoke is missing half of its leaves (where did they go?).  The crescenza tortelli is rich and cheesy but not filling at all.  And the lamb scottaditto is a small morsel of meat with some hummus and lettuce.  We seriously had to eat more bread than anything.

Next time, I am heading back to the comforts of Il Borgo...or even Olive Garden.
author: Chad S.

description:
I have gone there twice in the last couple of months. The first time was late, around 9:30, without a reservation and we sat at the bar.  The second time, a friend made a reservation. It's crowded and can be loud, but sitting at the bar ( my favorite) or in the back is great.  The scene is mostly over dressed, women in super high heels and guys in suit coats without ties and sweater vests, but the staff attitude is chill and unpretentious. The bartender was knowledgeable, if a wee bit too cool for school, and our servers super sweet. 

The two stars are for sitting at the bar, the staff and drinks. Their wine list is superb and their cocktails are tasty, but the food is over salted and just okay. I was not impressed, especially by the pastas. I would say if you haven't been, go check it out, but it won't blow you away.
author: Uda W.

description:
I hope this place doesn't claim to be authentic Italian. Because I brought an Italian to this place, who said that although the dishes might be somewhat Italian, the preparation is anything but.

The plates are very small, the pasta is overcooked, we tried 5 of the pastas and none of them were any special.

The Pecorino cheese they have in a lot of the dishes must be a very very cheap one, as it's nothing like Pecorino should be.

I did like the ambiance of the place, but such overcooked, bad quality pasta for that price? I'd rather go get a mac'n'cheese at Safeway.

I do like my pasta cooked more than al dente, but I expected more from a higher-scale restaurant.

I can't believe we wasted $40/each on this!
author: Martie K.

description: The Delfina Group never disappoints!!! Locanda is fabulous eating, cool buzz, friendly staff, and good value. Your most discerning food lover will be tickled eating here! Don't miss the  chanterelle mushroom pasta or fried olives...simple food cooked to perfection!!!
author: M. M.

description: I really wish they can be honest for the waiting time. I was told the wait time was 20 mins, but I've been waiting here for an hour now and the host's secret iPad was saying we are still 25 mins out for the table. we ended up walking out the place with no dinner. They are so greedy, and treated us like our time was worth nothing.
author: Amanda W.

description:
Been here a couple times now and it's just okay for me. While the bar program is excellent, I prefer the food at Delfina.

I like the ambitiousness with the offal on the menu but I've had more misses than hits on the menu. Skip the egg drop soup, and steer yourself towards the pastas and cocktails.
author: Derrick V.

description: Great atmosphere, crowd, food, design, and drinks. Just way overpriced. If money isn't something you're too worried about and you love Italian food, this is your place. Had the Artichoke, Bone Marrow Pizza, and Rabbit Sugo. Artichoke was crispy and just fantastic with a pinch of lemon. Bone marrow pizza was good but was just disappointed cause it actually wasn't a pizza and more like marrow with pita bread. Rabbit Sugo was very home style yummy tasting and the fettuccine was fresh and perfectly cooked. Bill turned out to be 80 bucks a person at the end of the meal with drinks. This is the place to go after you got your tax refund or promotion.
author: Charlie L.

description:
My friend and I came to drink so this review by nature will be incomplete.  

It's a beautiful space. The bar seats are comfy. Hooks for purses. Gorgeous bartenders. Oh yeah, and the drinks weren't half bad either! Kidding. They were really well made.  

I'm definitely coming back for a meal here someday...
author: Andrea L.

description: great ambience at the bar, nice vibe to hang out for the evening on a weeknight. Food was great also, but I would stick with the apps and cocktails.
author: Tanya W.

description:
I had a good "cacio and pepe" in Rome last Decembr, I found the same dish at the Locanda when I looked at the menu on line and I wanted to try it,
Try the "Tonnarelli cacio and pepe" very very good.
Baba are not so good, very dried while baba should be filled with lot of rhum, don't get those. Disappointing
author: Michele R.

description: One of my new favorite places to dine. Reasonably priced, everything was tasty, our salad could have used a touch more seasoning. Staff is friendly, comfortable and fun environment, open kitchen, nice wine list, great decor, and bar seating ( big plus!).
author: Elizabeth T.

description:
Walking by Locanda every morning to 16th Bart station, I use to think what kind of restaurant does not have their name on the sign? A pretentious one. Being an ambulatory dyslexic, I also thought their marble letters on the front window spelled "Lo Can-ada". WelI...I was wrong about one thing for sure, the spelling but not the pretension. 

I had hands down the best dining experience in the Mission at Locanda. An old friend from home came to visit and we debated b/w Bar Tartine and Locanda. Both had 45 min wait and Locanda offered us a spot first so we had to blow off Bar Tartine--hard life as a foodie, I know. 

Since I was w/ my foodie soul mate, we went all out ordering the fried artichockes, the Lamb Scottadito, Linguini, chicken and grilled corn and zuchs. We finished off w/ dessert in the form fried dough puffs. Warning: the chef has a pretty heavy hand w/ the salt especially on the fried artichokes and linguini. The lamb was succulent and didn't have their usual funky lamb after taste. What threw me off was DA GRILLED CORN. Oh my lord, the corn was sooooo good. I've never tasted such savory corn before. Each kernal was grilled to perfection. Seriously, out of everything the corn was unforgettable. 

My friend who works in the restaurant industry was impressed by their wine selection especially the dessert wine. They have a wide selection of dessert wine fermented in bitters. A couple we tried were: Montenegro Bologna, Ciao Ciaro, Lazio, and Jelineck Fernet. To be honest , the Montenegro was the only palatable one b/c it was super sweet and citrusy whereas the rest were just bitter. My palate still needs a little training in the wine department. Regardless of the lack of functional signage, I will be backkkk.
author: Bo R.

description:
This place has been on my list of places to try for quite some time.  Glad we finally made it.  

Went in on a Thursday night, 9:30 res.  Arrived a little early, hoping to get seated cause we were starving.  No luck.  Scored one seat at the bar and ordered cocktails.  A glass of Pinot, Agro Uve: (Grappa, Peach, Lemon, Egg, Bitters) and La Bella Confusione, bartenders choice:  Vodka, Elderflower, bitters...a Vodka Collins like drink (the perfect cocktail for a hot day).  The clear winner.  Our evening was off to a great start.

There are lots of things on the menu that looked interesting to us.  A good sign when you're trying a place for the first time.  Our server Emma did a great job making suggestions and helping us navigate.  We started with the Jewish Style artichoke, perfectly crisp.  Pizza Blanca, not really a pizza but more of a crostini.  4 pieces of crust topped with a white bass/fresh horseradish/dill topping that was amazing.  After our great dinner at Commonwealth, we're loving sweetbreads at the moment.  We ordered the fried sweetbreads and artichokes.  Yum!  They were perfectly cooked and really sweet topped with fried herbs and a sprinkle of sea salt.  They quickly disappeared.  The house made crusty focaccia bread was really great, we ate 2 plates!  

For main courses we ordered Lamb Scottadito:  rack of lamb cooked medium rare nicely seasoned.  2 bones.  Halibut collar with Earl Gray and Early girl tomatoes.  The fish was moist and well cooked, good flavor.  The clear winner for us was the Beef Cheek Ravioli.  Amazing flavor in a buttery sauce.  A hearty fall dish I would go back for.  The portions were all on the small side.  In hindsight, we should have ordered sides to go with our dinner.  I got the ravioli, which was perfect for me, but for the guys, they wanted a little more.  Lesson learned.  We did get a ricotta fritter to share for dessert.  It came with a citrus caramel sauce that was really tasty.  

Definitely a place to go back to.  The food interesting and flavorful.  The cocktails new and different.  The place has a great vibe and is visually stunning.  The menu changes weekly so there's always something new to try out.
author: Kim A.

description: I am new to writing reviews. I felt the need to start bc i am in the beauty industry where tourists ask me all time where to go. Well this is the place!!! To me, this is one of the most authentic italian restaurants in the city. Its in a cool area, food is reasonably priced and the service is friendly as well as attentive. I strongly suggest the Rabbit Fettuccine or the Steak (the steak is always cooked to perfection). I hope this is helpful for those fellow foodies.
author: Kaylie P.

description:
We had a great time at Locanda. We booked a table for four people at 7:30pm. The place looks great with a nice trendy and modern interior design. The appetizers and pasta dishes were great too! We got a nice $40 bottle of wine with:
- radishes and anchovy butter, oxtail arancini (fried cheesy rice balls with tender oxtail inside) as appetizers
- cuscini (shrimp ravioli in a creamy sauce) for entree
- marmalata crostata with buckwheat streusel (crumble) and fior di latte gelato.
It was a nice dinner, a bit pricy but everyone was satisfied!
author: Jerome T.

description:
I've been here before a couple times just for drinks, and have always enjoyed the cocktails. Pretty standard pricing for the caliber of drink that they tend to serve.

This past weekend I came for dinner, and sat at the bar. Pretty crowded, and had to wait a good half hour-45 minutes to snag a spot, but altogether wasn't too bad of a wait.

Our bartender appeared to be what I can only describe as "adorably exasperated," in the style of the French garçon. He warmed up after a while, though--we asked about shaking times and the size of ice cubes, and he seemed excited to tell us about that.

My friend and I ordered the head cheese, pastas with lamb and rabbit, and grilled lamb. All three were excellent, the pasta with lamb especially so.

There was a small miscommunication, and we were served somebody else's appetizer, for which we were compensated on the final bill. Nice touch.

Overall a great experience, though probably pricey for the amount of food and drink you get--ended up being about $70/each, after our drinks being comped. But I guess if you're going to Locanda, price isn't too much on your mind.
author: Sev G.

description:
It was kind of weird to be lined up outside with dozens of people waiting to get in the door when it opened (right at 5:30), but once inside the hostesses were friendly and there was a line of waitstaff waiting to take those of us with reservations to our tables. (I think the people without reservations only had the bar option.) 

I liked the space, but it was a little loud and warm back where we were seated. The waiter didn't hesitate to suggest his favorite pasta when I asked, so I went with his recommendation and ordered the fettuccine with rabbit sugo. It was basically a braised rabbit with dandelion greens and fettuccine and the sauce was the "jus" from the braising. It was a good dish. 

I'm not drinking alcohol right now, so I tried the cucumber limeade, which was delicious. It was refreshing and more on the tart side than the sweet side. My only beef was that my dinner partner ordered wine and they poured that immediately. Then they brought out our dishes pretty quickly after we ordered, but I still hadn't received my drink (again, no alcohol and on the rocks) and had to inquire about it. 

After we'd eaten and our dishes had been cleared, there was a little confusion when my friend and I thought the waiter asked if we wanted to see the dessert menu, but he brought us the regular menu. I guess we hadn't heard him say "savory" menu. Why would we want to see the savory menu again after we'd already eaten our meal? 

Anyway, we ended up ordering the chocolate cake with whipped cream on the side. I really wish we'd gone with the waiter's recommendation for dessert and ordered either the fig crostata or the fried ricotta because those sounded a lot more interesting than chocolate cake, but my dining companion wasn't having it. Her main meal consisted of an appetizer salad with a small amount of albacore and was stuffed from that, so I had to defer to her. 

As with my drink, there was a major holdup with our chocolate cake and we finally had to ask about it because we thought they'd forgotten it. The waiter apologized for the holdup and deducted the $9 from our check at the end of the meal because of the wait. I was glad because the cake was OK, but nothing that I'd order again. It wasn't memorable like the chocolate cake with salted caramel ice cream from Frances! 

All in all we had a pleasant experience. The space was attractive, my meal was good, and the waiter was knowledgeable and friendly. I'm just not sure if it was a memorable meal. I might come back with a couple of people who actually eat food at a meal so we could try a few other things on the menu.
author: Kimberly B.

description:
I really wanted to like this place. Ordered the fried artichoke which was good followed by their lamb ragu pasta.  You know a restaurant is trying too hard when they charge New York prices for pasta but don't even bother to get the ingredients to match.  The pasta clearly came from a box and was not fresh. The sauce was flavorful but undermined by cheap ingredients.  Not to mention the service was not up to par as well.

If a restaurant wants to be posh and upscale it needs food to match, which unfortunately it missed the mark here.
author: Tiffany L.

description:
So good!  Best roasted rock fish
Ive ever had.  Carbonara was rich though the pancetta was a tad salty.
author: David K.

description:
Locanda definitely has a lot going for it what with all the great "Roman" food that they serve. It's a concept that seems to work! 

Headed there for date night with my partner (it was a Friday) and 2 hours later, came away with an experience that was somewhere between "WOW". "ER-OK" and "MEH".

What made it "WOW"?
- Yes, hands down the food was THE winner. We had the Jewish Style Artichoke and Pizza Bianca for an appetizer and I highly recommend both! Pasta we had was the Bucatini all 'Amatriciana which we shared (the dish was spicy which we both loved but dayum! it was a tad bit oily but maybe when you're a Roman warrior all you do is indulge?!). I had the Bavette Steak and my partner had the Lamb Scottadito which were both really, really good! Dessert was the Warm Chocolate Cake which was a winner again!
- And the wine list is to die for!! If you're a wine lover, this place has it all!
- Kudos to the chef for some really excellent food and wine!

What made it "ER-OK"?
- As some of the other reviews mentioned, the music tended to go loud one minute and quiet the next and we never quite got the hang of that
- Maybe our eyes are going (after all, I'm 32!) but the mood lighting also did the same thing i.e. bright one minute, dim the next. 
- Guessing since its a new place, everyone is making a bee-line for it and that made the noise level close to unbearable. If noise make you cream your pants, this place is good. But if noise makes your flag go to half-mast, this place is not the best.

What made it "MEH"?
We got seated soon as we arrived and then we had a 15 minute wait before we got our menus. Then about a 10 minute wait before the waitress came to take our wine order. Then about another 10 minute wait before the waitress came to take our food order. And during that time, we noticed about 5 to 6 wait staff just milling around looking for something to do. Of course, while we were mid-way through dessert the waitress came to ask if there was anything else we wanted and we had not even finished our dessert and the check was on our table...as Bon Qui-Qui from SNL would have said "R-U-D-E!".

Long story short, the food is different, rich and an experience albeit a bit pricey and the wine list is exhaustive! Ambience is busy, loud, hipsterish and a bit tight at times. Service (right from the host to the wait staff) is something they definitely need to work on.

We'll probably give it another shot one the fanfare dies down and we can sit and enjoy a good meal.
author: Amit S.

description:
Be prepared, it's hard to get an early table.  So it's perfect for a later dinner.

The food is really delicious, the cocktails are good, great wine list, and the staff is EXCELLENT.
author: Mister G.

description: For a rainy Sunday at 6:00 it was a very energetic crowd. Every dish was excellent and the pavlova dessert not to be missed.
author: Eduardo A.

description: I eat at a lot of Italian restaurants. This one was okay, but had no soul. Rushed in and out. Pasta came while we're working on. Jr. cocktails. No real sense of hospitality. Never go back.
author: Laura F.

description:
We were in the mood for Italian food in the SF Market District, and we were referred to Locanda.  Locanda is a very trendy restaurant with a nice vibe and crowd.  Our server was excellent, and gave us very knowledgeable descriptions of the various dishes, along with her recommendations.

First, be aware this is not where you go for Italian food.  While there is an "Italian-ness" about this food, this is an upscale and modern restaurant, nothing traditional about it.  

What I liked:  The menu was varied and imaginitive, and ingredients were fresh. 
What I didn't like:  The flavors were a tad on the bland side.  The fried olive appetizer sounded good, but wound up being olives stuffed with cheese, caked in too much batter and then deep fried.  We ended up peeling off the batter to enjoy the olives.

The service was very good, and would get 4 stars.  The food, although it had potential, only gets 3 stars.
author: Steven K.

description: Disappointing! Sad. Sorry. I tried to love it, I wanted to, but it was just sort of average Italian food. My friend and I shared the fried lamb's brain and artichoke appetizer which to me was the stand out dish of the night. We then had the bucatini with guanciale and pepperoncinis, and the whole wheat pasta with stinging nettles and olives. I preferred the stinging nettles but they both were just fine, definitely not worth the price or wait for the food. I'm terribly sorry, Locanda.
author: Jessie M.

description:
This is where my husband and I had our first date nearly a decade ago when it was Ramblas. 'Member that place? 

We've made it something of a tradition to come back here on our anniversary. I'm not sure I'd go out of my way to come here if the space itself didn't have a special place in our hearts as it's kind of a scene and overpriced. 

The low-down:

- Jewish artichokes are for Jews and Gentiles alike- order these!

- Salmon pizza bianca? Was more like a piece of stale focaccia cut in half and smeared with a fishy spread. Seemed like leftovers, not a thoughtful dish.

- Entrees are hit or miss- my whole grilled fish was super charred and was a bony mess. It did come with a great chimichurri type sauce, but that sauce was not worth $32 

 - Pastas are solid, especially the one with the lamb ragu.

 - Cocktails are aweomse- you can tell because each drink has its own uniquely sized ice cubes. I'll pay top dollar for those giant ice cubes. 

 - FRIED RICOTTA BALLS drizzled with a citrus caramel - imagine the most heavenly cheesecake crossed with the fluffiest beignet...and because it doesn't have a crust it's a pretty healthy treat.
author: Deborah G.

description:
Me Loco for Locanda....Probably top 5 meals I have had in my life. 

Did you hear the one about the Jewish Artichoke? :)
author: Matt H.

description:
In brief:
Some hits, some misses, big bill.

Hits:
-You can't really go wrong with this fried poached egg trend.  Gary Danko does it best, but Locanda is gaining on them.
-The Ricotta Fritta dessert: savory, sweet, warm, gooey, delicious
-The carbonara: really, you can't go wrong with carbonara in general, but their thick, rich sauce, with salty guanciale is extra good.
-Tripe is really well cooked and their fatty red sauce just begs to be wiped up with some of their nice bread.
-Lamb entree was perfectly cooked and nicely sauced.  
-Strong, bold cocktails with italian influences (grappa, antica vermouth)

Misses:
-Weren't the biggest fans of the pig terrine, sort of just like, gummy pork fat with argula
-Spaghetti with fava beans, nice light dish, a bit too al dente even for my taste.
-Problems with the pacing of service (until we asked them to slow down, which they did).

Big bill:
Ok, so we ate and drank a good amount.  But $150 is a pricey dinner for two people.  I don't think two tiny lamb chops should be $26 when they are essentially served with some cabbage and sauce (chickpea puree was not substantial).  And I don't think that non-entree sized pasta dishes should be $17.  Pasta costs like, 30 cents...not sure where the markup comes in.  If you want to charge that much for pasta, it should be a entree sized portion (and I'm not just being a big fat American here, our server specifically told us that the pasta was not entree sized and recommended we order two).

Overall, we really enjoyed our meal but maybe our next visit will be on someone else's tab.
author: Kristin P.

description:
The flavors of Locanda are composed like an old western sepia photograph --- everything somber, well ordered, perfectly paired yet powerful behind the understatement.

Pizza bianca with corn was sweet Sweet SWEET, very little salt in the sauce (rare and appreciated), but with a perfectly symmetrical undercurrent of earthy tang from the huitlacoche. Paired with a sweet Merlot, this was a stunning appetizer.

Halibut collar is rarely impressive. The higher oil content of the cut is often misused or ignored...Locanda blew me away with a dry tomato + caper accompaniment which absorbed the oil from the fish and made for a perfectly moist yet not greasy dish. I ate every last scrap of meat off the bone, and was perfectly satiated in the end.
author: Jay A.

description:
So I'm going to start on the good/positive things about Locanda.

1) Hostess are great and friendly.
2) Decor, is amazing.  Very Hippish place, and urban.  Loved it.
3) Deep fried artichokes, pastes and OMG the Pizza Bianca were right on point.  Last year i went to Rome and had the Bianca and both were perfect.  Chef Craig was on point.

The not so great / actually pissed me off.

1)  It took our table about 15 mins to get our cocktails, and when we did received them, none of us got what we order.  We told the server and she seemed like she was lost and didn't know what to do.  (I know that this restaurant is brand new and they are working the kinks, but then...)

2)  We order a bottle of wine, which we all thought was going to be perfect since we dinned at Delfina more than once.  It took our server another 10 mins to get the bottle of wine, which it seemed like she couldn't open a proper bottle of wine.

3)  After all the mistakes with our drink orders, we just wanted some coffee and leave.  When we got our coffee, it was colder than a Russian's bed.   A guess of mine order a espresso, and it was too weak, and cold.

4)  When we payed the check we decided to let the Bartenders know about our cocktail situation and coffee situation , because it seemed like the server was just trying to blow us .  When we got to the bar, we tried to talk to one of the bartenders but they just ignored us by saying "sorry / goodbye".  

I work for a very upscale restaurant in the city and that's not the proper way to handle a someone who had a miserable night.

Very disappointed.  Hopefully they get it right in a year.

Should of just ordered the food and water, and forget about the cocktails, coffees, and wine.
author: Sammy S.

description: Great staff, perfect atmosphere for a nice romantic dinner with great food.
author: Shawna P.

description:
If you're really into offal--you know: tripe, organ meats, tuna heart, pig ear (and you thought pig ear was just for dogs!)--and you really don't need any sides with that (except some decent wine or water), then this is the place for you! 

I know it's loosely tied to Delfina and I think perhaps the deal is this: whatever Delfina puts into the compost bin gets run over to Locanda for "repurposing" into $29 entrees, and en route, they grab whatever "greens" are on the roadway (put a little evoo and some vinegar on it and it's a "12 ingredient insalata"!). 

NOTE: Entree = small amount of strange meat with a micro amount of totally inedible accoutrements, such as greens that only a ruminant could stomach and some odd pairings like ten hard pinto beans underneath your salmon (salmon--the ONE thing non-offal/awful on the menu!). 

I totally get using the whole animal--but some of that stuff I just don't wanna eat, and I most definitely don't want that stuff in everything on the menu. I was worried the runny brown "jus" under my salmon was some kind of offal sauce in disguise. I can't imagine the horror a true vegetarian would experience at this place. 

Sorry, Locanda. You get one point for the sweet Italian waiter and decent service, but I'd much rather drop my scrilla at the 500 other restaurants in the Mission where the selection is more reasonable, less pretentious, and more palatable (e.g., Delfina, Flour + Water, Universal Cafe, Radius, Specchio, to name a few).
author: Emmabelle S.

description: Fantastic meal, great drinks (Church was awesome), cool atmosphere, great service and atmosphere! Highly recommend
author: Sam P.

description: Mission in the Mission accomplished!  The food, the peeps, the decor - love, love, love.  Chic interior that is true to the new gentrified Mission vibe.  I know, I know but the food is fabulous.  Yummy bread to start.  Stuffed and breaded olives.  Grilled romaine salad, and yummy pasta.  My bff loved her dishes too.  I suspect everything rocks here.
author: Amireh G.

description:
Outstanding. 

After a brilliant experience with Delfina, we backed up with Locanda and were equally impressed. 

Great vibe, echoed by exceptionally tasty food and friendly service. 

It's on the list!
author: Jan M.

description:
for our 4th anniversary, we decided to relive our roman holiday by eating at locanda.  if we had never been to rome, i would have thought locanda was pretty good.  however, it does not compare to rome at all.

we started w/ some cocktails, and i must say, they were amazing.  i had the church cocktail, and hubs had something w/ ginger that was strong but tasty.  we then got a jewish artichoke and the fried olives.  the artichoke was tiny for $7, and i should have known better than to order it, since it's not artichoke season.  the fried olives were amazing though.

for food, i got the whole fish acqua pazza, and my husband got the cacio e pepe, which he loved in rome.  we also got sides of the squash and the mashed potatoes.  my fish was good but had tons of bones.  i tried the cacio e pepe, and it didn't compare to the ones we had in rome.  

i would still come back, b/c the ambience is great, but if you want true roman food, go to rome!
author: Helen T.

description:
I can't remember the last time I was this uninspired by Italian food. First off, the carbonara was cream-based. Don't get me started. My husband's entree was tiny and mediocre. Even with a side, we had to stop off at the grocery store afterwards to pick up some extra food so he could fill up. If you're a guy, plan on ordering both the pasta and an entree, and maybe a side (approx. $50). In spite of eating next to nothing (no alcohol, no dessert), our meal came out to nearly $100. We didn't even bother ordering more food because it wasn't sufficiently tasty to justify the added costs.

The hostesses, though, were extremely sweet and helpful. Sadly, their extra star is canceled out by the somewhat contemptuous and unhelpful waiter.
author: Anonymous F.

description: I love the look of locanda-that bathroom is a masterpiece of tile work. I can say that they have Great bar bites and appetizers. The artichokes are definitely However, I was highly disappointed with the pasta courses. The carbonara did not resemble anything I've ordered in Rome; it was gloppy and soupy. I did something I rarely do and send an item back because it was just so wrong. Romans would be offended.
author: Monica L.

description:
Locanda is like Dubstep, bad.  I don't want to listen to dubstep, and I don't want to eat at Locanda.  I wonder how it is so popular.  I wondered the same about Dubstep.  Were people tricked into liking both?  What this tells me is that most people have shit taste in food and otherwise. And that the "popularity" of a restaurant is no indicator of how good the food will be. 

I was SO excited to try this place out. I made a reservation weeks in advance, I got a babysitter for the children, I got dressed up, I was filled with joy and anticipation.  I am a huge Delfina fan and eat there at least once a month, and eat at Delfinas Pizza at least once per week. So you can imagine how excited I was for a new Delfina restaurant.   I never imagined how dissapointed I would be.

First, we got there and were seated in a small table by the front.  It was not a bad table, but it was right next to the air conditioning vent and the AC was on FULL BLAST.  I was FREEZING.  Thank goodness this is San Francisco and I usually carry a jacket and sweater with me, but the cold air was unbearable.  I ended up having to cover the vent with my jacket and purse.  And when I mentioned something to our waitress she smiled and did nothing about it.  She didn' turn it down or try to re-seat us.  Even my husband was cold sitting at that table. We both ended up having to put on our sweaters, and even then we both wished we had a blanket. 

I ordered the 12 lettuce salad and it was ok.  I liked the flavor of the greens, but it was OVERDRESSED. It was drenched. It made the lettuce soggy. There is NO excuse to overdress a salad, especially not at a Delfina restaurant. Especially not when you are paying $9 for a small plate of lettuce.  

I also ordered the Halibut collar and it was UNDERCOOKED.  There is no excuse for that. You would immediately go home if you were on Top Chef, darling. Don't serve me undercooked fish.  How can you be so popular yet not know how to cook fish properly?

The green pasta I had (lima beans and ricotta) was so so. It was honestly a little dry.  

I was totally unimpressed. While I love Delifina's and it's sister pizza restaurant, I was so dissapointed with my experience at Locanda, that I will never go back, and that makes me sad, because I was really looking for a new favorite place to eat at.


EDIT:  Laconda is now one of my very favorite restaurants EVER!  I was wrong, oh so wrong. Actually I wrote this review after going to the restaurant shortly after it opened, so maybe it took them a minute to get things right.  And they did.  It is, oh so right now.

I go there a bunch now.  I look forward to it.  I plan for it.  It is my favorite date night restaurant.  I ALWAYS get the Crezenssa (spelling?) ravioli.  I cannot describe how good they are.  They are these cheese filled ravioli in a mushroom sauce with pine nuts I think.  When you bite into the ravioli the hot and liquid cheese explodes in your mouth (in the best way possible) and fills your taste buds with ecstasy.  I am hard pressed to think of a better pasta dish I have ever had in my life.  

My husband always gets the fish aqua pazza; the crazy water fish.  It is cooked to perfection.  The crazy water is just that- some sort of indiscernible sauce that is so crazy good you will want to drink your plate.   I also highly recommend the olives appetizer.  

The drinks are really good, though seriously pricey. I feel like they can slow it down on that tip- charging $15 for a mixed drink is frankly almost offensive.   The atmosphere is light and fun.  

So yeah, please disregard my previous review and fucking GO TO LACONDA.  You won't regret it.
author: Ivanna C.

description:
Really not good. I love Delfina and had high hopes for this place, but the food really missed the mark.
The Good:
The service was good and they've done great things with the space. The wine was excellent and the meat was cooked really well. 
The bad and the ugly.
The sides were totally weird and occasionally inedible. The salad with 12 greens had some greens that really looked like they came from the yard. Not the garden, the yard. There was some sort of green served with the delicious salmon that was, well, gross. 
The "pizza" was foccacia with stuff on it....if you think the folks who bring us the amazing Delfina Pizzeria will serve you pizza when it says pizza, sorry, you have made a $9 mistake.

Pretentious, overpriced, disappointing, sad.
author: Jen S.

description:
Arrived a bit early for our 10:30 reservations and the place was packed. It was very loud.  When we left about midnight, it was still going strong.  Very popular restaurant that we also enjoyed a lot. We loved the first two cocktails we ordered, the bartender was a pro.  We loved the asparagus appetizer.  Everything else was just average. Better pasta at perbacco.  The service was great but it was funny our waitress spoke in such a low voice considering how loud the place was, I couldn't hear her, lol.  Thank goodness the woman next to us told us about what she had just eaten!



HELEN di MONTENEGRO -tequila, amaro, agave, grapefruit, lime (loved it)
CHURCH -aperol, gin, cocchi americano, lemonnce (this one was good, too)

PIEDMONTE PUNCH -grappa, pineapple, lemon, bitters (no, did not like)


DUCK EGG - asparagus, bottarga, breadcrumbs $14 ( excellent)

RADIATORE "PECORA e PECORINO" - lamb ragu, pecorino, mint $17 (eh)
CRESCENZA TORTELLI - pioppini mushrooms, mint, pinenuts $16 ( tasty!)

BORLOTTI BEANS "con COTICHE" (boring)
author: Foodlover B.

description: I have always loved sitting at the bar here. The bar tenders are really nice and make a very good drink. The food is good and the ambience is cool, hip and trendy on any night of the week. Be sure to book in advance. Attire is smart casual. It's San Francisco so things are always a bit more fuss free and relaxed! I'm a fan!
author: Sarah H.

description:
I forgot some of the details I should have reviewed this right after.  Overall I was pleasantly surprised and loved the setting and the food.    The service was attentive and pleasant.
The artichoke was good but the fried olives were to die for.     We sampled all our entrees and they were all excellent (fish of the day, chicken, and a pasta).
Definitely going back.
author: John P.

description: The decor and the ambiance was wonderful.  I have to say that the food presentation was to the T... and the food, amazing.  We had the veal for appetizer (would not do it again), then we had the lamb (delicious) and I had a pasta dish that had capers (forgot the name).  Will go again to find out just the name of the dish.  Had dessert as well (little cookies) with my decaf coffee to top the meal.  Wonderful wonderful~~
author: Rudia L.

description: Food was unique and delicious. The atmosphere was warm and inviting. Try the beef jerky, the artichoke, and the steak. Yum! Can't wait to go back.
author: Andrea Z.

description:
