I had been looking forward to trying Lacanda, especially because I knew they serve Jewish style artichokes...yum, my favorite.  The ambiance is modern and perfect for people watching.  Which is all you can do because it is so loud you can't talk with your friends.

Our table was right in front of the door, which kept opening allowing for chill air to come blowing in.  They need to install a curtain to help solve this problem.  The service is mediocre at best, our waitress, took quite a while before greeting us, she came to take our appetizer order and left so quickly we weren't able to order drinks.  The restaurant appears somewhat understaffed.  Once I did get a cocktail order in it came long after appetizers were served.  However, the aperitivo and anniversario cocktails are tasty.

In terms of food, the Pizza Bianca and Jewish Style Artichokes (although very small) were delicious.  I ordered the linguini with lambs, they describe the sauce as "light", however "light" actually translates to bland.  My husband ordered the lamb, which was tasty, however, it is very small.  He left hungry.  I was also able to try the sole, which a friend ordered, also so simple it seemed bland.  The side order of carrots are incredible and absolutely worth it.  The warm chocolate cake and slow roasted strawberry and mint dessert are to die for.

Overall, left with the feeling of spending too much money on a restaurant with a lot of hype.  Good appetizers and desserts, tasty cocktails, less than average entrees.
author: Mags S.

description:
Came in a couple of days ago with my date.
We arrived at the late side of the evening and I was a little worried about the service.. (In some places if you arrive close to the end, they rush you and it ruins your evening. I had this terrible experience last week at Cotogna.)
To my surprise, everything went just perfect!
We were seated in the back section and our waiter arrived immediately.
He made suggestions on drinks, wine and food, we didn't even look at the menu.

We enjoyed:
carciofo fritto with crispy capers
animelle ai carciofi
worm focaccia (made only for us, since we were the last table)
coda di bue
agnello.

The food was simple, authentic and well prepared.

The wine that our server suggested (Cab Merlot blend 2005 from Alto Adige, Peter Dipoli) worked amazingly with the food.

This is one of  my favorite Italian restaurants.

I have to say that the service made my night memorable. 
Thank you Nicola for the wonderful experience!!!
author: Davide C.

description:
Fabulous. Grazie. 

P.S.   Rabbit sugo.
author: Julie L.

description:
Excellent food and service, but the portions are frustratingly small.  How small?  My buddy and I each ordered an entree after two apps at the bar while waiting for our table.  In response, our server, who was really good and nice as well, said we should order something else.  

You know what?  She was right.  Had we not eaten that app and bread, we would have gone hungry.  That doesn't make sense to me.

Sharing the bread with an adjacent party at the communal table wasn't an issue for me, but it was for most other folks.  

I won't be back unless I'm going with light eaters whose plates I can vulture.
author: Mike H.

description:
(+) Very nice place, atmosphere, food and drinks.
First I had an original and tasty cocktail with grappa.
Sweetbreads, lamb tongue and oxtail were good and not common to find on on menu
A red Corbieres was good pairing

(-) very busy and they cannot respect the reservation time, sat 30 min after the reserved time
recipes are not very elaborate
it's very noisy
If you do not speak Italian the menu is not very useful
avoid if angry or not ready to spend $100/mouth
author: Pascal P.

description: If you've eaten at Delfina - then you know where the bar is set (which is very very high). And suffice to say that Anne/Craig cleared it with ease. This is the culmination of perfecting their approach to food and service over 13 years creating an eating experience that is world class but also unique. Items like traditional classic Roman pizza Bianca and the unexpected pasta dishes are simply delightful. This place will carve out a permanent spot in the city's culinary landscape along with the genesis of it all Delfina.
author: Roland D.

description:
There is potential. Definitely. But at the moment, this place does not live up to all the hype it was able to muster. Trying to explain:

service-wise
~~~~~~~~~~
so I am somewhat conflicted: There are a few awesome guys there - nice and kind and accommodating and with a sense of humor, only they weren't in charge of our table nor where they the hosts, and the service did have its quarks.. For example, although I said that as long as its EVOO I don't care much, the dessert menu came stained with oil...
Also, they were so anxious that we leave, that we got the "do you need anything else?" question in the middle of dessert and the check a second later.


food-wise 
~~~~~~~~
I don't mean to be insulting, but the experience on the aggregate is that the food is good, and I really don't think that this is where they are aiming...  But the dishes are not consistent in their level, some great, some no more than mediocre. So on a great to mediocre index:

sweetbreads. lovely (to the extent you can think of offal in those terms), tender, juicy, perfectly balanced sweet/salty, fritto-misto version of sweetbreads.

jewish style artichoke. deep fried. crispy. aesthetic == (or as good as) fried ricotta balls dessert. caramel-citrus. delicate.
 
veal saltimbocca pasta.. this dish is the threshold between worth ordering and not so much.

carciofi with ricotta and avocado .. this dish had some interesting aspects to it like the raw carciofi, but the bottom line is that the components didn't quite work well with one another. My companion thought that the entire dish was negatively unripe, but I think that unripe was the positive aspect, which probably means it was interesting enough to merit a debate.

the anchovy pasta which we were forewarned was spicy. Now spicy I love, less so do I love attempts on my life... Still, I did derive some masochistic pleasure from the dish. But, such level of spiciness does require something to balance it out so that you can rest in between murderous bites. 

limoncello. Subpar. Too high a level of alcohol, too low a level of lemon. 

Another comment: the portions for both pastas where downright stingy, even for primis. (e.g. the anchovy was almost untraceable by an eye which is not behind a telescope)

decor-wise
~~~~~~~~~
I would rethink the artwork. 


Having said all that... If after this review they'd still let me in, I will give this place a couple more shots. Maybe what I've experienced are just quarks due to the rawness of this place. Yeah... maybe it just needs a little more cooking.
author: tal n.

description: I would come back for the smoky mashed potatoes..strong flavor and very unique.  The menu changed since the last time I came here but the dishes are creative and tasty.  A nice place for drinks and chit chat
author: Christina K.

description: Want to give 3.5 because the service was uneven, in that drinks took 15-20 min to arrive each time we ordered and the gap between starter and main was ~30 min, but the food was awesome. Green tomato soup and the most perfectly cooked salmon ever with beans, strong olives, and a celery leaf salsa verde. Just awesome food. Could use a little more air movement in the back of the house as it really heats up as the night goes on.
author: A K.

description: I went on a date with my hubby and we loved the place. The drinks were amazing, I had a Matador and was super good! To eat we both ordered a Pasta Amatrichana and was amazing too. I highly recommend this place!
author: Maria P.

description:
My friend and I came here for dinner on a Monday night and I'm really glad he made a reservation, because when I arrived the restaurant was full! So please, do make reservations when you come here. The decor is pretty cute. A mix between contemporary artistic and woodsy cabin?? I like how trendy the place is so that you can come dressed up or down and not feel out of place either way. Definitely not a formal place, but I like that there's the option of dressing up a little here. Anyways, I was seated right away and the server made great recommendations for our meal. In fact, the service was great throughout (attentive and friendly but never overbearing).

On to the food: I wish I could remember the name of the vodka cocktail I got, because it was amazing! Apparently it's the bartender's favorite ;) For an appetizer, we had the sweetbreads, which was new for me. They were fried perfectly and tasted interesting but very good! Perfect level of spiciness and saltiness. The portion size for the oxtails  was huge and definitely worth trying if you're a fan of oxtail. Flavorful and the meat falls right off the bone. My unexpected favorite was the hen leg over lentils. Cooked perfectly and the flavor was savory but not overpowering at all. Just perfect. Would definitely love to come back for a date or other fancy meal =)
author: Diana Y.

description:
I would give this place more stars if it weren't for the fact that many of their dishes have waaay too much oil! The last time we came in all five dishes had tons of oil, and even the extra bead we got was saturated. Come on chefs, you don't need to drench everything with oil. I don't get it, isn't it obvious? Yeah olive oil tastes amazing but you should know better about balancing proportions. 

Otherwise great ambiance, service and drinks.
author: Sunset L.

description:
I had an awesome dining experience at Locanda.  

Why the 3 stars? 

Well, it's pretty expensive. And like, if the food is good, the price should be besides the point or something, right?  But then I got to thinking how so many 4 or 5 star restaurants on Yelp are $$$, and how maybe, just maybe, we rate them more highly because we literally invested more in them (this is a thing, it's called cognitive dissonance). 

Okay, anyway, before I psychoanalyze all of Yelp's users, let me say that the shrimp burrata pasta dish (cuscini) is great. Definitely recommend it. That on its own is worth coming in again for. Buttery, cheesy, flavorful deliciousness. I like the complimentary bread they give too. And the ricotta fritta dessert is pretty cool.

In general the dishes are very rich here. I found the poached duck egg appetizer a little *too* buttery. I didn't find the albacore interesting enough. Everything was good, but just not amazing. People rave about the Jewish style artichoke here, but like, it's a fried artichoke. C'mon people. Hard to screw that up.

I do have to applaud Locanda for the superb service -- we had really awesome waitstaff and bartenders. I enjoyed sitting at the bar and watching the bartenders do their thing, and it's just nice to feel like you're being taken care of. And unlike some other places that are popular and get quite busy, the receptionists were really helpful in pointing us to spots at the bar that were about to open up when we found out there were no tables available for another 2 hrs (got there a bit before 8pm on a Wednesday).

To sum up, while I had a tasty meal, it wasn't the most delicious one I've had in recent weeks, and yet was easily the most expensive. While we ordered quite a bit of food, I don't think I would've filled up on one pasta dish alone. Worth trying? Definitely. But I don't think it'll be a regular spot for me.
author: Richa A.

description:
Finally, pasta the way it is supposed to be cooked and served. It is really true that now you have to pay a pretty penny for people to just NOT screw it up.

So good, so simple, and so tasty! You must give this place a shot. This is my new "go to" in San Francisco.
author: Brooks J.

description:
I really liked the atmosphere. Great redo of the space. However, I found the food really lacking. The "pizza" with mortadella was the best thing I had all evening. I had the pasta with gulf shrimp and burrata. It was okay but not at all memorable and I could barely taste the burrata. My friend got the carbonara and it was so salty we couldn't finish it. I love guanciale, but it is salty, no need to add a bunch more salt to the dish! 

For dessert we had the chocolate cake which was okay but not memorable either. Overall it was a truly "meh" experience. I'm hoping this is just a "working out the kinks" situation and the food improves. 

I fear the high reviews here reflect the hype not the food.
author: Jennifer C.

description:
We stopped in here on a Thursday night with out a reservation. I didn't think this would be a problem, but the place was packed! If you don't want to wait, you might want to snag a reservation. We started out with the fried sweetbreads and artichokes. So good! You can't go wrong with fried sweetbreads, my personal favorite offal! I had the Bucatini all'Amatriciana with guanciale, tomato, peperoncini, and pecorino. The pasta was cooked to a perfect al dente. The tomato sauce was perfect, with a nice pork-y essence from the guanciale. The hubs had Fettuccini with rabit sugo. It was awesome! 

They have a nice size wine list, and some great cocktails as well. I had a cocktail called an Apertivo, with campari, orange, lemon and prosecco. It had a great bitter orange flavor. A great restaurant. With great food and great service.
author: Lori F.

description:
You know when you've had a long week and all you want is a nice relaxing Friday night dinner... lo and behold, Locanda. It was everything I wanted it to be. Just perfect.

Most things on the menu are small-medium plates (which is my fave way to eat), so be sure to order 4-5 dishes for two people! 

Food:
Radiatore (ridged pasta perfect pockets for lamby ragu heaven!)
Bucatini (tip: get extra guanciale-soft and crispy cured bits of pork fat..AMAZING)
Oxtails (so tender! & big dish)
Fried Lambs Brain & fried artichokes  (Thats right..lamb brain...it was......creamy.....try it! fried artichokes were stellar..I wanted a giant bowl of them right now.)
Jewish Style artichoke (Never had a fried artichoke quite like this..I'm not sure how I feel about it..but I couldn't stop eating it either)
Ricotta frittata (What the.........wow.)

Drink: Wine on tap..how cool! I got the one from Italy..very happy with it :)

Our server was really nice as was the hostesses, runners, friendly service all around! Beautiful space and a great place to spend my Friday night.. can't wait to come back!
author: Jessica h.

description: The food here is delicious. I went with a friend of mine who is a foodie on a Monday night at 7:30. I told him it is currently one of the hottest restaurants in town, but he still commented every half an hour that he couldn't believe how busy it was on a Monday night. And even though it was packed, our service was still good. Our dishes came out in a timely manner and we were always offered refills on water and bread. We had the duck egg, the veal pasta, the fettucini with rabbit ragu, the guinea hen and the chocolate cake for dessert. Everything was really good. I think my favorite was the guinea hen followed closely by the fettucini. The chocolate cake was just ok, but I can overlook that since the rest of the meal was so good.
author: Kerry K.

description: The wait for 2 on a Saturday night at 6:15pm was only 20 minutes. Cocktails were delicious, though the ginger cocktail was too gingery. We got the whole grilled fish. It was pretty good but a bit too salty. The atmosphere is great.
author: Kaya C.

description: Had one of the better meal at Locanda - the dungeness crab pasta was cooked to perfection and full of crab flavor.  Pork chop was roasted but quite juicy.  Great service.  This place is always crowded especially on the weekend so prepare to wait.  We got lucky and had a 9:30 last minute reservation on opentable. Overall very satisfying meal.  Cocktails always a highlight.
author: Edmond T.

description:
We had meant to go to Bar Tartine, but they're remodeling and we stumbled upon this pretty little ditty a couple doors down sans sign (the former Las Ramblas still showing through the black paint) and went inside and a very welcoming hostess showed us to some open spots at the communal table.

While you're waiting for your food these amazing Pizza Bianca (?) crispy airy little almost focaccia like bread slices come out.  We accidentally received two (no complaints here! :)  )

We started with a Jerusulem style artichoke which is basically an artichoke with the tips fried.  So yummy - lemony herby goodness. 

I had the lamb ragu and my boyfriend had the bavette steak.  They were both really good.  The food is served kind of rustic style - no frills just good flavor. The pasta had a good fresh (with the little bit of "chewy") texture.

The staff are really nice and attentive - in a nice kind of quiet way...meaning just enough attention but they also let you enjoy your meal and your company.  

Lastly, I love the lighting here at night - it's really flattering and perfect if you're on a date - everyone looks really great! or that could be bad...because in some ways you know that's as good as he or she is going to get!  The layout of the restaurant is perfect too because there's a nice long bar and the communal table for walk-ins and a good energy.
author: Yvonne Y.

description: i enjoyed the jewish style artichoke, but after that, everything went down hill.  we had the GARDEN LETTUCES "MISTICANZA" - way overdressed.  next, we had the CUSCINI with Gulf Shrimp, which was overdressed, salty and fishy. Next up, the PANCETTA-WRAPPED MARY'S CHICKEN - looked and tasted like a big salty sausage... Once dishes were delivered, the server never stopped by to ask "how is your meal?"  If he had asked, we likely would have sent it back. disappointing and over-priced.
author: Julie C.

description:
There are so many of these kinds of Italian places in the city now, but I'm always excited to try a new one.  We went to Locanda last week with my wife and a couple friends, and while the meal was pretty good, I wasn't wowed.  The cocktails were probably the star of the meal -- I think what we had were called Kentucky Maids? -- and I kept wanting more.  The "pizza bianca" was delicious, but was just like a focaccia pizza.  Delicious, but somewhat uninspiring.  The fried artichoke was also very good.  The salad of arugula, avocado, and ricotta was good, but not great.  

The pastas we had were pretty good also, but there was nothing too exciting on the menu.  Our two friends both had the bucatini, which was cooked perfectly and had a nice tomato-guanciale sauce.  I ordered the radiatore with a very nice lamb-mint ragu, and I loved my dish.  Sadly, however, the most adventurous dish we ordered was the least successful.  The description said (other than the pasta name, which we did not know), only said "gulf shrimp, burrata," which sounded great.  Unfortunately, the pasta pillows that we got were overly fishy, and our least favorite dish of the night.  My wife actively disliked the dish.  

Again, I loved my pasta, but the bad dish that my wife got, combined with the somewhat unexciting menu, means that it doesn't rank up there with some of our favorite places.  I might give them another try in the future, but given the plethora of Italian options in SF, it might not be for awhile.
author: Pilan C.

description:
Very good dinner overall.  I'm a bit surprised they aren't surprised given its good location and proximity to other more popular places.  

For apps, the fava beans are excellent, and potatoes are decent as well. I had 2 pastas (the bucatini and orecchiette) were both very good, though I wished there was more meat.  For dessert I had the torta, which was decent but nothing special.  I also came here separately for dessert once, when I had an incredible hazelnut dessert.  Unfortunately they didn't have it the second time around.
author: Josh Q.

description:
Perhaps it is just not my thing but everything was drenched in oil. I felt like a grease pit when I left there.

The Jewish Artichoke my delicious (and oily), the artichokes with the sweetbread and friend capers was good (and oily), the linguine with anchovy was really oily and the Porchetta was fatty and oily. It could be me... maybe Roman food is oily x 10 and its just not my thing.

Our service was pleasant.
author: Liz C.

description:
The scene:  5:45 on opening night at Locanda... beautiful contemporary space, great energy and light, amazing service, beautiful artwork.

Oh, and the food is pretty good too!  Poached egg with asparagus for starters.  Roman style unique pasta dishes filled with bold flavors and very tasty meats.  Tasty Guinea hen leg stuffed with savory goodness, accompanied by pea shoots and small dark lentils.  

Reasonably priced wine choices, and overall meal was not excessively expensive.

Tip: try the 'bartenders choice' drink.  You tell them what type of spirit you like, and they bring you a cocktail.  Great idea and executed well.
author: Jane N.

description:
I've mourned the loss of Ramblas since the day they closed. One of the best tapas restaurants in SF and my go-to Sunday brunch, I've been waiting to see what would happen there next.  Well, the fine folks from Delfina took the space and turned it into a Roman Osteria.

The ambiance is certainly much lighter than the Ramblas days. The room feels much more open and far larger. Emeco (Starck) stools, etched glass water bottles...the little touches are all there to offer a hip experience and not overly fussy. Despite this being opening night...yep, other than a friends and family soft opening this was the first real night open...the service was spot on. Friendly, excited and efficient. I was really surprised how well they had it down. On the other hand, the owners are old hands now at running a popular SF restaurant. Now the food.

I'll say straight off that the Casarecce alla Carbonara (guanciale, egg, pecorino, black pepper) might be the best Carbonara in the city. Just perfect. The Lane (rabbit sugo, dandelion greens, verjus) was perhaps just a bit less successful...it arrived at the table just luke warm. The salad - Insalata Misticanza (12 greens, aceto, xvoo) was fine. Of the half dozen red wines offered by the glass we selected the 2007 Leone Conti Sangiovese and it was fine.

Locanda seems to have it nailed. Given this was opening night and everything was already so good, I expect by end of summer this place will be yet another impossible table to get in SF. Well done.
author: Gary C.

description:
It seems like several of the restaurants in the Mission have excellent cocktails and okay dining experiences.  Locanda fits this pattern. 

I had the nonna del diavolo, a delicious rye-based cocktail.  I liked that it was presented with a sugar lump so you could sweeten it to your liking.  The cocktail was the high point.  

The green tomato soup was tasty but not exciting.  The fusilli and sardines was also underwhelming.  The sardines were shredded, making the texture somewhat unpleasant.  I tried dishes that others ordered; they tended to be very salty.  

I was dining with a large group.  Most of the people rarely order dessert.  Almost everyone did.  I think they ordered dessert because they were still hungry.  

The service was spotty.  We were there very early so they were not busy (we had a reservation).  The servers did the minimum required to serve our table.  They did not feel welcoming.  I might be back for a drink at the bar and a snack, but I won't be frequenting Locanda for dinner.
author: Donna S.

description:
First Impression: As I walk by and read the reviews..hell no. Seemed pretentious. 

First Experience: This place is right on...

Worth the money and your time, even though you may think your time is money anyway (which it is not). I enjoyed a small meal with a friend, which consisted of the following:

- Pizza Bianca w/ Corn (Yes, Yes)
- Fettuccini w/ Rabbit Sogu (Yes, Yes, Yes)
- Radiatore w/ Lamb Ragu (Yes)
- Ricotta Fritta (Yes, Yes, Yes)
- Peach Crostata (Maybe)

All tasty, but to varying degrees. You won't find me using big foodie words because I am not going to act like I know what I am talking about. We had the server recommend wine parings, which were right on as well.

The server was knowledgeable, did not hesitate to offer advice or share her preferences, which I really enjoy. The clientele may generally be pretentious, but the servers are not all.
author: Pico S.

description:
By far one of the best neighborhood restaurants in SF! Its obvious to even the most amateur critic (myself haha) that every detail of this establishment has been meticulously thought out. 

This restaurant has it all - an intensely courteous staff, hip atmosphere, an exciting and diverse menu, great wine selection and variety of unique cocktails. I LOVE Locanda!!!

PS. The Jewish-style artichoke is TO DIE FOR! Yum!!
author: Becky N.

description:
First time at Locanda and I must say I am incredibly impressed. Every single thing we ordered was perfect. Our server, Jack, gave excellent recommendations and set the tone for a lovely evening. We started with fried olives, I have never had these before and they were a really great starter. Main courses were halibut and shrimp ravioli pasta which I wouldn't have tried but our server recommended it and *wow* I am so glad I tried this! The pasta was literally the BEST I have ever had, and my hunny is Italian, we eat a lot of pasta :) 

We decided on a baked yogurt dessert - the flavors were out of this world and I could almost not restrain myself from licking the plate. Extra points for  great atmosphere, nice music, good prices, and yummy cocktails.  

We will be back for sure for our next date night!
author: Saray D.

description: The food was delicious.  I went with three girls and we shared the "INSALATA VIGNAROLA".  This I think was my favorite.  I had the CASONCELLI "alla SALTIMBOCA" which was very rich and tasty, though if I was hungry would not have been enough.  We finished with TORTA DI SEMOLINA which was perfect to share.  They have a pretty good wine list and but the server stood to be a bit more upbeat.   If I could give them 3.5 starts I would have but rounded down bc of the service, she was attentive just made us feel rushed and the resto wasn't even that busy. #locanda #sf
author: Margarita H.

description:
Stopped in for a quick drink before dinner in the Mission.  

The place was packed even though it was only 6:30pm!  The drinks were unique and quite good.  The bartenders here sure know how to multitask!  Friendly and informative too.  

I must come back for dinner.  I have a bad habit of eyeing other peoples' plates, and was tempted to squeeze in a dinner here instead of heading off to our reservations down the block.
author: Sandee L.

description:
The food is obviously made w/ the freshest of ingredients and dishes are unique.  Prices are pretty inexpensive considering SF.  Most things less than $20.

But seriously, I think the hype is making people rate it higher than they normally would.

My meal was fresh and satisfying but not wow.  The pea soup with ricotta salata was more like liquidy chicken broth with dark green spirulina color (weird) and shavings of cheese floating in it (ok I guess).  The lamb ragu was tasty, kind of like bolognese ground meat but then there were random pieces of whole stewed fatty chunks in there for some reason.  Not tragic but not great chomping into mushy fat.

Other people at the communal table weren't happy with their starters.  What looked like a lardo salad they thought needed more flavor and acid to break the fat.  Some others thought the deep fried artichoke starter was scrawny and ugly.  ha!

They have a few wines on tap.  Don't order the pinot noir.  Tasted like it was corked but obviously no corks on that tap.  ;-)

Definitely a scene but still fun people-watching, and the food isn't bad.. It's just not 5 star imo.
author: Melanie C.

description:
So freakin' good!  I left feeling extremely satisfied.  The meal was amazing from start to finish.  The sweetbread was creamy and perfectly fried.  The pastas were all delicious.  The portions may have been a bit on the small side and there was not much meat with the dishes, but the flavors were so good it did not matter.  The chocolate cake was impressive too.  

And the drinks are stiff!  Oh and make sure to ask for the complimentary bread-- it's good. 

Just as good as Delfina and better than Cotogna and Flour + Water.
author: K V.

description:
I came into Locanda excited to try their Old Fashioned "Flight" and hungry for dinner after a looong day.

Walked out a little disappointed. And still hungry!

First let me say, the bartenders were fantastic. I really enjoyed watching them work over the course of the evening. Service was quick and everything looked really great.

The Flight - the rye and demerara was sweetest, the scotch and honey was smoothest (I liked this best) but the bourbon and maple. Oh you guys. Maple? Delicious. Bourbon? Delicious. Too bad it wasn't delicious at all! Seriously how can you mess that one up? :(

The food was good. Just good. I enjoyed the duck egg/zucchini blossom dish and the artichoke/sweetbread dish, but both were a little too heavy on the capers. We also had the oxtail & an order of cacio e pepe. Good but nothing outstanding.

I think the $2 pupusa we got after dinner (and the cotton candy from a man walking down the road........ and bi-rite right after that......) were infinitely more satisfying.
author: Lalitha K.

description:
You don't need reservations to sit at the bar. Although they don't take your name, so you basically have to hover and wait for a seat to open up, which can get kind of crazy.  My bf and I came here around 6pm Friday night and basically missed the first bar seating- bummer and had to wait until around 645 to get seats.  

Tried to Jewish artichoke, the lamb shank, and a pasta with some kind of smoked pork and red sauce.  The pasta was amazing, as expected.  I wasn't a huge fan of the artichoke even though it has rave reviews and came recommended.  I thought it had a bit too much salt and I just didn't prefer the super fried ness of it.  

Wine selection is huge and they have some interesting local beers on tap.  The bartenders were awesome and I had a really good time there.
author: Skye W.

description:
Earlier this week I went to dinner at Locanda, a restaurant that despite its high profile location (16th and Valencia) I hadn't heard much about. It opened in April 2011 and is run by the same owners as Delfina. I knew I'd like it right off the bat since its logo is an artichoke. I had decided to go there for dinner after scanning 7X7's list of "100 Things to Eat Before You Die" and the Jewish style artichokes at Locanda popped out to me. How does one make Jewish style artichokes? And why had I not heard of this before?

Turns out they're fried, herb-seasoned and delicious. But let me start from the beginning. Walking into Locanda, it has the similar atmosphere of its neighbors in the Mission.  It was darker, primarily candlelit and had bar and open kitchen spanning the length of the restaurant. After assessing the menu, we settled on calling it an Italian Roman fusion. Pretty much every antipasti on the menu looked delicious so we went for a wide variety. On top of the Jewish style artichokes, which were an obvious must, we also went with the king salmon crudo, shaved artichoke salad, egg and asparagus, grilled pizza bianca and peas and shoots. Let's start with the last. We ordered the peas and shoots as we'd heard the owner requires the wait staff to say one of his favorite jokes, "peas shoot, peas score" whenever serving the pea shoots. Sadly our server did not, but with the spring onion and straus yogurt mixed in, they were still the most flavorful pea side dish I've ever had. My least favorite starter (and let me caveat that this just means it was the least amazing) was the king salmon crudo. I liked that it was topped with salted capers and kept simple with a little xvoo. Unfortunately it lacked the acidity that really makes a crudo sing. The asparagus was not lacking in flavor, as it was topped with a poached egg, bottarga (cured fish roe) and burro nero (butter), finished off with crunchy breadcrumbs. Outside of the Jewish style artichoke, my favorite was the pizza Bianca, while was charred bread topped with an amazing amount of burrata, herbs and oil. It sounds so simple on paper but if you saw it in person you would understand. Even the basic bread brought for the table was anything but basic. It was fresh out of the grill, doused in olive oil and topped with sea salt.

But back to the artichokes. The shaved artichoke salad was mixed with arugula and avocado but what really brought it a step above other shaved salads I've had was the grilled ricotta. Usually when I have ricotta it's in its softer form but this was the hard cheese. And grilling it added this great smoky flavor to the cheese. It turns out Jewish style artichokes (carciofi all giudia) are a delicacy from the olden Roman days. The artichokes are fried in oil with their leaves out-turned, making them look like sunflower. The whole, fried artichokes is seasoned with herbs, lemon, salt and pepper. They're crunchy, flavorful and another fun way to enjoy artichokes.

For my main dish I ordered the chicken, which could be perceived as boring, but it was wrapped in pancetta and stuffed with some form of herbs. It was some of the most perfectly cooked chicken I've ever had and the pancetta really held in the flavor and moistness. After checking out everyone else's dishes, I'd also recommend the pork spareribs based off looks and that that person's satisfaction level. I ducked out before dessert but was more than satisfied. I highly recommend this spot and plan to go back soon.
author: Larisa J.

description: Went with bf and an employee of the restaurant. Every single thing was awesome. Pasta, tomato salad, steak, two desserts, three appertifs, wine, beer, onion rings, rabe. I don't remember having a meal this good in a long time. Amaretto croccante semifreddo killed it.
author: JD D.

description:
Loved this place!
My husband and I went here tonight for our anniversary. The food was amazing and service was impeccable! Everyone was so friendly and had such great teamwork. I had the lamb ragu and my husband had pork artista both amazing dishes!
author: Crystal P.

description:
LOVE this place.  Hubby and I came on a Thursday night - date - night and it was a lovely and relaxing place for dinner.  From the hostess checking you in, to our server, the service was excellent.  We thought we'd start with a cocktail and move onto some Italian vino, but the first cocktail was so good, we continued ordering them with the rest of dinner.

The food was super yum.  Everything was fresh and authentic.  We had the fried artichoke starter, pasta and split their fish of the day.  The food here reminded me of the three weeks we got to spend in Italy.  It's NOT all about red sauce and cheese.  It's about food that is fresh, seasonal and so tasty that it doesn't need to be too dolled up.  The ambiance was nice too- it wasn't a ridiculously loud restaurant and the art - funky but somehow fitting.
author: S.T. C.

description: I thought Locanda was A-OK. The beef cheeks ravioli was way too salty and not as tasty as they made it sound. The portions were small too. In terms of service, all the waiters & waitresses were really attentive to our 15-people group. But food wise, I really wasn't too impressed. Maybe it's just not my type of cuisine. meh.
author: Annie Z.

description:
Lambs tongue as a starter - tender with crisp edges.  Lots of other interesting tastes and textures on the plate as well.  Hubby had the sorrel soup with dungeness crab.  I was not so enamored but he loved the fresh tangy taste and devoured the large helping.  It was served piping hot which was nice.  I enjoyed a cocktail - the excellent smoke and spice.  Hubby had a delicious glass of a white on tap.
The rabbit sugo was quite delicious - a tad salty for my taste buds as I prefer lower salt on my food but the pasta itself had a great texture and the rabbit was tender and moist.  Hubby went for the grande option on the oxtails and enjoyed them.  Shared the delicious sheep milk budino.  Creamy flavorful and yummy.  i have to go back.
author: Ash A.

description: My husband and I happened upon Locanda while visiting San Francisco. It was amazing! The atmosphere was comfortable but lively - not too loud though. The food was delectable and satisfying. We had the grilled fish and it was expertly prepared - they even deboned the whole grilled for us. Even the bread served before the meal was excellent. Just a plain focaccia but soo flavorful. This is a must try.
author: Genevieve H.

description:
This place is really great! I have been here twice and each time was not a disappointment.  Atmosphere is chic and casual with a good energy.  
I enjoyed the waiters freedom of dress, but still keeping it casual-smart to add to the laxed environment.

All the pastas are all homemade from scratch, wine on tap, service was outstanding and professional, 'nuff said.

What to order:  Jewish fried artichoke, fried sweetbreads, braised oxtail, rabbit sugo.

My only gripe the second time I went is the food came out a bit quickly and felt like I was on an eating sprint...The first time, my friend and I ordered in spurts so we were able to enjoy ourselves in the experience a bit more.
author: Nicky N.

description:
Let me just say that I tried things here the other night that I would've never even thought of trying before. 

My friend Aimee was back in town from NY so where else to have our catch-up dinner than at the newest hot spot! I made reservations the day before and luckily we were both able to make an early dinner at 5:30pm. If not, the next availability would have been at 10pm! I hear their normal dinner times between 6-9pm are booked for weeks ..maybe even months!

Our waiter was amazing. Not only was he helpful, he was extremely patient with us since we had no idea what we wanted to order. But it was his helpful suggestions that got us through an amazing meal!

Since we both love artichokes we had to order the Jewish Style Artichoke and the Artichoke Salad (Carciofi Crudi). Both were delicious! The Jewish Style was fried and crispy but not over done. The salad with grilled ricotta, wild arugula, and avocado was refreshing and zesty to contrast enough from the other dish. 

Then it was on to the sweetbreads & artichoke dish which was made with veal that night instead of lamb. I've never eaten sweetbreads before so I was definitely nervous, but our waiter described them to resemble a creamier version of a chicken nugget with a slightly chewier texture. Let me just say I not only survived the dish, I actually enjoyed it! His description couldn't have been more accurate! Who doesn't like chicken nuggets? Just think of them as the classier version with much more flavor!!

Our pasta was up next. Since none of them really stuck out to us, we went with our waiter's suggestion again. This time we got adventurous with rabbit! Again, another first for me.  I like most meats except for ones that tend to be gamey like lamb, so I think this dish had to be THE MOST nerve racking for me.  Result? Success! Now I know that I can eat rabbit anyday over lamb! I've even concluded that this was my favorite dish of the night! The rabbit mixed with a bit of prosciutto and fettuccini was absolutely amazing. 

As if we didn't eat enough between the two of us, we ended our main courses with the hen. It was wrapped with some sort of cured meat (now I cant remember if it was prosciutto or bacon) but I have to say this was the least memorable of all the dishes. It was good, but our palettes might have been fooded out by this time. It definitely wasn't dry, but I don't recall it being juicy either.  

To finish off the meal we chose the Strawberry Crostata. Since strawberries are in season now, it was the perfect ending to our meal.

Locanda, I will be back again! Hopefully sooner than later!

TIP: Book your reservations asap and definitely listen to your waiter. I wish I remembered his name, but whoever you are, thank you!! :)
author: Kristen C.

description:
Perfectly cooked pasta. 
Amazing Jewish artichoke and tasty vegetable side dishes.
A bit pricey for what it is, but good food nonetheless.
author: Dean S.

description:
This is my first review on Yelp.  This restaurant really impressed me.  I think when a restaurant offers a memorable experience, it should be recognized.
We brought our cousin from New York on a Tuesday night.  We asked the waitress for a recommendation on the wine. We were looking for a super Tuscan.  When our wine arrived, we did not love it, but we didn't want to complain.  A man came over and introduced himself as the wine buyer for the restaurant.  He was not working that night, but happened to be in the restaurant.  He noticed that we didn't love the wine and took it back. He then offered another comparable bottle which we loved.  Its service like this that will make us come back.
Standout dishes were the linguine with clam sauce, the Carbonara, the steak and chicken under a brick.  The atmosphere was fun and service was very attentive.
author: Antoanela V.

description: What a wonderful restaurant. The Delfina people continue to offer some of the best food, service and environment anywhere in San Francisco.  This place is stunning and the Romanesque food is so delicious that I've returned several times to experience more and more. And finally (unlike Delfina who has wonderful wines), this place has a full bar and the drinks, all about $10,  are blended perfectly. No pretentious bartenders or server, but excellent service and they pat attention and listen to you..  Probably one of my top three places right now.  You can even stop by early just for a cocktail and appetizer at the bar, and I think they serve pretty late too.
author: N M.

description:
I visited Locanda with three other friends,we ate family style and everything was beyond delicious. We tried:

Jewish Style Artichokes: I'm generally not a fan of artichokes, but these were buttered up quite nicely adding good flavor
Linguini- very light yet flavorful, nice amount of crab meat, and lemon 
Cuscini- melt in your mouth good
Grilled lamb leg- prepared to perfection, no lamby taste
Guinea Hen- really good. 

The server was great as well (Justin). He was very attentive, and made excellent wine and dish recommendations that we really enjoyed. I plan to visit again!
author: T S.

description:
I had high expectations for Locanda given all the reviews before me but it sorely disappointed.  Valencia street is filled with tons of amazing restaurants but Locanda is not one of them.  We ordered the Jewish Artichokes as advertised (2 orders of them to be safe).  When they reached the table we thought the second order would be coming out shortly given the tiny portion but alas we were wrong.  The artichokes themselves were shriveled and oversalted, nothing special, and each one was only half an artichoke to boot!  Outrageous!  And this was only a sign of things to come.

I was with a group at dinner.  Some of us ordered pasta dishes.  I have never in my life seen a pasta dish where the serving did not even cover the entire plate.  The pasta dishes at Locanda barely covered two thirds of the plate.  It's not like there were any special ingredients in the pasta, just pasta and red or white sauce.  

It get's better.  My girlfriend ordered the oxtail stew.  You would think there would actually be oxtail in the stew.  No!  Instead there were only mushrooms and eggs and an oxtail broth (as the waiter was kind enough to explain when we asked her).  The menu was a total lie!

I ordered the Leg of Lamb, the coup de gras!  27 dollars.  It came with three slices of carved lamb.  No bone.  No leg in sight.  And it didnt even come with a side dish.  Next to the lamb were slices of lettuce, drenched in the same sauce as the lamb itself.  Unbelievable.  

We asked the manager to explain what we had ordered and she tried to defend the lies on the menu (and the lies that the waiter had told us when we asked for a description of the oxtail stew).  She was extraordinarily unhelpful.  She even had the gall to tell us that Locanda is comparable to other restaurants in the area!  Give me a break.  I can think of many restaurants within a block radius where I can find an amazing meal for much cheaper than this rip-off place (Picaro and Limon come to mind immediately).  I seriously cannot believe that this place survives in the extremely competitive San Francisco restaurant scene.  It is an embarrassment.
author: Josh B.

description:
Would not go back there if you paid me!

So went there for a birthday, and was told it was a very hip place.  Looked nice enough, lively and the bar choices were interesting.  Hard to find things on the menu we liked.  They were obviously trying hard to do new stuff, but going out of your way to be different does not mean it's good.

The first dishes were OK--not great but not bad.

My wife ordered a steak with mashed potatoes.  We were  surprised at seeing literally a dollop of potatoes since potatoes are so cheap.  It really was a garnishment.  My  wife asked if she could have a little extra so she could enjoy it with her steak.  In most  places, the server would  just bring  over a little additional potatoes if a customer asks.   In this place, the server sent over the manager. 
 
The manager basically told us that was how the dish came like it or not and they she would be very happy to sell us a very expensive side order of potatoes.    My wife said we paid enough already.  The menu was not really all that accurate -when you say mashed potatoes with steak,  you expect more than a tiny little garnishment/decorative affect.   The manager basically told us to go jump in a lake. 

 I have eaten in restaurants in over 80 countries all over the world spanning from tiny dives to places with three stars, and I cannot recall being treated like that. In fact, when I recall the worst five eating experiences spanning over 80 countries and many years, this place has made the top 5 list of bad experiences.  

Maybe a good place for a drink or to socialize but consider eating elsewhere.  Based on our experience, we were not guests, but merely a  metric.   So, they saved 25 cents worth of potatoes, but will never see us back, and got themselves a not so great YELP, not to mention we have already told a nubmer of people how bad this place is.    Makes a good story .  Was the 25 cents worth it?
author: L R.

description:
I typically don't write reviews, but was so disappointed with my experience last night, I'm hoping to save others the trouble...
Service:
Rude, not very pleasant of helpful.  I've NEVER tipped below 20%.  I couldn't bear to leave her with a standard tip.  Her demeanor ruined our evening.  Our waitress should not be in the service industry.

Food:
Meh.  Not very good.  We liked the Jewish style artichoke.  The clam linguini wasn't well balanced. You couldn't taste the brine of the Clams, too much lemon - plus there was sand in the clams and one came closed...sorry, that's ok for a $12 - $15 dish of pasta at a neighborhood restaurant, but not for the price you pay here.  The main course we ordered the whole fish - MP of $47.  Was not prepped table side, and the fish was mushy in texture not well seasoned at all.  Not enjoyable -- certainly not worth 47.

Drink:
I'd rather go to the hide out for cocktails.  These guys have good drinks but not for the $$. They use very basic rye's, bourbon's and whisky's and really charge a lot for the cocktails.  They should be using better quality spirits.  We had the old fashioned flight.  I liked the concept, but again, the ingredients weren't that great.

All in all, it was ok, but not worth the $200 spent.  I wish I had listened to fellow yelp reviews and gone elsewhere.  If this review saves you the trip, I'm glad.  If you really want to visit, go early and grab a seat at the bar. Share a pasta and have a cocktail -- go to dinner elsewhere.
author: JJ B.

description: Really good food but also on the expensive side.  Ate at the bar and enjoyed the cocktails and wine suggestions.  The beef cheeks, jerky, lamb tartar, and jewish artichokes were awesome.  Would definitely return.
author: Fatty A.

description:
Stopped in last night knowing our chances of getting in for dinner were slim. We put in our name (party of 2) were quoted a 2 hour wait. Deciding to grab a drink at the bar we lucked out and within minutes had secured bar seating. 

Fantastic bartender totally took care of us (no idea of his name but if you sit down in front of a British, bearded guy that looks a bit like Ray LaMontagne trust him). Left my drink fate in his hands and let him make me a Bartender's Choice cocktail...again...and again...and again. First was a magical ginger concoction, followed by a lemon-peach infused glass of deliciousness...and so on it went. Very happy (albeit tipsy) girl. 

We grabbed a few light bites including the CARCIOFI CRUDI (artichokes) with grilled ricotta, wild arugula and avocado. Amazing. Definitely would like to integrate that dish into my meals more often. Also had the POACHED DUCK EGG & ASPARAGUS...completely perfectly done. 

Will be back. Soon.
author: Lauren S.

description:
We came for happy hour drinks and ended up splitting a salad as well. The salad was tasty, and somehow we ended up with delicious free cheesy foccacia (pizza bianco, I think they called it). The bartender was able to concoct something wonderful from our vague directive of "something with limes and gin," and for that, we were grateful. 

The food being served at all the tables looked so good that I regretted having dinner plans elsewhere. 

Locanda's drinks are top notch, and their nibbles tantalizing; can't wait to return for a main course!
author: Monica S.

description:
Sad trombone... 

Doesn't live up to the hype.

Came here last night for friend's b-day... We had an 8:30 reservation, and there were six of us. We were seated at 9pm at a teeny tiny table. You know how you can push two tables together to comfortably seat four? Well, if you turn the tables the other way, you can seat more people across, making it longer but more narrow. That's what happened to us. It was awkward and small (it was me and five dudes), especially once the appetizers, bread, wine, and water all had to cram into the same narrow space. If you don't have room for us, you don't have room for us, but we had a reservation and it shouldn't have been an issue. I worked as a hostess for a long time when I was younger, and this was clearly just bad planning. I wish that they'd given us the option to wait for a bigger table (it had already been half an hour--what's another fifteen minutes at that point?), but the staff didn't seem concerned.

The green tomato soup was my favorite thing of the meal, but the pasta was SO DISAPPOINTING. I got ricotta bucattini, and they did not taste fresh. I'm guessing that this could have been due to the fact that we ended up only eating at 9:30, and perhaps they were made earlier in the day and left out or something. Anyways, it was really sad because I hardly ever eat pasta and I had been SO looking forward to something fresh and tasty. I ate exactly a third of my dish and filled up on the (delicious) bread.

If I ever come back, I'll just have bread, soup, and a glass of wine.

Flour + Water, you win this round.
author: Jenny M.

description:
5 star for friendly service.
2 star for noise.  I was yelling at my friend who was across the table.  they need to turn the music down a bit.  I dont mind loud lively places, but this isnt a bar.. .its more a restaurant than a bar.
2.5 stars for portion size.  I know americans are fat and getting fatter but 3 bites later i was done with my $17 pasta.  I would've liked 2-3 more bites to make me feel like it was worth the $$$.  I had the fettuccine with rabbit meat.  I saw 2 tiny pieces of rabbit.  
4.5 stars on taste.  It was delicious.
4.5 stars on dessert.  we had the warm chocolate cake.  the cream that came with the cake was DELICIOUS.
author: Marcia B.

description:
Their cauliflower pizza bianca is AMAZING.

I had the casarecce main, and it was very yummy. Al dente with a sauce of simple yet bold flavor.

We called 30 min ahead and made an early reservation for about 6:30 on a weeknight. It was a breeze to sit down then. And nice atmosphere.

Very nice service. 

I'd gladly come again.
author: Diana C.

description:
Wow.   I'm rarely impressed when my expectations are set high.   The experience here blew me away. 

The standouts:
Jewish Style Artichoke
Guinea Hen Leg with Pancetta
Patate Affumicate-  Wood roasted mashed potatoes
The Foccacia

The service was as professional as it gets.  

I will be back for more...
author: Fred X.

description: I usually pass this place because of the wait but luckily i had friends already seated.  Loved the Jewish-style Artichoke and the ginger ale (fresh). REALLY loved the drinks though.  I'm curious to come by and check out more of the menu...
author: Mike V.

description:
It's not entirely fair to review a restaurant which has only been open for a few days, or where you've only tried a few of the dishes, but I'm going to do it anyway. 

Pros: 
- Interesting dishes, many of which you probably never saw before. 
- Great flavors
- Excellent preparation
- Excellent ingredients
- Very warm and friendly staff
- The full menu is served until 12am every night

Cons:
- A bit pricey 
- The 12am to 1am bar menu is very limited


Dishes I tried: 

Pretzels made with lardo and prosciutto. This was 3 twists the size of mini donuts. Salty, piggy, and quite delicious. A bit pricey at $5. 

RADIATORE "PECORA e PECORINO" -lamb ragu, pecorino, mint. The flavors were intense and delicious. Just great with every bite. The pasta was almost too al dente, right on the edge for me. The portion size was okay, but I would have liked more, and I thought that $17 for pasta was maybe $3 more than I wanted to pay.

Peas & Pea Shoots "Vignarola". This was a good-sized portion of peas in and out of the pod, and some greens. I didn't see any pea shoots, though the greens may have been that. They were lightly cooked, with a brothy light sauce. Very refreshing. 

Dessert: RICOTTA FRITTA with citrus caramel, lemon thyme. These were little balls of fried dough with ricotta inside. They had a nice light citrus flavor, and the ricotta was creamy. 7 balls for $9. 

They have local wines on tap and European wines by the bottle. 

I was very happy with my late dinner here, and would be a regular if only the prices were slightly lower. As it is, I will definitely check back in a month or 2 when they have all the kinks worked out, and I'm hoping that they'll be 5 star by then.
author: Jacob L.

description: How to describe perfection?  Start with the breaded fried olives. Add a shared appetizer of fried artichokes with fresh lemon in the style of Jewish Rome. Such wonderful tastes!  The our party of 5 tucked into some pasta dishes. I had the orichietti with rabe garlic and homemade sausage. My wife loved her RIGATONI alla CARBONARA , and she is a real carbonara fan. We finished with a selection of wonderful deserts. Persimmon tart with pine nut crust. Amaro Nonino and expesso
author: Paul G.

description:
This was my first visit.  No expectations other than I heard it was a good spot.  Atmosphere wise, it is pretty good.  Clean and simple, not very flashy, but I am good with that.  Very hipsterish employees, though 90% of the patrons were not.

Decided to start at the bar and try some cocktails while we waited on a table.  An 1hr wait ended up taking about 30 minutes, but we probably could have been seated in 15 as the table sat empty for about 15minutes.

As for the cocktails, they were decent.  Considering the big push in SF to have really well made drinks, these were subpar in comparison to Bar Ag or Beretta.  At $12 a pop, even for a basic gin and tonic on the second round, I think they must have a pretty expensive lease that they need to cover.

Food wise, as it was about 10:30 when I ate, I really only had one main dish.  It was good, but the portion was a bit small, considering it was pasta.  Would I order it again, more than likely.

Service wise.  Tough one.  When we sat down, my friend exclaimed how starving he was.  The waitress was friendly and gave some good suggestions.  20 minutes later, she returns and asks if he received the appetizer, which he hadnt.  Then they decide to bring out some bread and after that was gone the app.  Not the best experience when your hungry.

I will give them another chance, but not in a rush.
author: Markus S.

description:
Wonderful restaurant on Valencia. Flavorful pastas, amazing appetizers, and bread (pizza bianca) to die for. 

The only down score was their version of pasta carbonara. I have to admit that I haven't found a good version of this wonderful Italian dish outside of Italy.
author: Martin D.

description:
One of the best new restaurants in SF to try.  My co-workers had been raving about it so finally had to make a trip to the mission.  Decor is trendy, with clean lines.  
We went on a Tuesday night around 6 and it was busy but were able to sit at the community table.

Had their fettucini with rabbit, flank steak and their pizza breads are AMAZING.  Try any of their mixed drinks.

Service was not as attentive but we were OK with that as we were so blown away by the food.
author: Sam S.

description:
I went here for the third time last night and every visit has been great. I would highly recommend the lamb pasta dish, the jewish artichoke, the lamb entree, and the salad with ricotta and avacado.

They have an awesome home-made ginger ale and Michael behind the bar makes some awesome cocktails. The place is pumping with action and is yet another example of the thriving dining scene around 16th and Valencia. 

My only minor complaint was that the otherwise great tasting food on our second visit arrived luke warm. If it were not for that minor detail, this would have been a 5-star rating.
author: Andy P.

description:
Again, the service could use a little polishing, I don't feel like I get the first-rate service that I do from places like Cotogna. But... the food here is just spectacular.

I wanted to write an update because I had the fortune of visiting a second time at an off-night. This place can cook pasta. The pasta I had was a shrimp-filled ravioli. I am not a fan of shrimp in combination with pasta, but was sold on ordering it because the server recommended it. It was something special. So was that jewish-style artichoke, which was cooked in a way that had made it have the consistency of a succulent fried-smashed potato.

The night-stealer, however, was the zucca (squash) side dish. It was unbelievable and a fantastic ending to my stressful day. My mouth waters as I write about putting forkful after forkful in my mouth - the texture was exquisite from the crusty exterior and chewing into its really soft, flavorful core. This restaurant goes down as one of my al-time favorites; I can't wait for my next go at Locanda.
author: Charlie D.

description: Great cocktails and delicious pastas. Pro tip: you can get half orders of the pastas!
author: Patrick L.

description:
Really liked it here! Arrived late on a Tuesday evening so there was no line.

The tables seemed a smidge too close together and music selection seemed out of sync with the decor... but the food was great! Wasn't a huge fan of the Jewish artichoke, but the lamb was fantastic and so was the mushroom pasta. Portions are not massive..., so maybe not the preferred place to go if you're starving. Quality over quantity :)
author: Doris T.

description:
We went to Locanda last night around 6:30 and got a table immediately, which was amazing and totally unexpected. We sat down and immediately got amazing drinks, the Aperitivo, which is like a lollipop and was hard not to gulp down in one sip. 

Then we got the Jewish artichoke that was crispy light wonderfulness to eat. My husband had a deliciously prepared Halibut with yummy side sauces and I have a special of cannelloni. The proportions of the dishes were all great and they preparation was perfection. We will be back. It's rare to find a place where each thing you order is so delicious!
author: Erin M.

description:
The cocktails are amazing, I had the L'avventura and loved it. The anchovies are light and served with radish on a kind of tostada. The lamb ragu pasta was flavorful and the fresh pasta was perfectly al dente. 
As for why 3 stars? Ordered the rigatoni alla carbonara and it was uncomfortably salty. We had to ask for bread and most importantly we ordered a glass of the Montepulciano and a glass of the Barbaresco $13/$16 each and they were both bitter with little depth... They were such a disappointment especially for the price and the quality of the food. This is a great place for a drink if you can find a seat. I'd give it another chance so theres always hope.
author: Georgina A.

description:
Not perfect, but very solid. Everything was good, but nothing blew me away. That's too bad, given the Delfina pedigree and how innovative and interesting things read on the menu. Somehow the food fell short of what I hoped it would be. The one exception was the rabbit sugo, which was incredible. (That dish alone made me consider moving the meal up from three to four stars.) 

We ordered:  the fried duck egg;  the sugo; the halibut cheek; and the tripe. 

The halibut cheek was nicely cooked, but underseasoned. I get that subtlety is key with a dish that fatty/silky, but this went beyond subtlety into absence. I hadn't tried tripe since childhood. I didn't like it then, but something made me think that I'd like the flavor as an adult. And I probably would have. But the pieces were cut so small that I really could have been eating anything. Tiny bits are probably the best way to get tripe tender and palatable, but when they're this small the flavor gets lost. The duck egg was good, not awesome. Maybe the brown butter egg dish at Cotogna has spoiled me. 

For a place that just opened, Locanda was solid and I was happy to have gone. Still, plenty of room for improvement. Look forward to going back and checking out the mean-looking carbonara.
author: Julio A.

description:
The rabbit fettuccine was the best. Multi-flavors infused with every ingredient in your entree with perfectly cooked hand made pasta, this place was simply divine! Service is great and the ambiance was very pleasant. Highly recommend you guys to try!

Quick tip: they stop seating at 12 am. Otherwise you can be there for drinks!
author: Johanna P.

description: I really enjoyed the ambience, cocktails, wine and food! The bucatini was al dente and the sauce was the perfect amount of spice. Will definitely be back the next chance I get!
author: Lisa W.

description:
Had our first Locanda visit this evening. On our arrival I suddenly remembered that Locanda is run by the Delphina Pizza folks - I was gripped in terror at the thought of music blaring so loudly that you are unable to hear your dining partners speak. I was relieved to note that one we entered the restaurant, the music was at a sensible volume. That changed however, throughout the meal. What is it with restaurants that play music at a sound level solely to keep the staff happy? Anyway, Food was great, though portions a little small. Not terribly Roman in that regard. Service was delightful and the look of the place was pretty cool. I'd recommend Locanda and we will be returning. 

Turn the music down and crank it up when it's clean-up time and your last patrons left the restaurant.

We parked in a garage on Hoff, same block behind the restaurant.
author: peter c.

description:
Haiku ode to Locanda and lamb:

Oh hey, Roman food!
The entire menu was
Mouth-watering good.

We stuck to one meat: 
LAMB. Brains, chops, other organs
All tasted different...

But all delicious!
Mashed potatoes were also
Really interesting.

Don't forget about
The great cocktails and wine list!
Definitely yum.

And now, for dessert...
Fried ricotta, warm dough balls
Yes. Seriously.
author: Hannah L.

description:
This is no Delfina.  Shocking the difference considering the same ownership.  Simple prep, while using high end ingredients, doesn't excuse you from making simple be good.  

This place is really nice, friendly staff, and a terrific date vibe.  But I'm only interested in food so here we go...artichoke app and a grilled ricotta salad were fine, but nothing over the top.  For one of the most popular dishes there, I'd expect more.  4 pasta dishes at the table, and they were average at best.  The pasta was cooked fine, but the sauces were just average.  My lobster spaghetti had the most watered down bland tomato sauce I've had (the lobster was actually undercooked but that didn't matter to me).  Honestly, I make a sauce that blows this out of the water.  Please don't pull some 'you have to appreciate the delicate flavor of lobster' crap on me either, the sauce should speak for itself plain and simple.  Sidekick got a vege mushroom pasta that was OK.  Old person #1 got a clam pasta...funny thing was we just made a clam pasta two days earlier...ours won.  Old person #2 got the carbonara...rich and acceptable, but again...average.

Pricing wasn't bad...$160 for 4 people, 2 apps, 4 mains, 3 drinks, and 1 desert.  Perhaps it's the slew of 20-something start up douche's with money and undeveloped taste buds calling the shots, or looks over substance (omg have restaurants become like dates?), but I've been peeved at the new eateries popping up in this city at this price point.  This falls into line with a Flour + Water, or A16.  If you like them (I hated both), you'll probably love this.  I'll still go with Delfina  who have made a simple spaghetti that would blow your mind...then again, that was a year ago when substance trumped all.
author: A A.

description:
I am rating Locanda above Cotognia, Flour and Water, Bar Bambino, Perbacco and even Delfina.   Maybe it was just a good night for them/us given that we were the very first guests to arrive, seated, and first to place our food order.  Or maybe it was because it was my bday meal, or maybe it was becos I ate like a pigeon all day just for this meal.  

Regardless, every dish I ordered was just a burst of great flavors.   From appertizers to dessert.  The portions are smaller than normal which I guess is not a bad thing because if I wanted to, I could have ordered a few other dishes to sample AND still have room for dessert.   Some of the dishes I ordered may seem adventurous to some but Locanda does it really well that you forget you are eating tongue or parts.  I can't wait to go back to try their other dishes.  

Appetizers:

Fried Sweatbreads with Artichokes
Warm lamb tongue

Pasta:
Veal Saltimbocca
Rabbit Sugo with Fettuccini

Dessert:
Warm Chocolate Cake with Maple Syrup n Curried Walnuts
author: Anna C.

description:
Honestly, I think this is what SF dining is all about.  Great food, wonderful service and an unpretentious atmosphere.  I loved the Jewish style artichoke, the pasta that starts with an F that was stuffed with ricotta and squash blossoms, snap peas and the ricotta fritta for dessert.  

I really have to give a shout-out to the service though.  They were friendly and charming without being overbearing.  Immediately after getting seated, the hostess came up to check if we were happy with our table - when does that ever happen proactively?

Nice work, Delfina people.  I will be back.
author: Julie B.

description:
Not impressed. Heard about this place from several people and reservations were impossible to get, so either my expectations were too high, or this place is just all hype. The salad had no flavor, artichoke in it was tough, and the cocoa lamb was just ok. Got beans per recommendation from the waitress, and got literally what we ordered: boiled beans. Honestly, I just don't get this place. Just a bunch of fancy sounding 
names on the menu.
author: Bubliki T.

description: six of us had an amazing dinner at Locanda last night. A perfect restaurant---Amazing food (The Artichoke was the best and most unusual ever) The service was friendly and professional. All the food was spectacular, perfectly prepared and served in beautiful surroundings! We will all be back.
author: Jim D.

description:
We had a late night dinner; it is great that there are now places where the kitchen stays open until 11 or midnight.
Service was excellent and timely. Food was good but not as good as Delfina.
Fried artichoke     - not bad
Artichoke salad with arugula,avocada and fried ricotta - very good
Lamb Scottadino - the meat was done to perfection but it needed seasoning to make it more exciting. 2 big chops with some escarole underneath. Maybe a bit more vegetable or potatoes for $ 26  ??
snap peas side dish - excellent and tasty
Cheese plate - good and good choices
Crostata - strawberry w. cream   - delicious

And the bread is outstanding, like a warm focaccia with some salt.
Wine choices are also excellent.. We especially like the variety of wines on tap.

It is a small menu though for the food.
author: Maria C.

description:
We went on a Monday and it was packed!
Cauliflower pizza bianca (3 stars; I like cauliflower but the puree sauce was just a bit too much for me), the fried duck egg (5 stars; super rich with a surprising combination of ingredients), the veal casoncelli (4 stars; I thought it was unique but not amazing), bucatini all'amatriciana (5 stars; distinctive and delicious flavor and the texture was just perfect). No dessert here; we went to Bi-Rite (:
author: Lilian W.

description: Authentic and delicious- artichokes, pizza, radiator with lamb ragu, porchetta
author: Frederic C.

description: Nice vibe , yummy pasta. many nice dishes. Only mediocre dish was leg of lamb. and small portion on appetizers. Excellent service
author: Nicholas H.

description:
WOW YUMM!

took my girlfriend here for her bday with two other friends..had to wait a long while for our table because the people ahead of us were lingering (and lingering and lingering and...) - the staff handled the situation very professionally and kept us happy during the wait

the food was amazinnnnggggg! the atmosphere is great - ..fun fun birthday meal / night

hungry like a wolf? head to locanda :-)

thanks!
author: elena o.

description:
we got a reservation here at locanda the day before. we came in on a tuesday night and the place was packed!  our tabled was almost ready so we went to the bar. our table was ready before we could order a drink!

their cocktails sound interesting.  i had the nonna del diavolo and it was yummy.  i liked it

service was friendly and warm

for starters we shared two orders of the jewish artichoke which was delcious.  the leaves are mostly removed and the heart  is deep fried.  splash of lemon.  yum!  we then share two past dishes:  the BUCATINI all'AMATRICIANA - guanciale, tomato, peperoncini, pecorino and also the RADIATORE - lamb ragu, pecorino, mint.  both were delicious.  it was fresh and the flavors were great.  you really have to eat the pastas right when they land on your table.  waiting means they get cold and lose some flavor.

then we shared the whole fish of tai snapper acqua pazza and also oxtails alla VACCINARA. the fish was fried and then served with a sauce of tomatoes, eggplant and olives.  i thought the fish was good.  i loved the oxtail!  so flavorful and tender!

oh i almost forgot to mention their focaccia bread.  came warm and delicious.

we finished with a red wine granita.  YUM

would return definitely!
author: claudia y.

description:
I have never written a yelp review before. I had to write one for Locanda because last night, after years of waiting to go, I was shocked at the poor quality and quantity of the food and have rarely felt so ripped off in my life. 

We ordered 2 pasta dishes, both of which did not share any of the same words in the menu description (written in Italian) yet when they arrived were both exactly the same spaghetti pasta but just with different, very light, sauces. I obviously had been hoping to get a variety of pastas. Also, the portions were tiny for around $15.

For entrees we got the lamb shoulder and the short ribs. The lamb shoulder was actually more like 1/4 of a lamb shoulder, no bone, and spread into 4 tiny pieces on the place with some baby carrots. Flavor was alright but for $26 I felt completely gypped. 
I ordered the short ribs because I absolutely love short ribs - they could be my favorite way to eat beef. I love how they fall of the bone and are so tender. However, what came to our table was KOREAN short ribs. Totally different in every way. Not only did the menu not mention they were korean-style short ribs, but there was also no description, and as Locanda is an ITALIAN restaurant, I could never, ever have expected the short ribs to be korean short ribs. I was really shocked.  Also there was about 3 mouthfuls of meat on the whole $24 plate, and definitely more bone than meat. Honestly, it was ridiculous.

Locanda's really only shining point is their cocktails, which are delicious.

I really hate to write a bad review, and that Locanda made me start a Yelp account, but I felt the need to complain and it was bothering me. I hope Locanda can fix their menu in the quantity department and hopefully be more clear on their menus about what patrons will be eating.
author: Alexandria P.

description: Fantastic service on bubbling Valencia street. During a crazy move, decided to take a break from all the work and try some new food in the neighborhood. I showed up to the restaurant with a suitcase - yeah, somewhat homelessly. The staff said no problem, let me take it off your hands and put it in the back. Great! Our waitress was knowledgable about the wine list and the ingredients - gotta love that. I had the bucatini which was a little under seasoned but a dash of salt and grind of pepper did the trick making the dish delectable. The salad was simple and fresh. It's a fun menu. I really enjoyed the wine on tap, the decor and watching the chef in action since the kitchen is open to the dining room. Heard the cocktails were good so I'll go back to have a taste and another sampling of delicious bites.
author: Kelly C.

description: Love the Jewish style artichokes and the tasty bread here.  In terms of entrees, the rigatoni, grilled fish, and osso bucco were excellent.  Hip setting, but not quite as loud or busy as Delfina. Good service and ambiance if you're into the whole urban, hip scene.  Very close to 16th street BART.
author: Clyde V.

description: I went to Locanda for the 2nd time last Saturday night.  It was my brother's birthday and I thought it would be a great choice since the 1st time we went here, it was great.  Not sure if we hit it on an off night, but it was totally UNDERWHELMING.  It ended up being $140 person (given we ate and drank quite a bit).  The thing that killed me is that the entrees came out piecemeal over the span of 10 minutes!  For that kind of money, they better bring the entrees within a few minutes of each other.  I feel ripped off.  And the food was soooo salty I almost couldn't eat it.  Keep in mind that my brother is a chef and loves his food "seasoned" so I'm accustomed to salty food.  I barely ever write bad Yelp reviews, but I just had to do it this time.  I really hope they see this review and address the issues.  I'd hate to see it go downhill.
author: Meredith B.

description:
One of the best restaurants I've been to in a while. The food is great. The poached egg dish was very good, and the rigatoni was perfectly cooked. I expected the food to be solid, but I wasn't expecting the cocktails to be top-notch. I had the agro uve and it was exemplary. I also recommend the santa rosa smash (fresh plum, bourbon, pinot noir) as it's very interesting and enjoyable.

The ambiance and service were also on-point. I thought the restroom organization (sink and mirror in a common area between the restrooms) was a smart way to keep restroom lines moving.

I will return!
author: Eric R.

description:
Overall, very good place, would highly recommend, except the service was HORRIFIC. 

Tonight, I rolled with 3 of my friends to Delfina's Italian spinoff eager to try this newly open Italian establishment. 

We had a late reservation (9:30), we arrived a bit early at 9:00 on the spot and had to wait, no more than 15 minutes. We were barely greeted by our waiter who was rude, arrogant, and never explained anything to us. Extremely rude and seriously ruined the experience for us. He made it obvious he did not want to serve us and was unhappy to be there and it showed through his service throughout our meal. 

The food on the other hand was excellent. We started off with a Pizza Bianca with figs and prosciutto which were sweet and savory, a very nice twist to a pizza. We also had the infamous (courtesy of yelp) the fried artichoke, which were so good that it tasted like fries! 

Our pastas were rich and tasty. I had the rabbit fettuccine, the others had the veal Saltimbocca and a lamb pasta. All the pastas were handmade, fresh and was overall very good. 

Desserts were also very good, we had the watermelon dish and the chocolate cake. 

I would easily give this a 4 star review, but our horrific waiter was just terrible. Didn't clear our tables promptly, didn't pour our wine, didn't even check on us. Although he did fail to charge corkage for our bottle, which was a win. Just proved his complete incompetence. 

Otherwise, I would return with the hope of getting a different waiter
author: Justin L.

description: Went here with a friend yesterday and sat at the bar. We ate the fried olives, pizza bianca, Jewish artichoke, spring vegetables, carbonara, spaghetti with pepper and cheese and rocky road semifreddo...not to mention a slew of expertly mixed drinks. Everything was delicious! I know this sounds like a lot of food, and it was, but we finished everything happily although a bit wider around the middle. I have to give a particular thank you to Steven the bartender for his gracious hospitality and mouth-watering cocktails. We will be back!!
author: melinda g.

description:
Even though 5:30 is crazy early for dinner it was the only reservation available.  Be warned they don't open until 5:30 so if you are a bit early you may need to duck into Casanova for a drink since you can't hang at the bar.    Lovely atmosphere.  Clean and modern while still being inviting.  The first courses were amazing - yummy, fresh, crisp salad and creamy pasta options.  Our server was friendly and funny and totally steered us in the right direction with recommendations for appetizers.  

Unfortunately, the main courses were a disappointment.  My steak (ordered medium) came well done and I can't even remember what my companion ordered.  
It's definitely worth going, but I'd stick to pasta and first courses.
author: Jordan P.

description:
Non alc drink : 2/5
Duck egg app: 5/5
FETTUCCINE - chicken-prosciutto meatballs, cockscombs: 5/5
CRESCENZA TORTELLI - hedgehog mushrooms, mint, pinenuts: 4/5
BUCATINI all'AMATRICIANA - guanciale, tomato, peperoncini, pecorino: 4/5
author: Cindy L.

description:
