Went to Locanda Friday evening with my significant other for a late dinner. The scene and atmosphere was very busy and modern, yet relaxing and comfortable. Agreeing with previous reviews, it seems a bit premature to review a place after one visit, however we did our best to try as much as possible and experience one or two items in each area of the menu paired with wine from their suggested list. 

The service was above par, which is to be expected for a place this new and under the Stoll name (think Delfina). We enjoyed the various wine on tap, which certainly isn't new, nor exclusive to Locanda, but an increasing trend which I find efficient and accommodating for the different flavors you will experience at a place like Locanda. 

Starting with a delightful poached egg and asparagus dish along with the facoli con cotiche, we followed with their fusilli and veal antipasti dish. All of which were very enjoyable.

For the entree, we shared the steak bavette which, quite frankly, was not the highlight of the meal. Overall a fantastic experience; the food and service were above par, and the atmosphere was very stimulating. I certainly look forward to returning for the antipasti and the wine, perhaps saving the entrée for another restaurant.
author: Andrew B.

description: Love this place!!! Came here for dinner by myself on a packed Friday night and sat at the bar. The bartenders were very nice, and attentive, but not overly so. Their cocktails were some of the best I've ever had, and at $12 a piece for a 'mystery cocktail' -- they were worth every dollar! The early girl tomato salad was phenomenal, and the lamb ragu was good (although I think it could have been a little saucier, and a tad less al dente). Such a good first time here, I will be back for cocktails (try to get one from Alex!) Nice ambiance, and good vibe.
author: Colleen M.

description:
Highlights:
-cute Italian waiter with hipster glasses
-Jewish style fried artichoke--much better and crispier than I imagined
-salad with artichoke and grilled ricotta--to die for!
-good people watching--a real mix
-homemade perfectly cooked al dente whole wheat pasta with spinach, pecorino, and a kick
-warm chocolate cake w/ maple syrup and cream

It was quite a meal but the portions were not enormous so I didn't leave feeling disgusting, rather happily fed.  

Also!  Free temporary tattoos--that is an amazing perk!
author: Julia D.

description: Great restaurant. Whole fish was cooked perfectly. Ambiance is nice. Acoustics are good too. Overall highly recommended.
author: Gavin T.

description: Great place.  Love the bar and the kitchen.  We had tons of stuff and it all was great!!!!
author: Joe M.

description:
I was really ready to love this place as a fan of Delfina.  I liked it, but didn't love it.

First off, the service was exemplar.  Everyone we interacted with was great.

The cocktails were very tasty.  We like our first order enough that we ordered a second time instead of trying new ones.

The food was quite tasty.  The menu seemed to be reaching.  Just a little bit.  But everything was well seasoned and well served.  The portions were smaller than I expected, but the flavor compensated.

The ambiance was pretty to look at, but this is where my experience dropped a star.  The place was loud.  The music was just a little loud but, with the abundance of hard surfaces and nowhere for the sound to escape, everyone in there was talking pretty loudly.  It was hard to hear my girlfriend across the table from me.

I wouldn't rush to go back, but it's a perfectly nice place to eat.
author: Philip F.

description: Locanda was pretty good.  Beautiful interior, great location in the Mission.  Pasta was perfectly al dente.  I had the chocolate torta for dessert which was on point.  You are definitely paying the Mission prices though.  While it's not crazy expensive, but I didn't have any drinks either.  Cute little spot in the Mission.
author: J Y.

description: Fun & lively spot with not your standard Italian food. Many visits and everything has been delicious. Some things that stood out were a plate piled with perfectly charred/pink slender lamb chops and a pappardelle rabbit ragu. Great wine selection, excellent cocktails, knowledgeable staff, celebratory vibe.
author: J. R.

description:
professional, yet friendly service serving food prepared with a sure hand.
The pork jerkey is a fun touch, and I enjoyed the steak which was perfectly cooked and had a almost crust like green peppercorn rub.  
The chocolate custard was also quite nice.
author: Paul S.

description: Excellent pasta, second best in SF to flour + water. While the pasta is great if they happen to have the porchetta, order it. They have an excellent wine list. For pastas the lamb ragu (pecorino and mint) is one of my favorite dishes in SF.
author: Eric W.

description: Really great! Went to SF from NYC for my friend's bday. Found this restaurant online and we loved it! Food was amazing, especially the caico de pepe pasta. And they have Lambrusco, my favorite and so hard to find outside of Italy!! Really happy with the service. The waitress bought us a round due to one of the entrees not meeting my friend's expectations. She was great! Def recommend anyone in the area.
author: Jessica C.

description:
To be fair I have not yet dined here.  But was there last night for a cocktail to check out this eagerly anticipated room.  It's beautiful and hip, but comfy and welcoming at the same time.  I can report at least that my cocktail was outstanding!

Really can't wait to go back for dinner - I have no doubt it will be stellar given the owners' pedigree with Delfina.
author: John G.

description: I don't write many reviews, but we had a fantastic dinner at Locanda.  It was our third time eating at the restaurant, but what really stood out on our most recent visit was our server Sarah.  Sarah was extremely knowledgable about the food and drink menu, and went out of her way to accommodate my wife's dietary restrictions.  Truly appreciated!
author: Robert O.

description:
Overall, I loved my experience at Locanda last night.  The atmosphere is definitely trendy and it seems to be a new 'hot spot' as it was packed and had a hip vibe to it.  We went with a group of three and tried a bit of everything.  Started with two signature cocktails while we waited for our table, the Apertivo (Campari, Orange, Lemon and Prosecco) and the Santa Rosa Smash (Plum, Bourbon and Pinot Noir).  They were both delicious, unique, and generous pours.  

For appetizers- we had the flatbread pizza with crushed fava beans, arugula and cucumber.  It was so delicious this morning I am still thinking about it.  We also shared two salads (Ricotta arugula and little gem).  Both were perfectly dressed with a good balance of flavor.  Oh another thing- the bread they bring for the table is amazing!  Can't forget that.  

The only reasons I am giving Locanda 4 stars are: 1.)They ran out of the artichokes for appetizers.  We had a 7:30 reservation so it was pretty early to be out, and 2.) I didn't love my entree and my girlfriend didn't love hers either.  I had the Sepia which is basically a skewer of grilled, breaded calamari, and she had the steak.  The Sepia was pretty dry and tough.  The steak was not her favorite, she didn't like the texture or the seasoning.   

We did end with two deserts, the donuts and the chocolate cake both which I thought were very good, although I was stuffed at this point.

Overall- lovely food, atmosphere, cocktails, and an amazing wine list.  I will definitely be back, at least to try the artichokes which everyone raves about and to have more of that flatbread pizza:)
author: Anne E.

description: The food was drenched in oil not a special taste with incredible small dishes. One dish came wrong and another didnt come. And the wrong dish took 15 minutes to be redone. This is a joke.
author: Berkin O.

description:
Did I just eat a bit of heaven? Is this what heaven is suppose to taste like?? If heaven is carbohydrates, then sign me up!

I've been wanting to check this place out for a few months but never had the time to getting around to it. I had a few friends coming into town so I suggested that we do. So all 11 of us had dinner at 10pm. They do things very italian here, dinner reservations can be made at 5:30, 10, 10:30, 11 or 11:30 I believe. Perfect in my book since I'm most hungry at bedtime.

I forgot what I had but it was the spaghetti dish. There was sausage in it as well which I tend to not love. The dish comes and immediately I notice that the noodles look like they are made fresh at the restaurant (not sure if they are but I'll keep telling myself that). I finally get around to tasting the food after it cools a little and BAM - yup I was in carbohydrate heaven! I tried a few of my friends dishes as well and theres was REALLY good too.

Only downfall, its NOT ENOUGH! I wanted to order another one just cuz I'm a pig, but for normal people this should do the trick of filling you up (I just wanted to be stuffed with heaven). I also had the fernet drink which was really really good and highly recommended. Our waitress was very cool and very attentive. I did feel as if I were back in Italy with friends out in a piazza, but they did a good job of making the ambiance good. 

After about 11ish the place died down on a Friday night so it seems that you shouldn't have to worry too much with reservations if getting a "late night" eat. I will definitely be coming back to taste more on the menu. Vegetarians should find a good amount of food as well to eat.
author: Robert E.

description: Very good restaurant in the Mission. Their menu changes daily which keeps it interesting. It is a lively restaurant which fits well in this part of the city. The quieter tables are in the back by the open kitchen which is quite nice!
author: Suzanne C.

description:
The mushroom tortelli filled with cheese (pecorino?) was why I need to go back. Amazing flavor. 

Tomato soup was OK and the shredded artichoke salad was really good. 

Service was noticeably good.
author: Ojus P.

description: This place is awesome! We started with cocktails and they were delicious and inventive and that set the tone for the rest of the night! I had the Church cocktail and I loved it. It was tart and sweet and tasted super fresh. My boyfriend had the old fashioned flight and it was awesome. We split the pizza bianca (basically homemade focaccia), the fried olives and the artichoke and all three were super good. My boyfriend and I shared the orecchiette and the lambshank and they were both really good. The orecchiette was rich with sausage and the pasta was a little thicker and had a similar texture to gnocchi and the lambshank was super tender and served in a rich gravy with escarole. My brother and his partner shared the orecchiette and the pork saltimbocca. The pork was pounded really thin and layered with sage and prosciutto and then a lemon sauce was poured over it. I didn't love the lemony-ness of the pork but my brother enjoyed it. Altogether this was a fabulous meal with great service! I loved the feel and decor of the restaurant as well. Make reservations earlier than later!
author: Tamra G.

description:
Here's a quicky: our group of six had a great dinner at Locanda the other night. Food was excellent, they took good care of us, drinks were well-made. 

I'm prompted to write the review because of one, strangely aweful, desert. On the menu is a thing called: NEGRONI GRANITA - orange panna, buddha's hand. We tried it, curious. But what came was a very odd, rosewater-ish ice mixed in with heavy cream. It tasted like soapy perfume. My wife described it as licking the cheap perfume off your great grandmother's neck. 

We appreciate creativity, but recommend steering clear of this one dish. 

Otherwise -- great experience!
author: Abe L.

description:
Came here tonight with a friend and it definitely lived up to the hype!

We started with the oxtails alla vaccinara - delish! I wasn't sure about this but it really was tasty! The meat just slid of the bone...we then had the jewish style artichoke and it was really great as well. As a side note it was quite pretty to look at!

We then shared the cuscini - BY FAR THE WINNER! and we also shared the veal casoncelli - also amazing! There was just something super tasty and special about the cuscini...the spicy finish, the shrimp was super tender and amazing this!

We finished up with ricotta fritta & warm chocolate cake. Both were amazing but I think the ricotta was my favorite of the two! It tasted like a mini warm donut with lemon merengue....HOLY MOLY. I can taste it right now! The chocolate cake was amazing, as I said and it had a really different taste - the server told us it had some sort of vinegar syrup which was really interesting. Totally glad we tried it - yum!

I'll also mention the bread they give you with dinner is really good! It's quite simple, a little olive oil and salt...but tastes extremely good. I also like the special touch of the water jug on the table that says locanda...

The service was excellent and I loved that they have valet outside!
Can't wait to go back!
author: Isabel M. L.

description: I love every single appetizer on the menu here. They also have a bottle of the 23-year old Pappy Van Winkle!
author: Hanah K.

description: First off, I'd been here before and on Valentine's day of all days without a reservation I didn't expect to get a table, but somehow thanks to a fabulous hostess Lisa we did (no wait I might add)! Top notch service they are very attentive to your every need. The crab pasta dish was a wee bit light on crab, but very tasty. The steak dish was thick and juicy and perfectly cooked.
author: Olin W.

description: I stopped at Locanda with a friend for a drink and bar snack.  I had the "Church" cocktail and we shared the Pizza Bianca and Fried Castelvetrano Olives.  Everything was very delicious. The olives were amazing and the portion was satisfying.  The bartender was very friendly.  We were there on a Monday afternoon (about 6:00pm) and the bar area was relatively crowded. We managed to find the last two open seats at the bar.
author: Nadia K.

description:
I don't think this place lives up to the hype.  In particular the service is quite poor.  Two dishes we ordered had different ingredients than what were listed on the menu.  When we tried to order additional glasses of wine, we had to ask three time and were half way through our entrees before they arrived.
The food itself is good but no better than at Bar Bambino or Beretta. And the prices are a bit higher.   I will give them props on the wine by the glass selection including some very nice choices on tap.
author: Peter H.

description: Great drinks & food, especially the bread, Bronzino, and fried olives. Went with groups of 8-10 twice recently.
author: Jason T.

description: I was first time at that restaurant which was recommended to me by lots of friends. We were seated on time! Drinks were very good! Food great, and service too. I didn't like the surraunding area filled with homless people. And it's hard to find parking.
author: Elena M.

description:
Get:
Jewish Style Artichoke
Trippa w/ Tomato, Mint, Pecorino
Fettuccini w/ Rabbit Sugo, Dandelion Greens, Verjus (Could live on this)

Tip: Pour all your money into apps, mids, and pasta. Though the entrees are great, they are simple. The kitchen shows best on smaller plates... oh, and booze, great ice.
author: Jordan Reis C.

description: Horrible service - would never return.  Started with making me wait an hour after my reservation time and they didn't even care.  Better options.  Go elsewhere.
author: Nick M.

description:
Anyplace that can successfully combine good food and a music mix featuring David Bowie, the Cure. And some fun 80's pop is ok in my book. The ambiance is busy and energetic without being frantic. The floor was thankfully laid out to give ample enough space around the tables. 

The food was great. We went veggie and were happily surprised with the care given to the vegetables. We had a Jerusalem style artichoke. Not a Jerusalem artichoke, or a sun choke. An artichoke cooked in the style of the Roman Jewish quarter. It was delicious. This was one of those dishes that made me think of the sun choke and feel like I understood how a potato looking thing was named after an artichoke. We had a lovely pasta with squash blossoms that let the blossoms shine AND accented the shape/sauce relationship. Dessert was a fantastically melty chocolate cake. 

Great experience all around. 

Note: if you sit at the bar, don't grab at all the glass bottles laid out in front of you. They may look like an array of vinegars and oils, but they're actually liqueurs that the bartenders use in their cocktails.
author: Jay V.

description:
4.5 stars. 

Stopped by here last week for a pre dinner drink. Well, lucky us, we ended up with a table and a drink, right away!

We started with the two artichoke dishes. Both were very good! I'd still like to try a few other appetizers! 

We then all ordered our main course (all ordered pasta) and a couple side dishes (carrots- very good and snow peas- tasty). 

Gary and I had the veal stuffed triangle pasta and it was delicious. I could have eaten two plate-fulls of the pasta- so good!

We enjoyed the meal with a bottle of while that the amazing sommelier recommended and it was quite good!

We then finished off with the warm chocolate cake, which was divine. As a savory guy, I never expect dessert to be the highlight of the meal, but it was. Wow, was it good!

All in all, a great experience with terrific service, fabulous drinks, fun atmosphere and decor, and good food. Look forward to trying more dishes next time!
author: Art A.

description: My favorite Italian restaurant in the city, maybe even the US. I lived in Italy for a while and Locanda is one of the few restaurants which I feel truly replicate authentic Italian food. If you're wondering what to order I say be brave and order what you don't normally see in menus from other restaurants. My personal is bucatini all'amatriciana. A simple dish yet so hard to cook right. Locanda does it perfectly with the right amount of sauce and by cooking with guanciale vs. any other cured meat.
author: Johel D.

description: Very nice decor.  Other than good presentation the meals were unremarkable.   Some servers were pleasant, but our waitress seemed to be having a bad night.  Someone delivered a drink to our table.  I thought it was a "comp" for our bad experience, but the waitress removed the drink (after I took a sip!)  explaining that it was delivered in error.  We got a chuckle out of it.  Maybe just an off night
author: Ray V.

description:
FOOD and DRINKS:
We started off with drinks that were masterfully crafted by their female bartender of the night.  Nothing on their cocktail really popped out to us so we left our fate in the hands of the bartender and she created some DE-LICIOUS cocktails, so good that we had to order another round.

Then our food started coming out, our first course was their fish crudo special and the Jerusalem artichoke...absolutely to die for.  Just magnificent!!!!

Next was our entree and we both chose two different pasta dishes: Radiatorre with Lamb Ragu and another pasta with a squash blossom sauce.  Hands down the Radiatorre was just delectable and the other pasta with squash blossoms was good but I think they put a little too much tumeric in the mix.  I love Tumeric and use it all the time in my cooking but the flavor of the tumeric overpowered the dish.

Finally we had our dessert:  Ricottta Fritta  absolutely delicious and it was not heavy at all.  Very light tasting.

SERVICE:
The reason why I am giving Locanda 4 stars is because the service was definitely not up to par.  Our server would be looking away when we were talking to her and would rarely look us in the eye.  It was very weird.  We, my boyfriend and I, were super excited to have a date night together and super duper excited to have reservations at Locanda and our server was just so blah and a little pretentious.  And to top it off she rushed to give us our check.  I know it's a busy Friday night but it's never a good look to swiftly give someone their check as if to say, "All right you're done, now get out of here."

Since the food is so good we will definitely be back and I will be on the look out for that server and definitely request to not be served by that person again.
author: Salomeh G.

description: The food is decent but way overpriced, especially for the small portions.
author: Brittany L.

description: great place. good food. bar is fun
author: Lori S.

description: You need to get to Locanda now! Smoked mashed potatoes with peppercorn butter!!!!! Hello....... Mind blowing! The cocktails are always amazing, Service is great and the ever changing menu makes things exciting. My wife and I come here often and have a couple staple items. We always look forward to see whats is new and what is gone from the menu. So Locanda keep up the great work!
author: Ray C.

description: For the curious about Roman style food, who don't feel for a somewhat long flight, this is the spot. I was truly delighted by the authenticity of the food, given the fact I lived in Rome for several years. Don't expect large portions, but do expect amazing food. My recommendations: Jewish-style artichokes, Tonnarelli cacio e pepe, lamb-chop scottadito. A fine selection of Italian wines is just the frosting on the cake.
author: Steve E.

description: Stolen credit card number! As are waiter smiled and served us someone took down our numbers and ordered thing from air italia and other things in italy that evening. There was no possible way it happened anywhere else and as I explained to there manager someone stole from me and they seemed to careless. The food is sub par and if i have any say this place will fall off the map sooner than later! adios laconda
author: Urs F.

description: I took my GF to Locanda for her birthday. It was loud, the wait staff were miserable, the food was forgettable, except for the jewish artichoke appetizer, which was like eating a combination of leaves and fish bones. Oh yeah, it was also super expensive. This place is totally overrated. Luckily, there are so many other great restaurants in the neighborhood.
author: Kelly C.

description: OMG the burrata with lobster! FYI, there's $12 valet parking right in front.
author: Marina N.

description:
New Italian place in the Mission by the people of Delfina.  I figure, surely those people know how to do Italian food.

I guess the menu changes frequently so a pasta dish that a friend was ranting and raving about wasn't available the night I went.  We had the bucatini and rigatoni which were both good, but not great.  Pasta is al dente, but flavors are not robust and portions are fairly small.  It's not like I'm trying to carb load before a marathon, but I ate my entire bowl of pasta and was still hungry, which is very unusual.

Drinks are very good- smoke n spice is wonderful and bartender's choice is interesting- you pick a liquor and they'll think up the rest.

Maybe a good place to come with lots of people so you can sample more dishes and hopefully some of them will be spectacular, but mostly just average this time around.
author: Maxine S.

description:
Great meal, highly recommend the Jewish Artichoke starter. And the Spaghetti with fava beans was amazing. Doesn't sound special, but the flavors were to die for. Boyfriend was super excited for the rigatoni bolognase, it was good, but we both agreed the spaghetti was great. The foccacia bread was really good too, just olive oil and salt on it, yummy. 

We got the best table I think, right by the open kitchen where you can see the action. Servers were all very young, attentive and friendly. Good wine and cocktail selection. It is quite loud in there, place was packed at 6pm, but it was a fun, energetic noise. 

Overall all a fun twist on traditional Italian. Oh- check out Monks Kitchen nearby before or after dinner for a great beer selection.
author: C M.

description:
FIVE STARS

Had dinner here on Thursday evening after serendiptiously running into a colleague who had to give up his reservation for three.  When we had come in to have a drink at the bar.  Got sat in the corner 3-top and thus began a very enjoyable dining experience.  We each had a drink, which we all enjoyed.

We started with the two artichoke dishes.  The first was the "Jewish Artichoke" (still haven't figured the naming out on that one), which is a small artichoke that turned into a blossom by repeatedly dipping it into searing oil oil.  I think they topped it off with a little sea salt and we could add fresh lemon.  Wow, it was truly amazing.  The second was the artichoke carpacio, which was thinly shaved and served with some similarly thinly shaved cheese and greens.  All three of us loved it.

After finishing the drinks, the sommelier suggested a nice, inexpensive ($38) bottle of Italian white wine (can't recall the name).  This was after giving us a taste of a white we had picked up by the glass but didn't like.  He asked us what we liked and thought we might enjoy and then made his suggestion.  Good call on his part.

I had the carbonara and thought it was excellent: light yet flavorful, with thing strips of bacon about an inch long.  My dining companions (Art and Gary) both had the veal-stuffed pasta triangles.  Yum, yum, yum.  The sauce seemed to be a light butter and parmesan type sauce.  We all splits to vegetable sides: snow peas and carrots, which were panned seared with some herbs, salt and pepper, and served al dente.  Quite good.

We finished with the warm chocolate cake, which was out of this world.  

Service was excellent.  Atmosphere was inviting and decor beautiful.  It was a bit loud when we sat down but as soon as I asked our server to turn down the speaker that was directly overhead and pointed at our table, he turned it down and it was fine.
author: Kevin M.

description: Staff is friendly and the drinks are amazing. Only had apps but the fried olives are a must.  Will definitely return
author: Anthony D.

description:
Summary - Locanda serves up solid Italian food in a cutting-edge energized setting. We found the meat dishes stronger than the pasta. The appetizers are excellent but the prices are higher than expected.

Picks:
SMOKE & SPICE ($10) Gin, Antica, a float of Islay, served on Rock with Citrus Peel was a beautiful looking and potent cocktail.

JEWISH STYLE ARTICHOKE ($6/ea.) Was excellent. A deep fried one battered crispy thing of goodness.

FRIED MURDOCK'S DUCK EGG - guanciale, dandelion ($11) is their tribute to the soft cooked egg. This egg had a nice soft runny center.

PIZZA BIANCA- w/ Fra Mani Mortadella ($7)  focaccia-like Roman-style flatbread and not really a pizza as most people know what, had some very crunchy bread along with high-quality mortadella. This is more of a mini sandwich.
Frankly they give you this type of flat bread for free, so you really don't need to order this dish.

Deep fried lamb brains and artichokes ($12) was more deep fried goodness. We worried about getting mad cow disease, but what the heck. The brains taste just like sweetbreads.

Radiatore "Pecora E Pecorino" lamb ragu, pecorino, mint  ($17) was a very good circular pasta with balanced flavors. The mint was not overpowering thankfully.

GUINEA HEN LEG al SPIEDO ($21) was roasted on the rotisserie and very tender. Portion size was on the small side though.

BAVETTE STEAK - radicchio trevisano ($25) was cooked to our desired level of doneness and a tender tasty, well portioned piece of meat.

Lamb Scottaditto anchovy & coriander ($26) were 2 excellent lamb chops, but way too tiny! We could have used to more at this price. The waiter did a good job explaining how the name came from burnt fingers.

Snap peas ($8) with mint, spring onion was fresh, crisp, and delectable.

Erbette ($8) chard with garum, pine nuts was overly lemony, but that was okay with us. They need to tone this down.

OK: (Order if you like this dish)
Mojito ($10) was excellent and well balanced, but filled with so much crushed ice that we should have sent it back!

TONNARELLI CACIO e PEPE - pecorino, black pepper, basta ($14) was a peppery pasta which was just too cheesy.

Bucatini All'amatriciana guanciale, tomato, pepperoncini, pecorino ($17) was okay, also pretty peppery, with a sour tomato sauce that tilted the dishes' balance.
author: Ellen H.

description: There are many great things about Locanda: the cocktail selection (wonderful), the service (attentive/friendly) and the decor. Also our appetizer was stellar. However the leg of lamb was good but not stellar, the dessert was just okay, and I just did not think the value was great. If I am going to spend so much money on my dinner, it should be more impressive.
author: Christy D.

description:
Last week my boyfriend, a chef at Wayfare Tavern, and I got dinner as a date night at Locanda. We had made a 9:30 reservation and the place was still pretty busy for a weekday. I was shocked to see it was literally next door to Bar Tartine and I asked the GM who told me the two restaurants have a totally friendly relationship. Nice to hear :) 

We we're looking to drink so we stuck with water which was just fine. We decided to split the Lamb's Tongue appetizer even though I usually dislike tongue I knew my boyfriend wanted to try it. Best Tongue I ever had!I had heard about the Halibut collar but they were out of the special . I was so disappointed it took me a while to choose my entree since I was already set on having fish. I ordered the pasta with squash blossoms and ricotta, and my boyfriend had a fettucini with rabbit sugo. Both pastas with delicious, light, and flavorful. Mine was lemony without being acidic. I was impressed. 

To our benefit, the back of house was confused and sent out my pasta as an appetizer. We sent it back and they were so apologetic and nice about the mixup. They sent us two drinks that were like an italian soda meets a mojito as well as a side of snap peas that were fresh and tasty but too buttery for me. Overall the front of house did a great job making us feel welcome and we enjoyed this experience. I will be back soon!
author: Pilar P.

description: Locanda is my favorite go-to spot in the Mission. Whenever I think "I'd like a good cocktail, plus a little something to eat...", I go here. It's always a good idea! I love the ambiance, the food, the drinks--everything! In particular, I recommend the fried olives to start, affogato for dessert, and any of the cocktails. Be it date night, drinks with friends, dinner with a coworker, this is a great spot for any occasion. It does get crowded, so I recommend reservations for dinner, but if you're just going for a drink and an app/dessert you can usually find a spot at the bar.
author: Erin H.

description: Everything was executed perfectly, but nothing was great. Nothing stood out or was memerable. The portions were ridiculously small for the price. Service had too much attitude for my taste as well.
author: A J.

description:
Second visit last night.....felt like we were going for the senior special since our reservation was for 5:30pm! But it was packed right away so we were not alone. Had the Jewish artichoke again because it is fabulous and I think it was even better this time. The outside leaves nice and crunchy and the heart creamy. I had the carbonara and I have to say that I think Sgt. Pepper was cooking it because it was way over peppered. A little pepper in this is excellent but when it is the predominant flavor I don't think it is the best way to go. That being said I ate it all but did comment on it to our waitperson who was very sweet.

Love the bread - enjoyed the wine and left with a smile on my face. Even if we have to eat at an early hour I like to think it gives me time to "digest".
author: holly B.

description:
awesome food. Awesome drinks. Beautiful restaurant.
A great mix of Italian ideas and Californian implementation, and I mean that in a positive way.

The only thing we didn't like was the nocino - cool that they make their own but I think they didn't read the recipe properly (just missing 1 lbs of sugar per liter of alcohol).

Anyway, highly recommend it.
author: Fred A.

description:
Finally went to Locanda this past Saturday after waiting for months to get a reservation.  One word:  DISAPPOINTED!  It truly does not live up to all the hype.  My reservation was at 8:30pm but we didn't get seated until 9:15pm.  I wonder if the restaurant knows the definition of reservation???  

The service was ok but food was extremely mediocre.  The cauliflower pizza was good but the short ribs were are huge miss.  It was dry and salty, completely unappetizing.  Even though the appetizers were disappointing, I was hoping the entrees would redeem the place somehow but that didn't happened.  I had the LAMB SCOTTADITO and if you want your meat to have the texture of chewing gum, then this is the right dish to order.  I'm sure everyone has had their share of low quality meat where the more you chew the harder the meat gets.  My friends had pasta:  CUSCINI - ravioli w/ burrata & shrimp which was decent but have you breath freshener ready, you'll need it.  As for the CRESCENZA  TORTELLI, all I tasted was dough and a hint of mint but didn't get any pine nuts or a taste of mushroom.  

Word of advise, enter the restaurant with no expectation and a very small appetite.
author: Jules T.

description:
My new favorite restaurant in SF!

We started with the Jewish style artichoke and green tomato soup. I had an amazing pasta dish and my BF had the lamb. Sides were the chili corn and peas and shoots dish. We dine out ALL the time and love trying new restaurants. This is at the top of our list! We had a great little table right next to the kitchen and loved seeing all the action.

Can't wait to go back!
author: Stephanie Q.

description:
Great new addition to the Mission! And finaaaally, somewhere that doesn't have the hipster ( i don't care but i do just not about you) tude :-) 


FOOD;Overall I think the dishes were good but very heavy and almost overly rich.  Needs more flavor overall i would say.
Service; FIVE STARS- no attitude very knowledgeable and attentive.
SPACE; The space itself is very cool and funky, a hipsters house after 30 and they've made some money :-) 
SCENE; This is a great scene for a date or group of friends!

While I am a vegetarian and can only review first hand those dishes I will also speak on my meat eating friends behalf...

If you don't eat meat, there won't be a ton for you but just enough..

Asparagus and Duck egg, Delish!
12 or 15 green Salad- just ok
Pea Shoot app- yummy
Pasta- was disappointing- a little tough to be honest, not "fresh" tasting

Beef tendon- table loved, said it was very flavorful
Shrimp- table loved

I will go back and try again for sure...
author: Heather S.

description:
Based on prior reviews, it seems important to order the right items. 

We had an excellent experience.  

Here's how you can do the same:

Cocktails: old fashion tasting flight  5/5

Buratta/grilled focaccia  5/5

Bucatini  4/5

Tortellini /w mushrooms  5+/5

Halibut collar  5+/5

Pinot by the glass 5/5

Service was top notch
author: Patrick S.

description:
Ok, I'll get straight to the point...delicious, delicious, delicious.
Jewish style artichoke  - light, crispy, salty deep fried goodness with thinly sliced mint leaves that added a bright after taste.
Sweet Bread and artichoke qvinto qvarto -  lightly breaded and seasoned to subtle perfection. The fried capers were a nice touch.
Rabbit Sugo fettuccini - heaven on a plate, the pasta was perfectly cooked, the sauce was light, but rich at the same time. Just melted in your mouth good.
Lamb ragu - also very delicious, but the rabbit sugo really stole the show. Was a very good play on a meat marinara.
Chocolate cake - fluffy and moist, perfectly paired with fresh whip cream drizzle with honey and candied walnuts...my oh my!
Great service, too!

Only downside is getting a table. We, a party of 2, took a chance on walking in on a Monday night b/c the only reservations available were 5:30 or 10pm. They have one communal table with 10 seats and its pretty cozy. We were the first to be seated at 6:15pm, but there was a line for the communal table by 7. So, if you want a private table in the dining room, reserve a few days ahead. 

Definitely going back to try the Ox tail and Barlotti beans!
author: Kiri I.

description: We had the arugula artichoke salad which was delicious! To start we also had the shrimp which was also delicious. The entrees were also very good (steak, crab pasta, and lamb chops). The staff was very helpful in choosing a great wine for dinner. It took over around an hour to receive out entrees which was my only complaint. I would have given 3.5 stars due to the lengthy wait time.
author: Gabriela H.

description:
fun and lively.  come early for a drink and get lucky (or be very patient) with bar seats.  

'the church' with gin is my favorite drink!
author: Josie M.

description: Besides the artichoke and fish I can't recall what we ate. Everything was good but nothing was outstanding.  It is a very pretty place and has a cool semi unisex bathroom.  I just remember thinking it was awfully loud and my seat was not comfortable.  I'm such a nitpicker though, service was really lovely and overall I would go back again.
author: Poppy C.

description: Food portions were very small,for the price but its Valencia st. Service was ok nothing memorable the server was very nice but didnt suggest anything I asked about a dish and she didn't seem to know..it's a great place for drinks...will be back though...
author: Emeritus C.

description:
This place is pretentious and lame,  The food isn't terrible, but you can find better Italian at half the price in a more comfortable setting at more than one place within a few blocks walk from here (check out La Traviata on Mission, for instance.)  

Bonus douchery:  Their valets let cars sit parked blocking the bike lane for half a block down.  Seriously, guys?  That's just adding insult to injury.
author: Tod G.

description:
Drinks: so good.

Food: get the oxtail dish if possible.

Everything I expected, loved it so much. Lighting and ambience are also pleasant.
author: Christina V.

description: I had heard that this place was known for its drinks.  It definitely delivered.  I ordered the "Church" drink which was awesome!  I love everything about that drink...the presentation, the taste, etc.  I only went for drinks, but one of my friends ordered the deep fried olives.  Now I HATE olive with a passion.  This is probably the only thing that I refuse to eat.  I ate it and did not know it was an olive until I asked my friend and tried it again.  Either a) this dish is awesome or 2) it just goes to prove that everything deep fried is delicious!  Since my friend ordered that appetizer we received bread to go along with it and O.M.G....was that bread delicious.  It was soft and buttery but not too buttery.  It was perfect.  I ordered another plate of bread because why not?  I definitely want to go back and have dinner and try the food.
author: Vagabond V.

description: The Jewish-style artichokes were phenomenal. And the bread was excellent too.  My main dish (Tonnarelli Cacio E Pepe) was solid, though not amazing.
author: Rajiv B.

description: Service was great.  Meat plate was great.  I like the decor and would come back again.  Bartender was annoying and the tiny drinks need work.  Stick with Wine or Beer and you should be fine.
author: Doreen D.

description:
My wife and I had an early dinner last Wednesday at the new hotspot, Locanda on Valencia in the Mission.  Got there when it opened (5:30 pm) and could sense the recent buzz from the sight of anxious diners outside cozying up next to the recent addition of valet parking service (street parking really easy at that time during the week, though).  

We were immediately seated at a two-top next to another two-top already in progress.  My only complaint about the entire experience that evening was this initial seating arrangement.  My wife and I have no problem showing up at a restaurant w/o reservations hoping for any seats available, but we made reservations and it was borderline hilarious how close the two small tables were from each other.  Literally there was about a two-inch separation.  To me, this is far more awkward than sitting at a communal table knowing that side-to-side banter is occasionally expected/welcomed.  It was more confusing when noticing that this arrangement didn't seem all that necessary considering the layout of the front room.  There seemed to be more than enough space to actually make these two-tops separate dining adventures.

Restaurants have a tendency to employ this table technique when space is limited or poorly-laid out.  This is not the case at Locanda.  The interior is beautiful, with a spacious and gorgeous bar that slightly juts out the further you venture back, giving way to the open kitchen and constellation-like chandeliers that adorn the back dining area.  You can tell that a considerable amount of thought was put into the design and layout, and the results are impressive, even the setup of the two bathrooms divided by a shared, sleek wash area.  

My wife and I quickly changed seats and moved to the bar (which remained accessible at the beginning of service) to have our meal.  Our bartender was very welcoming and willing to dispense his thorough knowledge of the menu and how ingredients were sourced, all with a thick English accent.  I ordered the Smoke and Spice, a delicious blend of gin, antica carpano, and scotch.  Tried to recreate it at home without as much luck.  Maybe it had something to do with the enormous ice cube that made Locanda's version so much better.  Probably not, but the ice is a nice touch, nonetheless.

Started with carciofi crudi, which was a medley of grilled ricotta, thin slices of avocado and artichoke, and arugula.  This was a pleasing combination and the greens were nicely dressed.  The "grill" aspect of the ricotta was lost on me but didn't affect the overall success of the dish.  We also ordered warm lamb's tongue, which was my favorite.  The lamb was delicately sliced and strewn across braised turnips and mystery greens.  I love going to restaurants and trying ingredients that I don't have often, never had before or never liked very much before being introduced to a delicious way of preparation.  The tongue was divine and the turnips...wow...I've never liked them before but here, they were soft, warm, and melted in your mouth.

Finished with the VEAL CASONCELLI alla SALTIMBOCCA, guinea hen leg with pancetta and blue lake beans with anchovies.  The veal pasta was rich yet absolutely fantastic.  I don't go for veal but this is definitely worth an exception.  The guniea hen was moist and savory and accompanied by lentils and dandelion greens that were a bit bitter, but, then again, I've never had less-bitter dandelion greens.  Beans with anchovies were a hit, as the anchovies were pureed into a coating for the fresh green beans and instantly made me want to recreate the dish at home.

Good Pinot Noir on tap (could have been slightly cooler), attentive service, lively atmosphere (place got crowded quick), artful interior and inventive food.  $130 for two with four drinks (including tip).  Not a place I can afford everyday, but we'll definitely be back as soon as we can.  Nice job.
author: Jason H.

description:
I would give this place ten stars if I could. My uncle gave me a gift card to this place for my birthday. Well it was a gift card for this or one of the other restaurants in the Defina restaurant group (Delfina Pizzeria and Delfina) both of which I have been to and adore, but he told me that I HAD to go to this restaurant. He was oh so very correct. We started out with Jewish Style Artichoke and the Dungeness Crab and Sorrel Soup with chili and croutons. While I was waiting I had a fresh ginger-ale. It was absolutely delicious, fresh, gingery, with ginger pulp in it, and some lime. It was garnished with a slice of lime and a cube of candied ginger on a toothpick. That drink set the stage for a FABULOUS meal. 
We told the waitress that we were splitting the appetizers and she brought us the soup in two bowls which was so sweet and thoughtful. The artichoke was amaaazing. My boyfriend had never had artichoke before and he LOVED it! Definitely inspired me to make some at home for him :) The soup was divine. You could really taste the chilies and the crab was so yummy. We practically licked the bowls clean. 
My boyfriend ordered the linguini with clams and I ordered the mixed grill. His linguini was good, but we both thought it lacked body. We wanted more of a sauce or something with it. He said it was really light and refreshing though. 
My mixed grill consisted of quail, spareribs, lamb loin chops, and sweetbread, with asparagus. It was absolutely delicious. The meats with the sauce it came with were so wonderful, but it was really, really rich and I had to split it with my boyfriend who didn't mind at all.  
We had the ricotta fritta and the budino and we split them. Both were SO delicious. 
We will definitely be returning!
author: Brigid M.

description: amazing food, fabulous service. Get the fried, cheese stuffed olives and the pancetta wrapped rabbit.
author: Lizzie S.

description:
The Food & Drinks here were obviously well thought out, meticulously prepared, and presented quite well. The server was knowledgeable about the food and the wine.
The meal starts with bread fresh from an oven that is right above the server station. Delicious buttered rustic italian breads. We ordered the Pizza Bianca with bone marrow, which our server was quick to let us know wasn't you're average slice of pie. 
It was perfectly seasoned flat bread along side a couple pieces of roasted bones, split in half with a very nice radish and parsley salad. A great first bite. The Tripe,  braised and as tender as can be was served in a red sauce (reminiscent of most people's grandma's cooking). A perfect vehicle with the never- ending bread that showed up at our table. Raw Artichoke Salad with peppery baby arugula, and smoked Ricotta Salata. The rich avocado was the perfect compliment to the arugula and crispy raw artichoke slices. The dressing was faint, i believe just a nice extra virgin olive oil and a touch of white wine vinegar. It definitely let the ingredients shine. 
Rich Oxtails were braised in red wine and then glazed with the reduced liquid. It was all i could do not to suck on the bones to get every last bit of meat off. The Rabbit Saddle was boneless and wrapped in it's own belly (rabbit bacon). It had a cured meat flavor, but was really good as was the  polenta gnocchi served alongside. The pasta(Bucantini) was perfectly cooked and the sauce with the cured pork cheeks and more tomato was exactly what  Amatriciana is all about. Ricotta Fritters were really nice with the honey, but my favorite dessert was the red wine granita with black  pepper panna. Tart granita layered with lightly whipped cream and a couple of sugar cookies was the perfect light dessert to aid in digestion. 
 The service might be slow for some. We sat Down at 6:15, had 3 first courses one after the other, and then all the entrees came out at once. By the time the dessert came out and our check was paid, it was about 8 pm. But come on, It's dinner. If you're in a hurry, let your server know. Otherwise, sit back, enjoy the company and a nice night out.
author: William B.

description: Strolled in this place not knowing what to expect. The white bass Pizza Bianca was just ok (would skip next time). If you want a light, no meat dish, the black mushroom Tortelli was delicious (even if it was a non-meat dish). The Veal Casoncelli was good, but a much heavier dish. Halibut collar is a must get! For dessert: Almond Cake all the way. Warm Chocolate Cake was good too but richer than the Almond cake. Drinks: Aperitvo cocktail and Bandol Rose wine (pairs great with tortelli and almond cake). Overall food flavors were good, but portions were very small so make sure you don't go there starving. Excellent service, great crowd, nice interior.
author: Samantha C.

description:
Must Order:
Bucatini

I also had the Pizza Lardo, Jewish Artichoke, Oxtail, a lamb pasta-- all decent, but not comparable to the Bucatini.  The Carbonara looked really good at the next table.
author: Tina N.

description: Ambience is excellent and the bartenders / drinks are top notch. The food was tasty (we had pasta) , but didn't blow us away.
author: Sandra S.

description: Good Italian food. Nice little brother to del fina. Nice atmosphere
author: Chris B.

description: The menu is indeed Roman. The Jewish artichokes are crunchy and lemony and you will not want to share. We went for the cacao e pepe pasta, a simple combination of ingredients that is done perfectly. The best carbanara outside of Rome. The creme on my espresso was beautiful. Service was excellent.
author: Beth W.

description: Flavorful focaccia bread. The crescenza tortelli is delicious- bursting w flavor from the cheese and mushrooms. The radiatore pecora e pecorino is also sumptuous.  Delicious Italian food in the Mission!
author: Romita J.

description: The cocktails and appetizers ESCAROLE and ROASTED SQUASH  and DUCK EGG "al LIONESE" and PUNTARELLE alla ROMANA where superb, the decor and service excellent. The staff very helpful and friendly. I would have live to give 5 stars but our main dishes the MIXED GRILL  and MARIN SUN CHICKEN alla CACCIATORA was over salted. This is something that in a resturant of this caliper needs to be very careful of. We will go back to try it again, definitely worth a second chance.
author: Garden Lover S.

description: Was really not impressed. Food was tasty but portions were RIDICULOUSLY small. My husband literally had to order two entrees, and they are not cheap. Will not be back.
author: Ashley S.

description: Sat at the bar and had several drinks and small plates. All very good. Fried olives were quite a treat. Bartender (I didn't catch his name) knows all of the pre-Prohibition Era cocktails. Modest selection of fernets and amaros. The space is a confusing and confused, but a good little spot nonetheless.
author: Sasha N.

description:
Very good!
We had loads of foods as follows:

Well.. first, the drinks:

Church: sweet and refreshing. Perfect after a hot day in the mission. 5/5
Nonna del Diavola: Stronger drink but nice finish; nice Rye 4/5

For antipasti:
Shaved artichoke: the cheese with artichoke was a great combo. 5/5

Main:
Rigatoni alla Carbonara: This was pretty good but the pork in the dish overpowered the whole dish. 4/5
Tortelli: Fantastic! The chanterelle mushroom was amazing in this dish. 5/5
The whole fish in acqua pazza: Man, this was amazing. We ate the whole thing and practically licked the bones. Having it in acqua pazza rather than grilled was definitely a nice touch. 5/5
author: Ck P.

description:
Locanda has incredible cocktails and amazing pastas, and the artichoke appetizer was one of the most unique and delicious things I've had in SF. It's a great date restaurant, with a unique atmosphere and amazing service (our server was really cool and had an impressive mustache).

The romanesco side was drowning in butter, but aside from that everything we had -- including the complementary bread -- was outstanding. Definitely coming back here.
author: Brian D.

description: Made a reservation and the three of us were seated in the back corner so we could see all of the action in this large, airy space.  Saw the Mythbusters guys holding court at some sort of business dinner at a nearby table, which was fun.  Food was delicious, but scantily portioned, drinks good, and service was decent.
author: Esther R.

description:
stopped by Locanda last night for a pre-nightcap and really liked their COPPIETTE! if youve never had coppiette before, its an air dried jerky style of salami stick...house made...perfect texture, a bit peppery, a bit vinegary, not salty at all...and all around totally delish!!! ended up ordering a second order and they were nice enough to give us a double portion...also ordered the PIZZA BIANCA w/ bone marrow and radish salad...not a traditional pizza in any way...not even a flatbread...just 1 good sized bone split down the middle with the marrow out in the open to scoop up and slather onto 3 pieces of crostini...very good bar eats!

other than that, Locanda is known for their mixed drinks.  the mixologists at the bar made a handful of drinks for us to try...at only 10 bucks a drinks, its easily one of the more reasonably priced cocktail lists in the city...the first round was the ANNIVERSARIO - gin, aperol, elderflower, prosecco, grapefruit...second round was the ONNA DEL DIAVOLO - rye, strega, ginger, lime, seltzer...3rd round ended up being shots of FERNET...great thing about their fernet is that they have 4 or 5 different flavors of it to try...not to mention the "ginger backs" that they serve up are the best ive had in the city...not just ginger ale...its a totally separate concoction that they serve up for the fernet, along with a candied ginger jelly on top to boot....
author: Kyu L.

description: SO good. So, so good. Delfina is my go to pizzeria in the city, so when I heard the owners were giving this restaurant a go I had to try it. Until coming here my favorite Italian place was SPQR, but I think Locanda may have usurped that title! The pasta was perfectly cooked, the salads were light and well balanced, using perfectly in season, fresh ingredients. Ambiance was great and will most certainly be back!
author: Kathryn M.

description: Went here for my birthday dinner this past year.  We had to wait a bit for the table (reason for half of the minus one star), but the cocktails while waiting were fantastic.  Further, once the meal started they waitstaff was very attentive and the food was excellent.  In particular, the pastas were the star of the evening.  The plain salt and pepper pasta was eye-opening in terms of the depth of flavor imparted to such a simple dish.  I would go here again in a heartbeat.  Too bad they are so busy and getting a table is so hard (reason for the other half of the minus one star).
author: Zac A.

description: My gauge on Italian food is simple. If it reminds me of my childhood at my Grandma Nicastro's table then I give it 5 stars. This did. Mind you, my grandma used to tell us we were having rabbit for dinner and then she would go outside and select one from the rabbit house, kill it, clean it up and start cooking it. Locanda sort of reminded me of that. I'll definitely be back.
author: Tammy N.

description: Craig and Amy did it again!  Congrats on another absolutely fantastic Italian culinary adventure in SF.   The pastas can't be done any better and the fried olives I crave now!!  congrats!!!
author: Emi C.

description: One of the most memorable dinners I've had in several trips to the Bay Area - food and service were excellent.
author: Chris O.

description:
second time.
the service was ok.  moderately priced. 
considering it is italian, all the dishes were still salty.
this place was overcrowded and some of them seemed to be enjoying their meals.
author: hun y.

description: I was pleasantly surprised by Locanda last night. I came here with a couple of girlfriends for a last minute holiday dinner and the place was humming for a Monday night. We were immediately seated at the very large community table. We started with the artichoke appetizer...YUM...and the bread they bring out is outstanding...double YUM. We each got a pasta dish, and while they were complex and delicious in their own way, I would say they are slightly on the small side. In retrospect, I should have ordered a salad to accompany the meal. Regardless, the atmosphere is really inviting and pleasing and the food is solid. I will definitely come back here! This spot is good for friends or a date...
author: Shannon C.

description:
Awesomeness all around.

Delicious cocktails (try The Church), bartenders are friendly and knowledgeable (Al is great), and we somehow got super lucky and scored a table on Friday night without reservations.  Had the Grilled seabass with artichokes which was delicious.  The warm chocolate cake was not only to die for, but the presentation was stunning, laid out like a piece of modern art you didn't want to eat. 

Would go back in a heartbeat.
author: Shruti Y.

description: The Church cocktail is pure summer cocktail perfection. Service and food were also excellent. The jerusalem artichoke was simply prepared, yet complex and very tasty. And the grilled halibut collar was a unique and memorably delicious dish. Overall, a great place!
author: Terry N.

description: Came here last Friday night and I definitely enjoyed it.  Good times.  Not sure if its as good as the hype but its good.  I started with the Church cocktail and it was delish, even if half of the glass was full of ice.  We started with the 'FRIED SWEETBREADS and ARTICHOKES' , nicely done. The fried parsley and capers lovely touch.  We then split the 'TONNARELLI CACIO e PEPE' which was a little one note and I thought it needed something.  We then did the 'MIXED GRILL' which was unique.  There was livers, blood sausage, quail and something else that I forget.  The blood sausage was the least cooked I have ever eaten it but not too iron'ey and it was very pleasant.   We also got a side of vegetables as well but don't recall it.  We finished with the 'AFFOGATO CORRETO' which was very good, but also not hard to get wrong. Would recommend this place and hopefully we will be back.
author: ORLA L.

description:
I went here with some friends for the first of (hopefully) many dinners as part of a supper club.  This was a great restaurant to start, and I absolutely recommend this place!  We ordered:   

apps:
**Jewish artichokes = Amazing.  If only the serving was slightly larger! Lightly fried, they were perfect.
**Carciofi Crudi = A light, refreshing salad to start with.  pretty simply dish, but very good.  consisted of grilled ricotta, wild arugula, and avocado. 
**Pizza Bianca = topped with smoked herring, horseradish, beets.  the chickpea spread on the pizza was slightly off for my taste, but my friends liked it.  

dinner:
**FETTUCCINI - capon sugo, pancetta, cicoria, verjus - excellent, highly recommend
**RADIATORE "PECORA e PECORINO" - lamb ragu, pecorino, mint - too much mint on this dish.  it really overwhelmed what would have, otherwise, been great
**CUSCINI - gulf shrimp and burrata - my favorite food of the night.  it was perfect.  wasn't my dish, but i should have ordered it.  

there's a decent wine selection here too, with about 10 wines on tap.  a good chunk of the wines are from italy.
author: Joel F.

description: Feeling fancy? Go here.  You can over spend until you can't no more. Went here last Saturday... had a great time, it could be that I was with awesome company.  I do like the feel and vibe of the bar, but it just seems to be too much right next to the dinner tables.Something about that seems so disruptive to a meal. But I shall go back and get a better taste of it all... for now... it's not horrible... it's not something I would recommend as a top choice... but things can always change. ;)
author: Amelia M.

description:
Hands down the best meal I have had in SF in 5-6 years (and I eat out a ton due to client entertaining, etc.). 

Everything was amazing.  Highlights were deep fried olives, the bread, roasted leg of lamb, flat bread pizza, the lamb ragu and of course the coppiette.

Can't wait to get back.
author: Brad K.

description: Probably the best new restaurant I've been to in SF in 10 yrs, really top notch on so many levels incl valet parking, nice touch. Great drink starters, the old fashion flight is amazing, the bread is absurdly good, artichokes we ordered twice, everyone loved their entrees except for the lamb which tasted a touch charred but all else stunning. My only 2 complaints are the jammed in seating areas, not much room to spread out and the Italian only wine list, come on, you're in SF, show some love to your local region please! I will definitely be back next trip.
author: Adam U.

description: I have been here 4 times since it opened and consistency and service had declined until NOW - The servers were all helpful and knowledgeable - an unmistakable turnaround and the food similarly was properly cooked. Once again a believer... Thanks
author: richard F.

description: We had a great meal here.  One of the stand out "dishes" was the jerky that we ordered.  We saw strips of something hanging over the smoker/grill and we asked about them.  The server explained that they were strips of meat (jerky like strips) that the kitchen uses to give the flavor the oven/grill.  Lucky for us, you can buy them too.  They are flavorful and cheap.  Worth the few bucks it adds to your bill.
author: Larry L.

description:
I usually just go later in the evening, have a delicious cocktail and some fried artichoke and my night is complete.

Seriously some of the best mixologists in the city.
author: n. k.

description: I really wanted to love Locanda but walked away pretty dissapointed. This place definitely has a cool look and feels modern and trendy, but the food was just ok. The carbonara was tasty but forgetable, the sauteed brussel sprouts were cooked to prefection, and the jewish artichoke appetizer was good but too plain; it would have benefited from an aioli or dressing being served on the side. Overall the food was good but definitely not worth the $60 dollar check.
author: Maryyyy S.

description: Had a great cocktail and some tasty appetizers.  Excellent service in a cool atmosphere.
author: Steve R.

description:
Customer service was an utter failure last night.  No hyperbole, simple facts.  I know that this is not a Danny Meyer restaurant but I was shocked how the front of the house was such a clusterf*ck considering Anne Stoll (and her corresponding reputation) is running the program.    

We had reservations at 9:00 pm.  We were not seated until 9:40 pm.  While we were waiting for our table, we were offered complimentary house make pork jerky (1 string each).  I didn't eat mine, my gf thought it was too spicy.  Around 9:20, I asked the gf if she wanted try chef Balla's food at Bar Tartine next door?  She wanted to stay, so we stayed.  We were told and shown (!?!?!?!) which table was "enjoying their wine too long" and "holding things up." (the host's words not mine)  First, you should never rush another table; second, you should NEVER identify the table in question to the next party in line; third, my reservation should not be tied to a single two top (i.e., seat me at the next open table).  Pro-tip: stop stacking reservations if you don't have the seats to sit everyone.  What is the point of making a reservation if I have to wait the same length of time as if I had simply walked in for a table.  

Moreover, the two two-tops near the bathroom (high chairs) were given away to other guests while we were waiting (both sets of guests arrived after we did).  I'm not sure if those tops were reserved for walk-ins or not, but I should have been offered those seats.  I was not.

At around 9:30, the only male at the front of the house promised me that "food would be on the table" when we were seated.  I suspected that it was an empty promise (unless this guy was cooking my food and serving it to us personally, which he was clearly not doing either, there was no way he was going to fulfill such a gambit).  To no one's surprise, no food was present when we were finally seated at 9:40.  The front of the house should never make promises it cannot keep to the customer.  The terrible customer service did not end there.

10 minutes after being seat, our server had not made an appearance.  I had to get up from my seat, walk back to the host stand, and ask them to send our waiter over because we were starving at that point. 

These were the more egregious errors of the night.  Pacing between course was also really really slow.            

But you know what, all of the above would have been forgotten (or largely mitigated) as ancillary atmospherics had the food been spectacular.  The food was not spectacular.  It was just ok.  The tripe and hen leg were good, both pastas (carbonara and spring blossom) were average to below average.  The portions were small (the hen leg was just that).  

Op-ed time: your money can be better spent at the following restaurants serving similar style food at similar price points: Flour+Water; Cotogna; and SPQR.
author: Charlie C.

description: Delicious!!!  I have not been to Delfina since they opened (when I lived in SF) but this really reminded me of that feeling I had when first eating at Delfina.  The food was so perfectly rustic, and reminded me of various regions of Italy.  I enjoyed the artichoke and sweetbread appetizer, and our table shared many pasta dishes which were all so freshly prepared and full of flavor.  The standout was a pasta dish with rabbit.  We also split some fish and lamb which were both very tasty.  Wine was paired by our waiter, and he was spot on.  I'm happy to have experienced this meal with some great friends and my brother.
author: Josh F.

description:
-very expensive
-excellent service
-incredible anchovy dishes - on puntarelle& broccoli -
but DONT DO NOT get the bar snack - 'PIZZA".
it's just 2 tiny triangles of focaccia w/ creamy cheese spread on top. 
now i wasn't expecting an arnell's type ny slice, but it was just bad.
author: Kim Y.

description: Really good, interesting. Slightly pricey and fancy shmancy. Good for a special evening out.
author: Sarma A.

description:
meh...  place was simply ok...

first, everyone whining about the bike lane being blocked by the valet service, shut up.  if you don't like it then stop riding your bikes at night.  the fact that locanda blocks a bike lane, +1 star

second, i hate hipsters.  the hoodies, the beards, the "i'm so much better than you even though I've never done anything notable with my life" attitude that pervades this place made me want to punch every other person.  the place is full of self important pretentious d-bags calling themselves "foodies" and wearing scarves, -1 star

the cocktails were great.  not a bottle of grey goose in the place but that didn't stop them from making a mean Moscow Mule, and the waitress kept bringing them without me having to ask. +1 star

the food was decent.  not great, not life changing, but decent.  The jewish artichoke wasn't what everyone raves about, it was dry and devoid of flavor.  I had the rabbit and it certainly didn't knock my socks off.  my wife and her girlfriend split the fried duck egg salad and that was actually amazing.  the brussel sprouts were tasty and as a general rule i loathe brussel sprouts.  +1 star

the waitress was friendly and personable.  not pretentious or on a high horse like some of the reviews would lead you to believe.  we were a fairly large party and not once were we told to "keep it down", and she even interacted with our group and joked around with us.  +1 star

the bill for 6 people was only $450, so not as "outrageously expensive" as most have said, i found it to be rather economical especially given the number of cocktails that we had.

would i return?  maybe, but i wouldn't go out of my way to go here.  there are much better places to try, even in the mission.
author: Robert M.

description:
A week prior one of my girlfriends came here and said that she enjoyed all the dishes her and her boyfriend had at Locanda. After hearing her talk about how much she liked the food and the place my boyfriend decided he had to go here last Friday. So I called Locanda for a reservation. Obviously without much planning and because it's one of the hot new restaurants in the area the hostess told me that the next available seating was at 11pm. Well that did not deter us from going there. We declined the reservation and decided to just try our luck and head over as a "walk in'. After arriving at 8:30pm last Friday we were seated in 20 minutes at the communal table. This is actually a fun place to sit other than at the bar. We made friends at our table for 10. It's also a great place to see what other folks ordered that you didn't. Also, the communal table you can hear an honest and candid review. The menu had so many things we wanted to try but only two of us, my boyfriend and I ordered the following:

Jewish Style Artichoke. A must. It's grilled not steamed. Something different from what you're use to. 

Oxtails alla Vaccinara. It was cooked right as the meat fell off the bone. The dish was tasty and surprisingly contained tiny bits of cocoa nibs. The sauce it's cooked in reminds me of Mole.

Fettuccine rabbit sugo, cicoria, verjus. A recommendation from our girlfriend and glad we listened and ordered it. It was made with a lite white cream sauce. The dish was simple even though it doesn't sound simple.  This was delicious. 

Grilled Halibut Collar. It was cooked in garlic and included sauteed pea shoots. This was our least favorite dish because the fish was a little fishy. 

For dessert we shared the chocolate cake which was just okay.  

Locanda also has a full bar and offers a variety of their signature cocktails that my boyfriend enjoyed.

Definitely coming back again and since they offer Valet service this makes it easier to come back. (It's so hard to find parking in this area.)
author: Eileen B.

description: The menu is boring (I can cook the same dishes at home), they are freaking expensive, they have a hipster attitude, overall way overvalued.
author: Luca R.

description: This restaurant is the shadowed little sister to Delfina. They offered fancy-named bread which to me, was just focaccia. I tried the tripa as an appetizer. This was good to dip the focaccia bread in. The service was good. For some reason, there's something about this place that just doesn't compare to Delfina.
author: Elaine L.

description: The fried olives are delightful! Friendly service and a fun up spin on Italian! Lots of wine from the peimonte region, which has a sweet spot in my heart! Our wine was delish but I was also very envious of the old fashioned flight the guy at the table next to us ordered!! We will definitely be back to explore the rest of the menu.
author: stephanie s.

description: Great atmosphere if you're into the A crowd and like a lively noisy place (which I like on occasion). big minus points for greasy food (almost everything we ate swam in some sort of fat or another) at New York prices.
author: Tudor H.

description: Fantastic food!! We ordered the Qvinto di Qvarto and it was absolutely stunning. Three of us shared these portions and it was just enough to get a taste what these chefs can do. Although they were out of sweetbreads they substituted lamb brains which were the highlight of the evening. Tender, buttery, crispy and smart. They're brains after all... Anyway, one of my favorite SF Italian meals to date!!
author: Frank B.

description:
The quick version: the food was good, though overpriced in my opinion for what it is, but what makes me in no rush to go back is that the service was awful. 

We had the Jerusalem artichokes, the tripe, and the duck egg to start. We then had the bucatini all'amatriciana and the linguini with anchovies and padron peppers. We finished with the lamb chops. Overall, it was delicious. The bucatini and the lamb chops were our favorites. Least favorite was the linguini, as the padron peppers overwhelmed the anchovies.  The lamb was great, but 26 bucks for two lamb chops is high. 

But the service is what really was disappointing.  Especially since this is an offshoot of Delfina, which, despite some slipping the last couple of years, was always made more special by its amazing staff. 

Our waitress did a number of things wrong.  First, she didn't know the wine list well, but instead of just admitting that, she struggled through giving us pretty unclear answers. Next, our pasta course was brought after we ordered the wine but before the wine was delivered -- the wine is to drink with the food and they totally screwed that up.  

Worst, the food was not brought in the right order.  We had asked for our apps, then our pasta, and finally our lamb.  Instead they brought the lamb with the pasta, which frankly is just dumb if you hold yourself out as an Italian/Roman restaurant.  What really annoyed me is that when we asked them to remove the lamb and keep it warm for us, the server who brought it agreed, but then our waitress came by to say "I thought you wanted the lamb with the pasta".  What is the point of her coming by to ask that?  We had already asked them to remedy it and her coming by accomplished nothing.  It was an amateur move.  

I'm not willing to pay these prices for good food with bad service.  I might try them again down the road if I hear service is fixed, but until then, Range continues to displace Delfina & Co as the best experience in the Mission.
author: Ross D.

description: I loved everything about Locanda. The service was impecable and warm, the food a delight. Everything I ordered was delicious, including my cocktail. I will be going back soon.
author: Wendy K.

description: Fabulous Food! The Jerusalem artichoke was wonderful. Following that, my friend and I shared an order of beef cheek ravioli- again, outstanding. My entree was the lamb- again, outstanding. My dessert was the ricotta fritta- again, outstanding. If I were forced to say anything negative about this restaurant, the only possible thing I could say is that the staff could use a bit of polish. We arrived for our reservation, were told that they were clearing the table, and were sent to the bar for cocktails---only to then find out that half of our party had already been seated before our arrival, were at our table and were having cocktails there. Our group of 7 never got served at the same time, so half of us were often sitting with our food in front of us waiting for the others to get served. Lesson: Dine with a party of 2 and all will be perfect at this gem of a place.
author: Pam D.

description: Unique and sophisticated environment and top-notch service. The food is fresh and flavorful, and the portions are perfect for sharing. We want to try everything on the menu (including all of the speciality cocktails), so we will definitely be back!
author: Sarah S.

description: Can I say second on the bread PLEASE!!!! So this is my long overdue review after 2 visits and I am sold.  Locanda has amazing cocktails and as I stated previously the bread is what pops up in my dreams at night! Our server was so helpful and friendly, I didn't feel like they rushed you...even though there is always a wait, so make a reservation! I will be back
author: Maureen R.

description: Wow!  What an incredible meal!  The green tomato soup was amazing - so tomatoey and so intense in flavor.  The saddle of rabbit was out of this world - tender, perfectly cooked and perfectly seasoned.  I AM IMPRESSED! And a great crowd, great atmosphere and great service to boot.  This place is a gem!
author: David A.

description:
Delicious delicious pasta. I'm partial to their lamb ragu, but the carbonara is also amazing. The artichoke is a must order. Also a huge fan of their "bartender's choice" cocktails - each time I've specified that I want a gin-based drink and they always come up with someone new and exciting!

Went with 4 (not 5) stars because I've been underwhelmed with their desserts twice, although on my most recent trip they nailed it with chocolate cake and earl grey ice cream.
author: Adrienne D.

description: My entire group was a bit more impressed than I was--but since it was my suggestion, I just soaked up the compliments. Everybody tried a little bit of each others dishes, so I was able to check out the brains, tendons, lamb, rabbit, broccoli--I'm sure I am forgetting a few. The server (and the server's helpers) were all excellent and appeared to really enjoy serving the food and drinks, which goes a long way in the enjoyment process. I loved the physical space and, of course, it had the noise level that seems to be mandatory for all hip spots in the City.
author: Robert M.

description: The food was outstanding, especially the beef cheek ravioli. On the way out, literally every employee of the restaurant thanked us. If the biggest complaint is that the clientele is "too Marina", that's hardly a reason to not go.
author: Curtis F.

description:
had a visit at least 6 months ago and did not write a review ? the reason is around that time i realized some of my reviews fell into a filtered basket. why? and why spending time to write reviews and see them hidden from the world!
anyway, 6 months later, what we ate at Locanda did not impress us (were we 3 or 4 sitting near the vent and it was freezing!) we were inmpressed by the decor but not the food and we were disappointed to be dissappointed because we love delphina (except for the tiny portions) 
last word about wines: very good wines but not very affordable. who can afford 2 glasses of $12-16 a piece?
definitely a high-end restaurant in term of prices.
this is the kind of reviews you'll likely find in the filtered basket, euh?
author: Thuy G.

description:
i love this restaurant, and that's not common.
drinks were unique, not too hipster, quite tasty
ambience is good, especially for dates, couples
food was unique and oh so yummy
only thing that i don't love is the wait time, but this is a restaurant i'd be willing to wait for...
author: Sandy K.

description:
Fantabuloso!

Stopped in with a friend for dinner on Wednesday night. Although the place was packed and buzzing, the gracious hostess, Dianne, found us a table in the quieter rear section.  The attentive, professional, and unpretentious staff helped us select a bottle of Italian Pinot Noir Rose to complement our varied meal selection. First came the Spring Onions appetizer: fried perfectly, well seasoned and crunchy in a tempura batter, with wispy strands of cheese on top.  We almost ordered a second, just as our Radiatore pasta dish arrived.  The unusual, barrel shaped pasta had tasty bits of lamb in a lovely tomato ragu sauce, highlighted by pecorino cheese. A perfectly executed bavette (flank) steak followed; cooked medium rare and set atop a melange of radicchio and smoky mashed potatoes (of which there could have been a bit more!). Dessert was a delicious crostada with bits of candied fruit topped with a dollop of creamy goat cheese.

Our first visit was magical and we'll be back again!
author: Tom B.

description: Absolutely amazing drinks and appetizers (especially olives) main dishes are hit and miss. If you come early you can get a spot at the bar and see an amazing magic of bartenders.
author: Alex N.

description:
We had an outstanding dinner at Locanda last night.  Good god.  I was not expecting much, given a couple of my friends' mediocre reviews, but apparently the dining gods were smiling on us.

We had the jewish-style artichoke to start, which was greasy fried delicious deliciousness, and my boyfriend had a piece of their house-made pork jerky, which he said was awesome.
