For the main course, I had the chestnut agnolotti, and it was AMAZING.  I'm drooling just thinking about it.  House-made pasta stuffed with chestnut cream, topped with brown butter with sage and I think a bit of pepper.  SO GOOD.  I could eat that stuff by the gallon.  My boyfriend had the grilled lamb leg with anchovy butter.  He's pretty fussy and gave the (very good-natured) waiter super-specific instructions about how he wanted the meat done.  It came out precisely as he'd asked for, and he loved it.

The low point was dessert (odd, for me).  We got the warm chocolate cake to share.  It was fine, but nothing special.  The cake itself was not what I was expecting -- slightly dry, and not particularly sweet.  Combined with the garnishes (maple syrup, cream, and walnuts) it tasted good, but on its own I actually didn't like it very much.  After the sweet delicious amazingness of the chestnut pasta, I was a little disappointed.

Special shout-out for the service -- our waiter was so ridiculously nice I noted his name to include in this review:  it was Jason.  Thanks Jason!
author: Sarah B.

description: Their food is always delicious and their drinks nice and strong. A favorite place for dinner.
author: Linh P.

description: Anyone who is a fan of Delfina and, well, food in general, will adore Locanda!  The dishes are masterfully thought out...we chose the shaved artichoke and pecerino salad (divine), jewish style artichoke (a must-try), garbanzo and tuna-heart pasta (the flavors were so authentically Italian) and the fig crostata for dessert.  The waiters were attentive but never overbearing, the sommalier never let our wine glasses get near empty, and the chefs are cute!  With so many great restaurants in the area, I don't often find one that I want to rush back to (before trying another new spot), but I will be back soon!
author: Celia T.

description: Hip and trendy place, cute and cheerful waitresses, fantastic food. Artichokes, sweetbreads, oxtails, fettuccine with rabbit - wow!
author: Sergei B.

description: Great Spot.  Got lucky and was walking past right as it opened and got a table on Saturday night.  Everything from service to cocktails to food was fantastic.  I would recommend the fettuccine rabbit sugo w/ dandelion and the rigatoni carbonarra.  Tripe and beans was also the show! Aviation Gin Cocktails... Loved it!
author: Joe S.

description:
There was a time when friends and family in other parts of the country asked what I was talking about whenever I mentioned eating an artichoke.  Today this wonderful thistle is grown almost everywhere the sun and water can be found, and they're cultivated year round.  When I see these beauties on a menu anywhere, I take note and face a tough choice whether to go for one or eat the fare the restaurant is known for.  My partner and I frequently dine at Chow here in the City, Duarte's in Pescadero and Little Napoli in Carmel because each treats the 'choke' with respect and a touch of reverence.  When we yelped Locanda, we saw dozens of five star reviews and even more mentions of their artichoke presentation so it became a mission and we were soon at this truly wonderful 'Roman' restaurant enjoying our coveted treasure and the other handcrafted and delicious offerings with great relish.  So, our friend Bobby called and suggested we catch an early dinner on a Monday night and we made reservations here and made our first foray into Locanda to see ourselves what all the chatter is really about.  It's on uber cool Valencia and next door to what was recently Bar Tartine, but like most chic joints in the Mission it's a rectangular storefront with windows open to the street and a designer interior which is really comfortable as well as suave and debonair.  We were seated in the back with a corner that suited us perfectly and we were able to talk like a family without busybodies eavesdropping on our dirty little secrets.  

I'd checked the menu on Yelp, then read many of the 200 plus reviews to get a feel for what people were raving or ranting about to guide our initial visit, but I knew the Artichoke and Sweetbreads were going to arrive at our table before we left.  They have a full bar with a terrific cocktail menu, good wine list and unfortunately no kind of diet beverage.  Starbelly refused to carry diet soda but the complaints were loud and furious and they relented and now serve an organic diet cola and everyone is happy.  I tend to be resentful when a restaurant owner decides for me what I can and can't drink and I remember when a great local restaurateur opened a French place on Van Ness and refused to allow salt or pepper to be served by the wait staff because the French Chef said his food was perfectly seasoned and adding anything would be an insult to him.  They didn't last long.  So we ordered the 'Jewish style artichoke' and a plate of Sweetbreads to start.  Both were mouth watering and solid hits.  The hosts were well trained, courteous and attentive and followed up on their work, a nice touch.  The servers and floor manger all took pride in their jobs and worked hard to provide five star service.  When it came to the next courses, we got lost and probably should have asked for more guidance from the staff because we weren't happy with the heavily peppered Carbonara w/ Guanciale which was tossed generously with a strong mustard type sauce although the Penne itself was almost perfect.  We also shared the poached Salmon which was excellent but perhaps under accompanied with complementary tastes.  The peas were rock hard and the Mussels were almost mushy.  We split the ricotta fritte for dessert and this was a homerun all the way around the table.

This is an ambitious, serious, accomplished restaurant created by smart and successful restaurant pro's and is already an out of the ball park homerun, so I owe it to myself and my guests to go back at least several times to taste and try their unique menu offerings in a stylish setting with superior service.
author: Stu S.

description:
Sweetbreads - good
Carbonara pasta - good

Must try & would return in a heartbeat.
author: Ryan S.

description: Visiting from Boston and went to locanda because a friend read about it in the ny times. Ordered the fried artichoke and rabbit fettucine at the suggestion of the yelp reviews and loved them both. The food was great but the real reason I'm writing this review was because we had AMAZING service from our server Ethan. First, he overheard my friend complaining about her wine and very sympathetically told us that they had gotten a lot of complaints about that particular wine. He brought her another glass, great wine and similar price range to the wine she originally ordered. He was extremely helpful with the menu, gave great suggestions, and even called a taxi for us when we were done with dinner. Great food enhanced by great service.
author: Brittany B.

description: If not the best Italian restaurant in SF maybe the most innovative. Just freaking great.
author: Thadd L.

description: Locanda is SO good! My new favorite. Atmosphere is great- relaxed vibe and good crowd. Jason was our server and enchanted us with the very best service. He was very friendly, knowledgeable about the menu, and attentive. We ordered a steak, spaghetti, and English pea pasta. We then ordered another steak because it was so good. The donut hole dessert is to die for. I can't wait to go back!
author: Jenna Q.

description: Outstanding. Started with some amazing cocktails at a busy bar on a Saturday night, this cosy neighbourhood eatery offers a level of sophistication that the rest of the restaurants in the Mission fail to reach. I'm all for 'vivre la difference' and having great choice and variety in this locale, but I wouldn't hesitate to go back here in a heart beat. The service was very attentive, the quality of the food just perfect and the atmosphere contributed to a great 'last supper' after a 2 week vacation in SF. Highly recommended - especially the Basil Thyme cocktail, fried sweetbreads and bavette steak...yum
author: James G.

description:
Jewish artichoke, lamb ragu pasta, anchovy linguine, and cauliflower side--all were yum, yum, yum! I wish the portion size reflected the price a bit more. When my radiatore lamb ragu pasta came out, i could see the bottom of my plate in between the noodles. It made me want to count how many noodles I got. Anyway, still a great dish. 
Their aperol drink, Church, is so awesome. I was in love with the large ice cube. It's so modern and hip. ;) 
We also ended with the yogurt budino. It was fresh and light and not too rich to send you into a food-guilt spiral. Can't wait to go back. Probably will next week.
author: Joanna L.

description:
Not only is the food fabulous, but the staff could not be more attentive. I've been to Locanda several times and have always had a stellar experience. From the hostess to the bartender to the server to the manager, this group of employees is a cut above the rest.

On a crowded evening, the hostess went out of her way to point out bar space that had just cleared that I hadn't noticed. Later when our table was ready, I asked to close out rather than transfer our tab to ensure the bartender was tipped properly. We later saw that our drinks were comped in appreciation. On a different very busy evening, our cheese plate took a bit longer than expected. Not only did the server delete the charge, but the manager brought us two glasses of wine on the house because we had finished ours already. 

None of these gestures were expected, but all were greatly appreciated. This is a place that values its customers and hires thoughtful people. On top of that, the food is always amazing.
author: M C.

description:
Wandered in here early one night for dinner, and had a wonderful meal.  One of the best pasta dishes I have had in a looooong time.  Love the bread, and we shared a wonderful appetizer.  Our service was perfectly fine, and I would definitely come back.
My one suggestion to the restaurant:  turn the music DOWN.  We found ourselves singing along to the music, which means it's too loud.  The place has a great vibe and the music isn't necessary (especially at that decibel).
author: Sandra K.

description: Great food. A super-friendly, non-hipster wait staff and lovely ambiance.
author: Yogi B.

description:
Favorite new restaurant of 2011.  Fantastic space.  Great bar with selection of italian liquors.  Had the nonna del diavolo (rye, Strega, ginger, lime, seltzer) at the bar.  Ordered the radiatore pecora e pecorino (radiatore pasta with lamb ragu, pecorino, and mint).   Jewish style artichoke. 

Want to try the chilled nervetti, lamb chop, hog island clams/lettuce/chillies/linguini, roman carbonara, pizza bianca.

"The Church," (Aperol, gin, Cocchi Americano, lemon)

Went for the fourth time and still love.  Notable things to have again: burrata, bellwether crescenza tortilla , old fashioned flight.
author: around town e.

description: Our waitress Sarah was awesome.  My family is a bit difficult, had tons of questions for her, and she was so patient and kind with us.  Great service!
author: Alex D.

description: amazing from the margaritas down to the dessert.  I was amazed by the bartender's service and attention, and the food was awesome for the two of us.  I think you should check it out w/o telling you about what we ate or how we ate it.  Great service all around.
author: J C.

description: Pasta worth going out for at a great price with cocktails to match.  The olive oil bread is incredible and service was fantastic.
author: Matt T.

description:
So worth the wait!  We were so luck to get in on the first night of what I'm sure will be the restaurant of the year.

The vibe inside was contagious, everyone including the staff knew it was a special evening.

The table next to us "made" us get the poached egg & asparagus starter before we moved on to the primi of a rich, flavorful skate & ceci brodo and tonarelli "cacio e pepe".  

It's a sign of a great kitchen when they can take what would be considered a simple dish and make it memorable..  Delfina did it with it's Spaghetti and tomato sauce, Locanda does it with it's cacio e pepe.  The other pastas also looked amazing and we can't wait to try them.

For seconds, we had the Lamb Scottodito and the Bavette steak, both of which were excellent.  The steak has an almost buttery texture to it, but comes with a simple (looking) jus and wonderful radicchio underneath. 

Don't miss the desserts!  The ricotta fritters were so light and airy, not greasy at all, and the grape & black pepper granita with panna was almost the highlight of the evening.

Chris the sommelier gave us excellent suggestions.  The wine list leans heavily towards imports from small producers (not just Italy, but Spain France Germany & Austria),  so take my advice and get his advice.  He couldn't be more approachable and steered us to a great Spanish white that was among the most affordable bottles on the list.

The cocktails coming out also looked special, we'll get one next time for sure.

Summed up in a word: GO!
author: Robert M.

description:
I had a really lovely night here this week.  I arrived at 6pm, and I informed the hostesses that my friend would be another 15 minutes, so I'd like to put my name on the list.  They graciously offered to seat me immediately, which was shocking and appreciated.  I chose a bar table and proceeded to admire the lovely tiled wall and entire space.
The rest of the night went off without a hitch.  My friend and I had great drinks, food and service.  Everyone was in a good mood, and it felt like they had confidence and enthusiasm, despite what I imagine has been a hectic opening week.  We sat on our table for over 3 hours, and no one batted an eye.  If anything, I feel like every manager stopped by to chat and get our feedback.  I felt very comfortable and cared for.
I liked the space, the energy and the food was great.  
Highlights of my night:
Hearing Yo La Tengo and Modest Mouse on the iPod.  Hurray for a Pandora free restaurant.
Having our bottle of white wine stored away from the table for chilling, while having a friendly server who magically swooped in to refill my glass every time I got close to the bottom. 
The Soul Food farm fried egg salad
The spaghetti with fava leaves
The amatriciana that I took home for my wife.  She ate it so quickly,  I never got the chance to ask for a bite.
The overall attentiveness of the staff, without being overbearing or pushy.  That's a hard balance to achieve! 
Welcome to the neighborhood- I can't wait to go back.
author: Alisha A.

description: Appetizers were phenomenal.Pastas were great. The grill was disappointing. Great staff, great atmosphere. The highlight for me was the fried olives and the house made ginger ale.
author: Joe P.

description: Impeccable food and service. What a lovely restaurant- from the hosts at the door who are gracious and accommodating, to the amazing service and the astonishing food. The food rocks- creative, tasty, beautifully presented. Like most of us in SF, I eat a lot and you get a bit jaded. But this restaurant is hands down one of the best if not the best.
author: gbb u.

description: Excellent Food. But pushy 'hurry up' service... overkill on the up-selling, expensive tiny cocktails & VERY scant wine pours
author: Ms. T.

description: Ran into this spot on the way home the other day and stopped in for a meal.  The food was all very delicious, with the jewish artichoke being a favorite dish of mine.  The only downside was that this place uses one of those unnecessarily fancy menus that require decoding to understand.  I know this is crazy, but when I'm in the US, I really do appreciate being able to read menus without translation.  But I guess these menus bring out the ignorant side of all of us...
author: Megan M.

description: Bummer!!!  I have loved this place since it opened, but it has officially gone down hill.  Great cocktails now are hit-or-miss, pasta dishes that were once incredible are now just so-so, and even the appetizer (they didn't have the artichokes, unfortunately), the little gem lettuces, was just ok.  After 2 major misses with the place in a row, I won't be going back.  Guess the Locanda Hay Day is over.  Now it's just a hip restaurant with mediocre quality especially for the price. Very sad to say it!  Lastly, our waitress (for the 1st time ever at this place) was grumpy and stiff...feel like the love has drained out of the food & the wait staff here (which usually means management has flipped from focusing on great food, great service & good vibes, to focusing on just the bottom line...and that is palpable here now). Still bummed. Wish they would bring back the goodness!
author: I. B.

description:
The pasta was good but not amazing - Flour and Water definitely has a lock on the best pasta.

Fried jewish artichoke is amazing. Can't go wrong with fried food.

Best part of the meal was the hen leg.

Food ranged from "acceptable/interesting but not something I would seek out again" to "excellent."  Service was totally professional but the waitress lacked the ability to detect sarcasm, which made me uncomfortable.

Should you go there?  Yes.  Will you eat well but not cream your pants over it?  Probably.  Will you spend too much money?  Yes.
author: S S.

description: Iv had better food honestly. However the location and atmosphere is great. Again I thought this is one of the food spots in SF, that as I step in and step out, I will plan my next visit. However, apparently that wasn't the case. I was was waiting for that magical moment the whole time, weather its from the experience that I went through with the rude waitress or from the food. Other than that the food was okayish to goodish, but nothing special, maybe because I live in SF and tried  better food. But will definitely suggest to visit this place at least once.
author: Sulaiman B.

description: Went here for my birthday, and loved it! Best pasta I've had in SF. Totally made me disregard my short list of dietary restrictions.
author: Maggie T.

description: Great cocktails, amazing food, and attentive waiter. We had the jewish style artichokes, carciofi crudi, an amazing chestnut and amaro pasta dish with a side of grilled escarole (awesome!), and the local halibut dish. We finished with dessert of cheese (blue cheese and the la tour) that came with a cracker drizzled in honey. Fantastic! We will be back again.
author: Michele A.

description: Good food. I ordered the whole fish and asked them to remove the bones for me. Unfortunately it came with all the bones when the fish was served. When they served the fish a second time, everyone else was done with their steak and I could eat my fish  alone. A  restaurant like this should  get the basics right (you server everyone at once). People expect that, so when you don't, they have a bad experience.
author: Peter J.

description: Gorgeous space, magnificent cocktails, and incomparable carbonara.  I can't come up with enough hyperbolic adjectives to capture my contentment.  Find the nearest road and follow it to Locanda.
author: Christina P.

description: I stopped into Locanda last night in the pouring rain to meet a friend, and we were lucky enough to find seats at the bar on a busy Friday. I adore, adore, adore this restaurant. For such a stylish place, it's amazingly comfortable and devoid of attitude. The receptionists and wait and bar staffs couldn't be pleasanter or more knowledgeable. On my past visits, I've loved artichokes and sweetbreads, pasta with ricotta and hedgehog mushrooms, trippa alla Romana and lamb chops. The Church gin drink is inventive and delicious. Anthony Strong and the Delfina folk are doing a great job here on Valencia Street. Best wishes for a long run.
author: Jane K.

description: Wow.  My new favorite restaurant in the Mission.  Had a fabulous three hour dinner at the bar and didn't feel rushed at all.  It's kind of the new killer app because they have fabulous throwback cocktails, a great wine selection, and the delicious food that you would expect coming out of a Delfina sibling (but frankly - I think it's better).  Can't wait to go back.
author: Catherine J.

description: Locanda is unique and special. The cocktails alone are worth a visit, and the pastas are extraordinary. For me, the kitchen's diligence, talent, and passion shine in the pasta dishes. My only critique is the small pasta portions for a pretty penny, however, I do understand that everything must be taken into account in running a thriving restaurant.
author: Kadie C.

description: Our group of 8 people were 20 minutes early for our 8:30 reservations, and we still did not get seated until almost 9:00 pm. If not for this I would have given a higher rating. Excellent food. Pretty good drinks - their cocktail list is a bit underwhelming. Excellent service. I would return.
author: Cynthia C.

description:
I'd been looking forward to Locanda for weeks as I've been a fan of Delfina (and Delfina Pizzeria) for years. This weekend we had out-of-town guests with us and needed to take them to a place we could all get excited about. Locanda only had 10:30PM available on Saturday which I took, though I included a note on the on line reservation asking for earlier if it became available. Within a day, Locanda's host called to say a 9PM opened up - did we want it? So we go in earlier and I have to say the fact they read my note and acted upon it was impressive. Upon arriving we were greeted with warmth and enthusiasm. Seated immediately, spied house-made gianciale curing along with what looked like strips of jerky in a display case. After ordering a bottle of light Italian red wine, I asked the sommelier what the jerky was. Thought I can't recall the name, it was strips of pork loin cured for weeks in spices and herbs and eaten as a bar snack.

 We ordered that to much on while we perused the menu. I ordered the pig ear terrine, asparagus with a poached duck egg, and leg of guinea fowl. Others in our party ordered the pasta with rabbit sugo, sweetbreads with artichokes, anchovy pasta, and a contorni side dish of carrots stewed with green grapes. The asparagus, terrine, rabbit sumo and guinea fowl were hits we all agreed, one friend however disliked his anchovy pasta dish as being too spicy. It WAS spicy alright, but I have to say as a roman, rustic, rich pasta it was spot on for me. Just not for those with plainer tastes. The sweetbreads were delish and the poached duck egg's molten yolk ran all over the asparagus to combine with the brown butter included on the plate to create a velvety, very sumptuous dish. The big miss for everyone at the table was the cured strips of pork loin. I thought they were a bit under seasoned and less than optimal for sharing. Others at the table were just baffled by them. Service was top notch: friendly, interested, engaged, yet unobtrusive. 

I have address some of the really bitchy commentary on here about comments like 'whatever Delfina puts in the compost gets run over to Locanda', and 'pig's ears are for dogs' make me think the writer has a palate better suited for Fridays or perhaps Marie Callenders. The pig's ear terrine was rich, creamy, and flavorful. Everything one would expect to experience in an Italian salumeria or french charcuterie. I hope readers on here will try it. Offal, one of the glories of almost every culture in the world except America (see Maria Callenders), is delicious here: the sweetbreads delicately fried and carefully served with artichokes, the beef tendon, melt in your mouth. One of our party ordered the salad misticanza and it was a lovely melange of the best heirloom and micro greens, a few coins of radish and a light vinaigrette.

 I've heard places like Denny's & Fast food joints do salad bars with Iceberg lettuce and 2000 calorie dressings. Perhaps the reader who thought the greens were from the roadway would enjoy that experience more?
author: Jordan N.

description: I'm pretty stingy with my 5's. The Zucca and the Rabbit Fettucini compell me.
author: Bib G.

description: LAMB SCOTTADITTO $26 and its worth it.  fried farm egg $9 was also good. I do think that iit is one cf the best lamb i had. I have yet to try pasta but looked great.
author: Mika G.

description: Every part of our dinner was a wonderful experiance that we havent seen in a long time! Food, service, wine pairing suggestions, menu knowledge of wait staff was unbeleivable. So,so will go again!!!!! Please give them a try!
author: Brandon C.

description: sunday reservations and valet parking...tired of circling mission, hungry and missing each opportunity...small table towards the back...hip, dim and trendy atmosphere...mixed crowds of all ages...cozy seating with neighboring table a foot apart...taking a dink first...reviewing cocktail ingredients to picture taste...a rye cocktail with herbal tastes?...nonna del diavolo $ten...not exactly as imagined...tall sweet citrus cocktail...hint of rye and strega....mostly sweet, ginger, lime and seltzer flavors...taking a deep fried artichoke heart for antipasti...heavily salted and slightly over fried small bites...no leaves?...might be better with leaves deconstructed, flash fried and served together for more visual substance...a pasta dish for main...grilled corn for a side...small bowl of quite charred corn...full-flavored and seasoned well...slightly over blackened...switching to a glass of pinot grigio to wash down corn...small plate of rigatoni in white sauce...mix of egg and heavily cheesed...quite rich in flavor and fantastic...pasta prepared more al dente...each tube perfectly holding cheese, sauce and ingredients..a good pasta indeed...another glass of wine to finish...being treated and guessing about one-hundred-thirty after tax, tip and valet for dinner for two...
author: Hen A.

description: All I've had here is drinks, but I feel like they were good enough to merit a review. We went at 1230 on a Thursday, and got a table, our waiter was super nice and talkative without being intrusive.  I asked for the bartender to make me some sort of cocktail, my only requirements were 'with vodka and sweet.'  I got this delicious apricot flavored martini- just enough flavor to taste the apricot, but not sickeningly sweet like some apricot things tend to be.  My group of 3 friends ordered similarly, naming simply a flavor and alcohol type, and all got drinks they loved.
author: Tessa S.

description: OMG, OMG, OMG!!! That is all I can say. Was visiting SF, we planned on going to a different restaurant. Lucky us, there was no parking and we were forced to valet at this place and try it. We waited more than an hour for a table but so worth it. We were waiting at the bar, the bar surprised us with few drinks and I was blown away. Tasty, different but just enough alcohol. We ordered an appetizer which came with their bread, we could have easily filled ourselves up with breads but we controlled ourselves. When we sat down they told us about the specials which was Halibut, my friend ordered it and I ordered another fish on the menu. We both finished every single piece and ordered desert even though we were pretty full, I tell ya I am so happy we did. The chocolate cake was so good, we finished that too. The food was so tasty, not too rich, not too oily, it was full of amazing tastes and aroma. If you are in SF make sure you go but do make reservation. Cannot wait to go back again, YUM!
author: Nousha V.

description: We went here Oct 25th for my husband's birthday.  It was a very good experience. The opposite of what we have received at the owners other 2 restaurants. The hostess was very welcoming.  She sat us in a very good location.  Wine & cocktails were terrific. The waitperson recommended several wines & items on the menu. All excellent. My husband ordered the sweetbreads & artichokes to share - Delicious!.  For dinner he ordered cauliflower soup, the  fusilli with sardines, & little gem salad to finish.  I ordered the fettucine with rabbit suga which was also very good.  One drawback, there was only about 5 very small pieces of the rabbit. For dessert we shared the ricotta fritto.  Near the end the waitrees came out with a cup of sweet cream gelato with a lighted b'day candle - Very nice touch. We'd go back again for a special occasion as the prices are pretty high for what you get.
author: Pam R.

description: One of my favorite Italian restaurants!!! They have a very interesting menu of  things to try. I started with the Duck egg antipasta, SOOOOO delicious! I love bottarga, so I had to try this! And for my main dish I had pasta with tuna heart, which was also amazing. The wine was delicious, they have a great menu! And of course we finished with espresso and ricotta fritta!! YUMMMY...Can't wait to go back :)
author: Kristin N.

description:
Ridiculous lamb chop. I'll post a picture of it shortly but where the hell is the meat? All you get is carefully butchered bone. God awful. 

The steak bavette on the other hand was very nice.

Service was a tad pretenious but I guess it's fitting for the decor. Nice cocktail.

Will go again but will never ever order meat on the bone.
author: Tracy Y.

description:
Food is pretty good and at a good/average price. Bf and I made dinner reservations here a little while ago and liked our experience overall. We were seated at our reserved time (restaurants don't get enough credit for this). Their house bread is great, as other reviewers noted. They use the same bread for their pizza bianca. We had the bianca with mortadella that night and the Jewish artichokes. Both appetizers were really good. I had a pasta dish with rabbit and I thought it was good, but not outstanding. Bf had a tomato ravioli that I liked a lot better. Dessert was also good, but again, nothing to write home about.  Dinner for all the above was $70.

Service was attentive and friendly. We had a nice view of the open kitchen, and I thought that was a very nice touch to the restaurant. I would take visitors here and would recommend this restaurant to friends.
author: Trinh N.

description: We went to Locanda with a group of friends.  Food and drinks were both excellent.  A few weeks later I received an unexpectedly large bill for the meal.  I spoke to a manager and they confirmed that a mistake was made (the whole tab was placed on my card instead of split - still not quite sure how that happened).  The management was extremely apologetic and unprompted sent a gift card.  They made what could have left a very bad impression into a very good experience.
author: Christina B.

description: Spoke to a manager several days later, and they sent us a gift certificate to apologize for the mistake.  Hope next time the service is as good as the food!
author: John-Marc C.

description: Wow, a fantastic meal with good friends tonight at Locanda.  We started the evening with cocktails -- the drinks are no joke here.  I opted for the more lightweight aperitivo.  We sat down and savored the freshly baked focaccia bread.  For dinner, I had the hen leg which was delicious.  My husband had the rabbit sugo fettuccini, which was AMAZING.  The pasta was sooooo good.  We had the formaggi for dessert.  The la tur was to die for and fresh flat bread and a tomato / fruit preserve accompanied the cheeses.  Homemade limoncello to top things off.  Wonderful meal.  Big fan of Locanda over Delfina.
author: marcie v.

description: The service was charming.  It seemed like the waiter was even from Italy.  The food was extremely salty and medicore.  If it was in the Roman style, which is not even my favorite style of Italian, it really wasn't.  I've had many memorable dinners at Delfina--so this was a disappointment.  I couldn't tell you why the two differ--and that Locanda is so non-memorable.
author: Pip A.

description: This place was nice! We didn't have a reservation on Sunday night, but managed to walk in and get a table immediately (there were 4 of us). The sunchoke soup with fried capers was amazing. Their wine was really good but pretty pricey (or maybe I didn't look hard enough).  My boyfriend LOVED the desserts.
author: Dana O.

description: The Jewish style artichoke was the star of the evening. My main dish, the Cacio e pepe, was way too salty for me. I was told that's just the way the cheese tastes, but I could barely finish it. I kept downing the water. Service was great, seating a little cramped. Dessert was decent. Not sure if it's worth the price.
author: Aiko L.

description: I had fun at Locanda. Walked in on a Saturday night and scored a bar table relatively quickly. Love trying new restaurants when they're freshly opened, there's an energy in the air that mellows out with time. Service was great, one of the floor managers came by and had a chat with us about the tiled wall (hand-tiled!), you could tell that he was excited about the place and enjoyed working there. The wine list was great and the pasta dishes were good but quite small-portioned. Order a starter or two and soak in the lovely vibe.
author: Lisa P.

description: Great Roman food, done very well.  Our favorites are the Trippa alla Romana, Rigatoni alla Carbonara and Bucatini all'Amatriciana.  The Bucatini is one of my go to pastas in town.  We've been here many times, and the service is the only thing holding it back from 5 stars in our opinion.  Go for the great Roman food and company!
author: Danny M.

description: They did not honor our reservation. We waited over 40 minutes to be seated (on a week night) during which time the hostess had the attitude that she could not care less about our inconvenience. Other guests waiting at the bar were complaining about their wait as well. When finally seated we were served appetizers that were very good but very fried. The "Jewish" artichokes were greasy. The main courses were mediocre. The fish was full of bones and very salty and the lamb was grizzly.
author: Gayle H.

description: Without a reservation, decided not to go to Trader Joe's for groceries, and instead grabbed an Uber and headed to the Mission to one of my now all-time favorite places to eat! From the moment I walked into the door, I felt as if I were home. Packed, and yet a table with a view of the open kitchen was available. My dining companion hadn't arrived? No problem, we'll seat you right away. Early girl tomato salad along with some marvelous grilled (I think) peppers were making my mouth beg for more. The waitperson, Justin, was amazing, a rare combination of someone who seems to love their job and had polite understanding of the menu, without being the least bit pushy. The past with pecorino cheese, fresh ground pepper, and olive oil, was what the gracious owner mentioned is one of his wife's favorite dishes. I now know why. And the budino for dessert was one of the best desserts I've ever had....luscious, sinful, and the perfect way to complete the meal. Ah, Locanda, you had me at the front door!
author: David G.

description: One of my favorite restaurants in San Francisco! I dig the chic, modern ambiance. Food is also great. I had one of their pastas and also steak. Portion may not be big if you are looking to stuff yourself. But it was perfect for me as I did not want my belly sticking out before going out at night. And oh, try their cocktail "The Price." It is yummy.
author: Yasuhiro H.

description:
Late Sunday night and the place is hopping. Love it.  Got a table immediately but the waiter was a little swamped. He was a little off getting to the table to greet us but made up for it.  Good wine selection and interesting grouping of beer selection but found what we needed to start the great food experience..  I was a little disappointed with the cocktail selection. It was poorly thought out. Boring selection.
We started off with the Jewish Artichoke( excellent) then shared the Trippa ( also excellent). The sauce was seasoned to perfection and the bread served was perfect for the dish.  We then shared a Cresenza Tortelli which was cooked perfect and was delicious with the mushrooms and pinenuts. My wife had the Bavetta Steak which was cooked to perfection but the Treviso raddicchio was a little overwhelming ( warning).  I had the Lamb Chops with corriander and anchovies ( excellent combination) .  Must get the Roasted Peppers( WOW) great contorni. Finished off with a few deserts but nothing to rage about.  They were boring but okay. Overall I will definitely go back to try other dishes.  I was excited about the other selections.  If you are expecting an Italian place where you can eat huge portions of pasta for cheap, wrong place, but if you enjoy the flavors of well constructed dishes, you will love it.
author: Joe V.

description: I love this restaurant.  I could eat here at least everyday, or at least once a week.  Fried duck egg is the bomb.  All the pastas are excellent and both the steak and the guinea hen leg are so f-ing good.  Also, the ricotta fritti is a must to end your meal!
author: Preeti M.

description:
good but inconsistent food, more pricey than it should be. some dishes were great (chicken under a brick) and some were not so good (the whole fish, which came out undercooked twice even after sending it back). the salads were delicious, but a little bit small.

service was a total deal-breaker for me. our waitress was so rude and obnoxious she would literally slam things down on the table as she gave us a dirty look. she was totally unaccommodating to somebody in our group with a food allergy, and was all around unfriendly.

for all the other good food and dining experiences in SF, i would not recommend this place.
author: rebecca l.

description:
This is a mid-priced trendy italian fare..not too expensive.  Quite an eclectic menu and it deserves the recognition of bringing something new to the table.  However, don't be fooled by the "pizzas". They are sliced pieces of flat bread with minimal toppings. However, they are delicious. The waiter/waitress should inform you of this.  What i would do if i were you, is just order the bread for the table and put some oil on it. 

 My table had an array of delicious dishes- the rabbit, lamb, jewish atichokes, shrimp filled ravioli.  All was awesome. The pizza was my only half complaint.  And it just threw me for a curve ball. Its not really a complaint.
author: Jared K.

description: So yummy! Everything we tried was to die for delicious! Unique food menu & drink menu. The mash potatoes are the best I've ever had! The pasta dishes are exquisite, deep fried olives, pork jerky- yum-my!! I'm going back to try more stuff asap!
author: kelly l.

description: Food was extremely salty and too rich.  The place was ridiculously loud-- and the speakers are unbalanced leaving pockets of even louder than ridiculously loud.  They do have nice cocktails and a nice wine selection.  I would consider going back for drinks and appetizers in the mid afternoon when the place is quiet, but there are so many better places in SF.  I have been here several times and remain both underwhelmed and surprised with the hype.  Delfina is SO MUCH BETTER.
author: Shannon T.

description: The food was great, although the carbonara was a little salty for my tastes. Giving it 3 stars because the service was terrible! We ordered at the same time as the couple next to us, and they got bread and their meals all before we even had gotten our drinks! We waited for about 20 minutes just to get our drinks, and they never checked on us, or offered us bread--we had to ask for that, and they got a little attitudinal about it. They also forgot our appetizer.
author: Kathleen C.

description: Nice Place, Expensive Italian Wine Selection, Food Average, Place to be seen and only go for the bar. $322 dinner for four and we left hungry and not happy with our meals. One plus was the  attentive service until we pay the bill, we needed more water and had to ask several times.  I guess that when you already  had paid,  you are no longer their guest.
author: Bela M.

description:
We walked in on a Tuesday evening on a whim and got two seats at the bar easily. Mind you it was 5:45pm, so I'm guessing that this wouldn't have been possible at a non-early-bird-special hour. We ate the Pizza Bianca with smoked white bass, horseradish and dill. If you are expecting an actual little pizza you'll be disappointed by this. It's 4 pieces of bread but the flavor, OMG, the flavor. Totally unexpected. We also ate the Radiatore with Lamb Ragu and the Beef Cheek Ravioli. Both were great but the ravioli really stood out for me. Each ravioli was a little explosion of beef stew in its most refined form. For dessert we tried the Warm Chocolate Cake. I usually think of chocolate cake as the throw away on any dessert menu and avoid it accordingly, but something told me this time would be different. I was right! This is not some crude death-by-chocolate mess or the ubiquitous flourless chocolate cake. It's worth trying.  

We were impressed with Locanda and we'll definitely be back for a bigger meal.
author: Lily T.

description: Went back for Maura's b day party, great success! We had an 8 top, booked about a month out. Foccaccia and artichokes are great!!! Artichokes impressed even more this time. Delicious pasta's, I actually had the halibut collar and really enjoyed it. They finally have a wine cellar now too! Many more options this time around had a lovely Nebbiolo for about 50 bucks, nice value. Traditional from top to bottom, much more consistent than a recent visit to Spqr.
author: Tom W.

description: Yum! We have been wanting to try Locanda for a while & finally got reservations but it was at 6pm, earlier than I prefer but what the heck, sometime you gotta go with the flow. If I had known the layout of the restaurant, I would have requested seating in the back, where there was less daylight/cooler ambiant lighting that would have tricked me into thinking that I was dining later - so note that. Definately try the Jewish artichoke appy - delish! We shared this plus the lamb ragu (pretty good but better at Ideale in North Beach) and then each got an entree & it wasn't too much food. I had the Bavette Steak & my husband had the spareribs, both were cooked perfectly, but the dishes themselves were not that memorable or unique, IMO.  The cocktails were wonderful, and the Prosecco on the glass list was some of the best I have had. The wine list is mostly Italian & french wines, we had a 2006 Borollo which was fair to good. Personally, if I had known the corkage fee was only $18, would have brought a bottle from our stash that I knew we loved. So note that too. Overall? Tasty. Nice atmosphere, would go back maybe with friends...but too many more out there to try! Enjoy.
author: Jen S.

description: Great service, amazing food, sexy interior. Welcome to the neighborhood Loconda.
author: Shannon A.

description: Locanda is most definitely my favorite restaurant in SF. The rabbit papardelle is to die for, and I get it every time I go (creature of habit). The atmosphere is also awesome and very intimate. I try to find every excuse to come here whenever I can.
author: Meg B.

description:
Three strikes and you are out...

On Saturday night, I returned to Locanda for the third time.  Having been twice before, I was excited to take my visiting parents for dinner here.  The first time I went, I had loved the food, service, and ambiance.  The second, still loved the food and was disappointed by the service.  This time, the service was just atrocious and really just ruined the whole experience.

We arrived promptly at 8pm for our reservation.  We were seated quickly, which was the only thing quick about our meal.  Our waiter took about 10 minutes to come and greet us and quickly left when a few of us were still deciding on a drink.  After another 10 minutes, he came back and we quickly ordered a bottle of wine before losing him again.  I threw in a few appetizers just in case.  He did not even ask if we were ready to order (we were) and disappeared for another 15 minutes.  I finally flagged him down again to take our order, which he finally did.  At 9:15, more than an hour after arriving, we finally got our salads.  We had to wait another 30 minutes to get our entrees.  He had screwed up one of our orders and we again waited for that to be corrected.  When he finally cleared our plates and brought us dessert menus at 10:30pm, we had had it.  We just needed to leave!  We asked for the check (another slow process) and got out of there.

I will say that I still think the food is decent (albeit very small portions).  I just think that they have been open long enough that the service kinks should be worked out, not getting worse.  Not to mention that no one ever asked us once if we enjoyed our food.  NOT ONCE!  Not even the waiter.  I never saw a manager.  At least the previous time when service had been slow, they recognized there was a problem came and apologized.  I guess 2.5 hours for dinner (I would guess 3 if we had ordered dessert) is the new normal here?

There are enough restaurants with good service in this town that I would not recommend waiting 2 months to get a reservation here to then be ignored...
author: Marc P.

description:
Call me the dissenter, but this was a major disappointment, especially since it is linked to Delfina.

1) Overpriced cheap wine by the glass.  When a glass of wine is priced in the low teens, there is no excuse for it not to be good.  The first glass was close to vinegar.  We returned it and got another.  While better, it was barely above the threshold of drinkability.
2) Where's the bread?  There is a bunch of beautiful looking focaccia stacked high near the kitchen but it was never delivered to a single table.  We had to ask and got 4 measly slices after being in the restaurant for about 30 minutes.  OK, I get if you are trying to cut costs, but don't leave it out in plain sight.  And put a disclaimer on the menu that you need to ask for it.
3) Pizza, this is not pizza.  They call it pizza and it taste good, but it is three slices of bruschetta.  At least call it what it is.
4) The pasta is appetizer size.  When pasta cost in the high teens, it should be enough to fill you up.  These small plates qualify as an appetizer.  Come on, how much does it cost to put another 10-15 noodles in the water?  Pennies
5) And last but not least, where is the parmeggiano?  We had to ask for parmeggiano for the pasta and they brought it out in a tiny bowl.   I'm Italian and have eaten at a lot of Italian restaurants in San Francisco as well as Italy and I cannot remember a single time when parmeggiano was not either on the table or the waiter brings in by and hand grates it.  Geez
6) Also, no black pepper on any table.  A little pepper would have been nice with the pasta.

If you must go, enjoy, but really, there are other places in town that are better, offer a better value and understand how to service a customer.  I will not be back.
author: Gary N.

description: Dined here with outta town guest from Germany.  The menu and service is sophisticated and really satisfying.   We especially liked the deep fried Jewish artichokes, the Barlotti beans & the Buccatini.  Also had the Buvette steak which was slightly underwhelming.  Overall,  service and food was really good. However, the design and construction of  Locanda  lacks some much-needed soundproofing elements.  It was excessively noisy on the night we dined, which created an ambiance of chaos.
author: Baby J.

description: The Mission is a hot bed of good food, including Delfina, the mother and father that begot Locanda. That said, there is really no excuse for a sub par, incredibly expensive meal. Here are the positives: lovely waitress with very good suggestions, interesting menu, great decor, delicious cocktails, and an overall rating of the food - kinda tasty. Here are the negatives: expensive pasta that arrived cold (lame), and portions that are really small (and I have patience for small portions if it guarantees a flavor party in my mouth). I want Locanda to be good. And I will return in several months time and hope that whatever kinks exist have been figured out. PASTA SHOULD BE HOT! Is that too much to ask? Oh, and I shouldn't still be hungry after dinner and need to visit Arinell's for a slice. Double lame.
author: claire b.

description: Very nice people, valet parking, which makes it easy in this area, and delicious good. Artichoke small but great, two good pastas, the lobster one excellent, the radiatore lamb good. Great if in the area!
author: bob o.

description:
We didn't have reservations, but luckily the bar was first come/first serve, so we sat in under 20 minutes.

This little sister of Delfina was good-good service, great atmosphere (if a tad warm), and tasty food.  The atmosphere was cozy, the noise level boisterous but not loud, and the bar tenders were attentive.

We started the evening with the ArchAngelo: gin, cucumber and aperol which was a refreshing combination and garnished with a slice of cucumber.  The husband had a Napa Organic IPA which was tasty but had a different profile than the IPA he normally prefers (Racer 5/Sierra Nevada).

We shared the poached duck egg (w/ bottarga, squash blossoms, burro nero) which was terrific with both textures and taste.  It had the right amount of salt with a small dash of capers.  They served us a complimentary pizza bianca which was delicious -think a cross between focaccia and flat bread topped with olive oil and salt.

We both wanted red wine, and they offered sampling of three different wines so we could choose the best fit.  He had the 2008 Les Vins de Vienne "Remeage" (Syrah blend), Rhone, France which was full bodied and delicious.  I believe I had a California Pinot Noir, which is not listed on the menu, but was subtle.

He ordered the Rigatoni alla Carbonara (w/guanciale, egg, pecorino, black pepper).  It was very rich (good) and a little heavy handed with the black pepper, but was absolutely edible.  The guanciale and pecorino added a reasonable salty blend to combat the richness of the dish.

I ordered the Radiatore "pecora e pecorino" (lamb ragu, pecorino, nepitella).  The dish was savory, the lamb very fresh and the pasta texture was interesting.

After these dishes, we didn't have room for more food, but we would definitely return.
author: Amanda S.

description: Delicious and authentic Italian food.  The artichokes are fantastic and good cocktails.
author: Heather R.

description:
OK. I know this place is the hottest Mission District restaurant of the moment, but it's far from perfect. 

The service leaves a LOT to be desired. Our waiter was totally aloof. He wasn't the least bit apologetic when our drinks took 20 minutes (!) to get to our table. And he didn't seem to want to answer any questions about the menu, which is far from self-explanatory. 

The pizzas were minute but delicious as were the artichokes (raw and fried). The bucatini all'amatriciana, one of my favorite dishes, was too spicy, however. 

The food is very good-I'll give it that, but the quantities are so minute, that one appetizer is not nearly enough for a party of two (and I'm a very  light eater). 

Get ready to spend twice as much as you expected going in.
author: Dana M.

description:
Food- very good - six of us tried a variety of dishes all of whish were excellent.
Service- sub par. arrived to MANY ? buspersons in red aprons- all milling about but had to ask for bread.- - twice. Then received 5 pieces for 6 people- twice.
Long delay on serving initial bottle of wine- our waitress asked another staff person- ? role- woman not in apron, orange shoes- many partial tattoos- to do so. Long absent minded opening, failed to serve one member of our table.
Would return but would hope service MUCH sharper-of the same quality as the food.
author: s b.

description: Wait staff was very negligent and not caring to our needs.  Three of us ordered the carbonara which came highly recommended.  it resembled the Olive garden alfredo sauce with chunks of pork belly.  Completely flavorless.  It was described as flavorful with pork jowls.  It was nothing like that.  Everything else was great.  The waiter did not give any thought to the fact that three of us were unhappy with the meal.  Another over rated hipster mission restaurant.  They also cleared my plate with fork in hand and a mouth ful of food.  Horrible.
author: nicki l.

description: We heard about this new restaurants opening up by the same owners of Delfina so had to check it out. Still on our Paris kick we splurged and ordered numerous plates, wine and even dessert. Honestly, got pretty drunk and now can't remember everything I ate so must return!!!
author: Susan A.

description: One of the best meals I've had in a long time. Great service, great food. Get the fried artichokes, you'll need one each. The pastas have great texture and flavor and the portion sizes are just right.
author: Sarah M.

description: Popped in for drinks and delicious prosciutto with my cousin and husband.  Only had time for 1 round of hand made soul-filling cocktails and the mixologists were super knowledgeable, friendly and happy!  Great experience to want to go back to!
author: C S.

description:
Fantastic Staff. 
Great and Late hours
Superb wine list.
Tasty offal bits.  
Highly recommend.
author: Quite C.

description: My GF and I have been here multiple times and we always have an enjoyable meal and great wine. The shaved artichoke salad is a favorite and my steak is always cooked perfectly. The GF usually has a pasta dish and I think only once it wasn't up to expectations but still good.  Dessert has been a little hit or miss, sometimes the description doesn't fully match what you get. Affordable wine menu with interesting choices. Overall a great restaurant.
author: Ben W.

description: Locanda was good but stick with the recommendations on what to order.  Hands down the Jewish Artichoke was the most delicious preparation of an artichoke I have ever had.   We actually ordered a second order we enjoyed it so much.  But I wish I would have paid more attention to reviews on the "pizza".   We order the pizza bianca.  Only mistake of the night.  It lacked flavor and it was a weird texture.  Imagine a piece of bread ( the same bread they serve when you sit down) with some unsweetened plum jam and a thin slice of prosciuitto on top.   I wish it wasn't on the menu.  But we had 2 very yummy pasta dishes - the rabbit sugo and the lamb pasta  which finished dining our experience on a high note.
author: Laura L.

description: When we walked in the staff was great we had actually missed our reservation but were able to be seated. The first course pizza was good but it was just three pieces of charred bread with a thin spread of burrata and fava beans. Then came the pasta carbonara the sauce was over reduced an dry and completely covered in black pepper. The last course was the osso bucco which was tender but thats about it it was cold under seasoned and sitting on top of over cooked bland lentils and the most watery flavorless jus ive ever had. When the sever came over we had only taken a bite out  it she asked if she could clear the table not bothering to ever ask if it was ok or how our experience had been.  Over all it felt like a huge bust the only thing that i felt that was truly on point were the cocktails which were creative , delicious and reasonably priced.
author: Matt R.

description: pasta: omgsogood.  cocktails: do not allow the bartender to make you "whatever he wants" four times. twice is ok.  secret:  even though there are never reservations available, there are many secret ways to get served delicious dinner.  communal table is walk-in only, and bar serves full menu (and places you dangerously close to bartenders).
author: Stephanie L.

description:
Had dinner here on Wednesday. No reservation, but they are able to take us at the bar. The food was all fabulous! Tried 4 different pastas and all of them were out of this world. Very true to meals I've had in Rome. 
Fried Artichoke starter was so good we had to order another. The deserts were also spot on - there was one with fried dough and some kind of creamy goodness filling that I just couldn't get enough of. Bar service and cocktails were so rocking that I can't even remember the name of the desert - but I will definitely be going back for it!
author: r e.

description: Eggplant pasta was mind blowing.  The food here is outstanding.  Yet another winner from this group!
author: Danielle B.

description: The valet service consistently double parks vehicles on the Valencia bike line - one of the most use corridors in the city.  What makes your restaurant so special that you need to inconvenience hundreds of riders every day?
author: Robert Z.

description: Love this place - great vibe, great service, great food!  Great go-to Mission spot for night with friends or date night.
author: Anonymous S.

description: This place was something of a surprise for me, as i don't usually head to the mission for Italian, which i see is a bit of a mistake. Other than being a little over priced, the food, decore, atmosphere, and staff were all top notch. Had a few appetizers, a mix drink (first one on the menu for drinks) was delicious and well worth the price. The beef cheek ravioli was very good, only wanted a bigger portion. :)
author: Luis S.

description: Fun spot for dinner.  Was very happy with the food, service and ambiance.  I'd defintiely recommend if someone wanted to go a hip place focused on good food and drink.
author: TravelBug W.

description: Dirty martini with the most delicious olives I've ever tasted. Informed friendly staff with a passion for and almost scary knowledge of food. And they have gluten free, which was delic. I have been 6 times and won't stop while I'm ahead.
author: Kristie M.

description:
I would review the food but we didn't get to sit so this review is all about the service. First of all I'd like to take partial blame for just doing a walk in. I know it's more convenient to make a reservation but, by principle, I couldn't use their online service. The hostess offered up 3 seats at the communal table but they were all side to side making it hard to talk and it was right by the front door. No one likes a cold draft blowing on them while they eat right? So I ask how long a table would be. 20 minutes she says. There's a table just ordering dessert and they should be done soon.  Okay given the choice, I'd wait 20 minutes for a table.  
Here's where it gets bad. The hostess comes by a couple times with updates. The first time is after 35 minutes of waiting. She indicates the table has finished dessert and paid. They're just waiting for them to leave. Okay what happened to telling me 15 minutes ago at the 20 minute mark? The second time is at the 45 minute mark. She says she's still waiting for the table to leave and it'll be any moment. Usually I'm fine with this but I ask if the table she's waiting to clear is the one I'm pointing at. She's like yeah. So I know this table is not going to leave because the waiter just convinced them to buy a bottle of wine and they all have full glasses. They're going to be there at least another half hour. So the hostess sends the other hostess in to say oh we didn't know they're still drinking. Really? You can't look at the table and tell they're not leaving yet? Ridiculous! She then proceeds to offer three seats at the bar where more people haven't left yet. She goes you can sit at which ever leaves first.  
So here are my problems;
1. The lack of timely communication about the status of a table. If you had come to me at the 20 minute mark and said they're not leaving, I would have left and found another restaurant. Don't keep me milling around for another 25 minutes just so you can make money off me. 
2. Okay so our table wasn't leaving, why couldn't they offer us another table?
3. You offer us bar seats that aren't even available yet. Who knows how long they're going to be. I could be waiting another 45 minutes. Just say we don't have seating and let me go on my way. 
4. You would think they would have offered an appetizer or something for waiting so long. Nothing.
author: Victor L.

description: Brought my parents and visiting Manhattan cousins here last night and we had the best time!!!! Our waiter (brown hair with beard wish I had his name) was incredible at his job. He recommended great wine and dishes, answered our many questions with kindness and enthusiasm, and just made our dining experience really special. Everyone loved their food. The Jewish style artichokes with Italian mint were a huge hit. We loved the bread and I personally enjoyed the grilled fish, a shrimp pasta (that included burrata,) and yummy mushroom pasta with mint and pine nuts... We even had room for dessert! Afterward everyone felt satisfied but not overly full. High quality "clean" food allows you to chow down without being sorry afterward... Shout out for their Mission tequila cocktail too.., I would also like to add that everyone working at the restaurant was very kind- from the person who confirmed our res, to the person who seated us, and the nice girl who took our picture... 5+ stars!!!
author: Win S.

description: If you like Roman food and a great bar than look no further. The food is divine and the drinks ere fantastic. For a fun time in soma this is the place to be.
author: Michael R.

description: The bavette was delicious. My only complaint was that they had coursed the four shared starters of my friends so by the time they brought out entrees it seemed like forever, especially for me since I only ordered an entree. It would've been nice if she had asked how we wanted it served. But she was super friendly and I'd definitely go back but remind myself to order a starter so that I was fainting at the table.
author: S W.

description: Food and drinks were good, but really pricey. Nice setup and all that, my drink was good even if I waited a while to get it, which seems to be the eternal problem of all these fancy cocktail places. All in all, nothing bad, nothing good, just another average overpriced meal in sf.
author: Buckeye W.

description: San Francisco doesn't have enough places where you can get a meal after 11PM. Came here after the opera. The upscale hipster factor eclipses the food. The market radishes with anchovy butter were admittedly quite delicious, and the cocktails are pretty good, but overall - overpriced for what it offers. Service for this kind of restaurant was quite desultory - i.e. did not meet expectations. Not that well-informed about the menu, too many people serving one table... and yet... all of them failed to tell us that the kitchen was closing at midnight because they were so rabidly eager to get out of there. Letting your customers know the kitchen is closing is just standard courtesy. Nice 90's hip hop playlist.
author: Masha G.

description: A real gem.  Great ambiance, cocktails and food.  We went on a Sunday night and it was still pretty packed, but the service was still good.  The fried artichoke was fantastic, the rabbit was well prepared and the sweet breads were delicious.  We had a nice bottle of rose that paired well with the pasta and fish.  Overall, a phenomenal meal.
author: David A.

description: Very nice place, love its design and trendy atmosphere. The drinks were incredible and the bartenders really put on a show! Highly recommend.
author: Freda F.

description: We visited Locanda for the 1st time with 2 work colleagues and would not return. We rate it 2.5 out of 5 across the board. The biggest specific issue was that we brought a bottle of wine and bought 2 off the list... but they still charged corkage fee. Otherwise, decent food but too expensive and the service was cold, if well intended. "Amateur Hour" was the best description we came up with Garcon or Range would be a better bet on Valencia
author: Ted S.

description: the Ciociaria: helluva cocktail. oh and get some fried olives to nibble on. pricy place, but worth it.
author: Sean B.

description: Nice atmosphere, ok service, drinks whatever, food seriously?  Left unsatisfied, disappointed after waiting a year to try, oh yeah and $100 poorer
author: Bill K.

description: I had the cuscini here and it was fantastic.  The shrimp and cheese filled pasta pillows were cooked to perfection.  They were light and tender and covered in a sauce that was flavorful and well seasoned.  It was so delicious that I wiped the dish clean with the complementary foccacia that came with the meal.  But I did think that the wine was a bit pricey--$11 for a nondescript, run-of-the-mill Italian wine.  With prices like that, you would think they make enough money from the wine to forego the $1.50 service charge they tack on to cover employees' health benefits.  Seems a bit gougy.
author: Cecilia L.

description: The decor in this place is right up my alley.  I love it.  It's clean and chic all at the same time.  Just the way a restaurant should be!  It was really fun to sit by the kitchen and see the chefs in action.  Although it took a bit of time to get what I ordered, it was well worth the wait.  It was like a show and a meal.  The food was superb!  Definitely want to frequent Locanda!
author: Laura Z.

description: Everything we had was excellent. Pizza Bianca, Jewish Artichokes, Bucatini, Fettucini with Rabbit, and good desserts too. Hard to get in but worth it.
author: Matt C.

description: The warm foccacia bread they bring while waiting for your entree is delish. Beer and wine are both great. I recommend the Craftsman 1903 lager from Pasadena for beer and any of the red wines on the menu. The food did not dissapoint,mixed green salad with thyme vinagrette, pepper and breadcrumbs side dish,Fettucini rabbit  and BUCATINI all'AMATRICIANA, are all delicious. And for dessert, the hazelnut cookies with dipping chocolate are a great finish.
author: Laura K.

description: OK, I lived in Rome two years, so this was going to be a tough sell. Thought the vibe was classic Valencia st. tech elites, lots of young asian/ caucasians with good teeth dressed in black.  Nice mod interior, but too loud for my tastes. The food, well other than the pizza bianca, it missed the mark: fava covered foccaccia was really underwhelming/soggy, like it was sitting out for a while. The carbonara was not prepared properly, not eggy enough, lacking flavor, eggs cooked too long, the rabbit sauce on the other pasta dish  was also underwhelming, lacking depth, but OK; the best part of the evening was the waiter, a guy from Piedmonte, who suggested a fabulous wine from the region, and who provided perfect service.  The fried sweet breads and artichokes were pretty good. Overall, I am tired of these loud over-promising Mission District restaurant.  I think they are more about  vibe and social networking than they are about preparing authentic food.I just wish they would live up to their billing sometimes.
author: David W.

description: I was excited to go to Locanda, but very disappointed.  The waiter told us a few times how busy he was.  The Early Girl tomato salad was watery and flavorless, I make a better salad at home.   The shrimp pasta was very under cooked.  The pasta was doughy and chewy and the shrimp was basically raw and slimey.     The restaurant was very noisey and my friends and I had to yell at eachother.   This is not the place for me.
author: Frank C.

description:
I can't even begin to put in words how great the food was at Locanda. First, a little personal history:  I returned from Italy in late June, finishing up my trip in Rome.  I have been there before and I looked forward to some spectacular meals, but, alas due to some conditions beyond my control, myself and my friends ran out of money and could not eat the kind of food I so had looked forward to in Rome. 
  Locanda was my Rome.  From the moment I made the reservations I read everything I could about the owners, the chef, the menu and I waited for my long deserved perfectly made Negroni, Jewish Artichokes and pasta Carbonara.  I was not disappointed.  This place rocked.  I went with a party of 10 and more wanted to go but we could not get a larger table.  The server, Ethan, (you are the best)  was full of helpful tips and had a wonderful personalty.  We wanted for nothing, Everything ran smoothly.
  I applauded every course from the coctails, to the perfect bread with the salty crusty top, to the little crostini with the salmon eggs that melted in my mouth.  The Jewish Artichokes were perfect and the portion was generous.  I had the halibut collar  which was crusty on the outside and moist and fresh on the inside.  The homemade pasta Carbonara was as good as any I have had in Rome.  We also had a fresh corn and cheese contori which was great.  
  We opted for a couple of bottles of red wine and picked from the cheap seat price and it was very good.  
  We finished with the chocolate cake which was so heavenly we had to order a second serving with a glass of port to wash it down.  I know it is a lot of food, but this food is so good I can eat salad every day for a week after to loose the extra calories.  It is so worth it.  Bravo Locanda.
I have already made two more reservations here and I am usually the type of person who moves from restaurant to restaurant, but with Locanda I feel like this is as good as it gets.
author: linda g.

description: The flatbread (super salty) that comes before your food is amazing. Great pizza bianca - try the chile/cauliflower one, the bone marrow one is weird and doesn't have much marrow. Crab linguine was very good, as was fettuccine with rabbit. Pretty tasty food all around, nothing was bad, but nothing totally blew me away.
author: E T.

description: I like the food here a lot, though it's not as Roman as it pretends.  (The carbonara, for instance, has cream in it.)  But it's sneakily expensive for a pasta joint. The bartender asked me if I wanted him to pick out a glass of white wine to accompany my pasta. When the bill came I discovered that the glass he chose cost more than the pasta, which was not cheap.  I had the unpleasant sense that this might be a bill-building policy.  My modest dinner ended up costing me eighty dollars, and not by my choice.
author: Guy h.

description: Quality of the food is a notch above what you'll get in most good Italian restaurants. It's all fresh and local (as far as I can tell). The portions are on the smaller side, and the service lacks a bit of the warmth I've grown accustomed to at Delfina (although even there, it can be hit or miss recently). Drinks were fabulous if you're looking for inventive and potent cocktails.
author: Tina Z.

description: Incredibly delicious food (especially the desserts) and the nicest waitstaff and managers in the whole world!  What more can you ask for?  I would eat here every day, if I could :)
author: Elaine T.

description: I've been to this restaurant four times in the last year.  The experience, including the food, has been very good to excellent each time.  For appetizers, the artichoke and the duck egg were both expertly prepared (although there was one occasion when I felt that the oil they used to fry the artichoke could be fresher).  I like that they have a wide variety of main courses--I think they do a really good job with the meats (lamb or ribs) as well as the pasta.  We've tried several of their pizza's and while acceptable, not their strongest suit.  The service was attentive and people seem to be cheerful.  Like any busy place, it's difficult to get a table. My usual strategy is to go for an early dinner.
author: Mark C.

description: the chicken, the saltimboca, the lamb, the pasta, the booze....  this place is always awesome!
author: Brian J.

description: Great spot. Strong dishes and good, solid service. A bit of a hard reservation to get a hold of on peak nights but well worth it. Be ready to spend about a $100 a person with wine, but well worth it. There's good energy and food and drink there. Corkage is also reasonable at I think $18 or so... Recommend!
author: Cassidy L.

description: Great cocktails, wine list, amazing food from Anthony Strong, great staff and ambience - there's a reason this joint is jumping! Favorite dishes are the Carcioffi crudi (raw artichoke salad) and the beef cheek ravioli (a special that appears now and again).
author: Karen B.

description: There are only two memorable things about Locanda - the music and the cocktails. Unfortunately everything else was truly disappointing. I was expecting pasta that would surprise and delight me. Instead I found that the 4 dishes we tried were mediocre and all seemed to taste very similar. I have not been fortunate enough to travel to Rome but we had a friend who spent 6 months in Rome dining with us who said the Pizza Bianca couldn't compare. Service was definitely lacking as well. Aren't you supposed to take care of your fellow industry folks?
author: Jamie S.

description: This place is home to some of the best bartenders in town.  Jesse and Gabe are two drink slingers who never disappoint, not even on a bad day.
author: Ryan D.

description: Over priced and Over hyped -really nothing much else to say.  Most people just want to believe that this place is good. Sorry 7x7 is wrong sometimes.
author: Seth G.

description: I took my best friend here for her birthday dinner and let me just say it was PHENOMENAL! The Bone Marrow Pizza is to die for. The cocktails are so reasonably priced (all under $10~) for such a nice establishment! I will be going back!!
author: Kyra W.

description:
Ok I know 5 stars might make it seem like I'm overly excited or not a tough critic but living in the lovely city of San Francisco has made me picky and somewhat spoiled when it comes to eating out. 
My boyfriend and I were strolling along Valencia looking for somewhere that was still open (it was around 11pm on a Friday) but where we could get more than a taco or slice of pizza...plus we wanted a nice atmosphere. 
We decided to give Locanda a try and were both satisfied and impressed. From the glass of wine to the friendly server and welcoming ambiance (oh and the yummy fresh bread) I was sold. 
We were in the mood for some quality Italian pasta so I order the Crescenza Tortelli (trumpet mushrooms, pinenuts) and he ordered the Rigatoni alla Carbonara...and let me say--both were flavorful and delicious. We also tried the house-cured jerky which was tasty. I paired my dish with a glass of Sangiovese which was perfect, he had a beer. The bar area was still almost full at midnight when we were leaving...very lively yet sophisticated crowd. I will definitely be returning soon..very enjoyable experience.
author: Alison W.

description: Overrated and pretentious. Staff tends to larger and more important tables over normals. Cocktails were highlight over food. Could have made similar food at home. Duck egg had zero salt. Artichoke was way over salted. Pastas were mediocre and crostada was as thin as paper. More about hype than actual experience.
author: Tony C.

description: It pains me to say this, but I was really underwhelmed by Locanda.  Delfina is my all-time favorite restaurant so I really really wanted to love this place.  Instead, it was meh.  We had the grilled ricotta with arugula/avocado, 2 pasta dishes (radiatore with lamb sugo and tonnarelli cacio e pepe), and snap peas for dinner.  All of these dishes were serviceable, but not nearly as good as I expected.  For dessert, we had a crostata with cherries and ricotta gelato--again, good but not great.  I would never have guessed this place had any relation or connection to Delfina.  On the positive side, service was great and I love the decor.  It's also much more spacious than Delfina.  But, sadly, I don't think I'll return.  To make matters worse, we walked by Delfina afterwards and it nearly killed me when I saw they had their papparadelle with pork sugo on the menu w/ 2 open seats at the bar.  If I could have had a do-over, I totally would have gone for it.  :(
author: Sharyn F.

description:
Took a friend here for a birthday dinner tonight and had a fabulous time.  As requested, they seated us in a fairly quiet spot.  The music was too loud when we got there and they lowered it on our request.  The service was excellent--Special kudos to Eva and Tamara.  
The food was really good too. We had the broccoli and sweetbreads to start.  Thanks to another yelper for the suggestion to add the lemon, which made the sweetbread flavor really pop.  I had the spicy spaghetti pasta and she had the lamb ragu.  The portions were perfect and the pasta was cooked perfectly.  We shared the rabbit saddle, which was a bit salty, but not if you ate it with the lettuce and cheese that came with it.  The turnips were really good too.
For dessert we had the panna cotta, which was not cloyingly sweet.  They make it with sorbet and pepper and we really liked it.  The women at the table next to us did not care for it and gave it to us.  The staff did not charge them and also brought them a different dessert for free.
Great addition to the neighborhood!
author: Megami F.

description: Jerusalem artichoke....eh.   Lambs brains and tripe both good.  Pasta was solid.  Passed on desert.  Actually thought the broccoli side was the best thing we got.  Good atmosphere but seemed a bit too slick for a delfina owned place
author: Brent C.

description: disclaimer: I am a Delfina fan.  If I could go there every night, I would type of fan...wild and crazy.  So when I heard Locanda opened, I gave it a few months of opening jitters before trying it.  And am I ever glad I did.  The food ranks high.  Innovative; tasty; perfect portions.  The pizza biana with figs and proscuitto - enough said.  If I didn't have to share it, I would have eaten the whole thing myself.  I had the grilled halibut collar...tender, juicy, flavourful morsels.  My hubby had the pasta carbonara of which he said was amazing, and he's a carbonara snob.  our friend had the rabbit which from the one bite i had, solid.  we shared the fried ricotta with lemon reduction.  if only they hadn't run out of lemoncello...if only.  my only complaint - the timing was off between the appetizers and the main.  we waited over 1/2 hour for our mains to show...the manager came over to apologize, which made me feel a little better.  Definitely set for a return here.
author: Sonia C.

description: Fantastic.  The last time I had Italian food like this, it was in Italy.  The only reason I'm not giving 5 stars, is because I've only been once, and it was 10:30 at night, and I didn't want to eat too much.  Decor is enviably chic, and very appropos.  I'd go back in a heartbeat.
author: Joe C.

description: Very pleasant decor, helpful and friendly waitstaff, delicious food - including the artichoke appetizer, which was wonderful.  My entree was one of their fish specials, and it was terrific.  Great meal, great place.
author: Jeremy M.

description: Very good food, but the entree portions are TINY.
author: Robert M.

description: Finally, went back to Locanda after a "so-so" experience. Now, THIS IS WHAT I WAS EXPECTING!!! We had an amazing experience Friday night. We sat at the bar and the service was terrific. We enjoyed a couple of well crafted cocktails. The Amaro Tropicale and the Suspiria were awesome drinks and the guys behind the bar paid close attention to all the details, providing us with sublime drinks! Well done! Now for the food.
